One of Barry's closest political advisers said the mayor's campaign staff has started planning campaign events. ``He will run,'' the adviser said. ``His thinking is, he still has the support of many members of the community and he can beat these charges, so why not run?'' Barry, who was arrested at a downtown hotel after allegedly being videotaped using cocaine, is scheduled for trial June 4 on five misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession and three felony perjury charges related to his testimony before a grand jury about drug use. If convicted of a felony, Barry would be barred from holding office or running for re-election; conviction of a misdemeanor would not bar him from office. ``Even if he is convicted of a misdemeanor, he thinks he can run and win,'' said one aide. ``I don't think you will see anything until after the trial.'' The Washington Post quoted sources this weekend as saying that Barry rejected a suggestion from his attorney, R. Kenneth Mundy, that he plead guilty to a misdemeanor account of cocaine possession to strengthen his chances of acquittal on more serious charges. The paper said Barry refused to comment on his legal case. In an interview last week with The Associated Press, Barry refused to reveal his political plans but he would not rule out a run for a fourth four-year term. ``I'll make that decision at the right time,'' Barry said. ``I still have the personal and political support of a lot of people, and that gratifies me.'' Public opinion polls taken after Barry's arrest found that the mayor still had the support of between 20 percent and 25 percent of the community. Barry strategists believe that if all five candidates currently in the Democratic mayoral race are on the ballot, the mayor could win. Candidates must file by July 5 to qualify for the Sept. 11 Democratic primary, which is tantamount to election in the district. The deadline for filing as an independent candidate is Aug. 13. Barry, who in 1988 proudly described himself as a ``night owl,'' now tries to project a public image of humility and commitment to his family. At many public events, Barry concedes that he suffers from alcoholism but also insists that he is beating the problem and can govern effectively. Barry has been claiming a new understanding of the ravages of substance abuse and has pledged to improve drug treatment programs for the city's growing number of addicts. The mayor also is taking advantage of his incumbency to remain in the public eye. Last Tuesday, while the declared mayoral candidates appeared at an issues forum, Barry was at a nearby hospital praising an anti-drug program he had started there last year. ``He can certainly make a case that that problem is something in his past, that drugs are something he has put behind him,'' a third adviser said.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Trying to Keep Sex-Hungry Wasps Away From Launch Towers
DOC.TEXT: Perhaps even now, pregnant wasps are waking from their winter slumber at Kennedy Space Center to build paper nests and lay eggs in the warm Florida sun. By September the eager young hatchlings will be swarming to look for mates. The tops of 300-foot launch towers, built by humans for trips to the stars, are favorite places for wasp courtship and frenzied lovemaking. The swarming goes on until mid-December, weeks when workers at the center are pestered and threatened by the wasps, says an Agriculture Department report. Scientists are trying to rig effective traps but admit those may take a few more years of research. Entomologist Peter J. Landolt of the department's Agricultural Research Service suspects the wasps mistake the tall launch towers for their usual mating sites _ trees and hilltops. Thus, when the mating swarms leave nests built in bushes or on houses, the launch towers and other manmade structures at the center are the tallest things around. Landolt, who works for the agency's research laboratory in Gainesville, Fla., said thousands of male wasps lead off the mating ritual by swarming to Kennedy facilities. Favored gathering places are around a launch pad's crane and near the crane motor's housing room. The males search for anything that protrudes to sit on, a bolt, for example. Then they rub their heads and tails on the perch to release sex attractants, or pheromones, into the air to attract females. They bite and wrestle, trying to knock each other off the perches. It's a very competitive time. And there is a prize. ``We believe each male wants an ideal spot to sit and wait for virgin females to arrive so he can mate,'' Landolt said. ``Every male wants his pheromone odor to be strongest so that females will be attracted to him.'' Hundreds of female wasps, lured by the scents of sex-hungry males and the tall towers, swarm to greet the thousands of suitors, selecting the ones they desire. The couples mate in midair, requiring about a minute. Once inseminated, the females fly into the crane housing room, where they cluster together on walls to keep warm and protect themselves from predators. Or they squeeze into cracks and crevices. The females remain there all winter, living off stored body fat util spring, when they return to the ground to build nests of paper they make by chewing bark from trees. Then they lay their eggs, use themselves up protecting the brood and die in the fall. Meanwhile, the male wasps that were successful suitors during the previous swarm season eventually die also, having ``dutifully served their sole purpose in life,'' the report said. The unsuccessful males also die, of course. The space center wasp project was reported by Jessica Morrison Silva of the USDA agency's Beltsville, Md., staff in the current issue of Agricultural Research magazine. Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration asked USDA two years ago for help to control the wasps. So far, Landolt and colleague Hal C. Reed have worked out what they think is the wasp's annual mating ritual, but they aren't completely sure. For one thing, they have to be certain the wasps are mistaking launch towers for tall trees. So Landolt and Reed plan to go into the Everglades in search of nesting wasps in tall trees to corroborate the theory. Eventually, they hope to isolate and reproduce the pheromones used by the wasps in their sex rituals. With the synthetic sex attractants, traps can be built to control the pests. Since the problem began five years ago, only one NASA employee has been stung at the center, despite the large numbers of wasps. But just seeing a thousand or more wasps buzzing around at 300 feet can be hazardous by itself, Landolt said. Aside from the employee hazard, NASA wants to ensure that the wasps don't enter a space shuttle's electronic and mechanical equipment. ``Obviously, a shuttle liftoff is an effective and quick means of controlling the wasp problem,'' Reed said. But NASA wants a less drastic way of curbing the wasps between liftoffs.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Declaration Should Be Withdrawn, Soviet Says
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet official says Moscow is engaged in a ``political dialogue'' with Lithuania, but a Lithuanian calls that claim a ``lie.'' Vitaly Churkin, an advisor to the Soviet foreign ministry, also said Sunday that Lithuania should withdraw its declaration of independence so negotiations about the Baltic State's future can proceed. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's government wants to resolve the Lithuanian situation ``through political dialogue, and obviously this is what is going on now,'' Churkin said. ``We are thinking about it in those terms.'' But Algimantis Cekuolis, a Lithuanian official, called that statement a ``lie.'' Both men appeared on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley.'' ``They would be very happy to do anything to overthrow that (Lithuanian) government, like using a military force from inside and economical blockade from outside,'' Cekuolis said. ``That lie number three, that was told, that political dialogue going on ... There is no political dialogue, if you don't mean this Kalashnikov gun,'' he said. Lithuanians have tried to talk with the Soviets, but have only managed to get three hours of time from one of Gorbachev's deputies, he said. Churkin said the Lithuanians, who have demanded independence from Moscow, acted precipitously in trying to secede before working out details of their future relationship with the Soviet Union on economic and other matters.
DOC.HEAD: Bush Mourns AIDS Victim's Death
DOC.TEXT: President Bush mourned the death of AIDS victim Ryan White, saying Americans must continue fighting the deadly immune system disease. ``Barbara and I are deeply saddened with the death of Ryan White,'' Bush said in a statement Sunday a few hours after the 18-year-old Indiana youth died in a hospital in Indianapolis. ``All Americans are impressed by his courage, strength and his ability to continue fighting,'' the president said. ``Ryan's death reaffirms that we as a people must pledge to continue the fight, his fight against this dreaded disease.'' Last week, Bush planted a tree in Indianapolis in honor of White. White was diagnosed as having AIDS in December 1984. He contracted acquired immune deficiency syndrome through a blood-clotting agent used to treat his hemophilia. White gained national attention when he was barred from Western Middle School near Kokomo, Ind., after school officials and parents there rejected health authorities' reassurances that AIDS could not be spread through casual contact with those infected. Later, he moved to Cicero, Ind., where he attended school.
DOC.HEAD: GAO Head Says S&L Bailout May Require Tax Increase
DOC.TEXT: Comptroller General Charles A. Bowsher says a tax increase will be needed at some point to pay for escalating losses among a third of the nation's savings and loan institutions. Bowsher this past week raised the estimated price tag for the government's S&L bailout from $257 billion to $325 billion, and warned it could rise to $500 billion. ``This is one of the great financial disasters that we've ever had in this country and it's going to have to be added onto all the other problems we have in the federal budget,'' he said Sunday on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press.'' ``When you get done making the cuts that you hope you can make in defense and some of the other areas ... you're still going to have to look at the revenue side of the budget,'' the head of the congressional General Accounting Office said. Bowsher blamed the Bush administration's desire to meet deficit reduction targets without a tax increase for underestimating the size of the S&L problem. L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the Resolution Trust Corp., responsible for handling the bailout, said the government ``simply didn't know in what bad condition these S&Ls were.''

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITS a0441 to include writethru designation. ^Citing Motherhood and Travel, Maria Shriver Quits ``Sunday Today.'' ^Eds: SUBS penultimate graf, `In a ...' to CORRECT acronym of cable channel to CNBC, sted CNCB.
DOC.TEXT: The new baby and the weekly commute from Los Angeles were too much for NBC's Maria Shriver. That's why, she said, she no longer will anchor Saturday's ``NBC Nightly News'' and co-anchor ``Sunday Today.'' Shriver, who returned last week from maternity leave, announced her decision Sunday as she rejoined ``Sunday Today'' for a farewell appearance. She has co-anchored the show with Garrick Utley since it began in 1987. Although Shriver, who gave birth to a daughter in December, will stay with NBC News, her decision to leave ``Sunday Today'' may set the stage for former Cable News Network anchorwoman Mary Alice Williams to succeed her on the program. But NBC spokeswoman Peggy Hubble said no decision has been made yet on who will replace Shriver. She declined to comment on speculation about Williams, saying only that ``we're in discussions with Mary Alice about her role at NBC and we'll have an announcement later.'' Shriver, who with Williams and Chuck Scarborough last year anchored four much-criticized specials called ``Yesterday, Today & Tomorrow,'' will start doing a series of prime-time news specials. She also will do occasional special segments for NBC's weeknight news program anchored by Tom Brokaw. A former ``CBS Morning News'' anchorwoman, Shriver worked out an arrangement with NBC News that permitted her to be bicoastal. Under that arrangement, she lived with her husband, actor Arnold Schwarzenegger, in Los Angeles and commuted each week for Saturday's evening news in New York, ``Sunday Today'' in Washington with Garrick Utley, and occasional specials. ``Having a child, I realized I could no longer keep up my weekly commute from Los Angeles,'' Shriver said. She praised NBC for letting her stay as a ``vital member'' of the news division while giving her more time to spend with her family. ``It's difficult giving up my two coveted roles ... but I'm very excited about my new prime-time assignment,'' said Shriver. Williams has said she's unhappy over what she feels is NBC News' inability to make full use of her, according to a source close to the situation. But Williams, who lives in New York, has refused to discuss with reporters either her problems with NBC or talks that she and her agent are having with NBC to resolve them. In a March 27 appearance on the ``McLaughlin'' talk show on CNBC, she said she considers it ``tacky'' to discuss her negotiations in public. But, without elaboration, she did say that her NBC contract contains a clause that allows lets her leave under certain conditions.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 30,397.93, up 1,119.15 points, or 3.82 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Cowabunga! Teen-Age Turtles Are Box-Office Heroes
DOC.TEXT: They're hip. They're green. Cowabunga! A quartet of pizza-chomping turtles has taken Hollywood by storm. What's next for the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles? They have their own comic book, a cartoon series, toys and now their own movie that made $25.4 million at the box office in the biggest spring opening in Hollywood history. ``Maybe an amusement park,'' co-creator Peter Laird said. ``It's something that's crossed our minds a couple of times.'' The movie ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles'' fell behind only ``Batman'' and ``Ghostbuster II'' for the biggest box office take in a film's first three days, Exhibitor Relations Co. said last week. ``We had a good feeling about the movie,'' Laird said. ``From the beginning we thought it could do well, but not this well.'' It's a long way from a winter's night seven years ago when Laird and fellow starving artist Kevin Eastman dreamed up four irreverent, adolescent creatures skilled in the martial arts and named for Renaissance artists _ Leonardo, Michelangelo, Raphael and Donatello. Eastman and Laird are agog over the mutants' success. ``It's exciting. It's scary. It's tense. It's pinch yourself once a day,'' Eastman said. ``It's been an exciting experience and exhilarating and so forth,'' Laird said. ``It's also been a sobering and humbling experience. We now know that people who get famous for what they do are just ordinary people because that's what we are.'' The amphibian brothers, intended as parodies of the big-muscled heros of conventional comics, started as aquarium pets and mutated after falling into a pool of radioactive goo in a New York sewer. They were raised by Splinter, the mutant pet rat of a Ninja master, and became radical crime fighters fond of the surfer cry ``cowabunga.'' Eastman was a sandwich maker and Laird eked out a living drawing illustrations for local newspapers when they met in 1982. The mutant turtles gurgled from their heads onto paper about a year later after a late-night sketching duel that Eastman said was fueled by an evening of watching bad television. From there, the green ``heroes in a half shell'' never looked back. Laird and Eastman issued their first Ninja Turtle comic book in 1984, printed on $1,200 they scraped up between them. A smash TV cartoon series and some serious marketing followed. There are about 100 licensed Ninja Turtle products, including candy, cookies, a board game, a video game and 4-inch-tall action figures that have been best-selling toys last two years. The creators, who live in Northampton, are often asked to explain how four super turtles captured such a huge audience. ``I think they're appealing for a number of reasons,'' Laird said. ``The turtles live their lives with the philosophy that they don't want to hassle anybody and they don't want to be hassled themselves. But when trouble comes they're able to handle it.'' Eastman said fan letters range from crayoned missives to correspondence from doctors and lawyers. ``I think the kids in some respects like _ beside the silliness and the characters _ the family attitude with the four brothers and Splinter playing the father figure and the teacher,'' he said. Keeping control over the myriad turtle products is becoming more difficult, but Laird and Eastman said they've been careful to monitor the marketing. ``We do still maintain the approval process because they are our babies,'' Laird said.

DOC.HEAD: Nick Faldo Wins Masters for Second Year in Row
DOC.TEXT: Nick Faldo became only the second man to win the storied Masters golf tournament two years in a row, snaring the title from Raymond Floyd who blew a four-shot lead on the final six holes. The Englishman did it in similar fashion to last year's victory, winning on the second hole of a sudden-death playoff when Floyd's approach found the pond. ``It's the most devastating thing that's happened to me in my career,'' the distraught Floyd said. ``When you have a guy that you know is a great front-runner, it sets your course,'' said Faldo, who won on the second hole of a playoff with Scott Hoch last year. The two finished regulation with 10-under-par 278 totals. Both had pars on the first extra hole. Floyd may have cost himself a second Masters title by playing safe, hoping to par in for the victory that would make him, at 47, the oldest Masters winner in history. Jack Nicklaus won this title for the sixth time in 1986, when he was 46. Nicklaus also was the only back-to-back winner, in 1965 and '66. It would have made Floyd the first player with a major championship in four decades _ he won PGA crowns in 1969 and 1982, the Masters in 1976 and the U.S. Open in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: White's Struggle With AIDS Began At Age 13
With PM-Obit-White, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of 18-year-old Ryan White's battle with AIDS and his struggle to attend school: December 1984 _ White, 13, is diagnosed as having contracted AIDS through a blood-clotting agent used to treat his hemophilia. July 30, 1985 _ Western Schools Corp. Superintendent James O. Smith bars White from school near Kokomo, Ind., saying the health risk for other children is too great. Aug. 3 _ The State Board of Health sets guidelines for admitting children with AIDS to school, saying White should attend class as long as he's not severely ill. Aug. 8 _ White's family sues in federal court to get him admitted to school. A judge says administrative appeals must be exhausted first. Aug. 26 _ Classes begin at Western Middle School; Ryan is linked to school by a computer-telephone hookup. Nov. 25 _ Indiana Department of Education hearing officer rules White should be allowed to go to school when he is not intensely sick. Feb. 6, 1986 _ An appeals board rules White, now 14, can attend classes with clearance from the Howard County health officer. Clearance is granted. Feb. 19 _ A Howard County judge rejects request by parents and students to bar White from school. Feb. 21 _ White attends a half-day of school. A Howard County judge later in the day approves a temporary injunction preventing him from attending school. April 10 _ A Clinton County Circuit judge lifts the injunction. White returns to class later that day. Summer 1987 _ White's family moves to Cicero, about 20 miles away, saying they didn't want to stay where they were unwanted. Aug. 31 _ White attends his first day of classes as a freshman at Hamilton Heights High School. No protests are reported. March 3, 1988 _ Ryan testifies before the White House AIDS Commission, saying ``I came face to face with death at 13 years old'' but decided ``to live a normal life.'' Aug. 18 _ Filming begins in North Carolina of ``The Ryan White Story,'' an ABC television movie. It is broadcast on Jan. 16, 1989. Dec. 16, 1989 _ White turns 18 in ill health. March 29, 1990 _ White is admitted to Riley Children's Hospital in Indianapolis suffering from a respiratory infection. April 2 _ The announcement is made that White is in critical condition on a life-support system. April 8 _ White dies.

DOC.HEAD: Singer Killed in Ferry Fire Looking for Big Break
With PM-Ferry Fire
DOC.TEXT: An American performer believed killed in the North Sea ferry fire that claimed about 150 lives had been looking for her ``big break'' aboard the Scandinavian Star, her mother said. Ruth E. Rome, 27, part of a seven-member song-and-dance troupe from New York City hired a week earlier to entertain passengers on the overnight trip from Norway to Denmark, was missing and presumed dead in the fire that began before dawn Saturday, her mother, Winifred, said Sunday. Mrs. Rome of East Lansing, Mich., said her daughter had hoped the one-month singing stint aboard the ferry would give her an entrance into the entertainment industry. ``She hadn't had her big break,'' Mrs. Rome said. ``She was always hoping. She was the eternal optimist.'' Another member of the performance troupe Broadway on Board, Rick Qualls, said in a telephone interview from Oslo, Norway, that he and two other singers who survived the blaze had realized there was a fire while they were watching videos in the officer's mess. Qualls, a native of Little Rock, Ark., said the three performers tried to go down to a lower level where Ms. Rome had retired to her cabin earlier. The staircase was littered with people who appeared to be passed out; others were stampeding up the stairs to safety, he said. ``We got down one deck and the smoke was gushing up the stairwell, and looking down, we could see nothing _ not even the stairs of that bottom deck, and there were people stampeding up the stairs,'' he said. Qualls, 30, praised the Scandinavian Star's crew for trying to save lives, but said the ferry was understaffed and that the alarm never sounded until at least 15 minutes after the ship was on fire and filled with smoke. The ship carried about 500 tourists and crew members. He also said he said he never practiced an emergency drill on the ship. ``I'm upset. I just feel like there's a lot of negligence here that has cost a lot of lives, and possibly one in our party,'' Qualls, 30, said in a telephone interview from his Oslo, Norway, hotel. Miss Rome moved to New York City after her 1984 graduation from Northwestern University with a bachelor's degree in theater. ``She was just a wonderful, sweet, sweet, young and beautiful girl,'' Qualls said. And she loved the stage, her mother said. ``She had worked recently on a cruise with American Hawaiian Cruise,'' Mrs. Rome said in a telephone interview Sunday. ``Because that was such a positive experience, she decided to try this out in Norway.''

DOC.HEAD: Yen Jumps, Japan Stocks Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to Update with closing Nikkei, dollar; Pickup 5th, `The dollar...'
DOC.TEXT: In its fourth-largest single-day surge, the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange closed above the 30,000-point level Monday, while the dollar fell sharply against the Japanese yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average rose 1,119.15 points, or 3.82 percent, ending the day at 30,397.93. On Friday, the index rose 1,029.72 points in its fifth-largest single-day advance. The Nikkei last closed higher than 30,000 points on March 29, when it ended the day at 31,026.16. The dollar closed at 156.45 yen Monday, down 1.02 yen from Friday's close of 157.47 yen. It opened lower at 155.80 yen and then began to rise, ranging between 155.60 yen and 156.90 yen during the day. In bond dealings, the price of benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bonds was 86.81 at 3 p.m., up from Friday's close of 86.38. Their yield fell to 7.185 percent from 7.275 percent on Friday. The dollar rose quickly as market players with short, or oversold positions started buying the U.S. currency in the absence of coordinated intervention by the central banks of the Group of Seven (G-7) nations, said Minori Takeuchi, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. ``Investors had expected that the dollar would be pushed down further by coordinated dollar-selling intervention. Since that did not materialize today no matter how long they waited, market players finally started buying dollars again,'' she said. Monetary authorities from the G-7 _ Britain, Canada, France, West Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States _ agreed in their meeting in Paris Saturday that the yen's recent downswing could have ``undesirable consequences.'' They also promised to keep the exchange markets ``under review'' and renewed their commitment to coordinate economic policies, including cooperation on exchange markets. But analysts believe that many countries are reluctant to help Japan stem the fall in the yen because they see the yen's weakness as Japan's internal problem. Japan's central bank also insists that it will not raise its official discount rate. Japan's Finance Minister Ryotaro Hashimoto, who returned from the G-7 meeting Sunday, told an upper house budget committee session Monday morning that participants in the G-7 meeting shared concern over higher interest rates. Ms. Takeuchi said the yen might rise a certain extent but only temporarily. She said that will not change the dollar's uptrend ``because there is no other means beside market intervention to revive the yen.'' Akihiko Kagawa, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo, said many currency players believed that the G-7 countries had committed themselves firmly to preventing a further slide in the yen. He said the market was testing how closely the G-7 countries would cooperate in joint market intervention. On the stock market, Nomura Securities analyst Hisato Haganuma attributed the index's large gains to rises in the dollar and bond prices. ``Market players bought a broad range of issues, including electric issues,'' he said. But Haganuma said the surges Monday and Friday may not lead to further rises in stock prices. ``Currently, market players are short of stocks to sell, because few investors were buying issues when the index was falling last week, particularly since the index fell from the 32,000-point mark,'' he said. After a round of buying, the index's uptrend will slow and hit a plateau, he said. Toshiyuki Nushiguchi, an analyst with Daiwa Securities Co., said the stock market responded favorably to last week's Japan-U.S. structural trade talks as well as to the G-7 meeting. He said speculation on interest rate-sensitive issues had disappeared after the G-7 meeting. Some market participants had feared that participating countries might raise their interest rates to stem inflation. Higher interest rates tend to support a country's currency, but discourage stock investment.

DOC.HEAD: Benefit Urges Fans to Message Congress
DOC.TEXT: Farm Aid IV mixed fund raising with political lobbying in a 14-hour concert on behalf of the American family farmer. A sellout crowd of about 45,000 people at the Hoosier Dome heard more than 60 musicians _ including Elton John, Bonnie Raitt, Jackson Browne and the band Crosby, Stills and Nash _ perform in the Saturday night show. ``It would be nice if there wasn't a need for Farm Aid. It would be nice if our government's policies reflected a concern for families and for farming. There's all kinds of things in this world that would be nice. We have to fight to make this government responsive to our needs,'' Browne said. Donations for the fourth Farm Aid concert were still being tallied Sunday, and final figures were not scheduled to be released until today, said Farm Aid spokeswoman Linda Lewi. As of late Saturday, $1.3 million had been raised, she said. The concert came two weeks before the nation observes the 20th anniversary of Earth Day, and Willie Nelson and other Farm Aid leaders took the opportunity to announce the forging of a coalition with farmers, environmentalists and consumers to work toward less use of pesticides and other chemicals in food production and more support for organic farming. Postcards were distributed to concertgoers calling on Congress to pass a 1990 farm bill that will help family farmers use fewer chemicals and practice environmentally safe farming methods and to provide a pricing structure that covers the cost of food production. Rock star John Mellencamp, who helped organize the event, indicated in an interview that federal farm policy has sacrificed the welfare of the independent farmer to promote corporate agriculture concerns. ``I'm not giving up. The face of this nation changes by the men that we admire, right, and I think that we haven't felt the backlash of the last eight years yet. I think the '90s will reflect that,'' said Mellencamp, Mellencamp, Farm Aid President Nelson and fellow organizer Neil Young all played during the final, all-star hour of the marathon concert. John made an unexpected appearance late in the program and performed three songs. The British rock singer had been in Indianapolis to visit AIDS patient Ryan White, who died Sunday. ``This one's for Ryan,'' John said before beginning ``Candle in the Wind,'' a song he wrote about the tragic life of Marilyn Monroe. The song drew the biggest ovation of the show. The Rev. Jesse Jackson called for a moment of silence for White during the concert. The civil rights activist and Democratic politician visited White's family on Saturday, as did Nelson and musician-actor Kris Kristofferson.

DOC.HEAD: Dark Horse Candidate Captures Voter Sympathies In Presidential Race
DOC.TEXT: Celebrated novelist Mario Vargas Llosa won the most votes in Peru's presidential elections, but a politically independent agronomist who surged from behind has forced a runoff, unofficial returns showed today. This fragile democracy is wracked by economic crisis and the 10-year-old insurgency by the Maoist-inspired Shining Path, which staged attacks during Sunday's voting and in preceding weeks in an effort to thwart the election. Soldiers armed with automatic weapons protected polling stations, several of which were attacked Sunday by guerrillas hurling sticks of dynamite. Police reported no injuries in those attacks and millions of voters turned out to vote for a president and new congress. Unofficial returns early today showed Vargas Llosa, a 54-year-old advocate of free market reforms and economic shock therapy, leading with 33.9 percent of the vote _ far short of the 50 percent required to avoid a runoff. Alberto Fujimori, the 51-year-old son of Japanese immigrants, garnered 29 percent, pushing aside the candidate of the center-left governing party, Luis Alva Castro, who a few weeks ago held a solid second in the polls. Fujimori, a former university rector, has in his shoe-string campaign stressed ``honor, technology and work,'' qualities many associate with his Japanese ancestry. But he never provided a detailed plan of government. He is one of about 100,000 people of Japanese descent in the country and many voters said they thought he could attract substantial Japanese investment to this country where 70 percent of people are underemployed or unemployed. Independent pollsters gave Fujimori a better-than-even chance of defeating Vargas Llosa in the second round of voting, expected in late May or early June. The new president will be inaugurated on July 28. The unofficial results showed Alva Castro to have won 16.4 percent of the vote. Six other presidential candidates split the remaining vote. Official results were expected to take up to 20 days, as many polling stations were in remote villages. Voting is mandatory for those 18 and older. Guerrillas staged attacks throughout the country on Sunday, but most of the country's 9.8 million registered voters appeared to ignore rebel threats for death for those casting ballots. In recent weeks, the guerrillas have assassinated six congressional candidates and killed or wounded dozens of people in recent weeks, aiming to disrupt the election. At least 28 people were killed and 44 wounded in weekend attacks, including 17 peasants massacred by rebels in Santo Tomas de Pata, a village near Ayacucho. Also, two rebels died when a dynamite charge blew up as they placed it on a highway bridge 100 miles east of Lima. A third was seriously injured. The highest absentee ratio was registered in the Ayacucho, a Shining Path stronghold 235 miles southeast of Lima in the Andean highlands, where 38 percent of voters stayed away. Three quarters of the votes cast in Ayacucho were blank or null, compared to about 10 percent nationwide, according to the respected polling firm Datum. Repression by the military is particularly severe in the region, and human rights violations are frequent. Vargas Llosa's campaign often had the aspect of a crusade as he condemned the ``collectivist'' programs of President Alan Garcia and leftist candidates. Many Peruvians blame Garcia, who is barred by the constitution from serving consecutive five-year terms, for the severe economic crisis and growing political violence tearing apart this country of 22 million. They point, in particular, to his attempt to nationalize the country's banks after discouraging foreign investment by dictating his own terms for repaying outstanding loans. Inflation is running at more than 2,000 percent annually and more than 18,000 people, most of them civilians, have been killed in 10 years of violence between the Shining Path and government security forces. Vargas Llosa has repeatedly said he put aside his writing to help his country. But some of his former backers were turned off by the lavish campaign waged by the novelist's center-right Democratic Front coalition. Appearing together in a downtown hotel, Vargas Llosa and Fujimori applauded the massive voter turnout, an apparent rejection of Garcia's governing Aprista Party. Vargas Llosa invited Fujimori to join him in ``frank conversation'' to discuss a possible accord to avoid a second round. But Fujimori said he would not step aside. ``There has been in this first round two proposals for change,'' Fujimori said. ``I believe a second round is necessary to debate our proposals. The verdict should be the public's.'' Sunday's vote indicated the next president will face a divided congress. No party gained a working majority among the 60 senators and 180 representatives.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Candidate Vaults into Second Round
DOC.TEXT: The Japanese community is as perplexed as the rest of Peru by Alberto Fujimori, who vaulted from relative obscurity into a runoff vote in the presidential election in a matter of weeks. Unofficial returns after Sunday's voting showed Fujimori had forced a second round of voting by garnering enough ballots to deny the long-time favorite, novelist Mario Vargas Llosa, a simple majority. Until the final days of the campaign, hardly anyone knew of the 51-year-old agronomist. Six weeks ago, his own polls showed him with less that one percent support. ``His popularity is very surprising,'' said Juan Iida, publisher of a Japanese language newspaper in Lima. ``We didn't even know who he was.'' Fujimori, a former rector of the National Agricultural University, served for two years as an agricultural advisor to the government of President Alan Garcia. He is married with four children. One of almost 100,000 Peruvians of Japanese descent, Fujimoro has played on common Japanese stereotypes in his shoe-string campaign, whose slogan promises ``honesty, work, technology.'' He also has not discouraged the belief that he will attract Japanese aid and investment to this impoverished, war-ravaged country. The Japanese community, however, remains unimpressed by Fujimoro. According to pollsters, Japanese Peruvians believe Fujimori does not reflect the values of their community and is too ``Peruvian.'' ``I doubt he has any real program,'' said Amelia Morimoto of the Japanese Peruvian Cultural Center. ``His candidacy seems very improvised.'' Indeed, most of Fujimoro's campaign workers are youths from Lima's poor districts and his political movement, called simply ``Change 90,'' has only two sparsely furnished offices in Lima. Fujimoro, who has no political experience, says he sold his house, car and a tractor to fund the campaign and often travels without bodyguards because he says he can't afford them. Some people who worked under Fujimori when he was university rector from 1984 to 1989 have questioned his ability to govern. They dispute his claim he left the school with a $7 million budget surplus. If elected, he would be the first Japanese Peruvian to occupy a high government post. ``What is important for Japanese Peruvians is that this may lead to wider acceptance by the other Peruvians,'' Ms. Morimoto said. Fujimoro's parents came to Lima before World War II from Kumamoto, Japan, in a wave of immigration that began in 1899. Most Japanese families arrived in Peru to work on cotton and sugar plantations along the coast and many now own businesses and factories or work as doctors, lawyers and engineers. Fujimori seems as surprised as anyone at his sudden popularity. ``I'm not a dreamer, but, yes, I propose to become president of Peru,'' he said recently.

DOC.HEAD: `Community Policing' Focus of Conference
DOC.TEXT: A few years ago, charges of police brutality made headlines in the border town of McAllen, Texas. Today, residents come to a neighborhood mini-station to drop off plates of food for officers. Sgt. Belinda Cowan credits the smoother relations to the department's switch three years ago to ``community policing'' _ a philosophy that is the subject of a conference today and Tuesday at Michigan State University. Officers may patrol on foot, staff a small office or drive a patrol car, but the key to community policing is face-to-face contact with neighborhood residents, said Robert Trojanowicz, director of Michigan State's School of Criminal Justice. Cowan said the results are striking. ``We're seeing tremendous support from citizens because we're working together as partners,'' she said. ``It's no longer, `I'm the police. Just the facts, ma'am.' They are a part of our department.'' About 300 cities use some form of community policing and get similar results, Trojanowicz said. Community policing advocates planned to describe at the conference how this decentralized form of police work, which became popular in the late 1970s, can stop drugs from overwhelming neighborhoods. Officers in community policing programs work in the same neighborhood for at least a year, getting to know the area's problems and enlisting the help of citizens in fighting crime, fixing up the neighborhood and other programs. ``With this personalized approach to police work, officers have more contact, more communication with the public,'' Trojanowicz said. ``Trust is built up and information is exchanged that would not otherwise be exchanged and information is the lifeblood of police work.'' Community police officers try to get to the root of problems, as in Aurora, Colo., where police had frequent reports of women's purses being ripped off in car break-ins at a popular nightclub in the Denver suburb. ``Typical police response would have been to go out and take reports on stolen purses over and over and never go further,'' said Aurora Police Chief Jerry Williams. Instead, the Aurora officer encouraged the nightclub owner to build lockers where women could safely leave their purses while dancing. The crimes stopped. Police mobilize citizens into neighborhood watch groups, encourage people to testify in court, find out which children aren't attending school and pressure city leaders to tear down dilapidated buildings that are eyesores or havens for crime. That can mean less time for responding to minor complaints like barking dogs, Trojanowicz said, adding citizens are encouraged to handle those things themselves. In McAllen, police received more reports of crime in the first year after community policing began, possibly because citizens were more willing to file reports, Cowan said. ``The negative rap on community policing is it's public relations, grin and wave, it humors people and doesn't cure anything,'' Trojanowicz said. ``The focus of the conference is to show it is real policing and to show it in fact can get rid of drug dealers.'' Some police fear for their safety if they spend less time in patrol cars and more time in direct contact with citizens, but Trojanowicz said citizens are more likely to come to the aid of an officer they know. ``Studies have shown that as officers have become more personalized, if they are in danger, it's a little more difficult for citizens to be aloof,'' he said. ``He has a stake in the neighborhood and the neighborhood has a stake in him.''

DOC.BYLINE: O'Connor Defends Anti-Abortion Project ^By KIRK SEMPLE
DOC.TEXT: Cardinal John J. O'Connor defended the Roman Catholic Church's hiring of a public relations concern to launch an anti-abortion campaign, saying the move is neither a waste of money nor unusually political. ``We believe that the most critical issue in the United States is the problem of abortion, and if we believe that, then we should try to use the best possible means to communicate,'' O'Connor said after Sunday Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral. O'Connor announced Thursday that the nation's Roman Catholic bishops had engaged a public relations concern, Hill & Knowlton, and a polling company, the Wirthlin Group, to conduct a campaign opposing abortion. But he said that, contrary to some recent reports, no contract has been signed with the companies. O'Connor, chairman of the bishops' Committee for Pro-Life Activities, said no price tag has been put on the project, but some reports have said the bishops are expected to spend $3 million to $5 million on the effort. Funds would be raised from private individuals and organizations, and would not detract from existing programs, said O'Connor's spokesman, Joe Zwilling. Some critics have charged that the money going to the project could be better spent on the poor. But O'Connor said the Catholic Church spends billions of dollars annually on care for the needy and homeless. ``I'm not sure why the criticism, except again I find that whenever I do anything or say anything about any public policy problem, except abortion, there's practically no criticism,'' he said. The Catholic bishops have hired media consultants for events like Pope John Paul II's visit to the United States in 1987 but never before for the abortion issue. ''I've heard that Christ wouldn't have used a communications program,'' O'Connor said. ``Well, Christ never established a child care institution or an orphanage. Christ was able to work miracles to feed people. I can't do that. I have to raise money to do that.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Expels U.S. Diplomat
With PM-Iraq-Saddam, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Foreign Ministry said today that it was expelling an American diplomat in retaliation for the expulsion from the United States of an Iraqi diplomat accused by Washington of involvement in a murder plot. The ministry announcement, carried by the official Iraqi news agency, did not name the American to be expelled. An unidentifed spokesman for the ministry was quoted as saying, ``The accusation against the Iraqi diplomat has no basis in truth.'' The source said the American action was part of ``repeated hysterical campaigns to harm Iraq in order to serve the aggressive purposes of Israel.'' In Washington on Saturday, the State Department said it had expelled an Iraqi diplomat posted at the United Nations because of his suspected role in an alleged plot to murder two opponents of the Baghdad government. The diplomat, who was not identified, was expelled for ``abuse of his privileges of residence in the United States,'' said State Department spokeswoman Anita Stockman. ``Given the nature of the diplomat's actions, it would be inappropriate for the government of Iraq to take any retaliatory action,'' the spokeswoman said. She said the department could not provide more specific information except to confirm the expulsion was linked to an investigation in California. But government sources said on condition of anonymity that the expulsion was linked to a plot to assassinate two Iraqi opposition members in the United States. A newspaper in California identified the targets of the plot as Sargon Dadesho, a leader of the Assyrian community in California's Central Valley, and an unidentified Kurdish leader. Iraq has been the focus of international criticism for two months over a series of incidents. The latest was President Saddam Hussein's statement that he would use binary chemical weapons if attacked by Israel. Chemical weapons have been banned under a 1925 international agreement. Saddam's threats came after Iraq ignored international pleas and hanged an Iranian-born British journalist whom Baghdad branded an Israeli spy. They also followed accusations by the United States and Britain that Iraq had tried to smuggle atomic bomb triggers into the country, a charge Iraq has denied. Meanwhile, the Qatari newspaper al-Raya quoted informed sources as saying President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt relayed to Saddam a message from President Bush in which he said the U.S. administration was ``no party to the propaganda campaign against Iraq.'' Al-Raya said the two Arab leaders considered Bush's message ``a positive response that calls for self-control and non-escalation of the propaganda war.'' Baghdad last expelled an American diplomat in November 1988. Haywood Rankin, head of the embassy's political section, was kicked out for alleged close contacts with Iraq's Kurdish minority, which has been fighting for autonomy for 50 years.

DOC.HEAD: Executive Shakeup at Taj Mahal Casino
DOC.TEXT: Top executives are being shuffled at the newly opened Taj Mahal Casino Resort, which has had problems keeping its slot machines open, a spokeswoman said. Walter J. Haybert, who has been Taj Mahal president and chief executive officer since October 1989, would become chief financial officer, spokeswoman Karen Tuso said Sunday. Taj Mahal executive vice president W. Bucky Howard would be named president and chief operations officer. ``As a casino operator, Bucky is one of the best,'' owner Donald Trump said in a statement read by Ms. Tuso. ``He will provide the leadership that will ensure the Trump Taj Mahal its place as the world's greatest casino and convention resort.'' Trump said none of the proposed changes resulted from persistent slot machine trouble at the 1,250-room casino hotel, which opened April 2 billed as ``The Eighth Wonder of the World.'' The Taj Mahal ran into trouble Friday night when its 3,000 slot machines were shut down after an unexpectedly high volume of action. The slots had opened six hours late Friday because of staff shortages and problems accounting for the amount of money in the machines. The slots will be out of service indefinitely to allow for procedural changes, officials said. The casino, which was under construction for eight years, must win at least $1 million a day to service the debt on $675 million in bonds. In another change, Edward Tracy would be named president and chief executive officer of the Trump Hotel Corp. while continuing as president and chief operations officer of Trump Castle Casino Resort, a position he has held since November 1989, Ms. Tuso said. The Trump Hotel Corp. manages Trump's four Atlantic City properties. The proposed changes must be approved by the state Casino Control Commission. Haybert also had been vice president of Harrah's in 1984 when it managed Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino. At the time, more than 50 percent of the Plaza's slot machines were closed during its first three weeks, and Haybert resigned midway through that crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Reformer and Pro-Secessionist Face Runoff
With PM-Hungary, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Ljubljana is pronounced lyoob'-lyah'nah, Milan Kucan is Mee'-lahn Koo'-chahn and Joze Pucnik is Yoh'-Zheh Pooch'-nick
DOC.TEXT: The liberal republic of Slovenia held Yugoslavia's first free multiparty elections since 1945 and the presidential candidate who favored a cautious approach to secession won the most votes. But former Communist Milan Kucan did not gain an absolute majority in Sunday's balloting and faces an April 22 runoff vote with Joze Pucnik, a former political prisoner of the DEMOS opposition coalition, returns showed today. Political analysts predicted a neck-and-neck race between Pucnik, who advocates quick Slovenian independence from Yugoslavia, and Kucan, who has called for a more cautious political approach. About 75 percent of eligible voters cast ballots, choosing among 17 parties for a new Slovenian Parliament and among four candidates for president. With 90 percent of ballots counted, Kucan led with 44.5 percent of the vote to 26.1 percent for Pucnik. Independent candidate Ivan Kramberger won 18.8 percent and Liberal Party candidate Marko Demsar took 10.5 percent. The first-round results ``suggest that Slovenians have opted for a peaceful transition from a single-party monopoly to a parliamentary democracy,'' said Kucan, an engineer of the republic's move toward democracy. Pucnik, who spent seven years in Slovenian prisons in the 1950s for his opposition to communism, said he would win the runoff ``because those who voted for Kramberger and Demsar will now probably vote for me.'' Early returns from Sunday's balloting indicated the Slovenian Communists, who recently renamed themselves the Party of Democratic Renewal, would be the largest single party in the republic's Parliament but would face a tough DEMOS coalition of five conservative parties. The former Communists, who have also broken with the national Communist Party leadership because it has resisted democratic reform, won about 21 percent of the vote in balloting for the republic's 240-seat Parliament, with the five DEMOS parties getting about 35 percent, returns showed. Official results of parliamentary voting were not expected until Tuesday due to a slow and complicated counting process. Yugoslavia's president Janez Drnovsek, a Slovene, said after voting in Ljubljana that he hoped the whole country would hold its first free elections for federal parliament by year's end. Elections in Slovenia, the richest and most liberal of the six Yugoslav republics, ``represent a sign of the democracy drive that cannot be stopped in Yugoslavia,'' Drnovsek said. Slovenians have shown an increased desire to secede from Yugoslavia because they are unhappy with resistance to reform in much of the rest of the country, especially Serbia Slovenians have moved toward democracy despite harsh criticism and economic boycotts from Serbia, the largest Yugoslav republic, a bastion of centrallized control where the leaders demand continued Communist Party dominance. Croatia, the second-largest republic, is scheduled to hold free parliamentary elections later in April. Despite allowing the formation of oposition parties, Communists in the other four republics, including Serbia, have not yet announced free elections. Official Serbian media, under strong Communist influence, virtually ignored the Slovenian elections, claiming the Slovenian parties and presidential candidates have one goal in common: secession from Yugoslavia.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: With Easter just a week away, Georgia's egg producers have a lot to cluck about. For the first time since 1977, when native son Jimmy Carter was president, Georgia is providing eggs for the annual White House egg roll. The state's egg producers are sending 2,500 eggs, including a commemorative egg for first lady Barbara Bush, for the event in Washington. The White House event, coordinated by the American Egg Board and the Georgia Egg Commission, traditionally takes place on the Monday after Easter Sunday. The commemorative egg, made by Kay Harrison of Canton, sits on a small gold pedestal. Mrs. Harrison cut a hole in the side in the outline of the state. Inside are three dogwood blossoms carved from clay. Georgia is the nation's fifth-largest egg producing state, with 11.8 million commercial laying hens that lay nearly 3 billion eggs a year. Eggs have figured into Easter celebrations for centuries. ``Eggs are a symbol of new life, and people believe eggs given at this time bring them good luck,'' said Robert Howell, executive director of the state's Egg Commission. ``It's been a custom to color, decorate and exchange eggs for hundreds of years.''

Political pundits who like to point out what a difference one vote can make can now use this small Texas town as an example. Residents voted 51-50 on Saturday to allow the sales of package beer and wine in an election that drew more ballots than any in the town's history. Only three registered voters did not participate. And those three who failed to vote are bound to be badgered a bit by voters from the losing side, Mayor Jim Clinkscales said. ``I know one of those who didn't vote,'' Clinkscales said. ``And it wouldn't be too hard to narrow it down to find out the others.'' Opposition to beer and wine sales at the town's two grocery stores came primarily from members of the town's three churches. Those arguing in favor of going ``wet'' tried to convince neighbors already struggling under hefty sewer tax bills that liquor and beer sales would provide badly needed revenue for the town of 282 people about 30 miles south of Fort Worth. ``I really didn't take much of a stand on it,'' said Clinkscales, who refused to divulge which way he voted. ``But I will say I'm going to be glad to see more tax coming in from it. ``A lot of people said this is going to bring us heavier traffic and people throwing trash in our town. But there's already a place that sells beer a half-mile west of our town now, and people drive through here and toss down trash and we don't get any revenue from it.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down Sharply, Stocks Regain 30,000 Mark
DOC.TEXT: The dollar closed sharply lower against the Japanese yen today, helping to push the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index above 30,000 points for the first time since late March. The dollar closed at 156.45 yen, down 1.02 yen from Friday's close of 157.47 yen. It opened at 155.80 yen and then rose, trading between 155.60 yen and 156.90 yen during the day. Bolstered by the yen's recovery, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average rose 1,119.15 points, or 3.82 percent, to close at 30,397.93, its fourth largest single-day advance ever. The Nikkei last closed above 30,000 points on March 29, when it ended the day at 31,026.16. The advance extended a rebound begun on Friday, when the Nikkei index rose 1,029.72 points in its fifth-largest single-day advance. The dollar opened lower in Tokyo after wildly fluctuating between 155.50-159.50 in Oceanian markets, mainly Sydney, that opened earlier than Tokyo, dealers said. They said the dollar fell because of expectations of central bank intervention to prop up the faltering Japanese yen in the wake of talks among economic policymakers of the major industrialized nations, known as the Group of Seven, in Paris this weekend. Monetary authorities from Britain, Canada, France, West Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States agreed Saturday that the yen's recent downswing in world currency markets could have ``undesirable consequences.'' They also promised to keep the exchange markets ``under review'' and renewed their commitment to coordinate economic policies, including cooperation on exchange markets. Nihon Keizai Shimbun, a leading Japanese economic journal, reported on its front page this morning that central banks from G-7 would conduct coordinated dollar-selling interventions during today's tradings to support the yen. The dollar, which traded at 143.40 yen at the end of last year, surged almost 20 yen during the last three months to 160 yen before falling back slightly. Many analysts believe, however, that some G-7 countries are reluctant to help Japan prop up its currency because they see the yen's weakness as a domestic problem. Expectations of possible intervention to curb the dollar's rising value, they say, are temporarily helping the yen. ``The dollar's uptrend will slow down temporarily because market players are now reluctant to push it up because they fear intervention. But the dollar will soon start rising again,'' said Kenzo Shinomiya, a dealer with Fuji Bank. He predicted the dollar would fall only to 154.50 yen before resuming its climb. The rebound in prices on the stock exchange after three months of almost continual decline was directly linked to the yen's surge against the dollar, traders said. The Nikkei average has declined over 20 percent, or 8,517.94 points, since the end of last year. Kozo Hasunuma, a trader with Yamaichi Securities Co. attributed the index's surge today to a G-7 statement that stressed the importance of the yen's stability, which he said reassured stock investors. ``The index's increase slowed down in the afternoon when some market players sold issues for profit-taking, but as a whole, their buying incentive was strong throughout the day,'' he said. Many investors believe the market bottomed out last week when the Nikkei fell briefly below the 28,000-point level, he added. An estimated 800 million shares changed hands in one of the most active trading days in recent weeks. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bond closed at 86.73 points, up from Friday's close of 86.38, as bond investors were reassured by the yen's strength against the dollar. The No. 199's yield fell to 7.205 percent from 7.275 percent on Friday. Meanwhile, Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno told a news conference today that the yen's weakness was due to speculation and that speculative pressure in th market would be met by coordinated G-7 action. He enphasized that the Paris G-7 meeting was the first in which the yen was specificaly mentioned in the communique. Mieno stressed that the G-7 nations would take appropriate and timely measures in accordance with the communique, and said he hopes the market would interpret the G-7 statement in that light. He said there is no reason for the yen to weaken considering the strength of Japan's economic fundamentals.

DOC.HEAD: Two More Bodies Push Fire Toll to Six; Eight Still Missing
DOC.TEXT: Investigators picked through the charred remains of a residential hotel, looking for more bodies as the death toll in the fire rose to six. Searchers using dogs and heavy equipment continued sifting debris in the charred hulk of the 39-year-old Fontana Hotel today after finding the fifth and sixth bodies Sunday. The number of guests unaccounted for after the fast-moving fire swept through the 102-room hotel Friday dropped to eight. More than a score of federal, state, city and county agency officials began their search at the top and along the sides of the gutted building. ``Our main concern now is to get the bodies out, but safely so that we don't risk the teams,'' said Miami Beach Police Detective Jim Hyde, spokesman for the search effort. The fifth body was unidentifiable even as to gender. It was found Sunday morning when a bulldozer pushed aside some debris, Hyde said. At midafternoon, the sixth body, that of a woman, was found in the rear of the blackened remnants of the hotel. The fourth body, discovered Saturday, remained in the building throughout the weekend. Dr. Joseph Davis, chief medical examiner for Dade County, said searchers couldn't immediately get to it because of dangerous debris. A bathtub and a roof-top tank dangled above the spot where that body was found, and a weakened wall remained standing nearby, he said. Only one of the six victims, Dr. Joseph Wels, 92, has been identified. Davis said all bodies still in the hotel would eventually be found. About 100 people, many of them elderly retirees, were seasonal or year-round residents at the Fontana. Survivors had to grope down dark, smoky hallways or jump out windows to flee the fire. The Fontana complied with current fire regulations, according to city officials, and was equipped with smoke detectors in each room. But the hotel did not have sprinklers, which are required by law only beginning in 1991. Besides the death toll, 21 hotel residents were taken to three area hospitals Friday for treatment, and five remained hospitalized in good condition over the weekend.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower, Gold Rises Slightly
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was lower against other major currencies in calm trading in Europe this morning, as the market assessed the possible impact of the weekend meeting of the Group of Seven industrialized nations. Gold prices rose slightly. The dollar wasn't showing much reaction to reports that a number of European central banks stepped into the market to sell dollars for yen, dealers said. The yen failed to rally convincingly because the market doesn't believe the G-7 is committed to supporting the currency, dealers said. The finance ministers of Britain, Canada, France, West Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States agreed at their meeting in Paris on Saturday that the yen's recent downswing could have ``undesirable consequences.'' But they only said they would keep developments under review. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 1.02 yen to a closing 156.45 yen Monday. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 156.98 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Friday: _1.6914 West German marks, down from 1.6941 _1.4951 Swiss francs, down from 1.4992 _5.6803 French francs, down from 5.6942 _1.9043 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9070 _1,242.50 Italian lire, down from 1,245.50 _1.1635 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1652 In London, the dollar fell against the British pound, which was quoted at $1.6395, compared with $1.6385 late Friday. DOC.HEAD: Cold in East, Rockies
DOC.TEXT: Northwest winds continued to bring partly cloudy skies and colder temperatures to much of the East today. Cold also prevailed in the Rockies, and snow fell in Montana. Freezing temperatures were reported this morning in northern New England and northern New York state. Temperatures in the 30s were reported as far south as the Carolinas and Tennessee. Rain fell in parts of Florida and Texas. Elsewhere, showers dampened Nebraska and Iowa. On Sunday, as much as a foot of snow fell in the mountains of Utah. Thunderstorms produced golf ball-size hail and wind gusts to near 60 mph in southern Florida. Several parked planes turned over at Tamiami Airport near Miami. Thunderstorms also dropped small hail at Rock Springs, Wyo. Rain and thundershowers, with snow in the mountains, also fell in parts of Montana, Wyoming, Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona, Nevada and Idaho. The high temperature for the Lower 48 states Sunday was 90 degrees at Lajitas, Texas. DOC.HEAD: One Killed, 25 Hurt In Yet Another Suspicious Ferry Fire
With PM-Ferry Fire
DOC.TEXT: A fire early today on an Ireland-bound car ferry killed one person, left 25 injured and appeared to be arson, the vessel's owners said. Passengers reported crawling through thick smoke to safety. The fire started in two sleeping cabins in an unoccupied section of the ferry Norrona, which was carrying 297 people from Wales, Dublin, Ireland-based B and I shipping line said in a statement. It did not elaborate, but the company's marine superintendent, Capt. Peter McKenna, told Irish Radio that B and I was ``fairly certain about this.'' He said the company believes mattresses or lighted paper were used to start the fire. Police were interviewing all those on board. The ferry was eight miles off the Welsh coast en route from Milford Haven, 180 miles west of London, to Rosslare, Ireland, when the fire was discovered. Firefighters and crew members controlled the blaze within two hours of the captain's Mayday call, said coast guard spokesman George Clarke. Survivors described crawling through thick smoke that choked corridors and cabins, 10 of which were damaged. ``I took the skin off my knees and toes but, thank God, we got out alive,'' said Fred Jenkinson, who was asleep in his cabin when he heard shouts and smelled smoke. ``I am sure the terrible fire on the Scandinavian Star at the weekend was going through a lot of people's minds. Suddenly, we all seemed to be in a similar situation.'' About 150 people aboard the Scandinavian Star ferry were killed when fire broke out Saturday as the ship sailed in the North Sea on an overnight trip from Norway to Denmark. Investigators said they suspected arson. ``We were in the cabin when we heard a shout and the whole place was filled with smoke. It was quite frightening. But there was absolutely no panic,'' said Olive Leader, who was traveling with her sister and children. Another passenger, Delia Reynolds, said she heard screaming but no alarms. ``Crew members were busy going around saying `Everyone up on deck, go up on deck.' The smoke was awful but there was no panic,'' Mrs. Reynolds said. A team of B and I engineers boarded the ferry to assess the damage. The coast guard at Milford Haven, Wales, said the person killed in the fire had not been identified but a Royal Air Force spokesman said it was a crew member. Nine of the injured were airlifted from the ferry by two RAF helicopters and one Royal Navy helicopter, which also brought firefighters and two doctors to the vessel, Clarke said. Other casualties from among the 219 passengers and 78 crew members were taken to the hospital by ambulance when the vessel returned to the dock at Milford Haven under its own power. The injured were treated for smoke inhalation, cuts and bruises, said an unidentified spokeswoman at Withybush Hospital in Haverfordwest. One woman was transferred to the intensive care unit at another hospital, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Senior Communist Rebel Arrested At Airport
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested the alleged deputy chief of staff of the Communist rebel army today as he returned to the country from Europe, officials and state television reported. Antonio Cabardo, alleged deputy chief of staff of the New People's Army, was taken into custody about noon at Ninoy Aquino International Airport, said Col. Victor Tiangco, operations chief of the Capital Command. The government television station reported that Cabardo came from Europe with a stopover in Hong Kong but did not say which European country he had visited. As deputy chief of staff, Cabardo is believed to be the second-ranking figure in the 20,000-member New People's Army, which has been waging a 21-year insurgency to establish a Marxist state. Cabardo is believed to be a member of the political bureau of the outlawed Communist Party of the Philippines. The rebel chief of staff, Romulo Kintanar, escaped from prison in November 1988 after slipping away from a birthday party for a former jailer. The military had offered a 500,000 peso ($23,800) reward for his capture. Cabardo was the most senior party official to be apprehended since July, when suspected political bureau member Saturnino Ocampo and his wife were arrested in Manila.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Testify Orders to Break Bones Came from High Up
DOC.TEXT: Three Israeli soldiers have testified that they were told army orders to break the bones of Palestinian detainees came from the upper echelons of the military. The soldiers _ reserve Sgts. Guy Neeman, Amiram Avirosh and Ronen Ferber _ were called as defense witnesses in the court martial of Col. Yehuda Meir, the former commander of Israeli troops in the Nablus area of the West Bank. Meir, 38, who left the army last year, is charged with ordering soldiers to break the limbs of Palestinians taken into custody in the West Bank villages of Beita and Hawwara in January 1988. The trial began last month. Col. Menashe Finkelstein, the army's chief prosecutor, suggested in cross-examination that orders to break bones originated from officers in the field. But last month, Meir was quoted by the Hadashot newspaper as suggesting the orders originated from someone with a higher military rank. ``The entire leadership of the Israeli defense forces from the defense minister through the chief of staff and other commanders ... will have to answer questions they may wish to silence,'' he was quoted as saying. At the third session of his trial, Meir sat impassively, often smiling to himself, as the three soldiers detailed the brutal actions in Beita on Jan. 19 and in Hawarra two days later. According to Avirosh, the Beita incident began when soldiers went to investigate a firebomb attack. He said Meir appealed to village leaders for calm, but gangs of youths blocked the roads and hurled stones. He said the soldiers rounded up 12 Arabs who were handcuffed and in some cases blindfolded, put on a bus and driven out of town. After several miles they were ordered off and ``beaten very badly,'' he said. He said the company commander, identified only as Eldad, told the soldiers after the incident, ``it was not easy for him to give us this order.'' Avirosh recalled Eldad said ``it was immoral, but the order came from high up, I think he said from the defense minister.'' Avirosh referred to Yitzhak Rabin, who resigned as defense minister last month when the Labor Party pulled out of the ruling coalition and brought down the government. On Jan. 19, 1988 Rabin told a news conference the army had orders to quell riots with ``force, power and blows.'' He has denied he authorized soldiers to break prisoners' bones. Rabin's spokesman, Eitan Haber, said Rabin gave permission only to beat demonstrators during pursuit. ``He never said that we should break bones,'' Haber said. ``To beat, to hit, but not to break. He never said break.'' Ferber said the next day the company commander told the unit:``we are going someplace for an unusual action for the purpose of breaking arms and legs. ``He said this was part of a new iron-fist policy and these were not his orders but came from further up. I felt that he himself was unhappy with them.'' According to the testimony, the village leader in Hawwara rounded up Palestinians wanted by the army. Then, enroute to the detention center, the detainees were taken from the bus and beaten with sticks and rifle. Afterward, Ferber said Eldad told the soldiers ``all the other methods that were tried before hadn't worked so we thought that breaking arms and legs would be a longer-lasting deterrent.'' The next day, the unit was told the policy had been nullified.

It was only when the flames were around the bridge and we didn't have a chance to go down to look for more passengers on the deck that I gave the order to leave the ship.'' _ Hugo Larsen, captain of the Scandinavian Star, denying reports that he and his officers abandoned the ferry as rescue efforts began after it caught fire in the North Sea.

DOC.HEAD: With Mass Expression Of Defiance, Georgians Mark Bitter Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of Soviet Georgians rallied in Tbilisi today on the anniversary of the slaying of 19 pro-independence protesters by Soviet forces, and burned the region's military chief in effigy. There was a partial re-enactment of last year's 4 a.m. assault, when troops armed with shotguns, shovels and toxic gas charged onto Rustaveli Boulevard in the Georgian capital. Radio stations broadcast the sound of rumbling tanks and ringing bells. From midnight Sunday through early today, people carrying flowers and candles thronged the boulevard. About 100,000 Georgians stood with raised fists for a silent moment to honor the dead. Later, demonstrators burned an effigy of Col. Gen. I.N. Rodionov, regional military commander, in front of the city's Government House, which overlooks the broad square where Soviet troops moved in. Nineteen people died in the clash a year ago, and another was killed by troops in a separate incident. Thousands suffered ailments from the gas. The assault caused a nationwide furor, raised doubts about President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's proclaimed policy of not using troops to stifle dissent, and brought many Georgians into the battle for independence. The memorial protest on Sunday and today had more an air of defiance than mourning. Most speakers spoke of the impetus the deaths gave the republic's burgeoning independence movement. ``This is a day of great sorrow, but also a day of great victory,'' said Zviad Gamsakhurdia. ``On this day, the Georgian soul was revived.'' ``April 9 was the beginning of the national, democratic revolution of Georgia, which is continuing,'' said Gamsakhurdia, the dean of Georgian dissidents. Demonstrations were planned for later today in front of the regional military headquarters and at the central stadium. In Leningrad on Sunday, about 30,000 people gathered on historic Palace Square to mark the anniversary, journalist Maxim Korzlov said. He said the crowd lit candles and stood in silence. The square is the site of the 1905 ``Bloody Sunday'' incident in which czarist forces fired on a crowd of demonstrators. ``Today we recall the event of another Bloody Sunday, taking place a year ago on the ninth of April,'' Anatoly Sobchak, a national legislator, told the demonstrators. Gorbachev offered condolences Sunday, expressing his ``respect for Georgia and its industrious people who are distinguished for their glorious traditions, original culture and friendliness.'' But Georgian activists dismissed the gesture. ``I believe he's sorry for people but he can't be sincere on the government level because after Tbilisi came Baku,'' said a member of the Georgian People's Front, a new moderate political group. He did not give his name. Anti-Armenian riots broke out in Baku on Jan. 13 and Soviet troops stormed the city a week later. By official count, about 200 people were killed. Red-white-and-black Georgian flags flew from many Tbilisi buildings on Sunday, and women and children, some wearing black headbands, placed red carnations and other flowers on the steps before the arches of Government House. The steps glowed with the tiny flames of memorial candles and church bells rang. Banners held by protesters read, ``Better to Die in the Battle for Freedom Than to Live as a Slave,'' and ``Down with the Occupiers.'' Gamsakhurdia estimated that before April 9, 1989, only a small minority of Georgians favored full independence from Moscow. Now, he believes 90 percent of the people are on his side. Pro-independence politicians in Georgia, a Caucasus republic of 5 million, have scored major victories in recent weeks. On March 9, the Georgian Parliament condemned Georgia's forced annexation by the Soviet Union and demanded negotiations on the restoration of independence. Later last month, Georgian radicals persuaded lawmakers to put off local elections, thus giving newly legalized opposition parties time to gain support. But the opposition movement appears badly splintered. A rift exists between those who favor a Baltic-style parliamentary fight, and extremists who want mass civil disobedience and boycotts of state elections and the Soviet draft.

DOC.HEAD: Nepalese Celebrate Return To Multiparty System
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with two dead, new celebrations, CORRECTS that flag ceremony was today; Picks up 13th pvs,, `When I...'
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of Nepalese paraded through Katmandu in a delirium of joy today, chanting ``Victory, Victory'' as this mountain monarchy celebrated the establishment of a multiparty system. In a stunning announcement late Sunday, just two days after police shot and killed as many as 200 pro-democracy protesters, King Birendra lifted a 29-year ban on political parties. The city sprang to life early today after a two-day curfew was lifted, but doctors said security forces had opened fire on celebrants Sunday night. Relatives of a man and a 12-year-old boy said the two were shot and killed. Doctors at Bir Hospital said five other people were being treated for bullet wounds. The people who took the casualties to the hospital reported at least 10 other people were killed and their bodies taken away by the troops, the doctors said on condition of anonymity. The reports could not be confirmed. Police denied there was any firing. The 7-week-old pro-democracy campaign snowballed last week as strikes spread and more people took to the streets. On Friday, police opened fire on a crowd of more than 200,000 people marching toward the royal palace. Witnesses said as many as 200 people were killed but the government said only 10 people died and 107 were wounded. It was Nepal's worst bloodshed in more than a century. Today, hundreds of processions by foot, cars and motor-powered rickshaws wound through the capital's main streets. ``Today we will celebrate our freedom. We have no definite plan, but we only want to express our joy,'' said Yagya Nidhi Duhal, his face smeared with red powder used by Nepalese during celebrations. Most other processionists, including several Western tourists, sported the powder mark on their foreheads. Hundreds of troops who had been patrolling Katmandu and its suburbs assembled in a central park today preparing to return to barracks. Dozens of armored personnel carriers were withdrawn overnight. Revelries started shortly before midnight Sunday, when King Birendra's proclamation was announced on state television and radio. The movement for greater democracy was launched Feb. 18 by the Nepali Congress Party and the United Left Front, a coalition of left-wing parties. Early today, marchers carried the red and white flags of the Nepali Congress, hugged each other and shouted: ``Panchayat thieves go back. Hang the Panchayat,'' referring to the partyless national assembly, the Rashtriya Panchayat. ``When I was born 30 years ago, I could not breathe. Today I am like a free bird. I am so happy I want to fly,'' schoolteacher Nagendra Amatya said at Bir Hospital, where he had gone to meet the top Nepali Congress leader, Ganesh Man Singh. Singh, who had led the movement from his hospital bed for the past week, walked out of his room today for the first time to greet people. He had been under house arrest before being taken to the hospital for treatment of arthritis and a urinary infection. ``Our responsiblity has increased. The struggle for democracy was difficult, but it will be more difficult to maintain the democracy,'' the 75-year-old Singh said as he slowly walked out of his ward, aided by a stout stick and two associates. Foreign Minister Pashupati Rani said Sunday that elections for the yet-undissolved national assembly would be held soon, but gave no date. For 50 days, hundreds of thousands of people had taken part in demonstrations for a new political system in Nepal, where the monarchy wielded almost absolute power. There had been demonstrations in the past, but support was limited to students and a small circle of political agitators. The current campaign drew doctors, lawyers and teachers who went on strike. Then, the pilots of Royal Air Nepal walked off their jobs, followed by staffers in several state-run banks and even government ministries. Before police opened fire on demonstrators Friday, at least 16 people were killed in the ballooning movement.
