But Friday's bloodshed jolted the normally tranquil country, where the largely illiterate peasantry had revered the monarch as a reincarnation of the Hindu god Shiva. Not since 1846, when feuding members of the royal household battled had Nepal seen such bloodshed. Birendra, 44, is the heir of the Shaha dynasty that has held the throne since the middle of the 18th century. The kingdom's only previous experiment with Western-style democracy lasted less than two years and came to a halt in 1961 when Birendra's father, King Mahendra, dismissed the Nepali Congress government, accusing it of corruption and inefficiency. Until Sunday, political parties had been banned and the king had ruled with the rubber stamp National Assembly. Birendra selected one-fifth of the assembly's members. The rest were elected on a nonparty basis, but political observers said all candidates were approved by the palace.

DOC.HEAD: Filipino Creativity Often Leads To The Most Creative Of Escapes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to ADD second escape; Picks up 6th , `Military chief ...' EDITS thereafter to conform.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The knock at the door was supposed to be the delivery man bringing more beer to a party at the Manila city jail. Instead, 15 rebel soldiers burst in and freed Lt. Col. Billy Bibit. Sunday's escape by Bibit, jailed on charges of trying to overthrow the government for his alleged role in the Dec. 1-9 failed coup, was just the latest example of prisoners taking advantage of lax security to win freedom. President Corazon Aquino ordered a nationwide manhunt for Bibit. A presidential spokeswoman, Lourdes Sytangco, described Mrs. Aquino as ``angry'' and promised: ``We will be seeing more forceful action in this case.'' The Manila city jail superintendent was relieved and three jailers, including a deputy warden, were arrested for negligence after Sunday's escape. And today, an air force captain held for trying to overthrow the government escaped, eluding guards at Villamor Air Base, sources said on condition of anonymity. Capt. Rogelio Seradoy had during a failed August 1987 coup piloted the helicopter in which coup leader Lt. Col. Gregorio Honasan escaped. In the Philippines, ``great escapes'' are better described as ``great escapades.'' Military Chief of Staff Gen. Renato de Villa admitted recently that he was displeased with security at jails and stockades nationwide. But de Villa said it was difficult to enforce strict security because Filipino culture frowns on rules which prohibit conjugal visits, fraternization between guards and inmates and liberal furloughs to attend funerals, graduations and other family occasions. Police said Bibit escaped after guards, inmates and women visitors gathered and drank beer to celebrate the birthday of the deputy warden, Maj. Manuel Roxas. In November 1988, the chief of the Communist rebel army, Romulo Kintanar, slipped away from a birthday celebration for a former jailer and resumed command of the New People's Army. The fact that such an important prisoner was allowed out of his cell, albeit under guard, was suprising considering the flap surrounding Honasan's escape six months earlier. Honasan had been held aboard a prison ship in Manila Bay because he led the August 1987 attempt to topple Mrs. Aquino. Despite assurances Honasan had been neutralized, the charismatic officer convinced sailors to help him escape in April 1988. He remains at large and is believed to have played a major role in the failed December coup, which claimed the lives of at least 113 people and left more than 600 injured. Another alleged conspirator, Lt. Col. Eduardo Matillano, slipped away in 1988 when he was allowed to leave a stockade to visit a dentist. Matillano was arrested a few months later when waiters spotted him dining with a well-known pornographic movie star. Sometimes, prisoners have been allowed to leave jails by corrupt guards to commit crimes. In 1987, a suspect was arrested after witnesses identified him as one of the killers of Local Governments Secretary Jaime Ferrer. It turned out the suspect was supposed to have been in the national prison serving a life sentence for murder. He had been released a few days before Ferrer's murder to testify in a trial. A judge and the warden were later fired after investigators learned there was no trial and the release order was bogus. Such practices are not unique to the Aquino administration. In May 1985, during the late President Ferdinand Marcos' term, a senior Communist leader, Saturnino Ocampo, was allowed to leave prison to vote in the National Press Club elections. Ocampo, a former journalist, slipped away from his guards. He was arrested last July. Ironically, he had been living less than a block from the police headquarters in suburban Makati.

DOC.HEAD: Union Voting on Latest Offer By Kaiser
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of workers at Kaiser Permanente hospitals and medical centers were voting today on a new contract offer that could end a week-old strike at the nation's largest health maintenance organization. Seven Kaiser hospitals and more than 40 clinics were affected by the walkout by about 11,000 members of Service Workers International Union Local 399. The strike began April 2, two days after just over 4,500 of the affected workers voted to reject a $44 million, three-year offer from Kaiser. That offer guaranteed a 5 percent across-the-board raise the first year and 3 percent raises during subsequent years. Workers demanded higher wages, but did not reveal how much they wanted. Top pay for a licensed vocational nurse under the old contract was $13.01 per hour, Kaiser said. Union officials have said employees stood by Kaiser and accepted a wage freeze three years ago when the company was having financial problems. Now, they say, Kaiser is back on its feet and its workers should recoup as well. Kaiser Permanente of Southern California has more than 2 million members, about 1.5 million of whom live in Los Angeles, Orange and Ventura counties, the areas affected by the strike. Hospitals in Anaheim, Los Angeles, West Los Angeles, Panorama City, Woodland Hills, Harbor City, Bellflower and more than 40 satellite medical offices were affected by the walkout. Kaiser cut back some services and reduced patient populations as managers and workers from non-affected facilities filled in.

DOC.HEAD: Richards, Mattox Race to Finish in Texas Gubernatorial Runoff
DOC.TEXT: Democratic gubernatorial rivals Ann Richards and Jim Mattox raced to finish their bruising runoff campaign with stops in a dozen cities today. The candidates visited inner-city churches and campaigned in Hispanic communities Sunday, continuing to trade barbs but promising to make peace after Tuesday's election. The winner will take on Republican nominee Clayton Williams in the November election. Mattox, the state attorney general, accused Ms. Richards on Sunday of being treated for cocaine addiction 10 years ago, the latest and strongest in a series of drug-use allegations that have dominated the runoff campaign. ``I'm saying that she used cocaine at the age of 46 and marijuana, and she used other drugs,'' Mattox said in an interview broadcast on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation.'' The attorney general said he obtained the information from mutual friends he declined to identify. Ms. Richards, the state treasurer, phoned the program to deny she'd ever sought treatment for cocaine use, but declined to appear on the show. She dismissed the charge Saturday, when word of the pre-taped interview reached her while campaigning in Henderson. ``Jimmy's just going nuts,'' Ms. Richards said. Last week, three people claimed they saw Mattox smoke marijuana on separate occasions in the 1970s. Mattox denied the accusations. Ms. Richards has answered questions about illegal drug use by saying she has not used a ``mood-altering'' drug in 10 years. A poll published Sunday showed Ms. Richards and Mattox virtually deadlocked. Both candidates planned last-minute campaign swings through Texas. Ms. Richards was scheduled to stump in Arlington, Longview, Midland, San Antonio and Waco today. Mattox was spending the day before the election in Beaumont, Dallas, Hurst, Longview, Lufkin, Texarkana and Tyler. The candidates have apologized in recent days for the negative tone of the campaign and said the Democrats would unite to face Williams. ``We've had a family squabble. I think the family will come back together again because there's more of us in the family than outside the family,'' Mattox said in Houston. But he said, ``Deep down in my heart, I don't think Ann Richards should be governor of Texas. ``I believe her candidacy is a reflection of a social phenomenon that is taking place and it doesn't have anything to do with her ability to really make decisions.'' Mattox said the social phenomenon he meant was ``the demanding the election of a woman governor.'' Ms. Richards said she would mend fences with Mattox and expect his help if she becomes the Democratic nominee. She said, however, Mattox probably wouldn't have a place in her administration. ``His style of management and operation is not something I want,'' Ms. Richards said in Dallas. A poll published Sunday by the Houston Chronicle and The Dallas Morning News showed Ms. Richards and Mattox in a tight race. Of 759 Democrats who said they'd vote in the runoff, 44 percent backed Ms. Richards and 38 percent Mattox, and 16 percent said they were undecided, according to the poll. The telephone survey by the University of Houston had a margin of error of 4 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Four Soldiers Killed In Bomb Blast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with IRA claiming responsibility, civilian injured, details, adds govt comment.
DOC.TEXT: A land mine hidden in a culvert exploded under a military vehicle today, killing four soldiers and injuring a civilian near this southeastern town, police said. The Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility in a statement issued to news media in the British province. An army spokesman said the bomb hurled the heavily Land Rover into the air and left behind a huge crater in the road about 40 feet wide and 15 feet deep. Shattered pieces of the vehicle scattered the nearby countryside. The explosion occurred just before 8 a.m. near the Downpatrick race course in County Down, in the southeast part of the province. The area was quickly sealed off and police and soldiers were airlifted in to search for clues. A civilian in a passing car suffered cuts and bruises, said a spokesman for the Royal Ulster Constabulary. The soldiers were members of the Ulster Defense Regiment, the mainly Protestant, locally recruited regiment of the British army, said the spokesman, speaking anonymously in keeping with British custom. Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Brooke, the British government minister responsible for the province, said ``actions of this sort are wholly senseless in that they will not deflect us from our intention to defend the community against these evil men.'' The deaths bring to 16 killed in political and sectarian violence in Northern Ireland so far this year. The Irish Republican Army is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland and unite the predominantly Protestant province with the Roman Catholic Republic of Ireland.

DOC.HEAD: Three Family Members Die in Fire Blamed on Smoking
DOC.TEXT: A mother, her son and grandson died in an early morning house fire today that was blamed on careless smoking, fire officials said. The three were found in a second-floor bedroom of a two-story home following the fire at 2:30 a.m., Fire Captain Pat Flynn said. No one else was hurt. The victims were apparently trying to get out of the house when they were overcome by smoke, Flynn said. He said the fire had started in a chair on the first floor of the home, and was apparently lit by a cigarette. Fire officials believe a smoke alarm sounded, but the victims were trapped by the flames and unable to escape. Of 14 fire fatalities in Baltimore so far this year, 12 have been smoking related, according to the Fire Department.

DOC.HEAD: Glance At Sunday's Elections
DOC.TEXT: Here is a look at the outcome of elections held Sunday in several countries.
DOC.HEAD: PERU:
DOC.TEXT: Novelist Mario Vargas Llosa won the most votes for president but a politically independent agronomist, Alberto Fujimori, surged ahead of other candidates and forced a runoff. Unofficial returns show Vargas Llosa, an champion of free market reforms and economic shock therapy, leading with 33.9 percent of the vote _ far short of the 50 percent required to avoid a runoff. Soldiers protect polling stations in the economically-troubled Andean nation, but guerrillas of the 10-year-old leftist Shining Path stage attacks. Dynamite is hurled at several polling stations, but no injuries are reported. Fujimori, the 51-year-old son of Japanese immigrants, garnered 29 percent of the vote. Luis Alva Castro of the center-left governing Aprista Party won just 16.4 percent. A few weeks ago, he held a solid second in the polls. Independent pollsters give Fujimori a better-than-even chance of defeating Vargas Llosa in the second round of voting, expected in late May or early June.
DOC.HEAD: GREECE:
DOC.TEXT: In the country's third parliamentary elections in 10 months, the conservative New Democratic party won 150 of Parliament's 300 seats, falling one seat short of the majority needed to govern alone. New Democrat leader Constantine Mitsotakis says he'll nevertheless try to form a government. Lacking an outright majority, however, it was not clear if he would have to turn to a smaller party or an independent in his bid to become premier. A victory by the New Democrats, who fell just short of a majority in inconclusive June and November elections, would end a debilitating political deadlock that has left Greece unable to cope with a crumbling economy and growing urban terrorism. The conservatives last held power in 1981, when they lost in a landslide to the Panhellenic Socialist Movement (PASOK) of former Premier Andreas Papandreou. Both PASOK and the conservatives have governed Greece since the military dictatorship ended in 1974.
DOC.HEAD: HUNGARY:
DOC.TEXT: In balloting that ended four decades of Communist rule, the conservative and nationalistic Democratic Forum won a resounding victory over its liberal rival but fell short of a majority. Unofficial results show the party to have won 165 of 386 seats at stake in Sunday's runoff and first-round balloting two weeks ago. The liberal League of Free Democrats collected 92 seats. The agrarian Smallholders took 43 seats and the Christian Democrats won 21. The two parties are considered likely coalition partners, largely sharing the Democratic Forum's emphasis on family and Hungarian tradition. It is the second victory for a conservative party in free elections in the former Soviet bloc. Conservatives won big in East Germany's March 18 vote, falling just short of a majority. In both countries, the remnants of the long-ruling Communists were relegated to a relatively minor opposition role. The Socialist Party, comprised of Communist reformers who nearly two years ago initiated the democratic changes in Hungary, won 33 seats.
DOC.HEAD: YUGOSLAVIA:
DOC.TEXT: The liberal republic of Slovenia held Yugoslavia's first free multiparty elections since 1945, with the presidential candidate who favored a cautious approach to secession winning the most votes. But former Communist Milan Kucan did not gain an absolute majority and faces an April 22 runoff vote with Joze Pucnik, a former political prisoner who advocates quick Slovenian independence from Yugoslavia. Early returns from Sunday's balloting indicated the Slovenian Communists, who recently followed an East European trend and renamed themselves, would be the largest single party in the republic's Parliament but would face a tough five-party conservative coalition led by Pucnik. The former Communists have broken with the national Communist Party leadership because it has resisted democratic reform. Slovenians have shown an increased desire to secede from the loose and ethnically diverse Yugoslav federation because they are unhappy with resistance to reform in much of the rest of the country, especially Serbia. Serbia, the largest Yugoslav republic, is a bastion of centralized control where the leaders demand continued Communist Party dominance.

DOC.HEAD: Havel Proposes Creation of New European Security Commission
DOC.TEXT: In a speech to a six-nation conference on Central Europe today, President Vaclav Havel proposed creation of a new security commission that would gradually replace NATO and the Warsaw Pact. ``It is impossible to return to the Europe of the past'' and therefore a timetable should be agreed to shape the Europe of the future, Havel said in outlining his prescription for curbing the continent's historic conflicts. The dissident playwright turned president suggested the Bratislava conference find ways to ``build a solid wall against all expressions of nationalism and chauvinism,'' said his spokesman, Michael Zantovsky. The unique day-long meeting gathered representatives of Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia, with Austria, Italy and Hungary attending as observers. It seemed unlikely to reach any decisions on its broad agenda, partly because Hungary was represented by officials of the reformed Communist leadership that was soundly defeated in Sunday's free elections. Jozsef Antall, the leader of the victorious Hungarian Democratic Forum and the likely new premier of Hungary, was invited but sent the party's vice president, Ferenc Kulin, Hungarian officials said. Outlining 10 questions to the closed-door meeting, Havel invited consideration of a proposal to create a new all-European Security Commission this year, Zantovsky told reporters. The idea was first outlined by Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier at a Warsaw Pact meeting in Prague on March 17, when the Czechoslovaks said it drew a mixed response, the coolest reaction coming from the Soviets. Both superpowers have reacted somewhat coldly to the insistence by Havel and Dienstbier that Europe's military blocs are outdated and should be disbanded. Czechoslovakia wants to use the 35-nation Helsinki process, involving the United States, Canada and all European nations except Albania, as the basis for the new Security Commission, and for new agreements to preserve peace on the world's most heavily armed continent. Havel, who called today's conference for Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia to ponder cooperation in their ``return to Europe,'' proposed the three pool efforts to join the 12-nation European Economic Community. He also said they should take a joint stand on the Warsaw Pact and Soviet economic bloc, Comecon. All three countries are emerging from more than four decades of Soviet domination and Communist rule. Uniting could help them combat the influence likely to be wielded by a united Germany. However, such cooperation could be marred both by conflicting interests such as those of debt-ridden Poland and relatively wealthy Czechoslovakia, and by the ethnic conflicts that have clouded Eastern Europe's democratic reforms. Those conflicts could threaten European peace, as they did between the two World Wars and for centuries before. Eastern Europe's worst ethnic conflict currently is the tension between the Hungarian minority and Romanians in Transylvania, where an explosion of strife last month left at least six people dead in Tirgu Mures. The victory of the center-right Democratic Forum in Sunday's Hungarian elections is likely also to keep the fate of the Hungarian minorities in Romania, Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia high on Budapest's diplomatic agenda. The outgoing Socialist government in Hungary already has asked Prague to improve the rights of the 500,000 Hungarians living in Slovakia. Foreign Ministry sources suggested demands for Hungarian-language schools would be granted if matched by similar rights for the tiny Slovak minority in Hungary. In pushing their agenda for a new Europe, Havel and Dienstbier have been able to draw on their years-long contacts with former Solidarity activists now wielding power in Poland, and to a lesser extent on ties to one-time dissidents in Hungary.

DOC.HEAD: High-Ho? Neighbors Criticize Disney's Towering Dwarfs
DOC.TEXT: Many residents of the sleepy neighborhoods near the Walt Disney Co. are grumpy about towering additions to the firm's new headquarters, and they're not bashful about saying so. ``Obviously Disney always does things their own way, with a flair for the dramatic,'' said Jeff Vander Borght, a Burbank planning board member. ``But I'm afraid it's totally out of scale for the neighborhood.'' This week, a huge veil comes down at the new corporate headquarters to reveal 19-foot tall renderings of Happy, Grumpy, Sleepy, Sneezy, Dopey, Bashful and Doc perched on the third story. The statues appear to hold up the fifth-story roof. Alan Epstein, vice president of Disney Development Corp., and Burbank's city planner, Rick Pruetz, said the building conforms strictly to city codes, so no public hearings were held on the design. That's a pity, said Vander Borght, an architect who lives nearby. ``It gives a whole new meaning to the word dwarf,'' he said. ``Stretch dwarfs. We're going to be known as the city of the huge dwarfs.'' Abutting the sprawling Burbank lot on two sides are quiet residential neighborhoods, where neat bungalows sit on tree-lined streets. Yards sport neatly trimmed hedges, barbecue grills and pools. Founder Walt Disney allowed no identification of the company on the studio property. The studio gate carried only a small plaque identifying the nature of the enterprise inside. ``Walt didn't want tourists popping in to interfere with production,'' said a longtime employee, who asked not to be identified. ``And he didn't want people mistakenly believing that Disneyland was in Burbank.'' However, Michael Eisner changed all that when he became Disney chairman in 1984. Now the studio lot's huge water tower sports a picture of Mickey Mouse and soon the dwarfs _ characters from Disney's 1937 animated classic, ``Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs'' _ will peer down on those who enter the executive offices.

DOC.HEAD: Police Find Children's Bodies, Raise Death Estimate To 170
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thoughout with bodies of Children found, estimate of dead revised to upwards of 170, ADDS ferry fire of Britain, background. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Police investigators today breached the blackened interior of the Scandinavia Star ferry and found children's bodies, raising the estimated death toll from a weekend fire to 170, a spokesman said. The suspicious blaze, which broke out early Saturday while the ship was traveling from Norway to Denmark with at least 500 aboard, was extinguished Sunday night, officials said. A team of officers today entered cabins previously blocked by fire and searing heat, said Police Inspector Lief Skoglund. ``When they went inside the boat they saw lots and lots of dead bodies, maybe 100 more,'' said Skoglund. ``There may 170 dead on board,'' he said, making clear that it was rough estimate. Police earlier estimated the number of victims on the 20-year-old vessel at around 150 but said that did not count children who would not appear on any passenger list. The remains of 75 victims were removed from the blackened shell of the 470-foot Danish-owned ferry before the fire was extinguished, Skoglund said. Police listed 345 survivors, but it was uncertain how many people had been aboard when the fire broke out. The captain said 395 passengers and 97 crewmen were on board, leaving 147 people dead or missing and presumed dead. But that figure did not include children under age 7, said Onso. An accurate count of the victims was expected to take several days. The ship caught fire before dawn Saturday on the North Sea voyage from Oslo, Norway to Frederikshavn, Denmark. The captain of the ship denied improper behavior today, as reports surfaced that he and his officers abandoned the burning vessel as rescue efforts got under way. District police chief Roar Onso said a commission of officials from Sweden, Norway and Denmark would investigate the disaster, parallel to the police investigation focusing on suspicion of arson. ``We are working on the assumption that the fire was arranged,'' said Magnar Aukrust, assistant police chief in Oslo, Norway. ``In that case, it is a real disaster, caused by one or several persons,'' he said. Onso said Sunday that the investigation would probe all possibilities to the case, including any connection to three previous fires on North Sea ferries. But Onso said it was difficult to see a link between the fires, which occurred on different routes on ships from different companies. Another suspicious fire early today broke out on a ferry bound from Wales to Ireland, killing one person and injuring 25, the vessel's owners said. Passengers reported crawling through thick smoke to safety. The fire started in two sleeping cabins in an unoccupied section of the ferry Norrona, which was carrying 297 people, said a statement by the Dublin, Ireland-based B and I shipping line. Company officials blamed arson. Captain Hugo Larsen was on the bridge of the 10,500-ton ferry as the smoldering ship was towed into harbor at dusk on Saturday. Fire officials said he left the ship before all survivors were evacuated, and returned later. ``I never failed the passengers,'' Larsen was quoted as saying by Sweden's national TT news agency. ``It was only when the flames were around the bridge and we didn't have a chance to go down to look for more passengers on the deck that I gave the order to leave the ship,'' Larsen was quoted as saying. Fire inspector Ingvar Brynfors, who was among the first rescuers to reach the ship, said Larsen had moved to the Stena Saga, another ferry that picked up survivors and helped coordinate rescue efforts. Larsen, speaking on Swedish radio, also denied that the alarm failed to go off. ``The fire alarm sounded all over the boat,'' he said. Passengers complained that the crewmen, mostly Filipinos and Portuguese sailors, were untrained for emergencies and could not communicate with them. Rick Qualls, an American member of a song-and-dance troupe that worked on the ship, said the alarm was sounded 15 minutes after the vessel caught fire and filled with smoke. In a week aboard the ship, he said, he had never undergone a fire drill, though he praised the crew for trying to save lives. Firefighter Bjorn Ralbring told the Dagens Nyheter newspaper that he was given to understand that everyone was safely evacuated by the time he arrived _ 3{ hours after the distress signal was sent. He said he was surprised to stumble over bodies. ``Behind every cabin door there were more dead people. There were mothers who tried to protect their children with rags, older couples were huddled together,'' he said. Onso said Sunday that the hunt for the cause of the fire would begin in earnest as soon as all the bodies were taken out and the ship cooled enough for investigators to work. One unconfirmed report carried by several newspapers said Larsen was warned of possible arson 10 hours before the voyage. Police confirmed that at least two fires broke out independently on separate decks within a few minutes of each other. Onso declined to speculate on how that fit with claims by the ship'd Danish owner, VR Da-No, that the fires were deliberately set. On Sept. 25, 1989 a fire started in a linen closet killed two peple on the Tor Scandinavia west of the Danish coast. Police suspected arson but failed to charge anyone. Arson was not suspected in the other fires aboard the King of Scandinavia Feb. 18, 1989, in which five people were hospitalized, and on the Stena Nordica 10 days later, in which no one was injured.

DOC.HEAD: Non-Greyhound Bus Struck by Two Bullets In Fort Worth
DOC.TEXT: An Arrow Trailways bus was struck by two bullets as it drove on a highway near downtown, the first violence attributed to the Greyhound drivers strike in the city, officials said. The bus, carrying 11 passengers from San Angelo to Dallas, was hit about 10:30 p.m. Sunday, officials said. One bullet struck the passenger door near the front of the bus and another hit just behind the door, police said. ``It sounds like the metal or glass stopped one from penetrating or it would have hit the driver in the head,'' said Fort Worth Police Sgt. Jon Grady. He said there are no suspects in the incident. Arrow Trailways is not affiliated with Greyhound, but Greyhound spokesman Kevin Fry in Dallas said police notified the company of the incident. Killeen-based Arrow Trailways belongs to an association of bus companies that uses the name of the former Trailways bus line, which was taken over by Greyhound a few years ago. Arrow Trailways' drivers are not on strike. Asked this morning why Greyhound was notified of the shooting if the two companies are not affiliated, spokeswoman Liz Hale replied, ``Maybe somebody made a mistake.'' There have been more than 30 incidents of shootings of buses since Greyhound drivers went on strike March 2. The company has said it won't negotiate with the strikers until a week passes without strike-related violence. Elsewhere, a Greyhound replacement driver was charged Sunday with carrying a dangerous weapon after he brandished a rifle during a confrontation with striking bus workers in Washington, D.C. A Boston-bound Greyhound bus rear-ended a jeep Sunday on the Massachusetts Turnpike after suffering apparent brake failure, the state police said. No injuries were reported on the bus, but the jeep's driver was taken to a hospital complaining of back pain.

DOC.HEAD: Conservative, Nationalist Party Wins Resounding Victory
Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Forum leader beginning
DOC.TEXT: effort to form coalition government, expresses confidence. Pickup 7th graf `The crowd...'; EDITS thereafter to TRIM and CONFOarty, Antall said: ``It is not we, but the Hungarian people who have won these elections.'' Although the Hungarian Socialists were unique among the late Soviet bloc's ruling parties in implementing democratic reform without massive popular pressure, they were voted out of power in the first round. Many people associated the party with the excesses of 43 years of Communist rule. The Communists consolidated power in 1948, a year after Hungary's last multiparty elections, which were widely believed to have been rigged. In Sunday's runoffs, 171 seats were directly elected, and 90 were decided on the basis of proportional representation, achieved by tallying the votes for each party. In the first round 29 parties competed but most did not garner enough votes to qualify for the second round.

DOC.HEAD: One Siamese Twin Dies
DOC.TEXT: One of the Siamese twins surgically separated last week at the chest and abdomen has died, a hospital spokeswoman said. James Watkins died Sunday at 3:20 p.m. EDT, said Catherine Coleman at All Children's Hospital. The cause of death was not immediately being released, she said. Ms. Coleman said James' twin, Jakob, remained in critical but stable condition. ``Right now, that's all the parents want released,'' she said. ``I don't know at what point his condition changed.'' The twins were born Feb. 28 to Raquel and Scott Watkins of St. Petersburg. Both James and Jakob were listed in critical but stable condition after undergoing nearly 13 hours of separation surgery April 3. Chief surgeon Richard Harmel said after the operation that the main problem encountered by the operating team was dividing the twins' only shared organ, the liver. Jakob emerged from the operation as the larger and more dominant of the two boys, doctors said. Jakob was described as having more healthy liver tissue, more tissue around his abdominal cavity and more skin to cover the separation wound. Siamese twins occur about once every 100,000 births, with more than half dying within the first 48 hours.

DOC.HEAD: Andrew Lloyd Webber's `Aspects of Love' Opens on Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 4 grafs with what other critics said. No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: ``Intimate'' is not an adjective usually used in describing the musicals of Andrew Lloyd Webber, the man behind ``Cats,'' ``Evita,'' ``Starlight Express'' and ``The Phantom of the Opera.'' But ``Aspects of Love,'' which opened Sunday at Broadway's Broadhurst Theater, is a small Lloyd Webber musical that attempts to spin several personal, paper-thin stories into a rueful meditation on the wayward ways of love. Despite designer Maria Bjornson's stunning settings _ including one breathtaking mountain panorama, ``Aspects of Love'' is really a chamber piece, a showcase for what is Lloyd Webber's most unified and complex work to date. The musical won't be the audience pleaser that his past megahits have been. The tone is a little too rarified, and several of its leading characters are decidedly unlikable. But the show represents an important step forward for the composer in terms of musical construction. ``Aspects of Love'' is based on a short, snobby and sophisticated novel by David Garnett, a minor member of the Bloomsbury group. In the book, Garnett chronicled the couplings _ and uncouplings _ of various arty types in the south of France. Lloyd Webber has updated the book a bit, setting his story between the years 1947 and 1964. The protagonist is Alex Dillingham, whose obsession with an older actress, Rose Vibert, lasts those 17 years. His fascination with her transcends Rose's marriage to his uncle George, her flirtation with an Italian sculptress named Giulietta and even his infatuation with his niece, Jenny, the daughter of Rose and George. Got that? There is enough bed-hopping and sexual longing to satisfy the most ardent soap opera fan, but the Lloyd Webber music elevates the story to something more. And Trevor Nunn's fluid direction makes sure the show doesn't linger too long on the more precious permutations of Garnett's plot. Musically, the show, which is sung through with almost no spoken dialogue, mirrors the various aspects of love. There are soaring melodies of budding romance like ``Love Changes Everything'' and ``Seeing is Believing''; wistful, melancholy remembrances like ``Other Pleasures'' and ``The First Man You Remember''; ``Falling,'' a quartet that neatly and quickly reveals the leading characters' emotional states, and even an impassioned, terrifying plea for companionship, ``Anything But Lonely.'' The lyrics for ``Aspects of Love,'' like those written for ``The Phantom of the Opera,'' are not as strong as the music. Co-lyricists Don Black and Charles Hart have done a workmanlike job, but they strike fire only once in a while. Still, there are some ravishing moments in the show when everything comes together. The best occurs in the second act when George fox trots with his daughter Jenny to the haunting ``The First Man You Remember.'' It's an achingly beautiful scene, a perfect blending of Lloyd Webber romanticism, the simplicity of the lyrics by Black and Hart and Nunn's cinematic direction. The four leads are distinctive, able actors and fine singers too. Particularly adept is the boyish Michael Ball, whose booming tenor voice is just right for the overly eager Alex who turns into a disillusioned middle-aged man before the curtain falls. Ann Crumb gives a perfect predatory performance as the calculating Rose, and Kathleen Rowe McAllen is a sexy, wanton Giulietta. Best of all is Kevin Colson as the world-weary, pragmatic George, a man content with just ``A Memory of a Happy Moment'' and whose motto is ``Life goes on, love goes free.'' There also is fine support from Walter Charles as Marcel, Rose's loyal stage manager, and Danielle DuClos as the vulnerable Jenny. But in the end, the real star is Lloyd Webber, and his melodies are as seductive as ever.

What other critics said: Frank Rich, The New York Times: Mr. Lloyd Webber continues to compose in the official style that has made him an international favorite, sacrificing any personality of his own to the merchandisable common denominator of easy-listening pop music. Though ``Aspects of Love'' purports to deal with romance in many naughty guises ... it generates about as much heated passion as a visit to the bank. Howard Kissel, the Daily News: It never really explores the complex material. It is rather a relentless, heartless attempt to create another ``hit.'' Clive Barnes, New York Post: The really fascinating aspect of the new Andrew Lloyd Webber musical ``Aspects of Love'' ... is what a truly engrossing piece of music theater it all is. ..A breakthrough piece for Lloyd Webber ...This is a great night for love and lovers.

DOC.HEAD: Countdown Continues Toward Tuesday Launch
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 8-10 bgng `The heater' with 6 grafs to UPDATE with remarks from NASA test director that heater cable problem will not affect launch, astronauts will delay boarding shuttle if inclement weather appears likely to prevent a prompt launch. Pickup 11th graf pvs, `Discover is to...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CSB1
DOC.TEXT: Forecasters say the weather probably will cooperate when the space shuttle Discovery takes off with NASA's most valuable and eagerly awaited payload, the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope. ``This project has been difficult. ... There are at least three times when I thought we wouldn't do it,'' said Charles Pellerin Jr., NASA's director of astrophysics. ``But we're there and it all works and it's going to be great.'' The launch is scheduled for 8:47 a.m. EDT on Tuesday. Pellerin inspected the telescope before the payload bay doors were closed Sunday. He was pleased to note there was no evidence of midges, tiny mosquitolike insects that had invaded a payload preparation room at the launch pad two weeks ago. ``I can tell you there are no mosquitos visible, no midges, no anything. We're extremely clean,'' he said. ``We're ready to go.'' Later in the day, however, a short was detected in a heater cable in a strut that connects the shuttle to its huge fuel tank. The heater prevents ice from forming on the strut when the tank is filled with supercold liquid oxygen and liquid hydrogen. Shuttle program director Robert L. Crippen said the problem was not expected to delay the mission, which already is seven years late because of technical problems and the 1986 Challenger explosion. ``It's not a concern. We don't need it, and we're going to go ahead and fly with it like it is,'' NASA test director Al Sofge said today. Discovery's commander, Air Force Col. Loren J. Shriver, and its pilot, Marine Col. Charles F. Bolden Jr., practiced emergency landings at the Kennedy Space Center on Sunday. They flew the shuttle-training aircraft again today and were expected to review their flight plans. Air Force weather forecasters were giving 50 percent odds for favorable weather early Tuesday morning, with the main threat being a low cloud ceiling caused by a warm front moving in from the south. The odds were expected to improve later in the morning to 80 percent. The outlook worsened considerably if liftoff were delayed a day. NASA may delay putting the astronauts inside the shuttle if it appears the weather will prevent a prompt launch, Sofge said. The space agency does not want the crew inside for more than 2{ hours after the ``launch window'' opens at 8:47 a.m. to prevent fatigue. NASA can wait as long as about six hours, until midafternoon, to launch Discovery. ``We start counting, and if we have to sit and wait, we'll sit and wait'' before loading the astronauts, Sofge said. Discovery is to climb to an altitude of 380 miles, the highest a shuttle has ever gone, in order to put the telescope into its proper orbit. Mission specialist Steven A. Hawley will put the 24,250-pound telescope into open space with the shuttle's 50-foot-long mechanical arm on the second day of the five-day flight. Veteran spacewalkers Bruce McCandless II and Kathryn Sullivan will be standing by to step out of the shuttle cabin if a problem develops. Discovery will trail the Hubble from 46 miles away for nearly two days until the telescope's eight-foot mirror is exposed to space. The telescope, named after the late astronomer Edwin P. Hubble, will be capable during its 15 years in orbit of detecting objects 50 times fainter and with 10 times greater clarity than the best ground-based observatory. Astronomers expect to study stars and galaxies so distant their light has been traveling to Earth for 14 billion years. The universe is believed to have been formed about 15 billion years ago by a tremendous explosion known as the big bang. John Bahcall, president of the American Astronomical Society, said the Hubble will provide at least partial answers to fundamental questions about the universe. But, he said, he will be disappointed ``if all we do is answer these questions.'' ``The most important discoveries will provide answers to questions that we do not yet know how to ask,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Ryan White Taught Nation to Care About AIDS, Friends Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with morning assembly; picks up 2nd graf pvs: ``He was ...; SUBS 8th graf pvs: `His schoolmates . .., to conform.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY8, NY9, FX1
DOC.TEXT: Ryan White, ``the boy next door'' who put a youthful face on AIDS and fought discrimination against its victims, was mourned today by classmates who honored his 5{-year struggle with the disease. White, 18, died shortly after 7 a.m. Sunday of lung congestion from an AIDS-related respiratory infection. He had been in critical condition on a ventilator at Riley Hospital for Children since March 29. ``We will have a moment of silence and try to have school as normal as possible today,'' Principal Steve Dillon told the 550 students of Hamilton Heights High School in Arcadia at an 8 a.m. assembly today. White's death saddened many who had followed his battle with the illness since 1985, when he made national headliines after being barred from a public school system because of fears of the disease. ``I think one of the things we can all learn from Ryan is to be courageous, not to give up, and fight as hard as you can for what you want,'' Dillon said. Dillon said students who wanted to attend White's funeral Wednesday would be given time off from class. The school's four counselors would be available to students, who were encouraged to discuss White's death with their teachers. Students arriving at the school passed by dozens of reporters and camera crews from news organizations around the country. No reporters were allowed on school grounds. Sheriff's deputies provided extra security. White was recalled as a young man who ``made a difference.'' ``He was the boy next door who first showed a stunned nation that no one is safe from the risk of AIDS,'' said Dr. Martin B. Kleiman, White's physician throughout his illness. ``He had no bitterness. ``With an honest simplicity, his was the voice that many, if not most, first heard, even though his was not the first voice.'' ``At the end, his family and a few of the others who loved him were close at his side,'' said Kleiman. ``He never regained consciousness, and I am confident that he suffered no pain at the end.'' His mother, Jeanne, and his 16-year-old sister, Andrea, had kept a bedside vigil, joined at times singer Elton John and the Rev. Jesse Jackson. Singer Michael Jackson arrived in Indiana Sunday to offer condolences to the family. His schoolmates at Hamilton Heights were shocked Sunday to learn of White's death. ``I hoped they could find a cure before it was over,'' said freshman Aaron Gilmore, 15. ``He was aware of what could happen. But I remember him saying that he's going to live for five years, until they find a cure. And if they didn't, he'd live for five more, and keep going until they find a cure.'' John, who stayed at the hospital with the Whites nearly a week, dedicated the song ``Candle in the Wind'' to White during the Farm Aid IV concert Saturday night at the Hoosier Dome, about a mile from the hospital. ``This one's for Ryan,'' John said to the cheers of 45,000 fans at the concert to raise funds for financially troubled farmers. President Bush, who last week planted a tree in White's honor in downtown Indianapolis, said he and first lady Barbara were ``deeply saddened'' by White's death. ``Ryan's death reaffirms that we as a people must pledge to continue the fight, his fight, against this dreaded disease,'' Bush said. White, born Dec. 16, 1971, in Kokomo, was 13 when he was diagnosed with AIDS in December 1984. He had contracted acquired immune deficiency syndrome through a blood-clotting agent used to treat his hemophilia. In 1985, White was barred from Western Middle School near Kokomo after school officials and parents rejected health authorities' assurances that AIDS cannot be spread through casual contact. After months of school board battles and court hearings, White won the right to attend school. But pressures on his family later drove the Whites to the town of Cicero, and he enrolled at Hamilton Heights High School in nearby Arcadia. In his new home, townspeople and fellow students rallied around him and befriended him. White became a national spokesman for children with AIDS, appearing at congressional hearings and fund-raisers, and the story of his life was told in a 1989 made-for-TV movie. In 1988, White spoke before the National Education Association and discussed his battle with AIDS. ``I stand before you to ask for your help,'' White told the teachers. ``The many people against me said they weren't against me, but against my disease. Help me beat the odds and together let's educate and save the children of the world. By proper education, AIDS can be a disease, not a dirty word.'' Dr. Woodrow A Myers Jr., health commissioner of Indiana during White's legal struggle, said White was chosen to lead the nation out of ignorance and hatred of people with AIDS. ``This young man made a difference that may never again be achieved,'' Myers said. ``Through his actions and his eyes he taught us about ourselves. Only time will tell how well the lessons were learned.'' White's last public appearance was March 26 at an Oscar party for ill children in Los Angeles with former President Reagan and his wife, Nancy. Gov. Evan Bayh, who ordered flags at the Statehouse flown at half-staff Wednesday in White's honor, called the youth ``an American hero'' in a letter to Mrs. White. ``AIDS brought him to public attention, but his courage made him special. We can hope and pray that his family finds peace and consolation in the fact that, had the world not known Ryan White, our understanding, treatment and concern for people with AIDS would be harsher and more judgmental.'' Funeral services were scheduled for Wednesday, but arrangements were incomplete.

Contributions to the Ryan White Fund for the Care of Childhood Infections may be sent to the Indiana University Foundation in care of Indiana University Hospital in Indianapolis. Cards to the family can be sent to P.O. Box 40, Noblesville, Ind. 46060.

DOC.HEAD: At Least Five Killed in Sectarian Religious Clashes
DOC.TEXT: Clashes between Hindus and Moslems today left at least five people dead in the western state of Gujarat, according to police and news reports. The latest deaths brought to 60 the total number of people killed in Hindu-Moslem violence this year in Gujarat. Two people were stabbed to death and two others suffered knife wounds in Ahmedabad, the largest city in the state, an officer at the State Police Control Center said. Three more people were killed in Baroda, the United News of India said. Neither the police nor UNI identified the victims by religion in keeping with the policy of not publicizing religious conflicts. The officer, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said at least 1,000 people have been arrested since sectarian religious violence flared up in the state in the first week of March. The clashes reportedly broke out in Gujarat after a Hindu boy, who was in love with a Moslem girl, was stabbed to death. Eighty-two percent of India's 880 million people are Hindus, while 12 percent are Moslems.

DOC.HEAD: Two Men Killed Trying to Outrun Train On Bridge
DOC.TEXT: Two fishermen surprised on a railroad bridge by an oncoming freight train were struck and killed when they tried to outrun it, authorities said. Troy Dean Ford, 20, was pronounced dead Sunday at the Union Pacific Railroad trestle just above the Boise River's confluence with the Snake River, Canyon County Chief Deputy Coroner Vicki DeGeus said. David Lee Mott, 18, was taken by helicopter to St. Alphonsus Regional Medical Center, where he also was declared dead. The men, both from Parma, had been fishing from the railroad bridge adjacent to a dirt farm road when a witness reported hearing someone yell, ``Train!'' said Sheriff's Sgt. Steve Williams. ``When he looked up, he saw the two males running south on the bridge, which was the same way the train was running,'' Williams said. The train, traveling 65 miles an hour through the open rural country, was unable to stop in time. The men were struck about 60 feet from the east end of the trestle, DeGeus said. ``The train hit the one nearest the tracks, which forced him into the other person, and then they were both bounced back and forth between the bridge (struts and railing) and the train,'' Williams said. The engineer blew the train whistle and applied the brakes as soon as the crew saw the pedestrians, initially hidden from view by a curve west of the bridge, said Union Pacific spokesman Ed Trandahl of Omaha, Neb. The train included eight engines, some of which were being moved to new locations, and they might have helped the engineer actually stop sooner than usually is possible, Trandahl said. The main track was closed for about two hours while officials investigated and a new train crew arrived. The train was taken from the site by the crew of another eastbound freight that had been about an hour away at the time of the accident. ``We'll send this crew back home in a taxi,'' said Union Pacific representative Gary Bonner of Nampa.

DOC.HEAD: Suspect in Drive-In Shooting Turns Self In
DOC.TEXT: A man sought in the killing of a customer who was in line ahead of him at a drive-in fast-food restaurant was charged with murder today after turning himself in. Gary Bernard Scott, 23, of Augusta, surrendered at the Richmond County Law Enforcement Center and was held without bond, authorities said. A warrant had been issued for his arrest. He is accused of killing Dale Brantley Peeler, 30, who got out of his car to argue with two people who blew their horn at him when he paused to check his order in the drive-through lane at a Krystal restaurant last week. A 16-year-old who was with Scott was arrested Saturday and was charged with being an accessory to murder, authorities said. His name was not released because he is a juvenile. Richmond County Capt. J. ``Butch'' Wilhelm said Peeler was with his girlfriend when the shooting took place about 2:45 a.m. Thursday. He said Peeler had walked back to the other car to see what the problem was when one occupant got out and exchanged words with Peeler. He said a second passenger then got out and shot Peeler twice.

DOC.HEAD: Five Blacks Killed In Latest Unrest
DOC.TEXT: Five blacks were killed in violence over the past two days, including a boy who died when police fired on stone-throwing protesters in a northern town, police said today. Also today, police said they would be on special alert Tuesday following the release of a pamphlet that calls on blacks to ``kill all the white racists'' on April 10. The pamphlet, which circulated in black townships last week, was issued under the name of the African National Congress. But ANC deputy president Nelson Mandela said his organization had nothing to do with the pamphlet and did not know who was responsible. ``If we all strike on the 10th of April we will win out against the whites,'' the pamphlet said. ``Go choose your house in a white area today. When we win the house will be yours.'' Similar pamphlets have appeared in recent years, but have not resulted in any outbreaks of violence, police said. Today's police unrest report, which covers incidents from the preceding 24 hours, said a boy was killed when officers used pistol fire to disperse a mob that was throwing stones at a police station near the northcentral town of Danielskuil. Police did not specify if police gunfire killed the boy. A policeman was killed when assailants threw two grenades at officers headed toward a police station in Hlahatsi, east of Johannesburg, the report said. A woman sleeping in a nearby house also was killed in the Sunday night attack. Attackers killed a man by pouring gasoline on him and setting him alight in Wedela, west of Johannesburg, police said, and he body of a man who had been stabbed and hacked to death was found near Paarl, east of Cape Town, the report said. No motives were given in those attacks. More than 400 blacks have been killed in an upsurge of black factional fighting since President F.W. de Klerk legalized more than 60 black opposition groups Feb. 2. Large numbers of black workers in the southeastern cities of Durban and Pietermaritzburg stayed home today to protest police action in the black homeland of KwaZulu. Activists barricaded roads with stones and tires and some businesses were forced to close because of lack of staff. The Congress of South African Trade Unions, which is allied with the African National Congress, called the protest. Supporters of the ANC have been battling members of the relatively conservative Inkatha movement since 1986, resulting in some 4,000 deaths. The ANC and the trade union congress have accused both South African police and KwaZulu police of siding with Inkatha.

DOC.HEAD: Coalition Talks Produce Cabinet Lineup
DOC.TEXT: Weary negotiators today agreed on a Cabinet list for a coalition to replace the caretaker Communist government, but divisions remained over plans for unification with West Germany and conversion to capitalism. Lothar de Maiziere, the Christian Democrat leader named to form a government, said ``a first-rate climate'' prevailed in today's talks after a grueling five-hour session the previous night. The leadership of each party still must give a green light to the proposed list already agreed upon by the negotiators, de Maiziere told reporters, adding he hopes to have the Cabinet ready to present to Parliament on Thursday. Officials did not say who was on the proposed Cabinet list. Leaders of the Social Democratic Party, which won the second-largest number of votes in the country's first free election March 18, expressed satisfaction on the course of today's talks but said differences still had to be discussed. Guenther Krug, spokesman for the Social Democrats, said there were ``substantial differences'' with the conservative alliance led by the Christian Democrats that will be the dominant force in the new government. ``We assume that difficult negotiations lie ahead,'' Krug said. Among the issues which still must be clarified are Germany's relationship to NATO after unification, internal security and the thorny issue of private property. The left-leaning Social Democrats favor a more gradual form of unification than the conservative Christian Democrats. East Germany faces a tough road ahead in converting to capitalism after more than 40 years of communist rule. Lothar de Maiziere leads a three-party alliance that holds the most seats in the 400-member Parliament and closely follows the policies of West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, head of his country's Christian Democrats. De Maizier's alliance lacks the two-thirds majority that is needed to enact constitutional changes to allow unification with West Germany. A coalition with the Social Democrats would give de Maiziere control, but if negotiations with that party fail, he can try to build coalitions with other political parties. The Social Democrats are calling for employee participation in the ownership of former state-owned companies, while the Christian Democrats favor complete privatization. The Social Democrats, who finished second in the elections, also were demanding that the Christian Democrats use their close connections with Kohl to obtain a copy of West Germany's proposed blueprint for reunification. The treaty being discussed in Bonn would set out the laws that would be applied in a unified Germany, in effect outlining the terms for combining their social and economic structures. The Social Democrats have said that they will press to preserve at least some of East Germany's extensive social welfare system if they participate in the government.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands View Mapplethorpe Exhibit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with scene at museum today; pick up 4th graf, `The indictment ...' LaserPhoto CS1
DOC.TEXT: Crowds lined up again today to see photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe that have resulted in obscenity indictments against an art center. The 175-photograph exhibit includes seven pictures deemed objectionable Saturday by a Hamilton County grand jury, which indicted the Contemporary Arts Center and its director, Dennis Barrie. U.S. District Judge Carl Rubin issued an emergency protective order on Sunday that allows the show to remain open and unchanged. About 100 people waited in line today to get into the museum. ``I think we have a right to see it,'' Roshani Soyza, a University of Cincinnati law student, said outside the museum. ``The artist has a great reputation.'' After the museum opened at 10 a.m., security guards let people in 10 at a time. They said they wanted to avoid crowding. The indictment sparked public interest in the show Sunday, when the center opened an hour early to accommodate a large crowd. ``We're here as a show of support,'' said Michael Moore, accompanied by his wife, Diane. ``I thought (the indictment) was absurd and ridiculous. It lends a backward light to the city of Cincinnati.'' Arts center employees estimated that about 10,000 people saw the exhibit over the weekend, including a private showing for members on Friday night. That made it the biggest opening ever for the downtown center. County Prosecutor Arthur Ney on Saturday did not rule out the possibiliity of seizing the photos if the center didn't remove seven photographs, which depict homosexual acts or children with their genitals exposed. But the judge granted the art center a protective order during an unusual Sunday morning hearing. Rubin said he was concerned that the legal questions ``can be rendered moot'' if the exhibit is closed or partially seized. ``You may not recover any photos, you may not close the exhibit to the public, you may not take any action that could be intimidating in nature to prevent the public from seeing the exhibit,'' Rubin told lawyers for the county and city. The center hailed the protective order. ``That's all we wanted, just to stop the continued threats,'' said the center's lawyer, H. Louis Sirkin. James W. Harper, chief assistant prosecuting attorney for civil cases, also was upbeat about the ruling. ``It isn't our intention to seize the pictures,'' he said. The president of Citizens for Community Values, a leader in organizing opposition to the exhibit, had little comment on Rubin's ruling. ``It's time to let the legal system run its course,'' Monty Lobb Jr. said. The next step is Barrie's arraignment Friday, at which he is expected to plead innocent to charges of pandering obscenity and illegal use of a minor in pornographic material. The two counts carry a maximum penalty of a year in jail and fines of up to $2,000. The center was indicted on identical charges, carrying a maximum penalty of a $10,000 fine. The question of whether the seven photos are obscene will be left to an eight-member jury. A trial date is expected to be set Friday. The exhibit is scheduled to run through May 26 and move to Boston in August. Some of those who saw the exhibit over the weekend said they saw nothing obscene. ``I saw the show. I don't think it's obscene. There's some rough stuff I wouldn't want kids to see, but that doesn't mean adults shouldn't see it,'' Councilman Guy Guckenberger said. The arts center is not admitting people under 18 and has put up a warning sign at the door. The University of Pennsylvania's Institute of Contemporary Art organized the exhibit in the fall of 1988. It drew crowds in Philadelphia in December 1988 and in Chicago at the time of Mapplethorpe's March 1989 death from acquired immune deficiency yndrome. Mapplethorpe, 42, lived in New York City. Last June, the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C., canceled the exhibit. The Washington exhibit prompted Congress to limit funds for the arts after Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., declared the photographs obscene.

DOC.HEAD: Conservatives Claim Victory But Are One Seat Short Of Majority
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with New Democracy leader receiving support of small conservative party to form parliamentary majority, latest election returns, additional background. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: By NIKOS KONSTANDARAS
DOC.TEXT: The conservative New Democrats declared victory today after Greece's third parliamentary election in 10 months, and party leader Constantine Mitsotakis said he will form a government this week. Election officials said Mitsotakis' New Democracy party had won 150 of Parliament's 300 seats in Sunday's election, just one seat short of the majority needed to govern alone. New Democracy had fallen just short of a majority in inconclusive June and November elections. Mitsotakis met today with Costis Stephanopoulos, the leader of the small Democratic Renewal party which won one seat, in an effort to gain the support needed to form Greece's first right-wing government in nine years. After a 30-minute meeting, Stephanopoulos announced that his conservative group would support New Democracy in order to give it the necessary 151-seat parliamentary majority. Stephanopoulos, a former member of New Democracy, broke away from the party four years ago following a dispute with Mitsotakis. Before meeting with Stephanopoulos, Mitsotakis had expressed confidence at an early morning post-election news conference that he could form a government. ``In today's elections the Greek people decided,'' the 71-year-old Mitsotakis said. ``They gave the victory to New Democracy. In my view, with 150 seats we can form a government, and we will win the approval of Parliament.'' Stephanopoulos' support will end a 10-months political impasse that has left Greece unable to cope with a crumbling economy and growing urban terrorism. Under the constitution, Mitsotakis must first get the nod to form a government from President Christos Sartzetakis. Party officials said Mitsotakis would meet with Sartzetakis on Tuesday and announce the members of his cabinet the following day. A New Democracy spokesman said Mitsotakis would seek a vote of confidence when Parliament officially convenes April 23. The official returns showed New Democracy with 46.89 percent of the vote, up slightly from the party's 46.19 percent showing in November's inconclusive election. The left-of-center Panhellenic Socialist Movement (PASOK) had 38.62 percent of the vote and 123 parliamentary seats, while a Communist-led alliance of leftist parties had 10.28 percent and 19 seats. Small parties and independents took the remaining eight seats with a combined 3.21 percent of the vote. The socialists and communists, blocked from forming a coalition of their own, remained united in their opposition to the conservatives' plans to turn the ailing economy around. ``We will defend the vested interests of the Greek people,'' said PASOK leader and former Premier Andreas Papandreou, who did not concede defeat early today. ``PASOK will wage its battle both inside and outside of Parliament.'' New Democracy has taken a tough line on tackling the country's economic problems, which include an estimated $15.6 billion budget deficit and an inflation rate of about 17 percent. The conservatives have pledged to liberalize the economy, slash public spending, cut the country's unwieldy public sector and attract foreign investment. PASOK supports state intervention in the economy. The party wants to step up productivity in the public sector but not cut public spending. The brief conservative-Communist coalition government formed after the June election and the all-party coalition forged after the November polls both postponed key decisions on the economy. If Mitsotakis can form a government, it will mark the conservatives' return to power after losing in a landslide to Papandreou's PASOK in 1981. New Democracy and the Communists indicted Papandreou and several members of his eight-year administration in September on charges of corruption. No trial date has been set, however. A New Democracy victory could mean Greece will make long-postponed decisions on a U.S. extradition request for a Palestinian wanted for the 1982 bombing of an airliner over Hawaii, and on a new military bases agreement with the United States. Mitsotakis has said that he considers the four U.S. military bases crucial for the defense of Greece. He has also said that he would extradite Mohammed Rashid, the Palestinian wanted by the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Court Says Woman Needs Husband's Permission For Surname Change
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `The American ..., to CORRECT that maiden name is Riccitelli, sted Martin; SUBS grafs 5-6, bgng, `Frazier said ..., with 1 graf to CORRECT that couple is no longer separated, include that husband supports wife's efforts; pick up 7th graf, `In 1979 ...
DOC.TEXT: A woman is challenging a judge's ruling that she cannot change her surname without her husband's permission. Lucille Anne Riccitelli has filed an appeal of a probate judge's decision in Superior Court, saying she would like to use her maiden name because there are no more men to carry it on, according to court papers. The American Civil Liberties Union's Rhode Island affiliate said today it would back Riccitelli in her fight. She already is using her maiden name of Riccitelli, instead of her married name of Martin, on all legal documents except one bank account. On March 8, Providence Probate Judge Anthony B. Sciarretta asked Riccitelli her marital status ``and upon learning that she was married and would not obtain her husband's written consent, denied her petition,'' Riccitelli's lawyer, A. Gregory Frazier, said in court papers filed Friday. Riccitelli's husband, Edward Martin, said he supports his wife's efforts. However, Frazier said Riccitelli, 41, doesn't ``feel she has any obligation to get her husband's permission.'' In 1979, the state Supreme Court ruled that anyone can change his or her name without court approval as long as the name is used consistently and is not used to evade creditors or law enforcement officials, Frazier said. Frazier said cases such as Riccitelli's are not unique. He added, however, that because of the way the city's probate court system is set up, many who are denied name changes are unable to appeal. Because court fees are not assessed in those cases where the request is denied, there is no record of the case. Only those who are given approval to change their names are assessed a court fee. Riccitelli, however, insisted on paying the fee even though her request was denied in order for the case to go on record. This enabled her to document the case and appeal to a higher court, Frazier said.

DOC.HEAD: Terrorist Group Says It Will Release Three Europeans This Month
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf `The other...' with 1 graf to CORRECT spelling of Emmanuel Houtekins and Godelieve Kets. Pickup 10th graf `Referring to...'
DOC.TEXT: The Palestinian terrorist group led by Abu Nidal said today it will free three European hostages it holds by the end of this month. But the Fatah-Revolutionary Council linked the freedom of four other European hostages _ all Belgians _ to the release of a Palestinian serving a life sentence in Belgium for a grenade attack on Jewish youths. Walid Khaled, spokesman for Fatah-Revolutionary Council, said three hostages will be released by the end of the current Islamic holy month of Ramadan. The month is expected to end around April 26, depending on when the new moon is sighted. He listed the three as French hostage Jacqueline Valente, 32, her Belgian boyfriend Ferdinand Houtekins, in his 40s, and their 2-year-old daughter Sophie who was born in captivity . The couple were hostages since November 1987, when their yacht was seized in the Mediterranean Sea off the coast of the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip. Last week, Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi called for the release of Ms. Valente as a compassionate measure to mark the Ramadan holy month of Ramadan. Khaled would not comment on freedom for a second Valente daughter believed to have been born in captivity after Sophie. ``Ms. Valente will talk about that when she is released,'' he said. The other Belgians being held by Abu Nidal's group are Emmanuel Houtekins, in his 40s, his wife Godelieve Kets, age unavailable; his son Laurent and daughter Valerie, both teenagers. They were also seized on the yacht. Referring to the four Belgian hostages, Khaled brought up the case of Nasser Sa'eed, a Palestinian who received a life sentence for a June 27, 1980, attack against Jewish youths in Antwerp that killed a 15-year-old and injured 20 other people. ``Freeing Nasser Sa'eed is a basic demand for the resumption of negotiations related to the release of the four Belgians,'' Khaled said, speaking to reporters at his office in Beirut's Mar Elias Palestinian refugee camp. He refused to elaborate. The Belgian daily De Morgen published an interview today with Sa'eed, who is being held at Leuven prison. ``It is my release which is being demanded by the hostage-takers,'' the paper quoted Sa'eed as saying. ``They made that clear. My release can only be a political decision.'' Under Belgian law, Sa'eed can ask for early release later this year. On Sunday, Abu Nidal's group said that plans to free Ms. Valente, Ferdinand Houtekins and the child were proceeding according to plan. But it criticized Belgian Justice Minister Melchior Wathelet for ``reneging in public statements on commitments made during unannounced negotiations.'' Wathelet said last week that he had made no promises to obtain the release of the hostages. Abu Nidal's group announced on Nov. 8, 1987, that it had seized a group of hostages from the French yacht Silco off the Gaza Strip and accused them of collaborating with Israel's Mossad intelligence agency. Friends said the group was on a holiday cruise. Because the boat hostages are believed to be in Libya, they are not listed among the 18 Western hostages missing in Lebanon. Most of them are held by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem factions. The longest-held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Abu Nidal, whose real name is Sabri al-Banna, split with Yasser Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization in the 1970s and formed the Fatah-Revolutionary Council. The group has been blamed for scores of terrorist attacks, including the December 1985 attacks on the Rome and Vienna airports that killed more than 20 people.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Policeman Convicted in Neighbor's Murder
DOC.TEXT: The convoluted murder trial of a former policeman charged with the shotgun slaying of a neighbor ended today with his conviction for first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder. Robert McLaughlin, 49, had been a Hampton police officer for 18 years when he admitted killing Robert Cushing with two shotgun blasts on the evening of June 1, 1988. His lawyers argued that McLaughlin was insane. McLaughlin's ex-wife, Susan Cook, already has been found guilty of conspiracy to commit first-degree murder. Cook, who divorced McLaughlin after her conviction, is appealing her sentence to life in prison. The Rockingham County Superior Court jury returned the verdict after 3{ days of deliberations. McLaughlin stood expressionless as the jury announced its verdict and the individual jurors were polled. The conviction carries a sentence of life in prison without parole. Defense lawyer Michael Iacopino said the verdict will be appealed to the state Supreme Court. No date was set for sentencing. In the courtroom audience, Cushing's family wept as the rulings were announced. Cushing's son, Robert Jr., said the family members are glad that McLaughlin had been convicted, but now hope to put the tragedy behind them. Cushing, 63, a former schoolteacher and successful real estate agent, was cut down when he opened the door of his Hampton home. Shocked neighbors and police were baffled until McLaughlin turned himself two months later. His wife was convicted first, however, and during his pretrial hearings, McLaughlin testified that she had killed Cushing. His lawyers produced letters Cook wrote to McLaughlin from prison, in which she admitted killing the neighbor. Then, without explanation, McLaughlin's lawyers quit the case. It was delayed until new counsel could be found. Cook obtained a divorce earlier this year. In closing arguments, prosecutor Barbara Keshen contrasted a ``desperately unhappy'' McLaughlin with a contented, successful Cushing. The two had feuded for 13 years, and Keshen said the murder was the well-planned action of an angry, bitter man. Iacopino said in his closing statement that McLaughlin conceived the murder plan under a veil of alcohol and a large dose of a prescription drug, Xanax. He said McLaughlin was under his wife's influence when he killed Cushing. Robert McLaughlin Jr. testified against his father and Cook, 38, at their trials. ``They both get what they deserve,'' he said today. ``They took someone's life away and for that they deserve to pay with their own lives.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Pepsi To Be Traded For Soviet Vodka and Ships
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with confirmation, signing of deal, comment from Pepsico; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Pepsico Inc. and the Soviet Union signed an agreement today to trade Pepsi-Cola for ships and vodka. The deal is the largest between a U.S. corporation and the Soviet Union, and comes just two months before a ummit between President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev. It represents more than $3 billion in retail sales of Pepsi-Cola and Stolichnaya Russian Vodka and would make Pepsi-Cola more widely available in the Soviet Union. Since 1974, the Purchase, N.Y.-based company has shipped its soft-drink syrup to the Soviet Union, where it is made into cola and sold in bottles. The company took its profits out in vodka, selling it through a third party in the United States. Today's agreement will allow Pepsico to take some profits out during the next decade in the form of at least 10 oceangoing freighters and tankers valued at $300 million. The vessels will be sold or leased to international markets, Pepsico said. Pepisco said it eventually will be permitted to sell Pepsi in plastic bottles and aluminum cans instead of just the glass bottles now allowed in the Soviet Union. Pepsi sells in the Soviet Union for the equivalent of 75 cents for an 11-ounce bottle. ``This agreement reflects increasingly closer ties between the U.S., the Soviet Union and other Western interests, and the expressed optimism for the shared future,'' said Donald M. Kendall, chairman of Pepsico's executive committee. The contract was signed by Kendall and Soviet officials, including several members of the Soviet Commission of Agriculture and Procurement. In a news release, Pepsico said its Pepsi plants in the Soviet Union will increase to 50 from the current 24. It said it planned to pay for that expansion with proceeds from vodka sales.

DOC.HEAD: Two Big Telecommunications Companies Sign Merger Pact
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New thruout with today's stock market reports, AT&T comment and market share figures; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: MCI Communications Corp. and Telecom USA Inc. today announced they have agreed to merge in a $1.25 billion transaction. Under terms of the deal, which has been approved by the boards of directors of both companies, MCI will acquire all outstanding shares of Telecom USA's common stock for $42 a share. Telecom USA stock jumped $15.87{ higher to $37.75 a share in heavy midday trading on the New York Stock Exchange. MCI was down 87{ cents at $36 a share. The transaction is subject to approval by Telecom's stockholders. ``The prospect of merging two dynamic, high-growth companies with similar cultures is very exciting,'' said Bert C. Roberts Jr., MCI's president and chief operating officer. ``Combining their strengths will benefit shareholders, customers and employees alike.'' The proposed acquisition continues a pattern by MCI, which has increased its market share in part by buying smaller long-distance phone companies. In the last few years it has bought Satellite Business Systems, Western Union International and RCA Global Communications. MCI, which is headquartered in Washington, is the nation's second-largest long distance phone company after American Telephone & Telegraph Co. Telecom, based in Atlanta, is the fourth-largest. Telecom primarily serves customers in the Southeast and Midwest. MCI's 1989 revenues totaled $6.5 billion, while Telecom had $713 million in sales last year. AT&T spokesman Herb Linnen said the announcement showed how ``hotly competitive'' the industry is. AT&T, the dominant long distance carrier, is asking the Federal Communications Commission to loosen some regulatory ties on AT&T that other companies do not face. ``This development today is further evidence of the need for that,'' said Linnen. ``It suggests two vigorous companies are combining forces to provide even more competition. ... We wake up every day to a real knockdown, drag-out fight in the marketplace.'' AT&T holds about 64 percent of the long distance market, down from about 90 percent before the court-ordered breakup of the old Bell system in 1984, and had $19.5 billion in revenues last year, said Linnen. FCC figures showed MCI with about 12 percent of the market and Sprint with 9 percent. Roberts said both companies have played a major role in ``advancing technology, developing innovative services, and meeting customer requirements.'' He added: ``We look forward to having Telecom USA management and employees assume roles in the new structure, and welcome the opportunity to serve its customers.'' O. Gene Gabbard, Telecom's chairman and chief executive officer, said MCI recognizes his company's ``creative approach'' to product development and marketing. ``Both companies stand to gain by teaming employees, facilities and services, and as a unified force, working to further enhance the ability to provide the highest value services in this rapidly growing and demanding industry,'' Gabbard said. The merger is subject to government approval under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act. It is expected to be concluded as quickly as possible, the companies said in a joint news release. The complete terms of the merger will be included in a proxy statement to be mailed to Telecom shareholders.

DOC.HEAD: Man Sentenced to Death for Drug Trafficking
DOC.TEXT: The High Court on Monday sentenced a vegetable seller to death after finding him guilty of trafficking marijuania.
