The 26-year-old defendant was the 252nd person sentenced to death since laws were passed in 1975 allowing capital punishment for drug trafficking. Of the 252, 84 have been hanged. The others are awaiting dates for appeals or hanging.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Militants, Allegedly Part of Roving Commando, Charged
DOC.TEXT: Nine French Basque militants suspected of being part of a roving commando unit that carried out terrorist attacks in Spain have been charged and jailed, judicial sources said Monday. The nine, eight men and one woman, were transferred Sunday to Paris from Bayonne in a military transport plane. Judge Gilles Boulouque, who specializes in terrorist investigations, charged them Sunday night with criminal association related to a terrorist enterprise, the judicial sources said, speaking on condition they not be named. Three of them were also charged with possession of arms and explosives. The sources said that six of the nine admitted taking part in numerous attacks on Spanish soil. No charges on those counts were immediately brought because Spanish authorities had not yet officially complained to France. The nine were arrested Wednesday, two days after Spanish police arrested another Frenchman, Henri Parot, in Seville, Spain. Police found 660 pounds of explosives in his car. Parot confessed to participating in attacks that killed 33 people in Spain over the past few years, Spanish police sources said Sunday. Parot's brother, Jean Parot, was among the nine arrested last week. The alleged commando unit is said to have trained in the hills of France's Basque country, in southwestern France. They are accused of being members of a French network of the Spanish ETA movement, which is fighting for independence for the Spanish Basque country.

DOC.HEAD: Three Alleged Communist Rebels Arrested
DOC.TEXT: A man believed to be the No. 2 official in the Communist rebel army was arrested Monday along with two alleged rebel officials, the military announced. Also Monday, military sources said an officer jailed for trying to overthrow President Corazon Aquino in August 1987 had escaped. Antonio Cabardo, reputed deputy chief of staff of the New People's Army, was taken into custody Monday afternoon after returning to Manila from Hong Kong, said Col. Agerico Kagaoan. Kagaoan, chief of security for the Philippine Constabulary, said Cabardo and two female companions were stopped as they drove from Ninoy Aquino International Airport. Agnes Quitoriano and another woman carrying a passport identifying her as Maria Velarde were also arrested, Kagaoan said. Their driver escaped. Police found three handguns and about $1,500 in their vehicle, according to police spokesman Lt. Col. Cresencio Maralit. Cabardo is also believed to be a member of the political bureau of the outlawed Communist Party of the Philippines. The military had offered a $23,800 reward for his capture. He is believed to be the No. 2 official of the 20,000-strong Communist army. The army leader is Romulo Kintanar. He escaped from prison in November 1988. Kagaoan said the women arrested were believed to be members of the Communist Party's International Liaison Group. It coordinates weapons shipments and is responsible for overseeing businesses and other operations abroad. It was unclear why the group had gone to Hong Kong, but the rebels are believed to maintain bank accounts in the British colony and elsewhere in Asia. The arrests were described as a major blow to the Communists. They occurred one day after the embarrassing escape from prison of Lt. Col. Billy Bibit, former customs security chief and a leader of the Dec. 1-9 coup attempt. Bibit was freed when a group of rebels raided the Manila jail during a drinking spree by jail guards. The jail superintendent was fired and three guards, including a deputy warden, were arrested for negligence. Also Monday, military sources said air force Capt. Rogelio Seradoy, held in connection with an August 1987 coup attempt, had escaped from Villamor Air Base. Seradoy piloted the helicopter used by coup leader Gregorio Honasan to escape after the attempt failed. Sources said there were conflicting reports on Seradoy's escape. According to one report, he jumped from a window early Monday and fled. Another said he failed to return from a two-day furlough granted Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Report Fourth Government Air Raid
DOC.TEXT: Ethiopian rebels said Monday two people were killed in a government air raid on the Red Sea port of Massawa. They said it was the fourth such raid in five days. In a clandestine radio broadcast monitored in Nairobi, the Eritrean People's Liberation Front said the latest attack was Sunday and killed two civilians. The rebels accused the Ethiopian air force of targeting civilians with cluster bombs. A rebel spokesman in London said napalm also had been dropped on the port. Cluster bombs contain dozens of smaller bombs that are dispersed upon impact, hurling their shrapnel over a wide area.

DOC.HEAD: 32 Killed as Burmese Army Truck Plunges Down Ravine in Storm
DOC.TEXT: A Burmese army truck plunged down a ravine during a storm and 32 people were killed, including nine civilians, a Burmese official said Monday. The accident was caused by the same storm Friday that sank a passenger ferry, said the official. More than 200 people are believed to have been killed in the ferry accident. The truck crashed down a steep ravine along a road leading to Myawadi, near the Thai border, late Friday, said the official, who requested anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Sihanouk Calls for U.N. Force, New Peace Plan in Cambodia
DOC.TEXT: Cambodian resistance leader Prince Norodom Sihanouk on Monday urged an immediate cease-fire in his country and said the U.N. Security Council should deploy peacekeeping troops to enforce it. The proposed peacekeeping force would comprise American, Chinese and Soviet soldiers. Sihanouk is head of a three-faction guerrilla alliance fighting the Vietnamese-installed government in Cambodia. He said there was a moral responsibility to find a solution to end the 11-year-old war. Sihanouk said no winners will emerge from the conflict but that the big losers will be the ``small citizenry of Cambodia.'' In a statement issued from the village in northwestern Cambodia where he lives, Sihanouk said the five-member U.N. Security Council should send a peacekeeping force and along with the warring factions, proclaim an immediate cease-fire. The peacekeeping force should wear the ``blue helmet'' of the United Nations, he said. The five security council members are Britain, China, France, the Soviet Union and the United States. Sihanouk said the administrative power of the two warring groups in Cambodia should be transferred to a U.N. administrative authority, which would work alongside a supreme national council symbolizing national sovereignty. The council would be made up of six guerrilla members and six from the existing government, he said. Sihanouk was head of state in Cambodia until his government was ousted in a 1970 coup. The government that replaced his was in turn ousted by the communist Khmer Rouge in 1975. The Khmer Rouge's brutal rule ended in late 1978, when Vietnam invaded and set up the existing government. The Khmer Rouge is the strongest guerrilla faction in the alliance with Sihanouk. Vietnam said it pulled the last of its soldiers out of Cambodia last fall, but guerrillas have alleged that some Vietnamese have returned to fight alongside the Cambodian soldiers.

DOC.HEAD: No Blasphemy Trial For Rushdie, Court Rules
DOC.TEXT: The High Court on Monday rejected a bid by a Moslem group to prosecute author Salman Rushdie and publishers Viking Penguin for blasphemy in connection with Rushdie's novel ``The Satanic Verses.'' A panel of three judges upheld a lower court decision not to issue summonses against Rushdie and his publishers. It said Chief Metropolitan Magistrate Sir David Hopkin ruled correctly last year that Britain's blasphemy laws apply only to the Christian religion. Many Moslems believe Rushdie's novel blasphemes Islam. The writer has been in hiding since Feb. 14, 1989, when Iran's late spiritual leader, the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, called on Moslems to execute him and those closely connected with the book's publication. During a four-day hearing, the British Moslem Action Front argued blasphemy laws should be extended to protect other religions, including Islam. One of the Front's lawyers, Mohammed Akhtar, said: ``It's a sad day for race relations in this country and for the reputation of British justice. But we have succeeded in exposing the inadequate and the discriminatory nature of the British laws.'' The common law doctrine of blasphemy was laid down in 1675 by Chief Justice Sir Matthew Hale. He referred specifically to the Christian religion, but that was before Britain had large immigrant communities of other religions. The last successful prosecution for blasphemous libel in Britain was in 1979 over a poem depicting Jesus Christ as a homosexual. Rushdie issued a statement through his lawyer saying he was grateful for the court's ruling. He called for changes to Britain's blasphemy laws. ``I regret that our blasphemy law discriminates between religions as well as discriminating against humanists and non-believers,'' he said. ``I join with many persons of good will in urging Parliament to take the earliest opportunity to end this discrimination by abolishing an anachronistic crime which still, notwithstanding today's decision, carries dangers for freedom of expression.'' Rushdie was born into a Moslem family in India 42 years ago. He now is a British citizen and has left his faith. He reiterated in his statement that ``even if the blasphemy law extended to Islam, my book cannot fairly be interpreted as a scurrilous or insulting attack on that faith.''

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Independence Leaders Say Communist Party Split Helps Process
With AM-Soviet-Georgia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The leader of Latvia's Supreme Soviet said Monday he is certain Latvian legislators will vote to secede from the Soviet Union when they meet next month but that the independence process will be gradual. Anatolijs Gorbunovs, president of the Supreme Soviet, or parliament, said full separation is to be achieved in ``negotiations and discussions.'' He spoke at a news conference two days after a Communist Party congress in Latvia rejected a proposal to establish a Communist Party independent of the central Soviet party. About 300 of the 700 delegates at the congress walked out to protest the vote. Gorbunovs said the party split made clear the support for independence in Latvia. There is ``no doubt'' the required two-thirds majority will be achieved when parliament meets in May and considers independence, he said. Gorbunovs said this would have to be followed by a ``complicated process'' to resolve all problems related to Soviet-Latvian relations ``in the interest of both sides.'' Gorbunovs, a member of the breakaway Communist Party, said he met with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev last month and that Gorbachev told him he should submit his independence proposals in writing. He said he did so in a letter sent to Gorbachev, but he refused to disclose details of his plan. Gorbunovs and other pro-independence Latvian lawmakers were in Switzerland for a symposium this week marking the 125th birthday of Latvian writer Janis Rainis. Rainis lived in exile in Switzerland until 1920. Latvia was one of the three Baltic republics forcibly annexed by the Kremlin in 1940. The others are Lithuania and Estonia. Lithuania declared itself independent March 11, leading to a standoff with the Kremlin that is still going on. Estonia also has a strong pro-independence movement. Edvins Inkens, a senior member of the pro-independent Latvian Popular Front, said he met last month with Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis. Landsbergis had ``one major request _ that Latvia declare independence as quickly as possible because a united front of three republics is no longer just a regional problem,'' Inkens said. Gorbunovs said the three republics follow a ``united path. Differences are only in tactics, but the strategic goals are identical.'' ``We would like to achieve that (goal) through negotiations and discussions,'' he said. ``Practically, our stance coincides with Gorbachev's stance. But whether Gorbachev will consequently realize this stance is another question.''

DOC.HEAD: World War II Fighter Ace, Father of Female Cosmonaut, Dead at 80
DOC.TEXT: Air Marshal Yevgeny Savitsky, a World War II fighter ace whose daughter was the second woman in space, has died at age 80, the official Soviet Tass news agency said Monday. The news agency said Savitsky died Friday ``after a grave and long illness.'' An obituary signed by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other leaders called Savitsky ``a faithful son of the Soviet people who dedicated his entire life to selfless service to his socialist motherland, and the affairs of the Communist Party.'' Savitsky flew 216 missions during World War II, battling German fighter planes over the Soviet Union, Poland and Germany. He shot down 22 enemy planes during the war. After the war, he rose to the rank of air marshal and commanded the country's anti-aircraft defense air force. His daughter, Svetlana, became a test pilot and later a cosmonaut. She became the second woman in space with a flight in a Soyuz T-7 capsule that began Aug. 19, 1982. She flew a second Soyuz mission in 1984, and on that mission became the first woman to walk in space.

DOC.HEAD: Holders Of 5 Winning Tickets To Split More Than $50 Million
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with precise size of jackpot, background on records; picks up 3rd graf, `Tickets were ...; ADDS byline
DOC.TEXT: The holders of five winning Florida Lotto tickets will split a pot of more than $58.3 million, the Lottery Department said today. None of the winners have yet come forward. Tickets sold in Leesburg, Orlando, Miami, North Miami and Naples had all six numbers drawn late Saturday, Lottery Secretary Rebecca Paul said Sunday. The jackpot _ $58,320,000 _ surpasses the Florida record set in September 1988 when $55.16 million was paid out. That went to a single winner and is still a world record payout to one person. There have been several multi-winner lottery prizes in other states that exceed Saturday's Florida jackpot. Tickets were selling as fast as 552 a second Saturday, setting a weekly sales record of $56.1 million. Just over $22 million worth of tickets were sold Saturday, a new daily record. ``Our sales were so high they were in orbit,'' Mrs. Paul said Saturday. The previous weekly sales record was $44 million. The old daily record was $16.4 million. No one had claimed a share of the pot as of Sunday. Winners have 180 days from the date the date of the drawing to come forward. The number of winners means that Sheelah Ryan of Winter Springs, the sole winner of the Lotto jackpot that reached $55.16 million in September 1988, will still hold the world record for the biggest prize won by an individual in a weekly numbers game.

DOC.HEAD: Undersea Research Station Needs New Home
DOC.TEXT: Wanted: Tropical lot for relocation. Must move. Variety of neighbors preferred. Wet basement a must. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is looking for a new location for Aquarius, its undersea research station. The relocation is needed because Hurricane Hugo damaged on-shore support facilities at the current location in the Virgin Islands. The 81-ton underwater research lab itself was not damaged. The agency plans to move Aquarius this summer and wants a location in the Caribbean, Florida Keys or the Bahamas. Major factors in the new location will be access to power, telephone service, water and emergency care. In addition, scientists prefer a site with a diversity of plant and animal life and ecosystems for research. Teams of up to six scientists work in the lab for several days at a time conducting undersea research. More than two dozen teams have worked in the lab since it was located off St. Croix in 1987. Recommendations for a new location for Aquarius can be sent to Dr. David Duane, Director, National Undersea Research Program, NOAA, 6010 Executive Boulevard, Rockville, Md., 20852.

DOC.HEAD: President Sacks Anti-Corruption Chief
DOC.TEXT: The president has fired the director of a special police anti-corruption squad, Radio Tanzania said Monday. The official radio gave no reason for the firing of Zacharia Mafta. Last month, President Ali Hassan Mwinyi accused seven Cabinet members of lack of discipline and accountability in their departments and fired them. The anti-corruption squad is a special branch of the police that was established a decade ago. It operates independently of the regular police force. The executive committee of Mwinyi's ruling party earlier this year called for a crackdown on corruption in both the government and the party itself.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Decides Death Sentence for 12 Drug Smugglers
DOC.TEXT: A judge set legal proceedings in motion Monday to sentence 12 convicted drug smugglers to death, the Middle East News agency reported. The state-owned news agency said Judge Gamal Abdel-Halim of the Cairo criminal court sent the files of the 12 to Egypt's highest Moslem cleric for an opinion. That means the court plans to sentence them to death. Abdel-Halim postponed judgment on 18 other defendants in the same case until May 10, the news agency said. The 30 men, who include Egyptians, Sudanese, Lebanese and a Turk, were charged with smuggling and distributing 10 tons of hashish and 858 pounds of opium in Egypt. The prosecution said the defendants brought the drugs in by boat through the Red Sea.

DOC.HEAD: Communist and Conservative in Slovenian Runoff
DOC.TEXT: A Communist reformer got the most votes for president of Slovenia in Yugoslavia's first free election since the 1940s, but must face a conservative rival in a runoff, election results showed Monday. With 98 percent of the presidential vote counted from Sunday's elections in the liberal northern province, Communist candidate Milan Kucan led with 44.4 percent. Joze Pucnik of the conservative DEMOS coalition was second with 26.2 percent. Ivan Kramberger, an independent, ran third with 18.9 percent. The fourth candidate, Marko Demsar of the Liberal Party, got 10.5 percent of the votes. A runoff of the two leaders will be held April 22 because neither won a majority. An estimated 1.1 million Slovenians, 75 percent of the eligible voters, participated in the balloting. It was communist Yugoslavia's first multiparty election since World War II. In addition to a president, they chose a legislature from candidates representing 17 political parties. The results ``suggest that Slovenians have opted for a peaceful transition from a single-party monopoly to a parliamentary democracy,'' Kucan, a leading reformer in the Communist Party, told The Associated Press. Pucnik said he expected to win the runoff ``because those who voted for Kramberger and Demsar will probably vote for me.'' The former dissident, a philosopy professor, spent seven years in prison in the 1950s for opposing communism. He returned to Slovenia last year after more than 20 years of exile in West Germany. Pucnik said he was ``satisfied with the success in the first round of the elections,'' because he ``was until recently virtually unknown in the republic.'' Political analysts predict a close contest in the runoff. Pucnik wants Slovenia to secede from Yugoslavia, but Kucan advocates a more cautious approach. Initial results suggest the Slovenian Communist Party, which recently changed its name to the Party of Democratic Renewal, will become the largest single party in the republic's legislature but that DEMOS, a coalition of five conservative groups, will have the most seats. Partial results indicated the renamed Communists would have about 21 percent of the 240 seats and DEMOS about 35 percent. Election officials said results of the legislative elections would not be complete until Tuesday or Wednesday. Support for secession has grown in Slovenia, the most liberal and prosperous of Yugoslavia's six republics, because of the slow pace of political and economic reform elsewhere in the federation. Reform-minded Slovenian Communists have created pluralistic politics in the past three years despite criticism from Serbia, the largest Yugoslav republic. Serbian leaders favor continued dominance by the Communist Party. Kucan said he hoped the other republics, including Serbia, would hold free elections in 1990 ``so people there can elect their legitimate leaderships.'' Croatia, the second-largest republic, has elections scheduled later this month, but no plans have been announced by the other four republics. Official Serbian media virtually ignored the Slovenian elections and said all Slovenian parties and presidential candidates had the common goal of secession. Kramberger, a restaurant owner and charity worker who needed 6,000 petition signatures to run as an independent, said he was forming a new party whose members would be the ``poor, sick and unprivileged.'' Those who want to join the party ``will first have to prove they are not Communists,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.NOTE: Eds: First item for release at 6 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: Rose Kennedy, who turns 100 July 22, follows the news on television and radio, enjoys spending time with her family and is ``still fussy about the way she looks,'' according to one of her daughters. ``Mother is alert and feels pretty well for 100,'' Eunice Kennedy Shriver said in an interview with McCall's magazine. ``She loves having people around her, and all of us come _ the children, the grandchildren and the growing numbers of great-grandchildren.'' Mrs. Kennedy ``has her hair done at least once a week,'' Mrs. Shriver said. ``When she goes out, which is often, she wants to wear an attractive coat, checking carefully to see if the colors are right for her.''

Activist Angela Davis says black college students today are in a better position to identify and challenge racism from curriculums and from overt racist attacks on campus. Ms. Davis told black students at Georgia State University to push mostly white universities to create black studies programs to crush on-campus racism. ``The message we must bring to campus communities across the country is that the problem is not so much ours,'' she said. ``We fought for the right of African-American students to have access to the educational institutions of this country only to realize that the education ... was flawed in and of itself.'' The conference she addressed Saturday was devoted to problems of black students at predominantly white colleges. Ms. Davis was acquitted of aiding radicals in a courthouse shooting in Marin County, Calif., in 1972. In 1980, she was a vice presidential candidate on the Communist Party ticket. She now teaches women's and ethnic studies at San Francisco State University.

She's got a new show, her own production company and is one of the nation's richest women. But Oprah Winfrey said she feels like she's just coming into her own at age 36. ``I wouldn't trade places with anybody,'' Winfrey says in the May issue of Ladies Home Journal. ``I'm growing up. I'm really growing up. And I think that I'm getting better because of it.'' She said this past year was rough, with the tabloids sensationalizing her ongoing weight battle, her relationship with her boyfriend, Stedman Graham, and her half-brother's death from AIDS. But at the same time she became the first black to own a TV and film company, which is producing a new television series, ``Brewster Place,'' in which she stars. It's scheduled to air sometime this spring. She said not too long ago she worried about not being married, but now that doesn't bother her. ``We're not married because I'm not ready to be married,'' she said of Graham. `` ... Whatever we have now would be destroyed if we got married.''

She's dropped to No. 2 in the world rankings behind Steffi Graf, but Martina Navratilova says she doesn't feel like a tennis failure. ``Failure is in not trying,'' Navratilova writes in an article in Glamour magazine. ``If I give 100 percent to the game _ physical, mental, emotional _ I am satisfied. Even if I lose, I haven't failed. On the other hand, if I've been loafing and I win, there's not too much personal satisfaction in that; it means only that I have more talent than my opponents.'' Navratilova, 33, said in the article that she's recovered from a brush with tennis burnout, and she proved that Sunday by beating tennis' latest phenomenon, 14-year-old Jennifer Capriati, to capture the Family Circle Magazine Cup championship in Hilton Head Island, S.C.

Hotel queen Leona Helmsley, who is appealing a federal tax evasion conviction, said she and her real-estate tycoon husband, Harry, dine at home these days to avoid harassment. ``It's rare that we go out,'' she said in the May issue of the Ladies Home Journal. ``The one time we did, it was a cruel experience. A restaurant customer shouted at me.'' Mrs. Helmsley said she has been prosecuted because of her personality. ``I only know I am not going to jail. I'm innocent,'' she says. ``I have done nothing wrong.'' A federal judge has sentenced her to serve four years in prison and pay a $7.1 million fine for evading $1.2 million in taxes by disguising purchases for herself and her $11 million mansion as business expenses. In a pending state case, she is accused of falsifying $3 million worth of business records between 1982 and 1986. Her husband was found incompetent to stand trial on the federal charges and attorneys have asked for a similar ruling on the state charges.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Concedes S&L Bailout Will be More Expensive Than Estimated
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration conceded today that the savings-and-loan bailout will cost taxpayers more than previously estimated. ``There's no question that the cost is increasing and we'll have to take that into account in deciding future actions,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. His comments were in response to Friday's report by the General Accounting Office _ an investigatory arm of Congress _ that the 10-year cost of the program would be $243 billion instead of the $166 billion estimated by the administration. Furthermore, the GAO said, the 30-year cost of the program could reach $325 billion. ``We don't have an analysis either to endorse or reject the GAO numbers, except to say there clearly is going to be additional costs,'' Fitzwater said. ``Those numers will have to be decided upon at some point.'' Ftizwater rejected as ``total nonsense'' the contention by Charles Bowsher, the GAO's comptroller general, that the administration had deliberately understated the cost of the bailout. Bowsher, interviewed on NBC's ``Meet the Press,'' said the Bush administration had set an artifically low cost on the bailout so the government could appear to meet deficit-reduction targets. Fitzwater said the Resolution Trust Co., set up to oversee the restructuring of the S&L industry, had so far used about $10 billion of the $50 billion it was provided under that original bailout legislation signed by Bush last summer. ``The best thing to do, we believe, is to work speedily with the funds and the progress we now have in place,'' the spokesman said. ``At this time there is not enough information to make a reliable estimate of how much more may be required. Many factors will determine if we need more funds _ including loss ratios, interest rates, asset sales, et cetera,'' Fitzwater said. Asked if the net effect would be an increase in the federal deficit, Fitzwater said: ``There is always that consequence. If you have to increase amounts, you have a responding impact on the deficit and budgetary considerations.'' Bowsher has said that the extra cost of the S&L bailout is so substantial that a tax increase will be needed. Economists have said for some time that the rescue plan would cost more than the administration estimated.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: EAST LANSING, Mich. (AP) every time he sees him. You can hear him out in the nursery talking to everyone about him.'' The Leonards have two daughters _ one weighed 8 pounds at birth and the other weighed 11 pounds, 3 ounces.

Ron Haugen's view of partisan politics is pretty flexible, so he served as a delegate to both the Republican and Democratic state conventions over the weekend. ``I didn't really know what party I liked so I thought I'd go to both conventions and see,'' the 29-year old Northwood farmer said Sunday from the floor of the Democratic convention. Haugen was a bit embarrassed when reporters noticed him at both conventions. ``Is it illegal?'' he asked. ``I don't want any publicity.'' He said he attended the Democratic convention in legislative District 19, a Republican stronghold. ``In our district if you can crawl through the door you're a delegate,'' he said of the Democrats. The district was allowed to send 23 delegates to the state convention but could muster only eight, he noted. He didn't attend the Republicans' district convention but was selected as a delegate to the state meeting anyway, he said. Republican state Rep. Dagne Olsen of Larimore said District 19 Republicans weren't aware Haugen also would be a delegate to the Democrats' convention. Olsen said she didn't think party rules even addressed the question of whether Haugen's double duty was allowed. ``But I don't think he should make it a habit,'' she said. Haugen said he'll study the platforms of each party before deciding which he likes best. ``But I don't know,'' he added. ``I'll probably forget about politics next year.''

DOC.HEAD: Exxon to Plead Innocent to Criminal Indictments Stemming From Spill
DOC.TEXT: Exxon announced today that it would plead innocent to a five-count criminal indictment charging it with negligence and other crimes in the nation's worst oil spill a year ago. The grounding of the tanker Exxon Valdez ``was tragic, but it was an accident,'' the company said in a prepared statement announcing its intended plea. Exxon and its subsidiary Exxon Shipping Co. were scheduled for separate arraignments before a federal magistrate later in the day. On Feb. 27, a federal grand jury handed up a five-count criminal indictment against the company stemming from the oil spill, which occurred after the Exxon Valdez slammed into a charted reef on March 24, 1989, in Prince William Sound. The spill of nearly 11 million gallons of North Slope crude oil coated hundreds of miles of coastline and killed uncounted numbers of fish, birds and other marine life. Exxon said it would vigorously defend itself against the charges, which include violating clean water and refuse acts, and negligently and unlawfully discharging oil into a navigable waterway. ``We have said that from the beginning because nobody willfully grounded the ship or caused the spill. We believe the conclusion is thoroughly supported by the testimony and the verdict in the trial of Capt. Hazelwood,'' the statement said. Capt. Joseph Hazelwood, the Exxon Valdez skipper, was convicted last month on a single charge of negligently discharging oil but was acquitted on three other counts. More than 160 civil suits are pending against Exxon by the state of Alaska, environmentalists and private individuals.

DOC.HEAD: Inmate Charged in Slaying of Oregon Prisons Chief
DOC.TEXT: A jail inmate was arraigned today on aggravated murder charges in last year's slaying of Oregon prisons chief Michael Francke. The suspect, Frank Gable, 30, had been the focus of an investigation into the January 1989 slaying. Franke, director of the state Corrections Department, was stabbed in the heart outside his office in Salem. Gable, an inmate in the Coos County jail, was arraigned before Marion County Circuit Judge C. Gregory West on six counts of aggravated murder and one of murder, said West's judicial assistant, who declined to identify herself. She referred all other questions to District Attorney Dale Penn, who did not immediately return telephone calls. Oregon State Police officials scheduled a news conference for later in the day to discuss the case. Gable had been scheduled for release Thursday from the county jail after serving a sentence for assaulting his wife.

DOC.HEAD: Dole Says Assad Seeking Hostage Releases; Group Says it Will Free Three
DOC.TEXT: Senate minority leader Robert Dole said Monday that Syrian President Hafez Assad is making efforts to obtain the release of Western hostages held in Lebanon. Also Monday, the Abu Nidal terrorist group said it would free three European hostages this month. It also linked freedom for four Belgians it holds to freedom for a Palestinian terrorist jailed in Belgium. Before flying to Cairo, Dole and five Senate colleagues met with Assad in Damascus for what the Kansas Republican called ``frank and contructive'' talks on the situation in Lebanon, the hostages, and means of achieving peace in the Middle East. Dole said Assad was making efforts ``to obtain the hostages' release,'' but he did not give details. Syria has good relations with Iran, which has influence with the hostage-holders. The Senate delegation, on a tour of the Middle East, is scheduled to meet Tuesday with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid. Syria has repeatedly said it would like the 18 Westerners held in Lebanon to be freed and has assisted with hostage releases in the past. Many of the captives are believed held by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem groups. The Westerners missing in Lebanon are eight Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Irishman and an Italian. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped in west Beirut on March 16, 1985. Most of the others have been held at least three years. Dole also said his group asked for Syria's assistance in recovering the remains of Lt. Col. William R. Higgins, an American serving with a U.N. peacekeeping force who was kidnapped in south Lebanon on Feb. 17, 1988. The Shiite Organization of the Oppressed on Earth claimed July 31, 1989, that it killed Higgins in retaliation for Israel's kidnapping of a Shiite leader, Sheik Abdul-Karim Obeid, in south Lebanon three days earlier. The group released a videotape showing a body on a gallows, but U.S. officials believe Higgins was killed, or died, months earlier. The other five senators are Republican whip Alan Simpson of Wyoming, Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, and Republicans Jim McClure of Idaho, Charles Grassley of Iowa and Frank Murkowski of Alaska. After Cairo, the delegation is scheduled to visit Israel and Jordan. In Beirut, meanwhile, Belgian envoy Jan Hollants van Loocke said Monday he was negotiating with Palestinian guerrillas led by terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal for the release of Belgians held by the group. Abu Nidal's Fatah-Revolutionary Council says it holds seven hostages, who were seized aboard a yacht in November 1987. Their wherabouts is not known, and they are not counted among the hostages held in Lebanon. Walid Khaled, spokesman for the Fatah-Revolutionary Council, said three of the captives will be released by the end of the Islamic holy month of Ramadan. Ramadan is expected to end around April 26, depending on when the new moon is sighted. Khaled listed the three to be released as French hostage Jacqueline Valente, 32, her Belgian boyfriend Ferdinand Houtekins, in his 40s, and their 2-year-old daughter Sophie who was born in captivity. Van Loocke, director-general for political affairs at Belgium's Foreign Ministry, spoke to reporters later at Khaled's office. ``Of course it's true that one of the points we have been discussing is the release of Nasser Sa'eed, who is in prison in Belgium,'' said van Loocke. Earlier, Khaled said that freeing Sa'eed is a ``basic demand'' for the resumption of negotiations related to the release of four Belgians also held by Abu Nidal. Sa'eed, a Palestinian, received a life sentence for a June 27, 1980 attack on Jewish youths in Antwerp, Belgium, that killed a 15-year-old and injured 20 other people.

DOC.HEAD: Major-League Baseball Opens Season Delayed by Lockout
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with games beginning in Boston, New York; pick up 3rd graf, `There was ...
DOC.TEXT: A capacity crowd at Boston's venerable Fenway Park cheered today as Red Sox pitcher Roger Clemens fired the first pitch of the 1990 baseball season, which began a week late because of a monthlong lockout by its owners. No bitterness was evident in the stands, where fans seemed to take a better-late-than-never attitude. ``People forgive them,'' said one Boston fan, William Cullen of Cherry Valley, Mass. ``We're Americans. You love a thing, you're going to go.'' Toni Giamatti, widow of the late baseball Commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti, threw out the ceremonial first pitch at Fenway, where the Red Sox faced the Detroit Tigers. A few minutes later, Giamatti's successor as commissioner, Fay Vincent, threw out the ball at New York's Shea Stadium before the Mets took on the Pittsburgh Pirates. Mets pitcher Dwight Gooden followed with the first real pitch of the game _ like Clemens, he threw a strike. There was no game in Cincinnati, marking just the third time since 1876 the Reds have opened on the road. Because of the revised schedules due to the season's delay, the Reds play tonight in Houston, where the Astrodome is celebrating its 25th anniiversary. ``We're not going to be at home, so it's not going to be as big a deal,'' Cincinnati's Tom Browning said. ``The crowd's not going to be part of the hoopla.'' In Chicago, the Cubs and White Sox were each home today. The White Sox, starting their last season at Comiskey Park, played Milwaukee, and the Cubs faced Philadelphia in the first night opener at Wrigley Field. The Oakland Athletics, trying to become the first World Series winner to repeat since the New York Yankees in 1977-78, open at home tonight against Minnesota. In other openers, Baltimore was at Kansas City, Seattle played California, San Diego played at Los Angeles and Montreal was at St. Louis.

DOC.HEAD: Company Replaces Push-Button Phones With Rotary Dials to Fight Drugs
DOC.TEXT: A telephone company is taking a technological leap backward in an effort to fight the drug problem. U S West has replaced push-button pay phones with rotary models at about 18 Twin Cities locations to make it harder for drug dealers to conduct business with telephone pagers, U S West spokesman Mike Breda said. Because most pagers don't work unless the call comes from a push-button phone, drug dealers with pagers can't use the rotary phones. Pagers have become a way of life for dealers, who often fear their telephone lines are tapped. ``Everybody's got them,'' Lt. James Singer of the St. Paul police narcotics unit said of the pagers. Customers order drugs by telephoning a dealer's pager and then punching in a phone number or a pre-arranged code, police say. The dealer responds by calling back or showing up with the drugs. In the past, Minneapolis and St. Paul police regularly asked the telephone company to remove pay phones in drug-infested areas or to adjust the phones so they don't accept incoming calls. But removing public phones can hurt people who can't afford private telephones. ``We have noticed a decrease in traffic in at least a couple of locations where we changed the phones,'' said Minneapolis Council member Jackie Cherryhomes. ``I don't think it is going to win the battle against drugs, but if you can affect it in any way, that's important.'' However, U S West's tactic may not work for long. At least one paging company now offers a pager in which the caller can use any phone. At least one paging company has taken steps to try to halt the use of pagers for illegal purposes, said Steven Miorana, general manager of MinnComm Paging in Minneapolis. A typical drug dealer will receive more than 1,000 pages per month, he said. MinnComm now charges an extra 20 cents per call after 500 calls to discourage excessive use, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Peres Predicts Palestinian Uprising Will Wilt Under Labor
DOC.TEXT: Labor Party leader Shimon Peres predicted Monday that the 28-month-old Palestinian uprising will wane once his party leads the government into a Palestinian-Israeli dialogue. Peres also predicted the Soviet Union would upgrade ties with Israel and allow direct Moscow-Tel Aviv flights to spee up Jewish emigration. Peres' comments appeared in two Hebrew-language newspapers as Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of the right-wing Likud bloc was making intensive last-ditch efforts to block his road to power. Shamir was wooing defectors in advance of a Wednesday parliamentary vote on Peres' confirmation. Peres told the Al Hamishmar daily that once his government is installed, Israel will approve proposals by Secretary of State James A. Baker III for an Israeli-Palestinian meeting in Cairo. Peres' support for Baker's ideas toppled the Labor-Likud coalition government March 15, when Shamir lost a vote of confidence in the parliament. He had refused to agree to the U.S. proposals. Baker's plan was aimed at bridging differences between Israel and the PLO over an Israeli proposal to hold elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The 1.7 million Palestinians would choose representatives to negotiate an interim agreement. Peres told the mass-circulation Yediot Ahronot, ``I estimate that the intefadeh (uprising) will ... wane and that millions of shekels in the state budget can be diverted to constructive tasks. ``I can already foresee the fruits of opening peace negotiations,'' he added. ``Relations will be renewed with the Soviet Union ... in a matter of weeks.'' The Kremlin broke ties with Israel during the 1967 Middle East War. The two established low-level consular relations in 1987. The uprising has resulted in the death of 673 Palestinians from Israeli gunfire and 43 Israeli deaths as a result of Arab violence. In addition, it has cost Israel nearly $1 billion in added military costs and lost tourist revenue. ``I want to solve the problem of the residents of (these) territories. It is our main burden,'' Peres told Al Hamishmar. ``The whole world is moving toward elections. Why not for the Palestinians?'' Peres indicated he planned no change in Israel's policy of refusing to speak to the PLO, but he appeared to leave room for some indirect PLO involvement in the negotiations. ``There is a Palestinian side for negotiations. I don't understand why we should go beyond that,'' Peres told Al Hamishmar. Peres said he had no immediate plans to change Israel's electoral system, despite a weekend rally at which more than 100,000 Israelis demanded election laws to counter the wheeling and dealing that has characterized the government-building process. ``I want to change the system but not now,'' Peres told Yediot Ahronot, adding ``Peace is no less important.''

DOC.HEAD: Buckey Retrial Delayed As Lawyer Calls in Sick
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with trial postponed, lawyer ill; pick up 3rd graf, `Buckey was ...
DOC.TEXT: The start of Raymond Buckey's second trial in the McMartin preschool molestation case was abruptly postponed today after his lawyer called in sick. Attorney Danny Davis had complained earlier of back trouble and asked last week for the appointment of an assistant counsel to help in case he was incapacitated. Superior Court Judge Stanley Weisberg took no action on the matter then. After Davis failed to appear today, Weisberg met in chambers with prosecutors and an attorney who accompanied Buckey to the courthouse. Buckey said the attorney, John Wagner, was seeking appointment as Davis' co-counsel. Wagner previously represented Buckey's sister, Peggy Ann, and is familiar with the McMartin case. Jury selection had been scheduled to begin today in what promises to be another emotionally charged trial involving the 31-year-old Buckey. Buckey and Davis were among the few familiar faces in court today. The prosecutors and judge in the first marathon trial have been replaced. And one of the original defendants is missing. Peggy McMartin Buckey, Raymond's mother, was acquitted of all charges Jan. 18. Buckey was acquitted of most of the molestation charges against him, but District Attorney Ira Reiner decided to retry eight counts on which the jury deadlocked. Critics have accused Reiner of yielding to pressure from McMartin parents and their supporters, who carried on a loud campaign for a retrial. Reiner, who is running for California attorney general, has denied any political motivations. The first trial of Buckey and his mother lasted nearly three years and cost $13 million _ the longest, costliest criminal trial in U.S. history. Initially, Reiner planned to retry Buckey on all 13 charges on which the jury could not reach a decision. But last month he dismissed five counts considered difficult to prove. The eight remaining charges involve three children, dramatically fewer than the hundreds once described as alleged McMartin molestation victims. ``The case is nothing more than a rehash of a case that was slanted for acquittal before,'' Buckey said outside a pretrial hearing last week. He called it ``a political maneuver'' and said it would be ``a mental, physical and spiritual grind'' for him to go through another trial. His lawyer, Davis, said: ``I've tried this case once before and it didn't stand. I don't expect this to be any different.'' The new chief prosecutor, Deputy District Attorney Joe Martinez, said he expects at least one thing to be different _ the trial's length. With far fewer charges and only one defendant, Martinez said he thinks the case could wrap up in six months. ``It all depends on how well the judge controls the procedure,'' he said, suggesting that Superior Court Judge Stanley Weisberg limit cross-examination by the defense to avoid the witness-stand marathons that marked the first case. In the trial that ended in January, Buckey, and his 63-year-old mother had been accused of molesting 11 children at their Manhattan Beach preschool during a five-year period. Jurors acquitted them of 52 molestation counts but deadlocked on the 13 charges against Buckey. That trial was the culmination of a case that began in 1983. Prosecutors alleged that Buckey, his mother, sister, grandmother and three other teachers molested hundreds of tots at the nursery school. There were accounts of satanic rites and animals tortured to frighten the youngsters into silence. But after an 18-month preliminary hearing, charges were dropped against five defendants after Reiner concluded the evidence was weak. When Buckey and his mother came to trial in 1987, the prosecution case had been pruned from hundreds of counts of child molestation to 64 counts and a shared count of conspiracy. The 41 children once said to have been abused came down to 11 alleged victims. It was a rancorous trial, and when it ended Superior Court Judge William Pounders was barred from presiding at the retrial because of his comments on TV talk shows after the verdict. Deputy District Attorneys Lael Rubin and Roger Gunson bowed out at their own request. Martinez and Deputy District Attorney Pam Ferrero replaced them. Weisberg stepped into Pounders' role.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Official Called `Satchel Man' for Imelda
DOC.TEXT: A former bank official said Monday that he was called ``the satchel man'' for Imelda Marcos because he carried $100,000 cash for her expenses during the funeral of South Korean President Park Chung-Hee in 1979. Oscar ``Oca'' Carino, who managed the Philippine National Bank's New York branch from 1973 to 1984, said he was asked to accompany Mrs. Marcos on the trip by her personal secretary, Fe Roa Jimenez, who told him to bring the cash. He said he closely guarded the money, even keeping the bag between his feet on the airplane. ``Of course, I never let it out of my sight.'' ``That's why people in Korea referred to me as the satchel man,'' Carino said during his third day on the witness stand at Mrs. Marcos' fraud trial. He said Mrs. Marcos gave $14,000 _ in bundles of $1,000 _ to the wives of Filipino generals also attending Park's funeral. The prosecution alleges that Mrs. Marcos, the former Philippine first lady, used the PNB as her ``personal piggy bank.'' In earlier testimony, Carino told of providing millions of dollars from the government-owned bank to finance Mrs. Marcos' frequent visits to New York between 1973 and 1984. The former bank manager also said he asked Mrs. Marcos' close friend, Gliceria Tantoco, why President Ferdinand E. Marcos bought a Manhattan office building in 1981 after first deciding against the purchase. ``I asked Mrs. Tantoco what happened that the decision not to go ahead was reversed ... was Mrs. Marcos extra nice to the president?'' Carino said Mrs. Tantoco replied, ``She cried to him and told the president to give the building to her as an inheritance or gift.'' The Crown Building on Fifth Avenue is one of four properties the government charges the Marcoses purchased with more than $160 million stolen from the Philippine treasury. Mrs. Marcos' lawyer, Gerald Spence, questioning Carino's testimony about his conversation with Mrs. Tantoco, elicited that Carino never confirmed Mrs. Tantoco's statements. Mrs. Marcos, 60, pleaded innocent to charges of racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. Her husband also was charged in the 1988 indictment but died in exile in Hawaii last September. Mrs. Tantoco, the owner of Rustans department store in the Philippines, and her husband, Bienvenido, the former Philippine ambassador to the Vatican, also were charged but are fugitives. A co-defendant, Saudi Arabian financier Adnan Khashoggi, is accused of mail fraud and obstruction of justice for allegedly helping the Marcoses hide their ownership of the Manhattan properties. After Monday, the trial will recess until April 17 because of the Passover and Easter holidays.

DOC.HEAD: NBC Loads Up New Saturday Morning Season With Live-Action Shows
DOC.TEXT: NBC, facing Saturday kid-show competition from cable as well as syndicated series, unveiled a fall schedule on Monday that includes what the network says is the most live-action Saturday programming in its history. The new roster moves NBC away from the traditional cartoons that for years have been a staple of Saturday morning network shows for children. NBC, which trails ABC by a full ratings point in Saturday morning ratings to date for this season, said its new lineup has two hours of shows with no animation and one hour of shows that mix animation with human characters. The latter includes its new rap music comedy, ``Kid `n' Play.'' ABC has a similar rap music show set for next fall, ``The New Kids on the Block,'' starring the rock group of the same name. NBC's schedule, which one NBC official said was designed ``to reach the kids of the 90s,'' was shown at a meeting of advertising agency officials here. The network's shift from cartoons comes at a time when the three major networks, in addition to cable and syndicated competition, also face a three-hour Saturday morning schedule that the Fox network will start next fall. NBC, which began its move from cartoons this season with a new sitcom for kids, ``Saved by the Bell,'' has five new series on its Saturday morning schedule for next fall, compared to three on ABC. CBS, currently third in Saturday morning ratings as well as in prime time and in morning programs, will unveil its fall childrens' schedule Tuesday. NBC's new live-action lineup includes a sports show for teen-agers and older viewers, ``Inside Stuff: The Entertainment Magazine of the NBA.'' It will premiere Oct. 27 and lead into NBC's National Basketball Association broadcasts. The other new live-action series are ``The Boys Next Door,'' a variety series ``secretly'' broadcast by five teen-agers from the basement of their home in Encino, Calif., and ``Saturday Videos,'' a childrens' version of NBC's pop-culture ``Friday Night Videos.'' NBC's new cartoon series include ``Rick Moranis in Graveyard High,'' which features the voice and cartoon face of the star of ``Honey, I Shrunk the Kids.'' The show is about a kindly teacher at a school where the students are literally monsters. Although parents may think of the networks' Saturday battles as kid stuff, NBC sales vice president Ron Dobson told advertising executives Monday that the influence of children on their parents' spending is estimated to be worth $70 billion annually. According to Betsy Frank, a senior vice president of Saatchi and Saatchi Advertising, advertisers spent $189 million in 1989 on the networks' Saturday childrens' shows. That's only a fraction of the $4.8 billion they spent on prime time network shows, she said, but Saturday morning in TV ``has become intensely competitive'' because of syndicated and cable programs for children. ``That's why we're seeing more players getting into it.''

DOC.HEAD: Colombian President Urges Stepped Up Fight Against Drugs
DOC.TEXT: Colombian President Virgilio Barco told an international drug conference Monday that drug barons are not invincible, and he appealed to cocaine users to give up the habit that has created havoc in his country. ``I should like to make an earnest plea to drug consumers to realize that their habit is bringing our countries to the brink of disaster, that their addiction is fostering violence, crime and corruption throughout the world,'' Barco said at the start of a three-day drug summit. Dr. Louis Sullivan, the U.S. secretary of health, said an international commitment to end the drug crisis would not only send drug kingpins a message that ``their days are numbered,'' but also would send ``a message to users that they bear responsibility in perpetuating the drug problem.'' ``We must communicate to users that help is available to them but that they must seek it,'' he said. Up to 10 million cocaine users in the United States spend approximately $20 billion to $25 billion per year on cocaine _ roughly equivalent to the gross national products of Colombia, Peru or Bolivia, according to a report produced by the Panos Institute. It is a non-profit international development organization. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar told the conference that the world traffic in illicit drugs amounts to about $500 billion a year, ranking just behind the arms trade. ``It is a sad commentary on the state of mankind at the end of the 20th century (that) the bulk of our vast productive energies is devoted to manufacturing our own destruction,'' Perez de Cuellar said. He added that conservative estimates put the number of illicit drug users at more than 40 million worldwide. The meeting _ formally called the World Ministerial Drugs Summit to Reduce the Demand for Drugs and to Combat the Cocaine Threat _ was called by British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. It is being sponsored by Britain and the United Nations. ``Our efforts to reduce production of drugs and to prevent traffic in them can never succeed while demand for drugs is still there,'' Mrs. Thatcher told the more than 800 ministers and delegates from 112 nations. She said Britain would set up task forces to train customs agents and officials fighting drug trafficking and to assist developing countries with drug education. She said Britain would contribute $7.3 million more to help Colombia battle its powerful cocaine cartels. Barco, whose anti-drug efforts have made him a target for South American drug barons, arrived at London's Queen Elizabeth II Conference Center under heavy security. He said authorities now understand that to break the noose of drugs, they must deal not only with the drug barons, but with the peasants who produce coca leaves; the large companies manufacturing processing chemicals; the transporters; those who conceal drugs in warehouses; and the banks that launder drug money. ``We are contending with an international criminal organization acknowledging no frontiers,'' Barco said. But, he added, ``The fight in which Colombia is engaged reveals that the drug barons are not invincible. They are not untouchable. ... The myth that the drug barons are stronger than the state or society is only that, a myth.'' Colombia has extradited 15 drug suspects to the United States since its crackdown began in August, and one of the Medellin cartel's leaders, Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, was shot to death by drug agents in December. Italy's Interior Minister Antonio Gava, quoting figures provided by the international police agency Interpol, said cocaine seizures in Europe had increased from 3,300 pounds in 1986 to 13,860 pounds in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: 7-Foot Gator Wanders Into Shop, Snares Vacuum
DOC.TEXT: Ed Shea was talking on the phone in his shop when a customer walked in, turned around and fled without a word. Shea looked over his shoulder and saw the reason the man had bolted. There was a 7-foot alligator in the shop. ``At first I thought it was plastic and that someone was just trying to scare ... me,'' said the 43-year-old proprietor of National Floor Care Products. When he realized the gator was real he called the Florida Game and Fresh Water Fish Commission. The univited guest just sat there for the 20 minutes it took for the wildlife officials to arrive. But when the trappers slipped a noose on the gator it turned ornery, flipping boxes, upending chairs and attacking a vacuum. It clenched the appliance's cord in its teeth. Mike Fagan, a wildlife official, figures the 125-pound gator wandered in a back door Saturday from a nearby pond in search of food. ``I've only been here a year and a half, and the last thing I would have thought was that there would be an alligator sitting behind me in my shop,'' said Shea, who moved to this rural community 40 miles north of Tampa from Plymouth, Mass.

DOC.HEAD: Masked Man Infatuated With Bride Disturbs Wedding With A Toy Gun
DOC.TEXT: A man infatuated with another man's bride-to-be was jailed after he interrupted a marriage ceremony armed with a toy gun and wearing a cape and black mask, police said Monday. James M. Jernigan showed up outside Our Lady of Good Counsel Roman Catholic Church just before the wedding on Saturday holding a cap gun and wearing a big cowboy hat, a white poncho and a mask. He threatened the bride, 28-year-old Teresa Parker, and her groom, David Bennett, and panicked guests fled, Police Chief Steve Sheppard said. ``He pointed a firearm at several people including police,'' the chief said. ``He was just trying to disrupt the wedding because he was infatuated with Miss Parker.'' Sheppard said the groom's relatives swept him away ``to keep him from getting upset and retaliating'' when Jernigan arrived outside the church, The bride's father, James Parker, said Jernigan had worked for six weeks in an office where his daughter was a manager. Parker refused to identify the office. The Rev. Joseph Maher, who officiated the marriage, said he was inside and missed the confrontation. ``The wedding itself went off beautifully,'' he said. ``I imagine they were quite nervous, but it didn't show that much.'' Jernigan, 30, of Isle of Palms, was charged with resisting arrest with deadly force, presenting and pointing a firearm, disturbance of religious worship and assaulting police while resisting arrest. Sheppard said police discovered the weapon was only a cap gun after Jernigan was arrested. He was in jail Monday in lieu of $35,000 bond.

Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez and Bolivian President Jaime Paz Zamora will make separate trips to Washington for talks with President Bush, it was announced Monday. Perez will make a state visit on April 26 and will be honored that night at a formal state dinner. He will fly to Washington directly from the inauguration of Violeta Chamorro as president of Nicaragua. Paz will make an official working visit on May 8.

DOC.HEAD: Weather Slight Threat To Shuttle Launch Schedule
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Launch scheduled for 8:47 a.m. EDT.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CSB2
DOC.TEXT: NASA said there was only a 40 percent chance that weather would delay Tuesday's launch of the space shuttle Discovery on its mission to place a telescope in orbit to look toward the edge of the universe. Launch of the 35th shuttle mission from Kennedy Space Center was set for 8:47 a.m. EDT. There was a chance that low clouds could push that time back. Once in orbit, the Hubble Space Telescope, 43 feet long, 14 feet in diameter and weighing 24,250 pounds, will be lifted out of Discovery's cargo bay with the ship's mechanical arm, given an exacting checkout, and will be dropped overboard Wednesday afternoon if all goes well. The telescope, being launched seven years late because of the 1986 Challenger accident and technical problems, represents an investment of more than $2 billion _ $1.5 billion for the telescope itself and $600 million for spare parts, astronaut training and ground support. It will cost $200 million a year to operate and maintain. The flight is deemed so important that all five of the crew are veterans of previous flights. Commander Loren J. Shriver and pilot Charles F. Bolden each have flown once before. Mission specialists Bruce McCandless II and Kathryn D. Sullivan not only have flown before but also have space-walking experience. They'll be ready to make space walks to rectify any problems with the telescope. And mission specialist Steven A. Hawley, whose job it is to operate the mechanical arm that lifts the telescope out, has two missions under his belt. The telescope's 94-inch mirror, according to experts, is the most flawless ever made. It was designed to capture and magnify light from nearly the farthest reaches of the universe _ light created billions of years ago when stars and solar systems were in their earliest stages of formation. ``Hubble has no rivals,'' said Lennard Fisk, NASA's chief scientist. ``Never before have we had a telescope or observatory with this capability, and it will not be surpassed until we begin to establish observatories on the moon some day.'' Above the atmosphere, which distorts visible light and blocks out ultraviolet, X-rays and gamma rays, the telescope will be able to see objects 50 times dimmer than those that can be observed from the ground. With this new tool, astronomers will see these celestial objects as they were billions of years ago. That should help determine whether the Big Bang that created the universe was 10 billion years ago, 20 billion years ago or somewhere in between, as scientists believe. Mostly, scientists stress, they expect to get answers to questions they haven't asked. ``We have to be consciously expecting that we may be surprised,'' said William Jeffreys of the University of Texas, leader of the astrometry team, and one of 1,200 scientists who will work with results from the Hubble's observations. In the 15-year life expected of the telescope, scientists hope also to find planets around other stars. Engineers will spend about five months calibrating the instrument once it is in orbit but the first photographs are expected within two weeks of launch. ``I think we have an obligation as soon as it's available to put out a picture that shows this is really the fantastic device we expect it to be,'' Fisk told reporters. The picture will most likely be of an object or objects for which good ground-based images are available as a basis for comparison. Astronomers gathered at the Kennedy Space Center as if for a convention. So did nearly 200 relatives of astronomer Edwin P. Hubble, who died in 1953. In the 1920s, Hubble discovered that the universe is organized into galaxies of many sizes and shapes and that they are rushing away from one another. His idea of an expanding universe gave support to the theory that the universe was created by an explosion.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Jews Celebrate First Passover With Joyous Meal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DROPS redundant 3rd graf `About 130...'; pickup 4th graf ``It's delicious...''
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Jewish immigrants celebrated their first Passover in this Jewish settlement Monday, marking their ancestors' release from slavery in ancient Egypt and the modern exodus from the Soviet Union. ``I see similarities between the Passover story and the Russian immigration,'' said Suzanna Eisenvarg, 38. She was among 130 new immigrants who joined with settlers for a Passover meal in the elementary school gymnasium. ``It's delicious,'' Ms. Eisenvarg said as she tried the chorosot, a pate of apple, nuts and wine which represents the mortar that the Jews used to build pyramids for Egyptian pharaohs. She recalled that in Leningrad, ``we brought matzo from the synagogue. We would just eat matzo on that night, somehow we knew the date, the date that Israelites left Egypt,'' she said. As she spoke, Rabbi Boris Yussin, a Russian immigrant who lives in Jerusalem, translated the Hebrew story into Russian while Israelis took turns reading from the Hagada, which tells the story of the Jews' flight from Egypt. Mrs. Eisenvarg is one of about 250 Soviet Jews living in the occupied West Bank, a little less than 1 percent of the 29,000 immigrants who arrived in 1989 and the first three months of 1990. The pace is apparently quickening. Soviet Jewish immigration activist Natan Sharansky estimated the total for this year at 200,000. The presence of Soviet Jews in the occupied lands has complicated the exodus by sparking criticism from the United States and galvanizing an Arab campaign against all Soviet immigration. Mrs. Eisenvarg and other new arrivals said they settled in Ariel because, unlike Israel, apartments were plentiful and cheap. None cited ideological reasons for being in Ariel, a settlement of about 8,000 people in the heart of the West Bank. Ariel's mayor, Ron Nachman, said the recent arrivals had been calling relatives in Moscow and Leningrad urging them to come and settle in Ariel. He said that with the U.S. policy against settlements in the occupied lands, ``we have to push as much as possible for them to come here.'' He said Israel will weather the protests over the settlement of Jews in the war-won land. ``There was a pharaoh in Egypt, and we got through that, and we will get through this too. This immigration is a miracle,'' he said. Reuven Rosenthal, 34, came to Ariel eight months ago with his wife and two children. ``It's a nice pretty place with good cheap prices,'' said Rosenthal. He said he was not concerned about the frequent clashes between Jewish settlers and Palestinian activists at his doorstep. ``What should I be afraid of? In the Soviet Union, there is much more fear of anti-Semitism,'' he said. The gymnasium was decorated with yellow, blue and purple streamers. Passover ingredients, such as eggs, apples, wine, nutmeg and horseradish, covered the yellow cloth-covered round tables. For most Soviet Jews, who have been cut off from Jewish traditions all their lives, this marked the first time they participated in a Seder, or Passover dinner. Passover is one of the most important holidays in the Jewish calendar. During the meal, held on the first evening of the holiday, Jews eat food symbolizing the Passover themes of redemption and freedom and read the story of the exodus from Egypt. One key ingredient is matzo, or unleavened bread, symbolizing the haste with which the Jews had to leave Egypt. While the Soviet immigrants in Ariel celebrated their homecoming, their presence in the West Bank continues to strain relations between Israel and the rest of the world. U.S. officials say settling immigrants in the occupied lands and Israeli-annexed Arab east Jerusalem raises obstacles to peace. Last month, Secretary of State James A. Baker III suggested Washington withhold special financial aid for immigrant absorption until Israel pledged not to settle Soviet Jews in the occupied lands. Arab and PLO leaders fear that the expected arrival of about 750,000 Soviet Jews in this decade will cause more suffering to the Palestinians. They claim that Palestinians will eventually be ousted from the West Bank and Gaza Strip to make room for new arrivals from the Soviet Union. In response to the Arab campaign, the Soviet Union has refused to ratify an agreement with Israel for direct Moscow-Tel Aviv flights that would expedite Jewish emigration. Soviet Jews now arrive in Israel via Eastern European transit points. There are long waits for a limited number of seats.

DOC.HEAD: Promise Of Democracy Sparks Celebration, But More Shot Before Curfew Ends
LaserPhoto KAT4,5
DOC.TEXT: People smeared their faces with ceremonial red dust and burst firecrackers Monday in nationwide jubilation over the king's promise to re-establish a multiparty system in Nepal. A left-wing radical group said Sunday's agreement between King Birendra and the leaders of a seven-week campaign for democracy did not go far enough. It pledged to continue the movement, using violence if necessary. Before a curfew was lifted Monday, reports said troops shot and killed at least two people. After curfew, hundreds of thousands of people marched through Katmandu and a half-dozen other towns in the Himalayan kingdom to celebrate the agreement, clinched by the Nepali Congress party and the United Left Front. The Front is a coalition of left-wing parties. Laughing, whistling, clapping and chanting ``Victory! Victory!'' people wound their way through the streets on foot, cars, motor-powered rickshaws and tractors. ``Democracy, democracy, we have now democracy!'' a man shouted in English into a megaphone. Boys with hand-scrawled ``I love democracy'' posters pinned on their backs zipped around on bicycles. ``Today we will celebrate our freedom. We have no definite plan, but we only want to express our joy,'' said Yagya Nidhi Duhal, his face smeared with red powder used by Nepalese during celebrations. Most other marchers, including several Western tourists, wore powder marks on their foreheads. On Sunday, Birendra announced he was lifting a 29-year-old ban on political parties that has kept the Rashtriya Panchayat, or national assembly, non-partisan and allowed the king to rule through a largely rubber-stamp government. The announcement came two days after the bloodiest day in modern Nepalese history. Witnesses said as many as 200 people were killed when security forces opened fire to prevent pro-democracy demonstrators from marching to the king's palace Friday. The government said 10 people were killed and 107 injured in nationwide violence that day. Immediately after the royal proclamation, the Nepali Congress party and the United Left Front said they were suspending their movement. But the United National People's Movement, a radical group that was supporting the pro-democracy campaign, said Monday the agreement to ``withdraw the current movement, without abolishing the present Panchayat constitution ... is definitely a betrayal to the people. ``We will continue the movement until we achieve more. We won't propagate violence but we also do not rule it out,'' said party spokesman Babu Ram Bhattarai. Bhattarai said ``the very fact that they want to amend the constitution and not form a new one means the king wants to remain the decisive body.'' The United People's Movement is not considered a major political force, but political observers say it commands a sizeable following in some towns. Prime Minister Lokendra Chand told reporters Monday a commission will amend the constitution to fulfill the king's promise of ``pluralistic democracy.'' Oblivious of the first signs of dissent among the movement leaders, people celebrated the royal proclamation into the night, lighting oil lamps, candles and electric bulbs around their houses. Celebrations began at dawn Monday when a two-day curfew was lifted in Katmandu and two suburbs, Patan and Bhaktapur. Tens of thousands of residents streamed out of their homes and marched through the main intersections and the narrow sidestreets. Sources in the Nepali Congress party said similar processions were also staged in at least a half-dozen other towns in the mountainous kingdom wedged between India and China. Amid the joy, relatives wept at two hospitals to mourn the deaths of a man and a 12-year-old boy, shot late Sunday shortly after the king yielded to demonstrators. Doctors at Bir Hospital said five other people were being treated for bullet wounds. The people who brought the injured to the hospital said at least 10 other people were killed and their bodies taken away by troops, according to the doctors who spoke on condition of anonymity. The report could not be confirmed. Police denied there was any firing. The government-run news agency RSS said one person was killed in police firing at Bharatpur in central Nepal. The news agency did not give details. Nepal last experiment with a Western-style democracy ended in 1961. Birendra's father, King Mahendra, dismissed the government, which at that time was led by the Nepali Congress party. He accused it of corruption and inefficiency and banned political parties.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Conservative Showing Could be Start of Soviet Bloc Trend
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Voters ended the Communist era by giving a strong mandate to the country's main conservative party in what could be the genesis of a center-right trend among Soviet bloc countries emerging into democracy. The Hungarian Democratic Forum campaigned on an anti-Communist platform that incorporated universal conservative values as well as a strong dose of nationalism. It scored an impressive victory in parliamentary elections that wrapped up Sunday. It was the second win in two Soviet bloc elections for conservative forces. In East Germany's March 18 vote, conservatives fell just short of a majority in the first free national elections in any Warsaw Pact country. As in Hungary, remnants of the long-ruling Communists were relegated to a relatively minor opposition role. Hungary's Democratic Forum captured 165 of the 386 seats at stake Sunday. In the first round of balloting March 25, they won 42.75 percent of the vote. Despite preliminary predictions of a close race, the Forum left the liberal League of Free Democrats far behind, with 92 seats and 23.83 percent of the vote, forcing the rival party to bury any aspirations of sharing a government role. The ruling Socialists, created by reform Communists last October, were sent packing. Despite their commitment to political plurality, they captured only 33 seats or 8.55 percent of the vote, victims of widespread sentiment that they were the heirs of decades of repressive Communist rule. Its strong position left the Democratic Forum independent of any party with which it had major differences. Instead, it gained the leeway to negotiate a coalition it could dominate with the agrarian Smallholders and Christian Democrats, which share many of its conservative views. The Smallholders captured 11.14 percent of the vote and the Christian Democrats were tied for fifth with 5.44 percent, meaning a conservative coalition headed by the Democratic Forum would control nearly 60 percent of the legislature. Conservatives in other East European countries preparing for the first free elections in more than four decades clearly hope that the same anti-Communist backlash that worked in favor of kindred parties in East Germany and Hungary will also give them an edge. In Czechoslovakia, where voters go to the polls June 8, the hope of victory has resulted in the Christian Democrats in Slovakia forging an alliance with Czech center-rightists, despite a general drifting apart of the two constituent republics. Only the conservatives have managed to formally coordinate their election strategies nationwide. The Slovak Christian Democrats, led by Czechoslovak Deputy Premier Jan Carnogursky, are expected to win up to 60 percent of the vote in their traditionally Catholic republic, and the well-organized alliance is likely to finish strong overall in the country, although no one can predict how strong. The election picture is confusing in Romania, where about 70 political parties have sprung up or been revived in the wake of the December revolution that ended the dictatorship of Nicolae Ceausescu. But the nation's strongest conservative force, the 700,000-member National Peasants' Party, is given the best chance of defeating the National Salvation Front, which took control of the country in the chaos of the revolution but was later forced to share power. It is suspected by many conservatives of harboring unrepentant Communists. The Peasants' hand has been strengthened by an election alliance with the Liberals and Social Democrats _ the two other leading parties. The alliance mandates cooperation up to the May 20 election, in an effort to defeat the National Salvation Front. In Bulgaria, the two traditional agrarian parties could pose the biggest threat to the still-powerful Communist Party, but only if they manage to bury differences ahead of election day June 10. Negotiations on unification of the two parties continue. There was no clear conservative trend in Poland last June, when voters participated in their freest election in more than four decades. They endorsed Solidarity candidates sharing an anti-Communist bent but no particular ideological platform.
EDITORS NOTE: George Jahn, based in Vienna, has been reporting on Eastern Europe since 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Will Send Already Appropriated Funds to Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration, suggesting Congress is dragging its feet on aid for Central America, said Monday it will spend $3.6 million in already appropriated funds to help the peace process in Nicaragua. ``This is just a stopgap measure,'' said presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. The money, he said, will be used to help the U.S.-backed Contras disband and resettle. The administration's $870 million aid package, bogged down in Congress, included about $30 million for that purpose. ``We had hoped to get that passed before the (Easter) recess. Congress chose to go home without acting on it. We'll push for it as soon as they get back,'' Fitzwater said. ``We are quite concerned about this,'' he said. ``We wanted to foster demobilization and repatriation (of the Contras) as expeditiously as possible.'' The administration's original package included $500 million for Panama, $300 million for Nicaragua and $70 million to enlarge programs in the United States that benefit refugees. However, the House increased the package to $2.4 billion, adding money U.S. projects including food stamps, disaster relief, fighting forest fires and veterans programs. The Senate has yet to act on the legislation. Fitzwater said the $3.6 million would come from what was left over from an earlier $47 million humanitarian aid package for Nicaragua. ``We believe that the money is needed there, that it is a worthy cause, that the United States has pushed for this as the ultimate goal of its policy for years, and that we do have a responsibility to make this money available,'' Fitzwater said. The $30 million in the administration's package that would be earmarked for repatriation includes $2 million to help finance a United Nations observer group that will receive the weapons of resistance members who demobilize.
