At the State Department, spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler called the $3.6 million ``start up money for the repatriation and resettlement operations,'' including money for the U.N. group. ``Both politically and financially'' the United States supports the ``voluntary demobilization, repatriation and reintegration'' of Contra rebels and their families, she said. She said both the U.N. and the Organization of American States had been ``informed of our intention to move quickly to disperse these dollars.'' Administration officials said the government is prepared to provide funds for food and medical care for the Contras, both in Honduras and Nicaragua. The $3.6 million is the remaining amount from a Central American humanitarian aid package approved by Congress last year to carry out its bipartisan accord with the White House.

DOC.HEAD: Dark Horse Candidate Sidetracks Vargas Llosa in Peru's Presidential Race
LaserPhoto LIM1
DOC.TEXT: Novelist Mario Vargas Llosa, once considered a sure bet to become Peru's next president, has found himself sidetracked by the ``Fujimori phenomenon.'' Alberto Fujimori, the son of Japanese immigrants and a political unknown until a month ago, forced the country's most famous novelist into a runoff and is now favored to win the presidency. Public opinion analysts say Fujimori's strong second-place finish in Sunday's election reflected Peruvians' alienation from the traditional political parties and their desire for ``miraculous, painless'' solutions to the country's ills. ``It was not a rational vote. It was a protest vote against the other candidates,'' said Alfredo Torres, media director for APOYO, a market research firm. Fujimori, a 51-year-old agricultural engineer, received 29 percent of the vote Sunday to 33.9 percent for the 54-year-old Vargas Llosa, according to unofficial returns. The writer needed a majority of the votes cast to avoid a runoff, which now most likely will take place in early June. Luis Alva Castro, candidate of the governing left-of-center Aprista Party, received 16.4 percent. Two Marxist candidates collected 11 percent of the vote between them. The remaining votes were divided among four minor candidates and blank and void ballots. Official results will not be available for weeks. But the unofficial results represented a slap in the face to Vargas Llosa, who campaigned hard for two years and as late as mid-February had more than 50 percent support in polls. Campaigning on a shoestring budget, Fujimori shot up from less than 1 percent in polls six weeks ago to nearly surpass Vargas Llosa. Vargas Llosa's campaign often seemed like a crusade. Running on a free-market platform, he harshly attacked the ``collectivist'' programs of President Alan Garcia and the proposals of leftist candidates. Many Peruvians blame Garcia for Peru's worst economic crisis of the century and the growing political violence that is tearing apart this Andean country of 22 million. Inflation is running at more than 2,000 percent annually. More than 18,000 people, most of them civilians, have died violently in a decade-long struggle between Shining Path guerrillas and security forces. Vargas Llosa was asking for a clear mandate from Peruvians to carry out radical reforms aimed at undoing two decades of socialist policies he blames for Peru's stagnation. ``I have put aside my career because I think there is a real chance to change the history of Peru,'' Vargas Llosa said in the closing days of the campaign. Analysts say Peruvian voters, dismayed by two decades of economic decline and falling living standards, were looking for someone with ``magical'' solutions to the country's problems. The spotlight fell on Fujimori, they say, after voters in recent weeks began to fear the economic shock therapy and harsh austerity measures advocated by Vargas Llosa. ``No one likes to go to the dentist even when his tooth hurts. And that's what Vargas Llosa offered,'' Manuel d'Ornellas, editor of the Expreso newspaper, wrote in a column Monday. ``Terrified by the government's disgraceful propaganda campaign against the so-called shock, many people have fled Vargas Llosa's proposed surgery to take shelter in Fujimori's oriental nirvana,'' d'Ornellas said. Fujimori is an agronomist and former university rector. His campaign has stressed ``honor, technology and work,'' qualities many here associate with his Japanese ancestry. Peru has a large number of people who trace their roots to Japanese immigrants. Public opinion analysts say Fujimori has awakened hopes in voters that he will be able to attract massive Japanese aid and investment if elected. The analysts say voters also were turned off by the multimillion-dollar campaign waged by the center-right Democratic Front coalition supporting Vargas Llosa. In contrast to Vargas Llosa, Fujimori adopted a conciliatory style in his campaign. He also avoided spelling out what he would do to resolve Peru's serious problems. Public opinion analysts agreed that unless Vargas Llosa changes his strategy, he is almost certain to be defeated in the second round by the ``Fujimori phenomenon.'' Vargas Llosa is unlikely to receive support from the Aprista Party or the defeated leftists, according to the analysts. Fujimori, on the other hand, has made few enemies. ``Because of the polarization that has been generated,'' he said Sunday night, ``the left is not going to support the Democratic Front.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Expels American Diplomat In Retaliation For U.S. Expulsion
With AM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq on Monday ordered a U.S. diplomat to leave the country in retaliation for the U.S. expulsion of an Iraqi envoy accused of involvement in a murder plot. The Foreign Ministry announcement, carried by the official Iraqi news agency, did not name the American. The State Department in Washington confirmed the expulsion but did not identify the diplomat. Spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said of the expulsion: ``We deplore Iraq's unjust action and believe it was totally inappropriate.'' Since the restoration of diplomatic ties in 1985, U.S. relations with Iraq have been ``complex and sometimes disturbing,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. ``Iraq should understand that such actions (the expulsion) only tend to exacerbate our relations.'' The Iraqi news agency quoted an unidentified ministry spokesman as saying the American action over the weekend was part of ``repeated hysterical campaigns to harm Iraq in order to serve the aggressive purposes of Israel.'' ``The accusation against the Iraqi diplomat has no basis in truth,'' he said. The State Department said Saturday it expelled an unidentified Iraqi diplomat posted at the United Nations because he was suspected of involvement in an alleged plot to murder two opponents of the Baghdad government. State Department spokeswoman Anita Stockman on Saturday said the department could only say that the expulsion was linked to an investigation in California. U.S. government sources said on condition of anonymity the expulsion involved a plot to assassinate two Iraqi opposition members in the United States. A newspaper in California identified the targets of the plot as Sargon Dadesho, a leader of the Assyrian community in California's Central Valley, and an unidentified Kurdish leader. Kurds in Iraq have been fighting for autonomy.

DOC.HEAD: Short-term Rates Drop
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities fell in Monday's auction to their lowest level in a month. The Treasury Department sold $8.2 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.80 percent, down from 7.83 percent last week. Another $8.2 billion was sold in six-month bills at the same average discount rate of 7.80 percent, down from 7.81 percent last week. The rates were the lowest since three-month bills sold for 7.72 percent on Feb. 26., and six-month bills averaged 7.79 percent on March 5. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 8.07 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,802.80 and 8.23 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,605.70. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, fell to 8.29 percent last week, down from 8.34 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Newspaper Wins Kennedy Journalism Grand Prize
DOC.TEXT: The Fort Myers (Fla.) News-Press won the Robert F. Kennedy Journalism Awards' $2,000 grand prize Monday for ``Far From the Dream,'' a 12-part series on the problems of blacks in southwestern Florida. The News-Press, which also received a $1,000 first prize for print journalism, was honored for its articles last year on housing, education, economics, politics and other problems affecting poor blacks. The awards committee said that as a result of the series, the Lee County, Fla., school board took steps to hire more minority teachers, the county director of public housing was suspended, and the Justice Department and the NAACP Legal Defense Fund requested a study of the county's desegregation policy of busing only black children. The News-Press will receive its awards at a May 14 reception at the suburban Virginia home of Ethel Kennedy, widow of the former New York senator who was assassinated during his 1968 presidential campaign. The awards, sponsored by the Robert F. Kennedy Memorial, are given for outstanding coverage of the problems of disadvantaged Americans. The first-prize winner in television was a team from WGBH, the Boston public TV station, for ``The AIDS Quarterly With Peter Jennings: Winter 1989.'' National Public Radio won a first prize for ``Young Black Men: Lost Generation?'' and Stormi Greener of the Minneapolis Star and Tribune was awarded first prize in the photojournalism category. Paul Conrad of the Los Angeles Times won first prize for cartoons. T. Jeff Rutherford of the University of Illinois won the student first prize for a series on medicare. International awards went to CBS' ``60 Minutes,'' Sandy Tolan and Jerry Kammer of The Arizona Republic in Phoenix, and Bruce Chambers of the Press-Telegram in Long Beach, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Fitzwater: Snags in Weapons Talks Won't Affect Summit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 7 grafs with Baker returning to Soviet Union before summit and Bush and Gorbachev exchange on multiple warhead missiles
DOC.TEXT: Sudden snags in talks to cut long-range nuclear weapons won't affect plans for next month's superpower summit between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the White House said Monday. ``We have a lot of things to talk about in our relationship besides arms control,'' said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. ``We are prepared to go ahead with the summit regardless of what happens on the arms control part of it.'' Problems in reaching an arms agreement aren't the only cloud hanging over the summit. Bush has warned Moscow that a crackdown in the secessionist republic of Lithuania would mar superpower relations and threaten progress across the entire superpower agenda. Bush and Gorbachev are to meet in the United States for five days, beginning May 30. The centerpiece of the second meeting between Bush and Gorbachev was to have been the signing of an outline of a treaty to cut strategic nuclear weapons. However, prospects for an agreement diminished last week after the United States and Soviet Union reported little progress during three days of high-level talks in Washington. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said the two sides remained at odds over air-launched and sea-launched cruise missiles, which have long been a key obstacle to reaching a strategic arms reduction treaty. U.S. officials said privately that the Soviet Union had pulled back in some areas where the two sides previously agreed. Fitzwater said the Bush administration remained hopeful, as it had during the first Bush-Gorbachev summit at Malta, that an agreement could be reached in time for the summit. ``If the emphasis is on the word doable, which is the new word, I think that there is certainly a great question whether or not it's doable that we would have a treaty,'' he said. ``I think there's an open question about whether all major points would be resolved at this time.'' On the other hand, Fitzwater said it was not unusual that problems crop up as negotiations approach a conclusion. ``As you get nearer the end, people get a little nervous and start having second thoughts and trying to employ a little last-minute advantage and so forth,'' Fitzwater said. ``Let's hope that that's what it is and that we can resume progress.'' Another attempt to break the arms deadlock will be made when Baker goes to the Soviet Union for talks with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze on May 16-19. Meanwhile, an adminstration official confirmed that Bush had written to Gorbachev proposing a ban on all land-based strategic missiles carrying multiple warheads. Gorbachev, in a response delivered Friday by Shevardnadze, said the U.S. plan was too limited and should include sea-based missiles as well as those deployed on land, said the official, who refused to be identified. The U.S. and Soviet positions reflect the different ways the two superpowers have structured their nuclear arsenals. The United States has deployed most of its nuclear warheads at sea, while the Soviet Union has deployed most of its warheads on land. Baker, at a news conference Friday, refused to discuss the issue of multiple-warhead weapons. ``There are some things we just don't comment on, and particularly if there's some chance that they are under consideration as part of our negotiations,'' Baker said.

DOC.HEAD: Manufacturers Reject Voluntary Regulation, FDA Said
DOC.TEXT: Most manufacturers of cosmetics are not signing up for voluntary federal oversight, according to a report to Congress released Monday. A congressman who wants to increase oversight of the $18 billion industry said the report raises safety questions. The Food and Drug Administration has no authority to require safety testing of personal-care products, which includes everything from toothpaste to bubble bath, or to force manufacturers to report safety data or cosmetics-related injuries, noted the report by the General Accounting Office, the investigating arm of Congress. ``Most people think somebody approves these products in advance ... that the government would have access to safety data, that there's a review of the chemicals (in the products), but that's not what goes on here,'' Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., who requested the report, said in an interview. Wyden is chairman of the Small Business subcommittee on regulation, He said the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act, on the books since 1938, needs to be rewritten to require cosmetics manufacturers to register with the FDA and provide the agency with data on safety tests and injury reports. He said he expects to introduce legislation to that effect later this year. The Cosmetics, Toiletry and Fragrance Association defended the industry, saying: ``There isn't a serious safety problem ... If there was ... the agency would know about it and the public would know about it.'' The association, the main trade organization for the cosmetics industry, has been encouraging manufacturers to register voluntarily with the FDA and has been collecting and reviewing safety data on chemicals used in cosmetics, said Michael Petrina, the group's vice president for legislative relations. ``The FDA has plenty of information now to make any judgments to deal with any safety concerns,'' he said. ``We don't think the FDA needs any more authority to regulate ... We don't think it makes any sense to divert their scarce resources to an industry that has a demonstrated safety record.'' The GAO report said that according to FDA estimates, there are about 2,000 to 2,500 cosmetics manufacturers and about twice as many distributors. The drug agency's records show that 778, or 31 percent to 39 percent, had registered with the agency as of July 1989, compared with about 40 percent in 1977, the report said. The trade association says the total number of manufacturers is no more than 2,000 and the number registered is closer to 60 percent. And the group notes that the 778 registered last year was 94 more than in July 1988. About 3 percent of the estimated 4,000 to 5,000 distributors have reported adverse effects of personal-care products to the FDA, the report said. The FDA can inspect manufacturers, collect samples and go to court to force products off the market if it finds safety problems. But the report noted that only companies that register with the FDA will be inspected, because otherwise the agency doesn't know they exist. Also, unless a company reports safety-testing data to the agency, their products won't be reviewed by the FDA. ``Because it is a voluntary program ... FDA will never be able to require reporting from all companies, particularly those that may be least likely to report because they have experienced problems with their cosmetics,'' the report said. The report also said FDA officials have said their investigators have found many manufacturers lack adequate data on safety tests of their products and, unless there is a problem, refuse to disclose the results of their safety tests. An FDA spokesman said agency officials had not yet seen the report and had no immediate comment. Cosmetic products sold to consumers must list ingredients on the label, but that regulation does not apply to products sold for use in business establishments like beauty salons, the report said. Wyden said he is particularly concerned that the FDA had not done its own assessments of the4 health effects of 884 chemicals available for use in cosmetics that are listed in the government's Registry of Toxic Effects of Chemical Substances. Petrina said his association has reviewed the chemicals and found that many are not used in personal-care products. Of those that are, none poses a safety problem in the small quantities in which it used, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Rallies Demand Soviet Soldiers Out of Georgia
LaserPhoto TBL11
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Georgians chanting ``Occupiers! Occupiers!'' rallied outside a Soviet military base Monday, capping a day of protests recalling a bloody clash that sparked their republic's independence movement. The day of commemorations drew almost 200,000 people to three separate rallies. It served as a show of strength by independence activists who have scored several major victories in the past month. Soldiers assaulted a peaceful pro-independence protest in front of government buildings in Tbilisi on April 9, 1989, with shovels and gas. Nineteen people died. The attack unleashed bitter criticism across the country. Several investigations have placed the blame for ordering the attack as high as the Communist Party Politburo. But no one has been blamed officially. Protesters near the Caucasus Military District headquarters posted signs reading, ``Get out of Georgia!'' and depicting a hooded executioner wearing a military star and holding a bloody shovel. Early Monday morning, about 100,000 people gathered in candlelight on Rustavelli Boulevard, the site of the clash. About 70,000 more nearly filled the republic's main stadium Monday evening in a similar rally. At an intersection outside the walled military base, about 10,000 people gathered in the afternoon and shouted through megaphones for the soldiers to abandon their posts. Eldar Shengelaya, a well-known Georgian director, addressed the soldiers as ``esteemed occupiers,'' and told them the army could turn them into ``beasts.'' ``Think!'' he said. ``This is your last chance to turn into people!'' There was no visible reaction from the few soldiers seen on the base. Authorities did not interfere with the protest, and Georgian policeman helped keep order. Protests in other Soviet republics have included anti-military elements, among them calls to boycott the draft, but Monday's demonstration was one of the largest directed specifically against the Soviet military. Top Soviet generals have complained in recent months about a growing ``campaign to discredit'' the army, particularly in republics with rising independence movements. In the Baltic republics, this spring's military call-up is expected to bring large numbers of draft dodgers, and Georgians said they expect the same. Georgia is not the only republic with a strong independence movement. The Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia, and Estonia; Moldavia; and the neighboring Caucasus republics of Azerbaijan and Armenia also have strong independence movements. Lithuania's is the strongest _ it declared itself independent from the Soviet Union on March 11, and the standoff with the Kremlin continues. In Moscow on Monday, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his top advisory body said new economic and political steps would be taken to break Lithuanian intransigence. No details were given. The leader of Latvia's Supreme Soviet said Monday he is certain Latvian legislators also will vote to secede from the Soviet Union when they meet next month, but that the independence process will be gradual. Zviad Gamsakhurdia, an independence activist long considered the dean of Georgian dissident, told reporters Sunday the April 9 anniversary was a ``day of great sorrow, but also a day of victory'' for Georgians. ``On this day, the Georgian soul was revived,'' he said. ``April 9 was the beginning of the national, democratic revolution of Georgia, which is continuing.'' He said only a small percentage of Georgians favored independence before the clash last April 9 but that now the vast majority favor independence from Moscow. On March 9, the Georgian Supreme Soviet, or parliament, condemned what it said was the republic's forced annexation to the Soviet Union and demanded negotiations on restoring independence. Later the same month, lawmakers put off local elections to give opponents to the Communists a chance to organize. At Monday's protest, speakers urged parents to help their children evade the draft. The protest ended with a mass recitation of the Lord's Prayer. At the stadium rally later, electric scoreboards read, ``In eternal memory of the innocents killed April 9.'' Among the guests on the field were five 8-year-old girls in white voile, who recited poems and a prayer in honor of two schoolmates who died in the clash. Most of the rally focused on hard-core politics. Gamsakhurdia read a list of 23 demands to the Soviet government. They included cancellation of military service for Georgians, declaration that the April 9 clash was ``genocide against the Georgian people,'' and punishment of those responsible. The thousands in the stands raised their hands to show their approval. Irakly Tsereteli, head of the radical National Independence Party, called for Gandhi-style civil disobedience to further the push for independence. The Soviet TV news program ``Vremya'' gave prominent and sympathetic play to the memorial service. Gorbachev offered his condolences to Georgia on Sunday, but independence activists dismissed them as empty words.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Must Overcome Resistance to Economic Reforms, Official Says
DOC.TEXT: A top economic adviser to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said Monday that authorities will have to overcome strong public resistance to push through a radical market-oriented economic reform program this year. ``A speedy transition to a market economy will come up against powerful opposition,'' Deputy Prime Minister Leonid Abalkin told a news conference. ``We must do it, whether we like it or not. ``What we must do first is to make all people understand and see clearly that without such a transition, the country has no future as a highly developed great power.'' As he answered reporters' questions, Abalkin repeatedly dodged specifics, implying that key decisions in the reform program had not yet been made. For example, he said the state must lift controls on prices, but would not specify which prices would be freed or when. He also denied reports circulating among the foreign business community that some form of convertible ruble would be introduced by this summer. He said experts believe the Soviet market must have something to sell first and it will take years before the country's currency will be convertible. Several officials have suggested in recent weeks that the Soviet Union was considering a plan to provide a Polish-style ``shock therapy'' for the Soviet economy, which would boost prices, drastically cut the value of the ruble and raise unemployment. In December, Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov outlined to the Soviet Congress an economic program calling for five more years of central planning, with a gradual introduction of some elements of a market economy. It further delayed a reform of prices, which are currently set by bureaucrats without regard to the cost of production. But in March, just after he was given a new, powerful post as president, Gorbachev said more radical economic reforms were urgently needed. The reforms are being speeded up due to ``destabilization of the political system, development of ethnic and regional conflicts, and deficits in the consumer goods market,'' Abalkin said. With the economy stalled partway between central planning and a market system, industrial production fell 1.2 percent in the first quarter of 1990 compared with the last quarter of 1989. ``Unless we go over to the new methods, we will deprive ourselves and our children of a highly developed and efficient economy and a powerful country, where people will want to live and which the people will not be ashamed of,'' Abalkin said. ``We will have to make sacrifices,'' he added. ``But there must be a social consensus for that.'' State Price Committee chief Vyacheslav Senchagov told the legislature last week that among the three reform variants under consideration was the Polish example of a crash program to create a maret economy. Poland hopes the abrupt transformation will keep the painful period short, and the inflation rate has already fallen drastically from the triple-digit level of January. But Abalkin said the Soviet government cannot count on public support for such a policy. He left unsaid the fact that Poland's shock program was instituted by the new Solidarity-led government, which replaced the unpopular Communists last August.

DOC.HEAD: Major Parties Disagree on How Much Socialism Should Remain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with 11 Cabinet posts tentatively filled, talks continue on remainder. Picks up 9th pvs, `Rainer Eppelmann...'
DOC.TEXT: Lothar de Maiziere, the prime minister-designate, proposed a Cabinet on Monday that includes the major political parties and has a peace activist as defense minister. The Christian Democrat leader unveiled the tentative composition of East Germany's first democratic government after negotiations with the nation's diverse political groups. Parliament is expected to vote on nominations to the 24-member Cabinet on Thursday. Agreement was reached in five days of talks with the Social Democrats, who finished second to the Christian Democrats in East Germany's first free elections March 18. Differences between the two main parties still exist on the pace and form of eventual unification with West Germany, including how much of the socialist welfare state should be retained for East Germans who depend on food and housing subsidies. German reunification was the main issue in the elections and remains the overriding priority, but agreement on a Cabinet clears a major hurdle. De Maiziere's government would replace Communist caretaker administrations that have run the country since the pro-democracy revolt in October. A three-party conservative alliance led by de Maiziere would dominate the new Cabinet with 14 seats. The Social Democrats would have seven posts and three would go to a smaller liberal alliance. Eleven of the 24 seats actually were filled, with talks to continue Tuesday on naming the rest of the ministers. Social Democrat leader Markus Meckel was nominated to be foreign minister. The Social Democrats also will hold the post of finance minister and named Walter Romberg, a key negotiator with Bonn over the planned monetary union. Rainer Eppelmann, who leads the Democratic Awakening party, part of de Maiziere's alliance, was chosen defense minister. His ministry's name was changed to Department of Defense and Disarmament, a symbolic reference to German demands for fewer nuclear weapons in superpower military stategy. Eppelmann, a Lutheran minister and peace activist who took part in the revolt against Stalinist leader Erich Honecker, probably will play a role in talks on a united Germany's future role in the Eastern and Western military alliances. Leaders of the Social Democrats expressed satisfaction with Monday's talks, but party spokesman Guenther Krug said ``substantial differences'' that remain would be the subject of further negotiations. ``We assume that difficult negotiations lie ahead,'' Krug said. Although de Maiziere's alliance won the most seats in the 400-member Parliament, it lacks the two-thirds majority needed to enact constitutional changes that would allow quick unification with West Germany. A coalition with the Social Democrats would give de Maiziere control. If negotiations with that party fail, he can try for agreements with other parties. De Maiziere supports rapid reunification of Germany, as does Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, but the Social Democrats favor a more gradual process. They also differ on the role of an East German government, which faces severe economic problems but also is likely to be a short-lived transitional administration. Among issues still to be clarified are West Germany's role in NATO, East Germany's membership in the Warsaw Pact, and the difficult question of private property. East Germans have not been allowed to own land, and West Germans have made claims on property their ancestors owned before the nation was divided after World War II. Social Democratic leaders want employees to share in former state-owned companies, but the Christian Democrats favor complete sale to private owners. The Parliament, elected March 18, convened April 4 and designated de Maiziere as prime minister. It also began dismantling the 40-year-old Communist system and created an office of president. Sabine Bergmann-Pohl, president of Parliament, was named acting national president and assumed her duties as head of state Monday. She urged a quick conclusion of the coalition talks, installation of a new government and choice of a permanent president. Hanging like a cloud over the process of building a new political order are allegations that some members of the new Parliament had ties to the reviled secret police of the old Communist regime. De Maiziere has denied such allegations in his own case. Two other accused political leaders have resigned. Parliament is expected to vote on whether to form an independent commission to investigate the allegations. The former secret police agency has been disbanded.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf to CORRECT reference to 'next year in Jerusalem,' sted Israel.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Israel-Soviet Passover
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and his wife, Barbara, issued a Passover message Monday saluting the ``march of freedom'' for Soviet Jews allowed to emigrate to Israel in the past year. ``A great march of freedom is underway for Soviet Jewry, and this year many thousands will celebrate the Seder with their families in Israel,'' Bush said. ``For these people, and for their brethren waiting to emigrate, `next year in Jerusalem,' is becoming a promise fulfilled,'' the message said. At the Seder, the traditional Passover meal, Jews worldwide pledge to celebrate the feast ``next year in Jerusalem.'' ``The call for liberty and freedom,'' Bush said, ``is now being heard around the world _ in Eastern Europe, in Central and South America, in Africa and even in the Soviet Union.'' About 29,000 Soviet Jews moved to Israel during 1989 and the first three months of this year, and the pace apparently is increasing.

DOC.HEAD: Philadelphia Auto Parts Firm to Pay $1.5 Million OSHA Fine
DOC.TEXT: A Philadelphia auto parts manufacturer will pay a $1.5 million fine for violations of government noise standards on the job, the Labor Department said Monday. The settlement between the Occupational Safety and Health Administration and the Budd Co. also calls for the firm to improve record-keeping and to protect employees from excessive noise. Last December, OSHA proposed $3.3 million in fines against the company for more than 840 alleged violations at its Philadelphia plant, including failure to tell some workers that tests showed their hearing was deteriorating. Government regulatory agencies frequently reduce proposed fines after negotiating with alleged violators. Budd, which makes doors, lift gates and other body stampings for motor vehicles, has about 2,400 people working at the Philadelphia plant. The Troy, Mich.-based company is a subsidiary of the West Germany's Thyssen Industries and has plants in Indiana, Kentucky, Michigan, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Tennessee. Under the settlement, the company will monitor noise and test employees to identify all workers exposed above a certain noise level. The workers will be notified of the results and trained to use hearing protectors, the Labor Department said. In addition, the company has agreed to reduce noise at its Philadelphia plant through engineering controls and repair and maintenance of equipment. The company also will train employees to keep records in line with agency requirements.

DOC.HEAD: 5 Felony Charges, 3 Misdemeanors Filed Against Hunter Thompson
DOC.TEXT: Hunter Thompson, the dean of gonzo journalism, was charged Monday with possessing blasting caps and various drugs police found after a former porn actress accused the writer of molesting her in his home. Thompson, 52, appeared in Pitkin County District Court with three lawyers and pleaded innocent to three misdemeanors: third-degree sexual assault, third-degree simple assault and possession of marijuana. Those charges were based on allegations by Gail Palmer-Slater, 35, star of ``The Erotic Adventures of Candy,'' that Thompson threw a drink at her, twisted her breast and shoved her during a visit at his home Feb. 21. Her allegations led to a police search of Thompson's home Feb. 26 and 27. Police said they seized blasting caps and substances they allege to be LSD, cocaine, the tranquilizer Diazepam and marijuana. An April 23 hearing was set on five felony charges: three counts of possession of a controlled substance, one charge of using cocaine and one charge of unlawful possession of incendiary devices. On leaving the courthouse, Thompson was asked why he thinks authorities have brought charges against him, when for years he has freely admitted to using drugs. ``I stand for everything they don't like,'' he said. ``It's a witch hunt.'' Palmer-Slater, who lives in Port Huron, Mich., said she went to Thompson's home in Woody Creek to discuss a business enterprise, and claimed he became angry when she refused to conduct the discussion in his hot tub. Thompson says he never assaulted the woman. He told reporters Palmer-Slater was drunk and was pressuring him to have sex with her when he pushed her away. Thompson remains free on $2,000 bond. Deputy District Attorney Charles McCrory said Thompson could receive a maximum of 16 years in prison if convicted of all eight charges against him. Thompson is the author of several books written in a style that has come to be known as ``gonzo journalism,'' intermingling a description of real events with exaggerated accounts of his own involvement, which often including drug and alcohol abuse. Thompson ran a full-page advertisement Monday in the Aspen Times Daily that read: ``BEWARE. Today: the Doctor. Tomorrow: You.'' The ad was paid for by the ``Hunter S. Thompson Legal Defense Fund.'' Thompson's books include ``Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas,'' ``Fear and Loathing on the Campaign Trail,'' ``The Great Shark Hunt'' and ``Generation of Swine,'' a compilation of some of his newspaper and magazine columns.

DOC.HEAD: Former Commerce Official Burns Self to Death
DOC.TEXT: The former head of the Slovakia commerce commission doused his body with gasoline and burned himself to death Monday, Czechoslovakia television reported. ``We found a container with gasoline and a set of matches on the spot where it happened,'' a police official insisting on anonymity told The Associated Press by phone. The 58-year-old executive, who was not named, once headed the state inspection body in Bratislava. The Commercial Commission is a watchdog body in Slovakia overseeing business transactions. At least five suicides by former officials have been reported in Czechoslovakia since the peaceful revolution last winter ended the Communists' long monopoly on power. Police said they had no immediate motive for Monday morning's suicide. ``The man died on the spot, the cause being heavy burns. The motivation of his act is still subject to investigation,'' he said. ``He did not leave a note or anything.'' According to the official, the man walked into a courtyard of the Drutechna company office building in downtown Bratislava and set himself on fire at 8 a.m.

DOC.HEAD: Winter Remains In The Upper Midwest And Northern Rockies
DOC.TEXT: Locally heavy snow fell Monday around Lake Superior, more snow fell from the northern Rockies to the western Plains, and thunderstorms drenched parts of Florida. Snow fell across northeastern Minnesota and Upper Michigan. In Minnesota, at least 7 inches of snow fell in Poplar Lake and International Falls, at least 6{ inches in Big Falls, 5 inches in Winton and 2{ inches in Red Lake. The storm was expected to drop nearly 10 inches of snow along Lake Superior's northwest shore. Snow also extended from northwestern and north-central Montana to south-central Montana and Wyoming, and snow was mixed with rain over the Nebraska Panhandle. Heavy showers and thunderstorms extended over southern and northeastern Florida. Up to 7 inches of rain fell from midnight to mid-afternoon in Dade County. During the early morning, 3.19 inches fell at Homestead and 3.45 inches at Miami, the National Weather Service said. Showers and thunderstorms reached across central and eastern Nebraska, central and western Colorado, from north-central Texas into south-central Oklahoma, over central and northern Wisconsin, northern Lower Michigan and north-central through northeastern New York state. In Colorado, hail fell west of Alamosa and near Hern during the late morning. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 21 degrees at Cut Bank, Mont., to 84 at McAllen, Texas. Monday's low for the Lower 48 states was 15 at Houlton, Maine.

DOC.HEAD: Deputy Premier: Government _ Not the Party _ is Making Decisions
With AM-Soviet-Economy
DOC.TEXT: A deputy premier said Monday that it now is the government _ and not Communist Party leaders _ who are making the key policy decisions in the Soviet Union. The comment by Deputy Premier Leonid Abalkin at a news conference on economic reform was an indication the 12-man Communist Party Politburo might be following through on Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan for the party to hand over some of its power to the government and permit a multiparty system. Gorbachev became the country's first executive president on March 15, and has formed new government advisory groups including a presidential council. Answering a question on proposed economic reforms, Abalkin said the Politburo ``will not be making any decisions from now on, and it is already not making the decisions. Decisions can be made by the president, the parliament and the Congress of People's Deputies. Those are the decision-making entities now.'' Abalkin, however, is neither a full nor non-voting member of the Politburo. He did not elaborate.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Presidential Council Rejects Lithuanian Answer
LaserPhoto TBL11
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his Presidential Council said Monday that new economic and political steps will be taken to break Lithuania's unyielding stand on independence. The advisory body's tough statement indicated the conflict is far from resolved despite a high-level meeting last week and conciliatory words by both sides. Lithuania told Gorbachev on Thursday it was ready to negotiate with Moscow but did not intend to bow to his order that it back away from its March 11 declaration of independence before any talks could begin. The Soviet Union forcibly annexed Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia in 1940. ``Members of the Presidential Council concluded that additional economic, political and other measures should be taken to protect the Soviet Constitution and the interests of citizens living in the republic and the Soviet Union as a whole,'' the Tass news agency reported Monday. It did not say what kinds of steps the council had in mind. Gorbachev has ordered Lithuanians to turn in their firearms and told the republic not to form unarmed patrols. The Soviet military has arrested some Lithuanian deserters who left after their homeland declared its independence, and has occupied several public buildings in Lithuania's capital Vilnius. But after a meeting last week between Lithuanian representatives and a major Gorbachev adviser, Politburo member Alexander N. Yakovlev, both sides were making conciliatory statements. On Sunday, however, a crowd of Lithuanians prevented hundreds of Soviet soldiers from entering a plant that prints pro-independence newspapers. Pro-Moscow Communists had ordered the plant to shut down. Quoting the Presidential Council, Tass said Monday: ``The reply by the Lithuanian Supreme Soviet was not constructive and did not open an avenue toward settling problems. In fact, it leads matters to a dead end. ... ``The present Lithuanian leadership is blocking any exit from the crisis with its anti-constitutional actions and the escalation of illegal measures. It is aggravating the situation in the republic, for which it bears full responsibility.'' Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis, speaking before the latest salvo from the Kremlin, was quoted by Tass as complaining that ``Moscow does not want talks or even preliminary good will contacts'' with Lithuania. The republic also told its young men who will be called up in the Soviet draft this spring that it is up to them whether they want to serve. Refusal to serve in the Soviet armed forces will not be considered a criminal offense, according to official Lithuanian radio, monitored by the British Broadcasting Corp. in London. In Moscow, national deputies opposing Lithuania's independence drive asked Gorbachev to dissolve the Lithuanian legislature and reiterated its demand for direct presidential rule. On Monday, Estonian leaders decided to send a draft response to Gorbachev's criticism of their bid for independence to legislative committees for debate, a local journalist reported, speaking on condition of anonymity. Estonia has declared Soviet rule occupation of an independent country, and voted to re-establish independence at the end of a still-undefined transition period. Gorbachev has demanded Estonia back down. Latvia's new Communist Party chief, Alfreds Rubiks, asked a minority group of members who walked out of the party congress over the weekend not to follow Lithuanians and Estonians by establishing an independent party. Most delegates voted to keep party ties with Moscow. The minority wants an independent Communist Party and moved to establish it this month. Anatolijs Gorbunovs, president of Latvia's Supreme Soviet, or parliament, said Monday he is certain Latvian legislators will vote to secede from the Soviet Union when they meet next month but full separation is to be achieved in ``negotiations and discussions.'' He spoke at a news conference in Geneva, where he attended a symposium.

DOC.HEAD: Former Police Office Guilty In Murder Of Neighbor
DOC.TEXT: A former policeman, who contended that insanity, drugs, alcohol and the movie ``Apocalypse Now'' drove him to the shotgun killing of an envied neighbor, was convicted Monday of first-degree murder. Robert McLaughlin, 49, of Hampton stood expressionless as the verdict was read. The Rockingham County Superior Court, which deliberated more than three days, also found him guilty of conspiracy to commit murder. McLaughlin faces an automatic prison sentence of life without parole. No date for sentencing was set. McLaughlin's attorney, Michael Iacopino, said the conviction would be appealed to the state Supreme Court. ``He deserves to spend his life in prison for all the hurt he's caused,'' said McLaughlin's son, Robert Jr., who was a witness for the prosecution. The twisted case began when former teacher Robert Cushing, 63, a successful real estate agent, was killed by two shotgun blasts when he answered the door of his home the night of June 1, 1988, while his wife sat in another room. The shooting shocked the seaside community of 12,000. Police were baffled until McLaughlin, an 18-year Hampton police officer who was not a suspect, surrendered that August. He admitted the shooting, then recanted. McLaughlin's wife, Susan, 38, was charged with being an accomplice to murder. She was convicted and sentenced to life without parole. At his pretrial hearings, McLaughlin testified that his wife had killed Cushing, and his lawyers produced letters she wrote McLaughlin from prison in which she admitted killing Cushing. Then, without explanation, McLaughlin's lawyers quit the case, and it was delayed more than six months while new lawyers were found and prepared his defense. Meanwhile, McLaughlin's wife obtained a divorce. When the trial began, his awyers acknowledged McLaughlin pulled the trigger, but pleaded insanity, saying he was under the influence of alcohol, the tranquilizer Xanax and had just watched the violent Vietnam movie ``Apocalypse Now'' on the night of the shooting. After several trial delays, a three-week trial and more than three days of deliberations, Assistant Attorney General Michael Ramsdell said, ``Finally ... justice has been done.'' The victim's son, Robert Cushing Jr., said ``there is no joy in any of this.'' He and other members of the family wept as the verdict was read. ``The one thing I hope now is we can go on and have a healing, not just for our family, but for Bobby McLaughlin ... their families and the community,'' he said. In closing arguments, prosecutor Barbara Keshen contrasted a ``desperately unhappy'' McLaughlin with a contented, successful Cushing. The two had been feuding for 13 years, since McLaughlin investigated a traffic accident outside Cushing's home in which Cushing, an onlooker, was arrested on a disorderly conduct charge. McLaughlin was cleared of brutality charges.

DOC.HEAD: Augusta Man Charged With Murder in Fast Food Shooting
DOC.TEXT: A man surrendered Monday and was charged with murder in the killing of a customer who was ahead of him in line at a drive-in fast food restaurant. Gary Bernard Scott, 23, of Augusta was being held without bond, sheriff's deputies said. He is accused of killing Dale Brantley Peeler, 30, who got out of his car to argue with two people who blew their horn after he paused to check his order in the drive-through lane at a Krystal restaurant south of Augusta early Thursday. A 16-year-old juvenile who was with Scott was arrested Saturday and was charged with being an accessory to murder, a felony, authorities said. Police obtained a warrant against Scott after interviewing the juvenile.

DOC.HEAD: Searchers Find More Bodies in Fire-Ravaged Hotel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with third body found, death toll now at nine; picks up 4th graf, `The search ...'
DOC.TEXT: Searchers poking through the rubble of a residential hotel razed by a fast-moving fire found three more bodies Monday, raising the death toll to nine, authorities said. As many as 60 searchers from several agencies used trained dogs and construction equipment to search the three-story Fontana Hotel. Six residents of the 39-year-old hotel still are listed as missing. One body found Monday was on the top floor in the rear, away from the most severe fire damage. Another victim was found in the lobby area, where the roof caved in during the pre-dawn fire Friday, police Detective Tom Hoolahan said. The third body was found in an elevator. The search for bodies is slowed by the meticulous examination of fragments from the 102-room hotel, located between Miami Beach's trendy art deco district and a strip of luxury high-rise condominiums. Crews are studying each charred board and sifting ashes and burned debris looking for any clues to the fire's origin and the victims' identities. The searchers included arson investigators from the city and state fire marshal's office and the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Firearms and Tobacco. Detective Jim Hyde said it may be two weeks before a final determination is made on the cause of the fire, the worst in the seaside city in nearly 20 years. Many of the nearly 100 residents who escaped the fire have taken temporary shelter at nearby hotels or with family members. The Fontana complied with current fire regulations, according to city officials, and was equipped with smoke detectors in each room. But the hotel did not have sprinklers, which are required by law beginning in 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Disturbances Reported Near China's Soviet Border
DOC.TEXT: Riots flared last weekend in Moslem areas near China's border with the Soviet Union, a Western diplomat said Monday. Speaking on the condition of anonymity, the diplomat said an official from the Zinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region confimed reports of civil unrest in the area. The disturbances erupted over the past few days near Kashgar, a bazaar city near China's arid border with the Soviet republics of Tadzhikistan and Kirghizia, said the diplomat, who had no further information. The Foreign Affairs Office in Urumqi, capital of Xinjiang, would neither confirm nor deny the reports. It said merely it was ``not clear'' when asked if troops were dispatched to quell rioting. In Xinjiang's government office in Beijing, an official said he did not know if reports that Kashgar was closed to foreigners were true. More than half Xinjiang's population of 14 million are from the Uygur, Hui and other Moslem groups with close ethnic ties to Soviet Moslems. Moslem riots occurred in Urumqi last May and relations between local minorities and the Beijing government have long been tense. All foreign journalists and diplomats have been barred from Xinjiang since the outbreak of ethnic unrest in adjacent republics of the Soviet Union. The sparsely populated desert province also borders Tibet, another province where resentment against Chinese rule has become violent in recent years. The China International Tourist Service claimed foreign tourists could still go to Kashgar but said they would have to leave from the Urumqi, the provinical capital, on a 700-mile bus trip. Xinjiang officials in recent months have repeatedly warned of separatists trying to stir up trouble. Xinjiang's delegates to the just-concluded annual session of China's legislature called for increased vigilance against ``a small number of separatists who present the greatest threat to Xinjiang's stability.'' The region's Communist Party chief, Song Hanliang, said after a tour of Kashgar and other areas of southern Xinjiang in February that ``every place and work unit now has some `hot spot' problems.'' He called for strengthened control over religious activities, saying the government must not allow religion to be used to promote separatist tendencies.

DOC.HEAD: Networks' Shuttle Coverage
With AM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: ABC, CBS, NBC and CNN planned to air the scheduled launch of the shuttle Discovery live Tuesday morning. The space shuttle was scheduled to lift off at 8:47 a.m. EDT from the Kennedy Space Center at Cape Canaveral, Fla. During the five-day voyage, five astronauts will put into orbit the Hubble Space Telescope, which will give scientists the most detailed look yet at the universe. CNN coverage was scheduled to begin Tuesday at 5:30 a.m. EDT. The three broadcast networks planned to begin coverage during their morning news programs at 7 a.m.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Land Mine Blast Kills Four Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: A powerful land mine exploded under a Land Rover on Monday morning, killing four soldiers and throwing the military vehicle 30 feet in the air. Two motorists also were injured. The Irish Republican Army's South Down Brigade claimed responsibility for the attack, which Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher linked to recent decisions by the Irish Supreme Court not to extradite prisoners wanted in Northern Ireland on terrorism charges. Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey discounted Thatcher's statements. ``I don't think anybody could seriously believe that the people who carry out these atrocities could have any regard for the decisions of any court,'' Haughey said. ``They follow their own futile agenda.'' Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Brooke, the British government minister responsible for the province, said ``actions of this sort are wholly senseless in that they will not deflect us from our intention to defend the community against these evil men.'' The explosion occurred just before 8 a.m. near the Downpatrick race course in County Down, in the southeast part of the province. The area was quickly sealed off and police and soldiers were airlifted in to search for clues. Police said the blast created a crater 15 feet deep and 40 feet wide and hurled the vehicle into a nearby field ``crushed like a sardine tin.'' Several other soldiers traveling in front in another Land Rover suffered shock, said a spokesman for the Royal Ulster Constabulary. The soldiers were members of the Ulster Defense Regiment, the mainly Protestant, locally recruited regiment of the British Army, said the spokesman, speaking anonymously in keeping with British custom. A pair of overalls was found a half-mile from the site of the explosion. Security chiefs then warned all police and army units that an attack might be imminent. On Friday, the Irish Supreme Court ruled not to extradite Owen Carron, a former Northern Ireland member of Parliament, saying he was a political prisoner. ``You take these murders of these four people today alongside those decisions in the Supreme Court of the Republic not to extradite those accused of violent crime and one is very, very depressed,'' Mrs. Thatcher said. ``Violent crime is not political, it's common criminal,'' she said. The court had issued a similar ruling earlier three weeks earlier in which it refused to extradite escaped prisoners, saying they would be subject to assault by prison guards if they were returned. The Irish Republican Army is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland and unite the predominantly Protestant province with the Roman Catholic Republic of Ireland.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Aboard French Ferry off Isle of Wight Leaves 1 Dead, 1 Hurt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with three grafs to UPDATE with crewman injured from smoke inhalation, minor editing. Pickup 4rd pvs, `Cause of...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Ferry Fires, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Fire broke out in the engine room of a French ferry 14 miles off Britain's Isle of Wight on Monday, and one of the 675 people aboard died after a heart attack. A crewman was overcome by smoke, but the blaze was extinguished by the crew, the coast guard said. It was the third fatal ferry fire in the region since Saturday, when a blaze destroyed the Norwegian North Sea ferry Scandivavian Star, leaving an estimated death toll of 170. In Britain, police began an arson investigation of a fire early Monday on the Irish Sea car ferry Norrona that killed one man. The fatality in Monday's fire on the Reine Mathilde off England's south coast was a 66-year-old passenger who was not immediately identified. The crew member, suffering from smoke inhalation, was to be transported by helicopter to a mainland hospital, a coast guard spokesman said. Cause of the blaze was unknown. The owner, Brittany Ferries, said the vessel was traveling from Caen, France, to Portsmouth, England, with 600 passengers, 71 crew and four service personnel. A doctor, traveling as a passenger, assisted the ship's doctor but was unable to revive the heart attack victim. A company spokeswoman said: ``The fire broke out half-an-hour before the end of the 5}-hour crossing, in a engine room not near where any of the passengers would normally be. ``We know the passenger suffered a heart attack but we do not yet know at what stage of the journey this happened, or whether it was during the fire.'' The vessel was without power, but there appeared to be no danger to the rest of the ship. The naval tug Powerful was being dispatched to tow the ferry into Portsmouth, where it was expected to arrive about 6 a.m. (1 a.m. EDT) Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Official Swedish Delegation Denied Visa to Lithuania
With AM-Soviet-Republics
DOC.TEXT: Soviet authorities have denied entry visas to an official Swedish delegation that was scheduled to visit Lithuania this month, the national news agency TT reported Monday. The visit was part of a cultural exchange program between Sweden and the Baltic republics. Foreign Ministry under-Secretary Pierre Schori, a member of the delegation, told the Swedish news agency that the Soviet decision was ``deeply regrettable.'' ``Already before, with its decision to deny visas to journalists, the Soviet Union has deviated'' from international agreements. Soviet authorities ordered foreign journalists to leave Lithuania by April 1. ``Now it apparently is going a step further and stops an official cultural delegation,'' TT quoted Schori as saying. The delegation was scheduled to visit Lithuania April 18-20.

DOC.HEAD: Playboy's Hugh Hefner and Wife Kimberley Have Baby Boy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS wife's name to `Kimberley,' sted `Kimberly,' throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Playboy magazine founder Hugh Hefner and his wife, Kimberley, became parents of a baby boy on Monday, Hefner's 64th birthday. Marston Glenn Hefner was born at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center about 8 a.m., weighing 8 pounds, 13 ounces, said Playboy spokesman Bill Farley. Both baby and mother were doing well, he said. Hefner and Kimberley Conrad were married July 1 in a highly publicized ceremony at the Playboy Mansion. She was the 1988 Playmate of the Year. Hefner has two children from a previous marriage: daughter Christie, the head of Playboy Enterprises, and son, David.

DOC.HEAD: Glance at Elections in Peru, Hungary, Yugoslavia, Greece
DOC.TEXT: Here is a look at developments following elections held Sunday in several countries.

PERU: Mario Vargas Llosa, the acclaimed novelist once considered a sure bet to become Peru's next president, finds himself sidetracked by the ``Fujimori phenomenon.'' Agricultural engineer Alberto Fujimori, 51, son of Japanese immigrants and a political unknown until a month ago, forced Vargas Llosa into a runoff and is now favored to win the presidency. Fujimori received 29 percent of the vote Sunday to 33.9 percent for Vargas Llosa, unofficial returns say. Vargas Llosa needed a majority to avoid a runoff, which now probably will take place in early June. Luis Alva Castro, candidate of the governing left-of-center Aprista Party, received 16.4 percent. Two Marxist candidates split 11 percent of the vote and the rest was divided among four minor candidates and blank and void ballots. Public opinion analysts say Fujimori's strong second-place finish Sunday reflected Peruvians' alienation from traditional political parties and their desire for ``miraculous, painless'' solutions to Peru's ills. Inflation runs at more than 2,000 percent annually. More than 18,000 people have died in the struggle between radical Shining Path guerrillas and security forces.

GREECE: Constantine Mitsotakis, leader of New Democracy, cut a deal with the small Democratic Renewal party to form a government after Sunday election returns showed his conservative party one seat short of a parliamentary majority. Official results showed New Democracy won 150 of the 300 seats in the single-house Parliament in the third parliamentary elections in 10 months. The conservatives also fell short in June and November elections. Mitsotakis met Monday with Costis Stephanopoulos and they agreed Democratic Renewal's one victorious candidate would support New Democracy to give it 151 seats. The government will be all-New Democracy, however. The political impasse since last June has left untended the problems of a crumbling economy and growing urban terrorism. With almost all of the 16,584 polling stations reporting, official returns gave New Democracy 46.89 percent of the vote; the Panhellenic Socialist Movement, or PASOK, 38.62 percent, and 123 seats; the Communist-led Coalition of the Left and Progress, 10.28 percent and 19 seats, and the eight remaining seats split among four independents, two Greek-Moslems, one environmentalist and Democratic Renewal.

HUNGARY: Leaders of the Hungarian Democratic Forum, the conservative party that won elections ending 43 years of Communist rule in Hungary, began work Monday to form a center-right governing coalition. Democratic Forum won nearly 43 percent of the vote and 165 of the 386 house seats contested Sunday and in a first round of elections two weeks ago, unofficial results showed. Jozsef Antall, president of Democratic Forum, told reporters Monday, ``We have the possibility of forming a solid government with our possible coalition partners'' _ the agrarian Independent Smallholders, third with 11 percent of the vote, and the Christian Democrats, tied for fifth with more than 5 percent. Unofficial results gave the Smallholders 43 seats and the Christian Democrats 21. Such a coalition would force the liberal League of Free Democrats and its ideological ally, the League of Young Democrats, into the opposition. The former Communists, now grouped into the governing Socialist Party, probably would join them. The Free Democrats won about 24 percent of Parliament, with 92 seats. The Young Democrats were tied with the Christian Democrats for 21 seats, and the Socialist Party was fourth with more than 8 percent, for 33 seats. Antall's new government is expected to introduce market forces into the economy.

YUGOSLAVIA: Communist reformer Milan Kucan got the most votes for president of Slovenia in Yugoslavia's first free election since 1945, but must face conservative rival Joze Pucnik in a runoff, election results showed Monday. The runoff will be held April 22 because neither won a majority. With 98 percent of the vote counted from Sunday's elections, Kucan led with 44.4 percent. Pucnik of DEMOS, a coalition of five conservative groups, was second with 26.2 percent; independent Ivan Kramberger third with 18.9 percent, and Marko Demsar of the Liberal Party fourth with 10.5 percent. An estimated 1.1 million Slovenians, 75 percent of those eligible, voted in communist Yugoslavia's first multiparty election since World War II. They also chose a legislature from candidates representing 17 political parties. Political analysts predict a close contest in the runoff. Pucnik wants Slovenia to secede from Yugoslavia. Kucan advocates a more cautious approach. Initial results suggest the Slovenian Communist Party _ its name newly changed to the Party of Democratic Renewal _ will become the largest single party in the republic's legislature but DEMOS will have the most seats. Support for secession has grown in Slovenia, the most liberal and prosperous of Yugoslavia's six republics, because of the slow pace of political and economic reform elsewhere in the federation.

DOC.HEAD: TV Critics Rate What's In, What Out
DOC.TEXT: Bug-eyed Bart Simpson of ``The Simpsons,'' the gallant, green ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles'' and late-night talk show host Arsenio Hall tickle some of the nation's television critics. But beware, Dan Rather, ``Alf'' and talk show host Pat Sajak _ the critics say you're no longer the hottest of the hot. In the April 14th issue of TV Guide, 10 television gurus from across the nation rated and berated celebrities, TV shows, commercials, and trends. Some more of the critics' choices for What's In: the Fox network's Tracey Ullman; ABC's Peter Jennings, ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' and ``thirtysomething''; CNN; and science-fiction buddy shows _ Fox's ``Alien Nation'' and NBC's ``Quantum Leap.'' What's Out: Vanna White; celebrities endorsing colas; talk show host Geraldo Rivera; miniseries more than six hours long; the MTV cable music channel and sitcoms featuring free spirits, witches or psychics.

DOC.HEAD: Conservatives Begin Trying to Form Government After Victory
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `The Hungarian' to CORRECT results from official to unofficial. Picks up 3rd pvs, `No one...' Official results not expected before Tuesday
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Hungary-Future, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: After a night of celebration, leaders of the conservative party that won elections ending 43 years of Communist rule began working Monday to form a center-right governing coalition. The Hungarian Democratic Forum won nearly 43 percent of the vote, securing 165 of the 386 house seats contested in Sunday's balloting and in a first round of elections two weeks ago, according to unofficial results. ``No one should be blinded by the euphoria of victory,'' the party's president, Jozsef Antall, told a news conference Monday. Referring to the agrarian Independent Smallholders and the Christian Democrats, Antall said: ``We have the possibility of forming a solid government with our possible coalition partners.'' Both parties are ideologically close to the Democratic Forum in their emphasis on Christian values and a generally conservative outlook. The Smallholders were third with 11 percent of the vote and the Christian Democrats tied for fifth with more than 5 percent. According to the unofficial results, the Smallholders got 43 seats and the Christian Democrats 21. Official results were not expected before Tuesday. Leaders of the Smallholders and the Christian Democrats told separate news conferences they were interested in a coalition with the Democratic Forum. Such a union would force the second-strongest party, the liberal League of Free Democrats, and its ideological ally, the League of Young Democrats, into the opposition. They would likely be joined by the former Communists, now grouped into the Socialist Party. The Free Democrats won about 24 percent of Parliament, with 92 seats. The Young Democrats were tied with the Christian Democrats for 21 seats, and the ruling Socialist Party was fourth with more than 8 percent, for 33 seats. Antall said it would take at least a month to form a new government, which is expected to introduce market forces into the economy, crippled after decades of centralized control under the Communists. It also faces a $20 billion foreign debt. The Forum favors a more gradual approach to economic reform to soften the effects of inevitable inflation and unemployment. The Free Democrats, formed by former leading dissidents, campaigned on a platform for quicker change. In apparent reference to his party's chief rival, the Free Democrats, Antall said he ``would like to rely on the other side as well.'' Antall ruled out cooperation with the Socialist Party, which was formed last year by Communist reformers. An additional eight seats in the 394 seat house will be allocated to representatives of the national minorities. The conservative victory was the second in the two free elections held in the East bloc this year. In East Germany, where Eastern Europe's first free elections were held March 18, conservatives also gained a clear victory. The Communists were relegated to a relatively unimportant opposition role.

DOC.HEAD: JVC Jazz Festival Announced
DOC.TEXT: Bobby McFerrin, minimalist composer Steve Reich and singers Mel Torme and Cleo Laine will headline three of the concerts at Carnegie Hall during this year's JVC Jazz Festival. Impresario George Wein on Monday announced the lineup for the festival to be held June 22 through 30. He also paid tribute to Sarah Vaughan, calling the late singer ``one who belongs in the Valhalla of jazz greats.'' Vaughan, a featured performer at the festival in past years, died April 3. ``Our schedule is messed up because we don't have the concert for Sarah Vaughan,'' Wein said. Concerts for June 29 will be announced later. Opening night will feature the Dizzy Gillespie United Nations Orchestra at Carnegie Hall. Trumpeter Jon Faddis and the group of pianist Marcus Roberts, stepping out from Winton Marsalis' combo, will be guests. Miles Davis and the popular group Hiroshima will give two concerts that night at Avery Fisher Hall. Lionel Hampton and Orchestra will play in Stamford, Conn. Earlier in the evening, ragtime specialist Terry Waldo will play piano at Weill Recital Hall and the Roy Campbell and William Parker Duo and Jazz Passengers will play at Equitable Auditorium. Those who prefer solo piano can attend the early piano series at Carnegie's Weill Recital Hall. It will feature Randy Weston, Sir Charles Thompson, Geoff Keezer, Marty Napoleon, John Lewis, Abdullah Ibrahim, Mulgrew Miller and Barbara Carroll. On Saturday, June 23, Reich and musicians and the World Saxophone Quartet are at Carnegie; Lee Ritenour and Patti Austin at Avery Fisher, and a salute to bassist Milt Hinton on his 80th birthday at Town Hall. Sunday finds George Benson and McCoy Tyner at Carnegie and Ray Charles and Roberta Flack at Avery Fisher. Monday has only early concerts. Tuesday brings Torme, Laine and John Dankworth to Carnegie, Milton Nascimento and Wayne Shorter to Avery Fisher and a salute to guitarist Jim Hall at Town Hall. McFerrin, best known for his hit record ``Don't Worry, Be Happy,'' will appear June 27 with Chick Corea in ``An Evening of Improvisations.'' Pearl Bailey makes her festival debut that night at Avery Fisher Hall with trumpeter Winton Marsalis and drummer Louis Bellson as musical director. At Town Hall that night, Gerry Mulligan, Ruby Braff and Dick Hyman participate in ``An Evening of American Song.'' The Dave Brubeck Quartet will give a free concert Thursday, June 28, at the World Financial Center. ``An Evening with Oscar Peterson'' will be at Avery Fisher Hall. Stan Getz, with quartet and sextet, will present 50 years of his music that evening in Carnegie Hall. Saturday brings a Latin jam, with Eddie Palmieri, Ramsey Lewis and Papo Lucca, to Carnegie. ``A New York City Tribute to Spike Lee,'' with Nancy Wilson, Ahmad Jamal and Terence Blanchard, at Avery Fisher, will be a benefit for Jazzmobile, which takes jazz musicians to city neighborhoods. Two concerts that night will be given by Jack DeJohnette, Herbie Hancock, Dave Holland and Pat Metheny at the Beacon Theater. Events away from New York include a noon to 6 p.m. piano spectacular June 23 and a jazz picnic from 11 a.m. to 6 June 24 at Waterloo Village in Stanhope, N.J., June 23. On the final Saturday and Sunday, there will be noon to midnight concerts at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center, Saratoga Springs, N.Y., and 2 to 11 p.m. at the Finger Lakes Performing Arts Center, Canandaigua, N.Y.

DOC.HEAD: Book by Former Polish Leader Gierek Brings Long Queues
DOC.TEXT: A history of Poland's tumultuous '70s by former Communist Party leader Edward Gierek topped local bestseller lists as Poles stood in block-long lines Monday to buy copies of his memoir. ``The Aborted Decade,'' is a 201-page book that features a series of interviews of Gierek by journalist Janusz Rolicki conducted from November to February. Despite its relatively high local price of $5.28, lines quickly formed to buy the book, which was sold from the backs of trucks and sidewalk tables. Much of the interest appeared to stem from a desire for a behind-the-scenes look at the country's recent political history. Despite his being deposed in 1980, the 77-year-old Gierek is remembered fondly by many Poles for raising the standard of living by borrowing heavily from abroad. The loans contributed in great part to Poland's $40 billion debt, which it still is unable to pay. The debt and subsequent economic problems led to the birth and rise of Solidarity, the first independent labor union in the Soviet bloc. Gierek legalized Solidarity in 1980, but because of the union's growing demands coupled with pressing economic problems, he was forced to retire. Gierek, first secretary of the party from 1970-80, is Poland's first communist ruler to return to the public eye after being ousted. The ruling Communists fell from power last year at the beginning of the East European reforms and in its wake the Solidarity-led government was created. ``There was no chance to publish this before,'' Gierek admits in a postscript to the paperback issued by a private publisher, Fakt. He says the Communist Party leadership during the 1980s rejected his repeated requests for an objective reassessment of the 1970s. ``A nation's forgetting or falsifying its past loses the proper perspective for coming years,'' he wrote. ``The history of People's Poland is not a history of a wild and festering struggle by society against the authorities. First of all it is a history of the life of several generations, full of bright and dark spots.'' He also said he had been ``imprisoned and laughed at'' and later ``condemned to ignomity and humiliation,'' without the right to defend himself. Gierek was briefly interned after martial law was declared in Poland in 1981. The imprisonment was an effort by the country's leaders to portray the crackdown as being aimed at both rebellious union leaders and corrupt party officials. He had come to power as the first secretary of the Polish United Workers Party in December 1970 succeeding Wladyslaw Gomulka, who was forced out after security forces opened fire on Polish workers in the Baltic cities of Gdansk and Gdynia, killing scores.

DOC.HEAD: Army Forces, Kurdish Tribesman Attack Guerrillas
DOC.TEXT: Army forces and government-armed tribesman attacked Kurdish guerrillas near the Iraqi border this weekend, killing 21 in the largest anti-rebel operation in the area since 1984, Turkish news agencies reported Monday. Fifteen guerrillas also were wounded and top rebel party leaders may have been among the dead, the reports said quoting the regional governor's office in the southeastern city of Diyarbakir. The guerrillas belong to the Kurdish Labor Party, a Marxist group fighting to establish an independent Kurdish state in Turkey's southeastern provinces. The independent Hurriyet News Agency said dozens of tribesmen spotted and battled the guerillas Saturday night, preventing the rebels from retreating into Iraq until government troops arrived. The Kurdish Labor Party has camps in neighboring Syria, Iraq and Iran and its headquarters in the Syrian capital of Damascus, according to Turkish security officials. So far about 2,500 civilians, guerrillas and security forces in Turkey have died since 1984 in clashes tied to the Kurdish independence bid. After the latest clashes, authorities reported seizing two rocket launchers and 26 automatic rifles from the guerrillas, according to the semi-official Anatolia News Agency.

DOC.HEAD: Inmate Arraignment in Corrections Chief's Death
DOC.TEXT: An inmate with alleged ties to Salem's drug underworld was arraigned Monday on aggravated murder charges in the slaying of Oregon's top prison official over a year ago, authorities announced Monday. Frank E. Gable was charged in an indictment returned Friday and released Monday with six counts of aggravated murder and one of murder. He was being held without bail pending another court appearance next week. Gable, 30, who had been serving a jail term for assaulting his wife and was due to be released Thursday, in recent months had become the focus of the inquiry into the January 1989 stabbing death of corrections chief Michael Francke. The slaying resulted in the state's most extensive criminal investigation and also sparked accusations that Department of Corrections employees were somehow involved in Francke's death. However, various investigations failed to substantiate claims of a conspiracy. Francke, 42, who had been recruited from New Mexico to run Oregon's prisons, was attacked as he was leaving work for the day and walking to his car parked outside the Corrections Department office. An autopsy showed he died of a stab wound to the heart. One of the counts against Gable alleges that Francke's death was related to his duties as corrections director. Others said Gable killed Francke in an attempt to cover up an armed robbery or theft. Marion County District Attorney Dale Penn said at a news conference that those ``alternative theories'' would be presented at trial and that it would be up to a jury to decide which is the most credible. At least one jail inmate has testified that Gable said he killed Francke during a bungled car burglary. Some inmates have told authorities Gable worked as a collector for drug traffickers, but others have described Gable as a small-time dealer who used drugs himself. Penn said his office would seek the death penalty if Gable were convicted of aggravated murder. Gable, who has denied any involvement in Francke's death, said Monday he was not surprised by the indictment. ``I just ask that they not stop looking,'' Gable said in an interview. ``There's a killer out there somewhere. Don't let me get railroaded for this.'' Gable has said that other inmates have been trying to implicate him in the slaying because he once worked as an informant for the Keizer police department.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Official Compares Lithuania To Lincoln's Battle Against Secession
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS throughout to CORRECT spelling of Reshetov.
DOC.TEXT: Moscow's opposition to Lithuanian independence can be compared to Abraham Lincoln's fight to keep the South from seceding, a Soviet official said Monday. Yuri A. Reshetov, head of the Soviet Foreign Ministry's department for international humanitarian cooperation and human rights, told a news conference he visited Washington's Lincoln Memorial on Sunday. The American Civil War president, ``in his second inaugural address in 1865, said that he is fighting against the forces which are seeking to dissolve the Union. Abraham Lincoln saved the American Union,'' Reshetov said. ``We have been together with Lithuania, with Estonia and with Latvia for many, many years,'' he said. ``I still hope that what unites us is much stronger than what is capable of leading to dissolution of our union.'' Reshetov argued that Lithuania's fate should be decided by a popular vote, rather than by the March 11 declaration by the parliament in Vilnius rejecting the 1940 Soviet annexation. Stasys Lozoraitis Jr., charge d'affaires of the Lithuanian legation in Washington, said at a separate news conference that since the Western Powers have never recognized the Soviet annexation of Lithuania ``the international law that should be applied is that the Soviets should withdraw.'' A majority of Lithuanians are for independence, Lozoraitis said, but a referendum would be ``a trap'' for neighboring Estonia and Latvia, where sizable minorities oppose independence. All three Baltic republics were part of the Russian empire from the late 18th century until after World War I.
