They were independent between the wars but forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940 after Moscow took control of the republics under terms of a secret pact with Nazi Germany. The Baltic republics have continued to maintain legations as their diplomatic representatives in Washington. Reshetov said the Soviet Union supports self-determination, but said self-determination can take various forms and ``the creation of a new state is the highest form.'' ``In international law it is well established that the means of determining the right to self-determination is a referendum or plebiscite,'' the Foreign Ministry official said. Asked about the presence of Soviet troops in Lithuania, Reshetov said, ``The only thing that is happening in this respect in Lithuania is that law and order should be upheld in this part of the Soviet Union.'' Lozoraitis, however, said, ``We can maintain law and order by ourselves and don't need the Red Army to maintain law and order.'' The Soviet official was also asked about the expulsion of Western correspondents from Lithuania on April 1 and about the occupation of a newspaper plant in Vilnius by Soviet troops on March 31. Reshetov replied that the journalists were exluded under international law principles that also permit exclusion of foreign diplomats. He said he hoped it will be ``just for a limited time.'' The official also said that in recent months Lithuanian newspapers that opposed secession received no newsprint from Lithuanian factories but newspapers in favor of secession ``received plenty of paper.'' Lozoraitis denied that there was any policy of denying newsprint to papers that opposed independence. He said some newspapers were not able to get paper because they lacked the financial means.

DOC.HEAD: Arson Suspected in Irish Sea Ferry Fire That Left 1 Dead, 32 Hurt
With AM-Ferry Fires, Bjt, and AM-French Ferry-Fire
DOC.TEXT: An early morning blaze on board the Irish Sea car ferry Norrona killed one man and injured 32 people on Monday, police said, and both police and the ship's owner said arson was suspected. The ferry was carrying 297 people from Milford Haven, 180 miles west of London, to Rosslare, Ireland, and was eight miles off Wales when the fire was discovered. The blaze damaged 10 cabins. The B and I shipping line, with headquarters in Dublin, Ireland, issued a statement saying it suspected the Norrona fire was started deliberately. The company said the blaze began in two of Norrona's unoccupied sleeping cabins. It did not elaborate, but the company's marine superintendent, Capt. Peter McKenna, told Irish Radio, ``The cabins are not normally locked, but the area was not allocated to passengers for this particular sailing. The cabins were close to each other in the same section.'' McKenna said the company believes mattresses or lighted paper started the fire. It followed a suspicious fire on the Scandinavia Star ferry early Saturday that killed an estimated 170 people. That fire broke out while the Danish-owned ship was traveling from Norway to Denmark with at least 500 aboard. ``I am sure the terrible fire on the Scandinavian Star at the weekend was going through a lot of people's minds. Suddenly, we all seemed to be in a similar situation,'' said Fred Jenkinson, a Norrona passenger. Survivors described crawling through thick smoke that choked corridors and cabins. ``I took the skin off my knees and toes but, thank God, we got out alive,'' said Jenkinson, who was asleep in his cabin when he heard shouts and smelled smoke. Assistant Chief Constable Eifion Pritchard, who announced the criminal inquiry in the Norrona fire, said: ``We do not know the cause at present but there are grounds for suspecting it may not have started accidentally.'' Pritchard said experts were aboard the vessel and a post-mortem examination was being carried out on the victim. B and I said the victim was not a member of the crew. Thirty-two passengers needed hospital treatment, mostly for smoke inhalation, police said. Company Chief Executive Jim Kennedy said: ``We are obviously very concerned ... and are holding our own investigation into the way everything was handled.'' Firefighters and crew controlled the blaze within two hours of the captain's distress call, said coast guard spokesman George Clarke. Three British military helicopters were used to remove injured people and to take firefighters and two doctors to the vessel. The ferry returned to the dock under its own power. Fire also broke out Monday in the engine room of the French ferry Reine Mathilde, which was carrying 675 people fron Caen, France, to Portsmouth, England, and was extinguished by the crew, the coast guard said. A 66-year-old passenger died of a heart attack, and one crew member was overcome by smoke. The fire was the third aboard a passenger ship in northern European waters since Saturday. Tugs were dispatched to pull in the Reine Mathilde, which was 14 miles off the Isle of Wight.

DOC.HEAD: Fan Club to Comedians: Quayle No `Hoosier Stumblebum'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 8th graf, `He's a ...,' to UPDATE with ``Tonight Show'' spokesman's comment; picks up 9th graf, `Quayle spokesman ...'
DOC.TEXT: Dan Quayle is not the ``Hoosier stumblebum'' that comedians joke about, says the vice president's fan club, which has launched a letter-writing campaign to enlighten late-night entertainers. Members of the Hit the Trail for Quayle Club said Monday they want Johnny Carson and other prominent comedians to knock off knocking Quayle and find some other target for their monologues. ``They make him out to be some Hoosier stumblebum, but he's no dummy,'' said Noel Clark of Peoria. ``He's really a sharp guy. But these comedians _ Johnny Carson, Jay Leno, Pat Sajak _ and the liberal-minded press keep jumping on him. ``We've written these comedians and told them to lay off Dan Quayle and clean up their acts.'' Clark is one of about 30 members of the club, founded earlier this year by Dorothy Vallosio of Peoria. ``We just resent all the jokes bashing our vice president,'' Mrs. Vallosio said. ``They are so mean. And they've criticized him over and over and over so often that they've got people believing them. The public is being programmed to think our vice president is a laughingstock.'' The group's first letters were directed at television networks, but they never got a response. So the group decided to write individual comics. ``He's a human being,'' Mrs. Vallosio said of Quayle. ``We think our officials have to be superhuman. But everybody makes mistakes.'' Charlie Barrett, a spokesman for NBC's ``The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson'' _ which features Leno as guest host _ said the fan club is overreacting to harmless comedic barbs. ``A lot of people in the public eye are lampooned by the media,'' Barrett said. ``It's meant to entertain, no more than that.'' Sajak was out of the country and unavailable to comment. Quayle spokesman David Beckwith applauded the club's efforts and suggested Carson and the others take note. ``They are perpetuating a stereotype that has no real correlation with reality,'' Beckwith said in a telephone interview. ``Sometimes, that sort of reputation is hard to shake. ``If you're doing a good job as vice president, as Dan Quayle is, you're not going to get a lot of publicity or get on television a lot. It's nice the Hit the Trail for Quayle Club is doing something about it.''

DOC.HEAD: Official Says Palestinian Parliament to be Trimmed
DOC.TEXT: Officials proposed trimming the size of a Palestinian parliament from 452 to 400 seats on Monday and said the Islamic Hamas movement and a longstanding dissident faction expressed interest in joining the council. Members of the nine Palestine Liberation Organization factions as well as independent figures made the recommendation after three days of talks aimed at convening a meeting this year of the Palestine National Council. The National Council functions as parliament for the Palestinian state it declared two years ago and sets policy for the PLO. The National Council speaker, Sheikh Abdul Hamid Al-Sayeh, told The Associated Press the cuts would come among representatives of Palestinian refugees living outside Israeli-held territory. Those in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip would retain their 186 seats. The recommendation will go before the PLO's Executive Committee. Sayeh said the nine factions would hold the same proportion of seats they do now, with Fatah, led by PLO chairman Yasser Arafat, holding the largest share. He said the fundamantalist movement Hamas, or Zeal in Arabic, and the Marxist Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command ``are very much interested in joining the new council.'' Hamas has widespread support in the Gaza Strip and West Bank, where it has sometimes vied with the PLO for leadership of the 28-month-old uprising against Israeli occupation. One sticking point might be the November 1988 PLO decision to renounce terrorism and accept Israel's right of existence as a step toward peace talks with Israel aimed at a Palestinian state alongside the Jewish country. Hamas favors struggle to regain all of what is now Israel for the Palestinians. Sayeh said Ahmed Jibril's Syrian-based PFLP-GC also sought council membership. Jibril's relatively small group also has opposed Arafat's efforts to reach peace through compromise. Sayeh said the National Council was due to meet in November. He said independents will continue to be allotted 45 percent of the seats. Nominal independents often have been allied with one or another of the guerrilla factions.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinista Army Reports Contra Attacks, Cattle Theft
DOC.TEXT: Sandinista army forces battled U.S.-supported Contras over the weekend but no casualties were reported, and rebels were accused of stealing nearly 700 cattle, the defense ministry said Monday. ``The counterrevolutionary forces continue violating the halt to offensive military operations decreed unilaterally by the Revolutionary Government of Nicaragua,'' a one-page Defense Ministry communique said. It accused the Contras of ``increasing its terrorist activity against the civilian population and economic objectives.'' According to the communique, a group of Contras on Sunday attacked the farm cooperative ``Dinamita'' southeast of Santo Domingo in Chontales province. It gave no details. Another communique, from the Region V military headquarters in Juigalpa, said Contra and Sandinista People's Army troops clashed Saturday near the hamlet of Muhan, also in Chontales. Last week, Contra leaders said negotiations to disband the rebel force stalled because of disagreement over the size of security zones in Nicaragua and over a verifiable cease-fire. The United National Opposition, a pro-American, 14-party coalition, beat the ruling Sandinistas in Feb. 25 elections and are to take power on April 25. An accord signed by the Contras and UNO in Tegucigalpa on March 23 calls for the rebels to start disarming no later than five days before President Daniel Ortega hands over power to President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, but sets no deadline for completing the process. The Region V dispatch said the fighting started when about 50 Contras were caught stealing about 500 cattle, but that the army was able to recover more than 150. According to the Defense communique, Contra groups also stole 160 cattle Saturday from the zones of Loma El Turbante and La Lajas, both in Chontales, and 30 cattle on Friday from an area known as Cano La Plancha in the South Atlantic Autonomous Region.

DOC.HEAD: `The Pat Sajak Show,' Suffering Low Ratings, Gets The Ax
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `The 6-month-old ...,' to CORRECT that show 15 months old.
DOC.TEXT: After months of rumors and a complete overhaul, ``The Pat Sajak Show'' will be yanked off the air effective April 16, CBS announced Monday. The one-hour time slot that begins at 11:30 p.m. will be replaced with reruns until the fall, when original programming will be introduced, Rod Perth, vice president of late-night programs, said in a statement. The 15-month-old show, long rumored to be headed for cancellation, has been at the bottom of late-night talk show ratings for most of its short life. In February, the network gave the show a new look to try to boost the number of viewers. But a new set and a new format only produced the same old ratings. Sajak, who is more famous as the host of ``Wheel of Fortune,'' will have no further projects with the network, said CBS spokeswoman Susan Tick. Sajak was out of the country on vacation Monday and unavailable for comment, Ms. Tick said.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0685 to fix writer designation
Sullivan: Beware of Forces Advocating Legalization of Drugs
With AM-Drug Conference
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Louis Sullivan, the U.S. secretary of health, said Monday that the United States would end up with more addiction and more deaths if it ever legalized drugs. ``Legalization would be a tragic, horrible mistake, and its folly has become so apparent that no one should seriously offer it as an alternative,'' he told a plenary session at a drug summit of 112 nations. Sullivan said there was ``a very small but vocal minority'' in the United States that opposes the war on drugs. ``We must beware of those who argue that ending substance abuse requires too much effort, time and resources,'' he said. ``Some of these critics claim that legalization is the answer. But, as we have discovered in the United States, it is no answer at all.'' Despite the U.S. investment of significant resources in drug prevention during the 1960s and 1970s, he said, ``those two decades encouraged pseudo-legalization and social tolerance.'' ``In the United States, our experience with those two decades demonstrated the price we will pay for appeasement _ more drugs, more addiction and more death,'' Sullivan said. ``Legalization would remove the stigma from drug use, the pressure for treatment and the few restraints there are on cost and supply,'' he said. ``Legalization would send the people the message that our society is morally indifferent to their use of harmful drugs,'' he said. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, opening the three-day conference, also urged delegates to ``make it absolutely clear that you can't beat drug-taking by legalizing drugs.'' ``That is the way to destroy young lives, ruin families and undermine society itself. Our task is to protect young people, not deliberately expose them to danger,'' she said. ``I can assure you that our government will never legalize illicit drugs, hard or soft,'' the prime minister said. Sullivan said the summit, sponsored by Britain and the United Nations, had a chance to ``write the final chapter in the horror story of the world's drug epidemic'' if it fostered an international commitment to work together to end the drug crisis. If this succeeded, he said, ``then we have sent the drug kingpins and dealers a warning they must heed or face certain doom. Their days are numbered. ``We also will be sending a message to users that they bear responsibility in perpetuating the drug problem. We must communicate to users that help is available to them but that they must seek it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Four People Jailed Without Bond in Crack House Slayings of Six
LaserPhoto DT5
DOC.TEXT: Four people accused of killing six men and boys at a reputed crack house in the city's worst mass slaying in nearly 19 years were ordered jailed without bond Monday. The four stood mute at their arraignment to six counts each of felony murder, and a District Court magistrate entered innocent pleas for them. Three of the defendants also were arraigned on one count each of use of a firearm during commission of a felony in the April 4 slayings. Magistrate Izetta Bright ordered Tamara M. Marshall, 18; Mark Bell, 20; Jamal Biggs 19; and Mark Caison, 19, all of Detroit, held without bond at the Wayne County Jail, pending a preliminary hearing April 20. Some witnesses said the slayings followed a soured love affair between Marshall and Steven Owens, at 32 the oldest of the six victims. Other witnesses said they believed the killings stemmed from a drug dispute, but Inspector Gerald Stewart dismissed that speculation again Monday and said robbery appears to be the motive. ``We have nothing to indicate this was anything but a straight robbery of a suspected drug house,'' Stewart, head of the police department's homicide division, told reporters. Three handguns were used in the shootings, Stewart said. Marshall, Bell and Biggs face the firearms charge. The four defendants were arrested over the weekend. Witnesses told police a woman and two men burst into the reputed crack house, forced the victims to lie on the floor and shot each in the head. The victims were identified as Owens, Carl D. Williams, 21, Bobby Lee Frazier, 16; Robert Lee Hill, 15; LeVon Robinson, 18; and Rodney Lewis, 22. Authorities said it was Detroit's worst mass shooting since June 1971, when seven members of a heroin ring were found shot execution-style in an apartment. Conviction on the felony murder charge is punishable by mandatory life imprisonment. The felony firearms conviction carries a mandatory two-year term.

DOC.HEAD: Mugabe Names Three Whites to Cabinet
DOC.TEXT: President Robert Mugabe reshuffled his Cabinet on Monday, appointing three whites to key posts and announcing one-time rival Joshua Nkomo will become one of two vice presidents. Rancher and businessman Denis Norman takes over the transport and national supplies ministry and Dr. Timothy Stamps was named minister of health, heading a department that must cope with a growing AIDS epidemic. Attorney Chris Andersen, public service minister the past five years, will move to the economically important mines ministry. The moves were part Mugabe's new government. Mugabe's ruling Zimbabwe African National Union (Patriotic Front) party won a landslide victory in national elections March 28-30. The new cabinet was to be sworn in Tuesday. Mugabe trimmed his cabinet from 42 to 38 ministers and deputies. He named as deputy home affairs minister Dumiso Dabengwa, who was accused of plotting to overthrow Mugabe. The home affairs ministry controls the police, its paramilitary units and internal security. Dabengwa, former intelligence chief of Nkomo's Zimbabwe African People's Union, was jailed without trial from 1982 to 1987 under Zimbabwe's sweeping state of emergency regulations. He was released from detention during talks between the two rival parties that led to their merger in December 1987. Nkomo has served in Mugabe's cabinet as a enior minister for rural development but his followers have repeatedly sought to elevate his rank to equal vice president Simon Muzenda, a veteran Mugabe loyalist. Mugabe told reporters the unified party agreed to create the post of a second vice president of equal rank to Muzenda and both would be assigned duties by his own office. Other key announcements included Sydney Sekeremayi remaining in the sensitive post of security minister and Nathan Shamuyarira keeping his position as foreign affairs minister. Observers in Harare said the appointment of three whites appeared to be a gesture of trust in Zimbabwe's 90,000-member white community. Norman was Mugabe's first agriculture minister after the former British colony of Rhodesia became independent Zimbabwe in 1980. But Norman was fired in 1985 because of continued white support then for the right-wing Conservative Alliance party of former Rhodesian prime Minister Ian Smith. Mugabe said he was angered by what he described as racist attitudes among whites removed Norman because of it. In the March elections, the ruling party won 116 of the 119 contested parliamentary seats, including two by white Mugabe supporters. There was no evidence that white voters supported opposition parties although the Conservative Alliance openly supported the opposition Zimbabwe Unity Movement. Norman has been closely associated with an organization raising investment to improve landlocked Zimbabwe's transport links to the sea through neighboring Mozambique. Stamps, a longtime Harare city councilman, inherits the health ministry, which has been accused of inefficiency and mismanagement in its awareness campaign to halt the steep increase in the spread of AIDS.

DOC.HEAD: State Senator Announces Election Challenge to Boggs
DOC.TEXT: A state senator announced Monday that he will run for the seat held by U.S. Rep. Lindy Boggs, D-La., in the nation's only majority black House district represented by a white. Sen. John D. Johnson, 41, a New Orleans Democrat who is black, is the first candidate to enter the Oct. 6 primary. Mrs. Boggs, 74, has not yet declared herself a candidate, but is expected to seek a ninth term. Mrs. Boggs represents Louisiana's 2nd Congressional District, which includes most of New Orleans and is the only majority black House district in the nation represented by a white. Johnson served in the Louisiana House from 1980 to 1987 and took his state Senate seat in 1987. He is the first black from New Orleans to serve in both Houses of the Legislature since Reconstruction.

DOC.HEAD: Popular Party Treasurer Jailed on Bribery Charges
DOC.TEXT: An opposition party treasurer and four others were arrested Monday on bribery charges in connection with an investigation into the real estate and construction industry of this Mediterranean resort. District Court No. 2 Judge Luis Manglano ordered the arrests of Popular Party treasurer Rosendo Naseiro, PP city councilman Salvador Palop and three businessmen. The arrests come days after the Spanish attorney general said he found no grounds for criminal charges following a two-month investigation into alleged influence-peddling by the brother of Socialist Deputy Prime Minister Alfonso Guerra. The conservative Popular Party has repeatedly called for Guerra's ouster for allowing his brother, Juan, to allegedly build a real estate empire while working out of a government office in southern Seville. The so-called ``Juan Guerra scandal'' led to a national debate over the need for stiffer legislation against influence-peddling. The others arrested were Luis Latorre, city architect of Cullera; Luis Janini, regional director of the Dragados construction company; Carlos Benett, provincial head of Huarte construction company; and Jose Balaguer, a local builder. Manglano said the five, being held in the Valencia jail, were to be arraigned Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: UNITA Rebels Offer Immediate Cease-Fire in Angola
DOC.TEXT: Jonas Savimbi's U.S.-backed UNITA rebels on Monday offered an immediate truce and conditional recognition of the Marxist Angolan state in an attempt to restart talks to end the 15-year-old civil war. The rebels proposed direct, closed-door peace talks to be held in Lisbon. It said Portugal _ the former colonial power in the southern African state _ can play a ``pivotal role among Angolans of all political sensibilities.'' Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos had also called for direct talks Friday after meeting with three other African heads of state in the tiny island nation of Sao Tome e Principe. UNITA, or the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, has been fighting the government since shortly after Angola gained independence in 1975. A statement released in Lisbon and signed by Savimbi and other top-ranking rebel officials announced major concessions to the government, but promised even fiercer fighting unless peace is agreed on. UNITA said it stood ``ready to cease hostilities immediately and without preconditions.'' The rebels earlier had demanded government troop withdrawal from positions captured in rebel heartlands in southeastern Angola before agreeing to a truce. The statement said UNITA would recognize the Angolan state on the basis of the Alvor Accords, which in 1975 plotted the course for independence from Portugal via a power-sharing transitional government. The government demanded full recognition of its authority and state institutions as part of its latest peace plan, but Monday's concessions could be enough to tempt the government back to the negotiating table. UNITA pledged in the statement to ``respect all accords signed over the past 15 years by the MPLA government,'' once free and fair elections were held in Angola. Agostinho Neto's MPLA, or Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, prevailed in the struggle over who would lead Angola following independence from Portugal. Neto, who died in 1979, was the first president of independent Angola. The MPLA Party now is led by Neto's successor, dos Santos. Norberto de Castro, the UNITA spokesman in Lisbon, dismissed as ``pure speculation'' news reports after the Sao Tome meeting that peace talks would start this week in Cape Verde. That meeting included presidents dos Santos and Denis Sassou N'guesso of Congo, Omar Bongo of Gabon and host Manuel Pinto da Costa of Sao Tome e Principe. While inviting the government to talks in Lisbon, the rebels reaffirmed their support for President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire, who first brought the two sides together for an initial truce at Gbadolite last June 22. Mobutu's efforts to broker a lasting peace failed after the cease-fire collapsed. Fighting has intensified recently, including rebel bombs and sabotage in the Angolan capital Luanda. Monday's statement said UNITA was ``determined to act with more aggression in Luanda'' until a truce is sealed. ``If there is no peace, we'll hit where it hurts most,'' it said. The rebels also welcomed the ``profound discussion'' of the Angolan conflict by U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze at their meeting last week in Washington. UNITA reportedly receives $50 million or more in U.S. military aid yearly. U.S. officials estimate Soviet support to the Luanda government is much higher.

DOC.HEAD: Police Reach Midships, Find Families Who Died Together
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 22 grafs to UPDATE with 93 bodies removed from ship, captain's quote about firing starting in three spots. Picks up 20th pvs, `Larsen acknowledged...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XLYS1
DOC.TEXT: Police reached the midship cabins of a burned-out ferry Monday and found families who died together at the heart of the fire, the bodies of parents lying over children in a desperate attempt to save them. Inspector Leif Skoglund raised the estimated death toll to 170 in the suspicious weekend blaze that destroyed the Norwegian North Sea ferry Scandinavian Star. He said one victim in every four may have been a child. ``It was incredible,'' he said, groping for words to describe the scene. ``They are so badly burned.'' Police in Oslo, Norway, said the death toll could reach 200. Spokesman Arne Huuse said the figures were unreliable, constantly changing, and a conclusive count might not be available for days. ``We may never find out how many there were because some bodies are in such bad shape that not even dental records may help,'' said Dr. Tom Brokopp, leader of the medical rescue team. In Britain, police began an arson investigation of a fire on the Irish Sea car ferry Norrona that killed one man early Monday and injured 32 people. The Norrona was carrying 297 people from Milford Haven, Wales, to Rosslare, Ireland. Fire also broke out Monday in the engine room of the French ferry Reine Mathilde 14 miles off the Isle of Wight and England's south coast, leaving one passenger dead from a heart attack and a crewman suffering from smoke inhalation. The passenger, 66, was not identified. The blaze aboard the vessel, carrying 675 people from Caen, France, to Portsmouth, England, was extinguished by the crew, the coast guard said, but the vessel lost power and would be towed overnight to Portsmouth. A statement from the Norrona owners, the B and I shipping line of Dublin, said the fire started in two unoccupied sleeping cabins and arson was suspected. A possible link of the Scandinavian Star fire to three ferry fires last year, including one in September that killed two Swedes, was being checked. Fierce heat on the Scandinavian Star prevented police from reaching the midship cabins on the third and fourth decks until nearly 24 hours after the blaze was declared extinguished Sunday. Previous estimates that 500 passengers and crew were aboard were largely guesswork and probably low, Skoglund said, since children under 7 travel free and would not be listed. ``There were a lot of families on board,'' he said. The fire started before dawn Saturday while the ferry was bound from Oslo to Frederikshavn, Denmark. Police said 93 bodies were removed from the wreckage by dusk Monday. Most were sent to Oslo for identification. Most of the victims were Norwegians and Danes. Four British citizens and an American singer were among those missing and presumed dead. The American was identified as Ruth E. Rome, 27, part of a seven-member song-and-dance troupe from New York City. The fire also apparently took the life of Jens C. Hagen, founder of the ship's operating company. ``Things point clearly in the direction of arson,'' said Magnar Aukrust, assistant police chief of Oslo. ``One survivor has explained seeing a person putting fire to inflammable material.'' He did not provide details. ``When a fire starts at three places at the same time and on different decks, it must have been set,'' said the ferry's captain, Hugo Larsen. ``Part of the investigation now is to check thoroughly all details about previous fires on ferries between Norway and Denmark,'' Aukrust told The Associated Press in Oslo. Leila Freival, the Swedish justice minister, told reporters in Lysekil, a small port 240 miles from Stockholm, that a joint Nordic inquiry commission would convene Tuesday in Oslo to investigate the fire. A separate maritime commission is to begin hearings Wednesday in Copenhagen, Denmark. Criticism was leveled at Larsen and his crew, most of them Filipino or Portuguese, for allegedly being unprepared for an emergency. Larsen acknowledged in a radio interview that the crew had not undergone a fire drill; one was scheduled Sunday, he said. The captain denied allegations the fire alarm failed. The first rescue workers to arrive early Saturday told reporters none of the crew members, including the captain, was on board to help. ``We started searching the boat, but then the fire became so powerful that we were forced to start fighting the fire,'' said Svante Carlsson. ``It was unbelievably difficult.'' ``No one had ever seen anything like it before,'' said Inge Ingemansson, a Lysekil fireman. ``It was so hot that the water on board started boiling and the water we sprayed just turned to steam.'' The captain denied that leaving his ship was improper. ``I never failed the passengers,'' he told the TT news agency. ``It was only when the flames were around the bridge and we didn't have a chance to go down to look for more passengers on the deck that I gave the order to leave the ship.'' On Swedish television, Larsen said his critics ``should have been there themselves ... They don't know what they're talking about.''

DOC.HEAD: Traditional Jazz Funeral For Trombonist Louis Nelson
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT cornetist's name to `DeVore,' sted `DeFore.'
DOC.TEXT: Trombonist Louis Nelson, the last member of the original Preservation Hall bands, went to his grave in style Monday in a traditional jazz funeral echoing through the narrow streets of old New Orleans. Nelson, 87, died Thursday, 10 days after a hit-and-run car accident. ``He was really the last of the old crop of trombonists,'' said Harold Dejan, leader of the Olympia Brass Band which led the funeral procession. ``There are plenty of imitators, but he was the last of the good, old crop.'' The Olympia, normally a dozen or so musicians, was joined by about two dozen others for the funeral. Among them were visitors from Australia, Switzerland, and Los Angeles. Butch Thompson, Nelson's pianist on his last tours to Japan, came from St. Paul, with cornetist Charley DeVore. About 500 people gathered outside the funeral home and followed the band as it walked the edge of the French Quarter playing old hymns like ``Sweet Bye And Bye,'' ``What a Friend'' and ``Precious Lord, Take Me Home.'' The entourage turned on Bourbon Street and wound through Nelson's neighborhood of Faubourg Marigny, moving slowly down narrow streets past bungalows and raised cottages to stop at Nelson's house. To the strains of ``Just a Closer Walk with Thee,'' the band separated for the hearse to pass and for each musician to touch goodbye. Two trumpets blew Taps, marking Nelson's tour with the Navy Band. When the tempo lifted for an upbeat version of ``Closer Walk,'' umbrellas _ the traditional ornament of a second line, that joyous street dance after the funeral _ popped open and the mourners started clapping in rhythm. Then abruptly, an unexpected shift to a waltz. It was ``After the Ball,'' one of Nelson's favorites. A couple of lilting courses later, the band drew away the bouncing, shouting crowd with a raucous ``Saints Go Marching In.'' The cortege, left by the crowd and the body ``cut loose'' from earthly friends, made its way to the cemetery, too far away for the crowd to walk. Nelson played many such funerals with many of these musicians. He worked with Dejan when the Olympia cut its first album of parade music in 1956. Nelson preferred the old-time sweet music, with a sliding melodic trombone influenced by the swing era, but he could also play the rough ``tailgate'' style, as he did with the Kid Thomas Valentine band. He was with Kid Thomas when Russell first recorded them in 1949. He and Thomas were still together in 1961 when they were one of the bands that opened Preservation Hall, dedicated to keeping traditional New Orleans music alive. Since then, Nelson played with many bands, including George Lewis, Kid Howard and Billie and DeDe Pierce, and became an international star, making periodic tours of Europe, South America and Japan. At the time of his death, he was playing two nights a week at Preservation Hall and was leading The Louis Nelson All Stars, which was booked for a summer tour of Japan. It would have been his tenth to that country. His last performance was the Saturday before his car was hit by a woman who ran a red light. ``The last night he played, he sounded as good as ever,'' said jazz historian Bill Russell.

DOC.HEAD: Canada Winds Up Debate on Unpopular Consumption Tax
DOC.TEXT: The House of Commons argued into the night Monday over a 7 percent consumption tax that the Conservative government of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney wants passed despite widespread protests. Monday was the final day of debate set for the goods and services tax, which prompted at least two defections from Conservative ranks. The levy would take effect Jan. 1. The Pro-Canada Network, an umbrella organization of unions, churches and social lobby groups, asked Canadians to vote against the tax in a referendum-style protest and in favor of tax reform based on peoples' ability to pay. By 10 p.m. EDT Monday, the lobby's campaign workers reported 2.1 million votes in this nation of 26 million residents asking for the Conservative government to scrap the tax. Government and opposition members of Parliament debating the tax managed to agree on one thing: parliamentary pages, mostly university students studying for exams, could go home at 8 p.m. That meant legislators had to go get their own water and run their own errands while votes on amendments dragged on into the night. Passage of the bill would send it to the Liberal-dominated Senate, which is widely expected to hold another round of hearings across Canada on the legislation.

DOC.HEAD: Publishers
Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for April 2-9:
DOC.HEAD: Editor Chides Colleagues for Becoming Too Comfortable
DOC.TEXT: The nation's press is too comfortable, too well-paid, too much part of the establishment for the country's own good, the president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors told colleagues April 4. ``We often think of ourselves as Davids, fighting the establishment, but the public sees us more and more as status-quo, establishment Goliaths,'' said Loren Ghiglione, publisher and editor of The News of Southbridge, Mass. He cited a poll showing most people think that news media are under the influence of ``powerful people and organizations.'' Ghiglione, addressing the society's 67th annual meeting, proposed that editors each ``adopt an institution that makes us uncomfortable _ a prison, a mental institution, a noisy, overcrowded, big-city school, an AIDS hospital ward _ and try to work in that world or at least understand it.'' He told of his own experiences removing his glasses, his belt, his watch and his shoes as he was admitted to a number of prisons in the past year while taking part in an ASNE study of prison journalism. Each time, he said, he vowed not to do it again, but ``in an era of law-and-order, electric-chair politics, I know I should go back.'' ``While we say we comfort the afflicted and afflict the comfortable, we need to guard against looking at the world increasingly through the eyes of the comfortable,'' Ghiglione said, arguing that newspapermen have lost touch with their readers. ``One poll showed that half of newspaper journalists earn over $40,000 a year, but only 18 percent of the public does,'' he said. ``And many of us live in almost exclusively white, middle-class worlds and send our children to private or suburban public schools.'' He argued that the world needs ``editors who will fight.'' Another speaker, author and prize-winning reporter David Halberstam, told the editors that the demands by owners of newspapers and newspaper company stocks for ever-rising profits are putting newspapers in jeopardy. ``There's a question of how much water you can bring out of the stone,'' Halberstam said. ``At what point are you taking out more than you're putting in?'' ``I think the threat to us is not from the outside, not from the government, not from television. It is from ourselves.''
DOC.HEAD: Homosexual Staffers Decry Coverage of Gay Issues
DOC.TEXT: In the first survey of its kind, homosexual members of the staffs of American newspapers said their papers do a poor job with news about gays or of concern to them. The gay journalists said their papers treat them fairly and give them opportunities to advance, but rarely call on their insights into gay lifestyles in the same way black reporters are asked to help guide coverage of black issues. And some newsrooms ``harbor a palpable undercurrent of bias,'' a summary of the findings concludes. One respondent commented that her colleagues who ``make snide homophobic comments and jokes'' are ``the same people who write those sensitive stories and editorials!'' The survey was made public April 4 at the annual meeting of the American Society of Newspaper Editors. It was undertaken at the request of outgoing ASNE President Loren Ghiglione, who asked whether ``anti-gay discrimination infects today's newsrooms.'' When word of the survey circulated, 205 homosexual members of the staffs of U.S. newspapers volunteered to respond. Three-fifths said they were openly gay, and two-thirds signed their questionnaires. Ninety-two percent said they knew other people on the staff who were gay and the majority of them estimated that fewer than 20 percent of the homosexuals on their papers were openly gay. Many experts estimate that one American in 10 is gay. ``Why does it matter?'' asked Leroy F. Aarons, an executive of The Tribune of Oakland, Calif., who coordinated the project. He said the subject is important because ``more than ever before, editors are grappling with a swirl of social and political currents around alternative lifestyle issues.'' ``Domestic partners legislation, gay adoption, anti-discrimination laws, fundamentalist attacks on the gay lifestyle, morality and public responsibility and, of course, the still-raging AIDS epidemic have brought once-easily ignored issues into demanding focus,'' he said. The respondents gave especially low ratings to the way their papers treated gay lifestyles, community events and politics, and only slightly better ratings to treatment of violence against gays, civil rights issues and legislation. As for terminology, nearly a third said they found the term ``homosexual'' to be prejudiced, explaining that it refers narrowly to sex whereas the term ``gay'' refers to lifestyles or issues. Aarons ended his report to the editors by publicly revealing his own sexual orientation. I a paragraph scribbled at the end of his typewritten text and read hurriedly in a choked voice, he said: ``I want you to know that the doing of this report has had tremendous impact on gay and lesbian journalists across the nation. It has given them hope and new optimism. It has enhanced their respect for this organization. I, as an editor and a gay man, am proud of ASNE.''
DOC.HEAD: Court May Have Opened Door to Bell Electronic Information
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Court of Appeals says it agrees with a lower court that the seven Bell operating companies cannot enter the long-distance or telephone equipment businesses. But the April 3 ruling reopens the possibility that the so-called Baby Bells can sell electronic information services to homes and offices, a prospect opposed by newspaper groups. The decision means that U.S. District Judge Harold Greene must consider anew whether the Bell companies may be allowed to develop so-called ``electronic Yellow Pages,'' allowing consumers to shop and bank _ among other possibilities _ via cheap, easy-to-use video terminals. A prototype, government-operated system in France called Minitel already serves 5 million homes and offices and offers 8,000 different services. The three-judge appeals panel found that Greene ruled correctly when, in his 1987 ``triennial review'' of the American Telephone & Telegraph Co. antitrust settlement, he sustained the original order barring the seven spinoff companies from competing with their one-time parent in the long-distance and telephone manufacturing arenas. But appeals judges Abner Mikva, Harry Edwards and Laurence Silberman faulted Greene's legal reasoning when, as part of that same review, he only partly opened the door for the operating companies to expand into computer-based information services. Greene allowed the Bell companies to offer computer gateways and access menus for databases and services offered by other companies _ but not to generate those services themselves. That precluded them from pursuing a U.S. version of Minitel.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Would Require Editorial Board Members To Disclose Finances
DOC.TEXT: Despite warnings that it violates the U.S. Constitution's First Amendment, a Florida House panel April 4 narrowly approved a bill requiring newspaper editorial board members to publicly disclose their finances. The bill, sponsored by Rep. Bruce McEwan, R-Orlando, would also make it a second-degree misdemeanor for a newspaper to publish any editorial unless it is signed by the author. A subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee approved the measure on a 4-3 vote. It would include editorial board members in a present law requiring state employees to file financial disclosure forms by July 1 every year or face a possible $5,000 fine. One of the 32 co-sponsors of the bill, Rep. Elvin Martinez, D-Tampa, said the measure is not a vendetta against newspapers but rather an attempt to shed more light on their role as public opinion leaders. ``The real molder of public opinion is the press,'' Martinez said. ``They can take you and beat you and do anything to you, and they're immune. I think people have a right to know if their views are jaundiced by some financial interest.'' Barry Richard, attorney for the Florida Press Association, said the measure clearly infringes on the First Amendment's guarantee of a free press and would never stand up in court. ``The only justification for it is that the person (editorialist) makes public comment,'' he said. ``Are we next going to include the League of Women's Voters and other groups in this category?'' McEwan said his intention is not to violate the First Amendment. ``There's nothing in this bill to prohibit freedom of the press,'' he said. Rep. John Cosgrove, D-Miami and chairman of the Court Systems, Probate and Consumer Law subcommittee, said some lawmakers supported the bill simply to take a stab at the press. ``As much as I might want to get in there and make a little jab at editorial boards, I think the greater freedom of expression is more important,'' Cosgrove said. The legislation next moves to the full House Judiciary Committee, which did not immediately set a date to consider it. McEwan said he was optimistic of approval. Richard was not so sure. ``It's press-bashing,'' he said. ``It depends on how many people are willing to put their names on something that's blatantly unconstitutional.''
DOC.HEAD: Union Chief Sues Daily News Over Remark
DOC.TEXT: The president of the mailers union sued the Daily News, one of its officers and its Chicago-based parent for $30 million on April 5, claiming they had damaged his reputation as a labor leader. The libel suit, filed by George McDonald, president of the mailers union and the Allied Printing Trades Council, names John T. Sloan, the News' vice president for human resources, and the Tribune Co. It seeks $5 million in compensatory damages and $25 million in punitive damages. The 10 unions in the council are involved in tense negotiations with the News over new contracts; the old contracts expired March 30. Sloan said he had not received the suit and thus had no comment. According to the suit, McDonald enjoyed a national reputation ``as a dedicated, honest, reputable, loyal and highly competent labor leader.'' That reputation was damaged, the suit said, by remarks Sloan made to the media on March 15 that McDonald gave away work to another union that traditionally was performed by the mailers union. In a related development, Local 3 of The Newspaper Guild asked that News Publisher James Hoge negotiate directly with the Guild because the News' negotiators were not familiar with the territory and the talks were proceeding slowly. Robert Ballow, a Nashville, Tenn.-based attorney, has been the News' lead negotiator. Sloan said he did not get an immediate response to the request.
DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Sues Union Official Who Filed Libel Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: The San Jose Mercury News on March 29 filed a lawsuit against the former chief of the San Jose hotel workers union, claiming his 1983 libel lawsuit against the newspaper was a violation of free press rights. The newspaper claimed the lawsuit filed by Frank Marolda damaged its reputation and is asking for $1 million in damages and recovery of ``a significant amount'' for legal fees. ``It's a combination of abuse of the process and malicious prosecution,'' said Edward Davis, attorney for the newspaper. ``The union's lawsuit was designed to send out a message to everyone else that if you write a negative story about the union, you're going to be in trouble.'' In late 1987, a Santa Clara County judge threw out Marolda's lawsuit against the paper and two of its reporters. Marolda, then president of a Hotel and Restaurant Employees and Bartenders Union local in San Jose, and the union objected to an article that appeared Oct. 24, 1982. The story described Marolda's administration of the union and his problems connected to a U.S. Senate investigation of labor corruption. The newspaper's suit alleges that Marolda and the union ``brought the action for the purpose of harassing, annoying, embarrassing, and otherwise oppressing the Mercury News.''
DOC.HEAD: Bee Victim of April Fool's Gag on `Victim's' Birthday
DOC.TEXT: The Fresno Bee says it was the victim of an April Fool's Day trick by someone who falsely reported a man's death. ``I thought it was a joke until I started getting phone calls,'' said Vern Elwood Elston, whose obituary ran April 1, his 38th birthday. ``Then I realized how serious it was. It didn't go over too well with my family.'' The Bee said the obituary was delivered March 31 on a form it furnishes to funeral homes. Managing Editor Donald Slinkard said the newspaper will strengthen its procedures to avoid a repeat of such a hoax.

DOC.HEAD: Court Orders IRS To Let Newspaper Co. Depreciate Subscriber Lists
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper company can depreciate paid subscriber lists acquired through the purchase of other publishing interests, a federal judged ruled April 3. The ruling paves the way for the Newhouse family-owned Morning Ledger Co. of Newark to depreciate $71 million on amended tax returns, said Donald A. Robinson, the Newark attorney who represented the Newhouse family. Robinson said the company also will collect an undetermined amount of interest from the Internal Revenue Service on the previously disallowed depreciation deductions. The Newark Morning Ledger Co., owner of The Star-Ledger of Newark, sued the IRS after the agency refused to let the company depreciate subscriber lists for eight Michigan papers it acquired in 1977. Depreciating the lists would decrease the company's taxable income. During the hearing, Morning Ledger attorneys argued that subscriber lists should be treated like tangible _ and hence depreciable _ assets because they are used in the taxpayer's business for a limited period of time. U.S. District Judge H. Lee Sarokin agreed with the plaintiffs that paid subscriber lists are of limited value because subscribers die, move and cancel subscriptions. Sarokin found that even if the circulation of a newspaper remains constant, the publisher spends a substantial amount of time and money in advertising and subscription drives to replace lost customers. The government argued that subscriber lists are an intangible asset that cannot be separated from the company's ``goodwill.'' If the company were given the depreciation allowance, any business with paying customers could claim depreciation by saying the customers have a limited useful life, Gregory Hrebiniak, a lawyer with the Justice Department's tax division, argued. The Morning Ledger company acquired Booth Newspapers, Inc., of Ann Arbor, Mich., in 1977. The group was worth about $314 million and had a combined circulation of 460,000, according to the legal opinion. Booth's eight newspapers in Michigan were The Ann Arbor News, The Bay City Times, The Flint Journal, The Grand Rapids Press, Jackson Citizen Patriot, Kalamazoo Gazette, The Muskegon Chronicle and Saginaw News. The Morning Ledger's parent company is Advance Publications Inc., a publishing company owned by the Newhouse family.
DOC.HEAD: Times Herald Editor, in Court, Denounces `Features Grab' by Rival
DOC.TEXT: The editor of the Dallas Times Herald said April 6 his counterpart at the rival Dallas Morning News ``stalked for years'' the features that have become the center of a $33 million antitrust suit. ``The features were extremely important but it was the act itself that was deplorable,'' Times Herald Editor Roy Bode said of a ``features grab'' by the Morning News and its editor, Burl Osborne. Bode's remarks drew immediate objections from Morning News attorneys. Osborne denied the characterization. ``I have no recollection of ever aggressively pursuing their package,'' he said during testimony as a hostile witness called by Times Herald attorneys. The Times Herald is seeking the $33 million and unspecified punitive damages from the Morning News and parent company A.H. Belo Corp. A joint venture between Belo and Universal Press Syndicate Inc. left the Times Herald without comics and columns that included Dear Abby, Erma Bombeck and Doonesbury _ all distributed by Kansas City-based UPS. Belo and Universal Press announced their venture, Universal Belo, to develop syndicate features for television use. Osborne said the shift of the entire UPS package to his newspaper was a condition required by the syndicate. The Times Herald alleges the venture and the transfer of the features violated antitrust laws and was an attempt to create a monopoly and drive the Times Herald out of business. The trial began April 2 and is expected to last at least a month.
DOC.HEAD: Monthly N.J. Sports Tabloid To Debut
DOC.TEXT: A monthly tabloid covering amateur sports in New Jersey is scheduled to debut by the end of April, its publisher said. Sports in New Jersey will cover over-30 softball, road races, junior wrestling, the Garden State Games and high school and college sports, publisher Jan Michael Pero said April 2. ``Basically, if it's non-professional, we'll cover it,'' Pero said. ``Our research showed there's a real market for this kind of news.'' The newspaper and its editorial staff of four will rely heavily on story contributions from private contractors. Pero said he hopes to publish 10,000 copies of the first issue. Subscriptions will cost $18 a year.

DOC.HEAD: Chronicle Loses Bid To Block Ad
DOC.TEXT: A judge on April 2 ruled that Attorney General John Van de Kamp may use San Francisco Chronicle articles in a TV commercial for his gubernatorial campaign despite the paper's objection that such use implied an endorsement. U.S. District Judge John Vukasin denied a Chronicle request to bar use of the newspaper's name in the commercial. ``I suspect it (the ad) comes dangerously close to creating a false impression that that is the Chronicle speaking,'' Vukasin said. But he said the Van de Kamp campaign properly identified itself as the sponsor of the commercial and was clearly quoting the Chronicle as a source of information. Neil Shapiro, a lawyer for the Chronicle, said the newspaper still may sue for damages. The ad attacks former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein, Van de Kamp's rival for the Democratic nomination, over her management of the city. Each subject is illustrated by a Chronicle clipping about a controversy. The paper's name appears several times at the bottom of the screen. The Chronicle sued to stop the use of its name and masthead, saying the ad violated the newspaper's trademark and was meant to mislead. ``If we wish to endorse someone, we will, but we don't want somebody stealing the endorsement,'' Shapiro told the judge. Saying some angry readers had telephoned the paper to complain about its apparent endorsement, the lawyer declared that the ad ``confuses people into believing the Chronicle supports, endorses or even prepared'' it. But Kantor said Van de Kamp had an obligation, as well as a constitutional right, to quote the Chronicle as the source of material in his commercial.
DOC.HEAD: Reuters Reporters Withhold Bylines
DOC.TEXT: U.S.-based journalists at the news agency Reuters withheld their bylines from stories for three days to protest management contract proposals. The byline strike, which began April 2, was organized by The Newspaper Guild, which represents about 500 Reuters employees around the country, including 150 journalists. Their contract expired Feb. 28. ``We hope this action will impress management with our anger that a company making so much money wants to severely cut the benefits and pay of those who are crucial to Reuters' success,'' said Barry Lipton, president of the Guild local. Lipton said the company's offer of a 2.5 percent raise would be offset by a proposed weekly increase of work time from 33.75 hours to 37.5 hours, with no overtime until after 40 hours. The company has also proposed having employees pay for part of the cost of health insurance. Reuters, in a statement, cited the rising cost of health care and said the company's benefits ``will remain competitive by all industry standards.''
DOC.HEAD: Hourly Newspaper Launched Aboard Pan Am Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: The Latest News, a 24-page tabloid billed as the nation's first hourly newspaper, made its debut April 2 on a mid-afternoon flight from Washington to New York. The paper will be available on Pan Am shuttles originating at National Airport from 3:30 to 6:30 p.m., on the theory that corporate passengers have been starved all day for news. The paper is updated hourly with copy from United Press International and States News Service to provide breaking news, business developments and weather reports. Advertising is sold by Financial World magazine. The partners plan to expand distribution to Boston and New York after a test period. They also are considering heavily traveled air routes between Los Angeles and San Francisco, Chicago and St. Louis, and Houston and Dallas. ``A radio station in print'' is how editor and publisher Leland Schwartz described the venture in a front-page letter to readers in the first edition of the first issue. ``There are critics who think we're crazy,'' Schwartz admitted in the article. But he noted that the same people returning to New York ``were so hungry when you came down to Washington this morning, the shuttle was a sea of newspapers.'' The maiden 3:30 p.m. edition contained front-page articles on the New York and Tokyo stock markets and a list of headlines to stories on inside pages. Featured inside were news briefs, sports briefs, 1 p.m. stock data and the latest filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, as well as short stories on the top news of the day.

DOC.HEAD: Connecticut Morning and Afternoon Papers Merge
DOC.TEXT: The Waterbury Republican-American appeared April 2 as the consolidation of the afternoon Waterbury American and its morning sibling, the Waterbury Republican. The decision to merge the papers, owned by American-Republican Inc., was announced in February. An editorial published in the March 31 Republican said, ``Publishing and delivering two newspapers each day takes a great deal of time, effort, talent and money ... Combining our resources, we are confident we can produce a much better newspaper.''
DOC.HEAD: Landmark Community Newspapers Buys Kentucky Weekly
DOC.TEXT: Landmark Community Newspapers Inc. has purchased The Spencer Magnet, its 16th newspaper in Kentucky. Landmark's president, Larry R. Coffey, closed the deal on March 30 with Laura Brock, widow of the late Claude Brock. The purchase price for the 2,300-circulation weekly was not disclosed. Brock and his wife bought the paper in 1948, when its circulation was only 150. He died in 1987. Mrs. Brock said she plans to retire and travel. She will serve as publisher emeritus and a Landmark consultant. Landmark owns all the surrounding county-seat weeklies and 34 other newspapers in 11 states.
DOC.HEAD: Western Publishing Buys Lexington Weeklies
DOC.TEXT: Western Publishing Co. of North Platte has agreed to buy the Dawson County Herald and the Lexington Clipper, the editor-publisher of both newspapers said March 30. Lexington Publishing Inc. President James Kelly said he will remain in charge of both weekly papers after the transfer of ownership, about May 1. Western Publishing owns and operates the North Platte Telegraph and the Scottsbluff Star-Herald.
DOC.HEAD: The Meridian Star Sold to American Publishing Co.
DOC.TEXT: James B. Skewes annouced April 2 that he has agreed to sell The Meridian Star and The Newton Record to American Publishing Co. of West Frankfort, Ill. Skewes' family has owned the daily Star since 1922 and weekly Record since 1972. He will retire as editor and publisher of The Star when the ownership change becomes effective. No terms were announced concerning the sale, which is expected to be complete by May 1. American Publishing, a subsidiary of Hollinger Inc., of Toronto, owns 186 publications, including 63 daily newspapers, all in the United States.
DOC.HEAD: Oklahoma Free-Circulation Daily Acquires Alva Review-Courier
DOC.TEXT: The Alva Review-Courier has been sold by Hammell Newspapers of Oklahoma Inc. to the Alva Newsgram, a free-circulation daily. The April 2 announcement did not list specifics of the agreement. The Newsgram was started by Lynn and Marione Martin in 1970 as a promotional tool for KALV radio, which the couple purchased in 1969. They retained the paper after selling the station two years ago. The magazine-sized Newsgram will continue unchanged four days per week and will publish jointly with the daily Review-Courier on Thursday and Sunday.
DOC.HEAD: Yale Students Launch Magazine for New Haven Schoolchildren
DOC.TEXT: Splatter!, a new low-budget children's magazine, was launched April 2 by two Yale students seeking to give New Haven youngsters a fun way to learn creative writing. The inaugural edition, printed with a copying machine, included short stories, poems, drawings, plays and essays written by students from area middle schools as well as by some Yale students. Copies were distributed free to middle school students. Co-founders and editors Jessica Plumb and Jessica Reich, both sophomores at Yale, said they hoped the publication would become a permanent part of the university's outreach programs. Dozens of students submitted articles for the first issue, ranging from a short story about a girl who was granted three wishes to an account of life in a drug-plagued neighborhood.
DOC.HEAD: The Times' Letters Editor Reflects on 11 Years at the Mailbag
DOC.TEXT: This is not a great age of correspondence, says the recently retired editor of The Times' venerable letters column, though the mailbags still bulge with opinions both profound and eccentric. ``There are many people who simply do not know how to put words onto paper; they have to become so used to talking on the telephone or dictating into machines and having them tidied up by their secretaries,'' Leon Pilpel said in an interview published April 4 by The Times. ``Of the 300 letters a day, only about 8 percent are publishable. I am not talking about matters of syntax, but about importance, or (fitness). ``Many of them are pretty mundane, although frequently half a dozen not very brilliant ones can be made into a very good correspondence indeed _ with a bit of judicious editing, and the specific approval of the letter-writer.'' Great debates have been waged in the sober letters columns of The Times, leavened with whimsical bits of English life, such as the sighting of the first cuckoo of spring. Pilpel, who is taking up new duties as a deputy ombudsman at the paper, joined The Times 40 years ago and became letters editor in 1979.

DOC.HEAD: Paper Barred From Concert After Column Flap
DOC.TEXT: A representative of Paul McCartney was angered by a column in The Arizona Republic critical of the musician's work and ordered the newspaper banned from an April 4 news conference and concert. The Republic's writers were able to cover the concert because the paper had purchased tickets for the sold-out performance at Arizona State University. But the ban meant the newspaper was unable to photograph either the evening concert or a news conference before it. The newspaper obtained photographs of the concert from The Associated Press. Republic staff member Dennis Love, who'd written the column, was barred from entering the news conference by Geoff Baker, McCartney's tour publicist. The Republic said it did not know whether McCartney approved or even knew of the ban. ``Dennis Love's column was merely an effort to provide the diversity of opinion that is in the best tradition of good journalism,'' said Robert Franken, a Republic assistant managing editor. ``We've provided a lot of positive publicity about this concert, including an entire section last month, and we're frankly surprised that one writer's personal opinion would be reason to exclude all Republic coverage. We don't see how that helps anyone.'' Love's column, published April 3, questioned McCartney's talents and abilities since the Beatles' breakup, contended that his post-Beatles music is ``schlock,'' and added that it is possible he was not a major contributor to the Beatles' success.
DOC.HEAD: Nine Officers Disciplined for Harassing Reporters
DOC.TEXT: Nine Norwalk police officers have been disciplined for harassing journalists covering the court appearance of a fellow officer charged in an accidental shooting death, the city's police chief said April 3. Officers allegedly bumped, butted and tossed a snowball at reporters and photographers outside Norwalk Superior Court on Jan. 4, when Officer David Russo appeared on a misdemeanor charge of unlawful discharge of a weapon. Officer Michael Price was put on departmental probation for six months and ordered to forfeit two vacation days for throwing the snowball, Police Chief Carl LaBianca said. The eight other officers received verbal reprimands for being at the courthouse without permission. Russo accidentally shot 19-year-old Ernest Gainor in the back with a shotgun after an Oct. 26 car chase. Gainor later died. Russo was sentenced to one year probation on the misdemeanor charge. Steve Meyerson, a cameraman for Cablevision News 12 in Norwalk, complained that officers hip-checked him as he carried about 72 pounds of camera equipment. Photographer Brian Poulter of The Advocate newspaper of Stamford said one officer bumped his chest against his. LaBianca said he considered the nine officers' length of service and service records in deciding the disciplinary measures.
DOC.HEAD: Voters Protest Story About Candidate's Taxes
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper story about a school board candidate's unpaid property taxes drew protesters to a sidewalk outside the Eau Claire Leader-Telegram on March 29 and 30. Demonstrators said the article was a calculated attack on David Flynn, who was running for re-election to the school board. Flynn lost in the April 3 race. Four people picketed the newspaper March 29 and five March 30. James Price of Eleva, who organized the picketing, said Flynn was typical of many Wisconsin farmers unable to keep up with taxes. Price said the newspaper should have waited until after the election to run the story. An article March 28 said Flynn owed Eau Claire County $18,920 in property taxes and owed $3,383 in back taxes in neighboring Dunn County. Editor Eugene Ringhand said the newspaper discovered information for the story earlier in the week. ``The voters place an enormous amount of trust in public officials,'' he said. ``Reporting information that could bear on that trust is necessary for voters to make an informed choice and weigh the value of that information against the potential benefit of a candidate.''

DOC.HEAD: Blacks Accuse Newspaper of Racism
DOC.TEXT: About 100 pickets marched in front of the Philadelphia Daily News on April 4 to protest what they they called racism on the part of the newspaper and negative coverage of the black community. The paper's editor denied the claims, pointing to the Daily News' record of minority hiring and support for the community. The marchers, including city Councilman Lucien E. Blackwell, a likely candidate for mayor in 1991, asked blacks to cease buying the newspaper. They said the newspaper overemphasizes crime news involving black people; presents a distorted picture of blacks in the city; ignores positive news involving blacks; and is overly aggressive and racially motivated in covering black officials. ``We're not trying to shut it down,'' said attorney Charles Bowser, who led the march. ``We're not trying to change the paper. We just want to get African-Americans to stop buying it. If they can sell it to other people and keep going, fine.'' Daily News Editor Zachary Stalberg denied the charges. ``I reject completely the idea of the Daily News as racist, and I particularly object to the notion that our political or government coverage is biased in any way,'' Stalberg said. In a note to readers, Stalberg said the Daily News has attracted the largest minority audience of any big city paper in the nation. He also noted the paper's record in hiring and promotion, and its 1988 endorsement of the Rev. Jesse Jackson for president. ``The News has made some blood enemies. That is because it is visceral and two-fisted and enjoys feasting on phonies and bungling politicians,'' Stalberg wrote. He also said Bowser had been offered space in the Daily News to state his case, but failed to take advantage of it.
DOC.HEAD: Three Baltic News Agencies Create News Service
DOC.TEXT: The news agencies of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia have agreed to create a news service called Baltija, the official Soviet news agency Tass reported April 5. The agency intends to transmit reports ``that are not influenced by any party, organization or public movement,'' Tass said. Such cooperation among the three Soviet Baltic republics has been relatively rare, although some economists predict if they gain full independence from the Soviet Union they will band together in an economic bloc. The Latvian agency Leta, Lithuanian agency Elta and Estonian agency Eta signed the agreement Thursday to establish a joint information bureau, Tass reported. The service will function both inside and outside the Baltic region, Tass said.
DOC.HEAD: Former Underground Publication Becomes Independent Daily
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia's best-read underground newspaper published its first issue as a full-fledged daily April 2 and pledged to stay independent. Despite police harassment, Lidove Noviny (People's News) had circulated monthly since December 1987. It carried frequent contributions from such notable former dissidents as Vaclav Havel, now Czechoslovakia's president, and Jiri Dienstbier, now foreign minister. The first daily issue, consisting of eight pages and a press run of 250,000 copies, included articles about Lithuania's independence drive and German reunification plans. The paper will remain politically and commercially independent, Editor Jiri Ruml said. ``There were offers from press tycoons like Robert Maxwell and Rupert Murdoch to buy stock in our paper, but we rejected them,'' he said. ``We are not going to accept any capital from anyone.''
DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Demands Protection From Drug Traffickers
DOC.TEXT: Drug traffickers killed up to 10 police officers and wounded at least eight April 2 and 3 in Colombia's cocaine capital of Medellin, and a leading Bogota newspaper left its editorial column blank to protest threats from the traffickers. The government of President Virgilio Barco pressed on in its U.S.-backed war against the drug dealers. It announced it would soon extradite three more drug suspects, including a congressman, El Tiempo newspaper reported. The attacks came after the Medellin cartel threatened to resume killing government officials, judges, policemen and the owners of Colombia's second-largest newspaper, El Espectador of Bogota. On April 3, the morning daily said in a front-page statement it would suspend its entire editorial column until the government gives the paper adequate protection. The editorial column, often filled with denunciations of traffickers, was a strip of blank, white paper two columns wide and 12 inches long. The Medellin cartel killed El Espectador's publisher, Guillermo Cano, in a submachine-gun attack in 1987. In the past four months, six El Espectador employees have been killed by hit squads.

DOC.HEAD: Students Protest Comic's Violent Fantasy
DOC.TEXT: A student comic strip depicting a violent sexual fantasy is ``going too far,'' says the chairman of a group of University of Illinois women. The Chancellor's Committee on the Status of Women is urging readers of The Daily Illini, which carried the comic strip, to cancel their subscriptions. ``We don't want sex and violence confused in anyone's mind,'' said committee chairwoman Michele Shoresman. ``We've got to stop this.'' Managing Editor Dan Bernard defended the cartoonist, saying, ``His goal definitely was to promote awareness of insincerity.'' The cartoon strip appeared over two days March 27 and March 28 and was drawn by student Mark Peaslee. The first strip depicts a conversation between a man and woman over exams. Another balloon depicts the man's thoughts, reading ``Censored thoughts of degradation, pain and eventual death.'' After the man leaves, the woman says, ``What a nice guy.'' The second strip shows another conversation and this time focuses on the woman's thoughts, reading, ``Hmm... Wonder what you'd look like...'' and goes on to describe a fantasy involving bondage and mutilation. ``What they did is dangerous because the sarcasm didn't work,'' said committee member Mary Ellen O'Shaughnessey, assistant dean of students.
DOC.HEAD: Iowa State Journalist Demoted for Comments on Coeds
DOC.TEXT: An Iowa State University student journalist who wrote that ISU coeds are big and strong but not very good-looking will keep his column but was removed from the paper's editorial board. Reed Landberg, editor of the Iowa State Daily, said April 2 the demotion means columnist David Young, a junior from Omaha, Neb., no longer will write news stories for the paper. Landberg said Young may continue writing his ``Facing Reality'' column but that the uncomplimentary view of Iowa State women in a recent column forced the paper to take disciplinary action. Young wrote that Iowa State coeds are ``a breed which has led to the coining of such terms as `Moo U' and the `Iowa Hip Disease.' '' He also said the coeds are muscle-bound. ``Unless a male student has a sick desire for farm women who are bigger and stronger than the East German Women's Olympic Team, he is likely out of luck,'' he wrote. Landberg said Young was one of the paper's best writers but that many readers assume his writing is biased because of the column. ``The mistake in printing Young's last column was not solely his own,'' Landberg wrote April 3, saying he had an advance copy of the column. ``It was mine, too, and I must stand behind him for that.''
DOC.HEAD: Winning Teen Essay Disqualified for Copying `Calvin and Hobbes'
DOC.TEXT: The winner of the Florida Young Writers Contest was disqualified after it was learned that the beginning of his winning story was an exact copy of three panels of a ``Calvin and Hobbes'' comic strip. Jeffrey Wright, 17, a senior at Fletcher High School, said April 2 the plagiarism was unintentional. He said he keeps notebooks filled with story ideas and sometimes jots down passages he reads. ``If someone took something of mine, I'd be upset. It's wrong. I know I owe everyone an apology,'' Wright said. The story, titled, ``Tracer Bullet,'' describes a child playing detective while cleaning his room. Tracer Bullet also was the name of the character in the ``Calvin and Hobbes'' strip. The first four paragraphs of Wright's story had appeared in The Florida Times-Union on April 2 with the announcement that he had won, and a caller pointed out the duplication to Mike Clark, the newspaper's reader advocate. Wright also lost a $1,000 scholarship to the University of North Florida, which sponsored the contest along with the Times-Union.

DOC.HEAD: Restauranteur or Restaurateur?
DOC.TEXT: Restaurateur by any spelling, whether with an ``n'' or without, is not a favorite word of keepers of the language, according to a survey released April 3. But if they have to use the word for keeper of a restaurant, they'll take it without the ``n,'' said respondents to the 12th English-language usage survey by the Indiana University School of Journalism. ``Many in the survey found it stuffy no matter how it is spelled, though its use is patently expanding in this country,'' wrote Professor Richard L. Tobin. The 10-question survey was mailed to 100 newspaper copy editors and 50 magazine editors in the United States and Canada and got a 60 percent return, Tobin said. ``The consensus throughout this year's survey was mighty close to unanimous in almost every example, which just goes to show that copyreaders know what they're doing and do it like the sterling language-usage guardians they are put there to be,'' the survey said. Nearly all editors agree ``percent'' should be one word and not two. Most editors agreed the region Deep South should be uppercase. Most copy desks caught the misuse of ``tremblor'' instead of ``temblor,'' in a line from a Maryland newspaper reporting a Palm Springs earthquake. Most changed ``forego'' to ``forgo'' in the sentence: ``The university decided to forego the traditional faculty banquet because of the financial situation.'' Copy desks were asked whether ``gibe'' or ``jibe'' was correct in the following sentence: ``Three suspects were taken to police headquarters but detectives announced later that their stories didn't gibe.'' The verdict was almost unanimous that ``jibe'' was correct. ``Complacent'' was correctly preferred over ``complaisant'' in an item saying a soccer team had become ``complaisant'' after four straight victories. Editors chose ``theretofore'' over ``hitherto'' in the sentence: ``In 1864, President Lincoln spent the hitherto unheard of sum of $3,000,000 on naval construction.'' Almost no one chose ``peddle'' over ``pedal'' in the final question, which came from a Florida sports page: ``When you're riding a bicycle you use the brake and the peddle with caution on today's highways.''
DOC.HEAD: Reporter Will Not Have To Testify Before Grand Jury
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors dropped efforts to subpoena a Statesman-Journal reporter for grand jury testimony April 4 after the newspaper's lawyer cited the Oregon Shield Law. The Marion County grand jury investigating the killing of state director of corrections Michael Francke will be able to review the newspaper's stories, however, said Michael McClinton, the paper's lawyer. The shield law protects reporters from having to reveal their sources and unpublished material. ``The protection of confidences obtained by investigative reporters is fundamental to a free press and must not be sacrificed regardless of the circumstances of any individual case,'' McClinton said. The grand jury had subpoenaed Steven P. Jackson and his notes from interviews with a figure in the case.
DOC.HEAD: Tribal Newspaper Seeks Rule Change
DOC.TEXT: The newspaper of the Seminole tribe said April 4 it is challenging a Pulitzer Prize rule that limits entries for the journalism prize to newspapers that publish at least once a week. An entry submitted by The Seminole Tribune on new evidence in the case of a convicted mass murderer was disqualified last year because the tribal newspaper appears twice a month, Editor Twyla Perkins said. The United Southern and Eastern Tribes, an Indian group representing 18 tribes in the Southeast, has called for a rule change, and the board of the Native American Press Association has been asked to do the same, Perkins said. ``We're disqualified because of that rule,'' she said. ``There's nothing we could do to get ourselves back in there.'' Pulitzer awards administrator Robert Christopher said the line has to be drawn somewhere on the frequency of publication, and there are no current plans for a change. James Richardson served more than two decades in state prison in the killing of his seven children before evidence uncovered by Tribune reporter Pete Gallagher and free-lance writer Charles Flowers led to his release. The reporters' work received widespread attention after The Miami Herald published their story in its ``Tropic'' Sunday magazine in December 1988.
DOC.HEAD: Skowhegan Weekly Newspaper Closes
DOC.TEXT: After several name changes and 25 years of losses, the weekly Skowhegan Reporter closed its doors April 3.
