Publisher Howard James said he was closing the Skowhegan Reporter and laying off four full-time workers and one part-time worker without producing a final edition for Thursday, April 5, the day the paper came out each week. ``This isn't The New York Times,'' he said. ``It's just a small paper in central Maine that for 25 years has never had a profit. At some point, you have to close it.'' James said he owned the 150-year-old paper for the past 10 years and consistently lost money, despite a recent change from tabloid to broadsheet. The 3,000-circulation weekly was previously known as the Independent Reporter and the Somerset County Reporter.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Charges Dropped, Replaced by State Prosecution
DOC.TEXT: A freelance journalist April 6 pleaded innocent to state charges related to computer hacking after U.S. prosecutors decided not to try him for allegedly attempting to steal information from a TV tabloid show. The reporter, Stuart Goldman, 44, was charged with seven felony counts of violating a California Penal Code section prohibiting unauthorized access to computers. Goldman allegedly used another person's access code to enter a computer used by the Fox Television show ``A Current Affair'' at the network's Hollywood television station, KTTV, said Sandi Gibbons, spokeswoman for the prosecutor's office. Information was allegedly taken out of the computer through a telephone connection and stored in Goldman's home computer. Last month, federal prosecutors filed an affidavit in U.S. District Court in New York stating that the reporter had tried to gain access to computer files concerning news stories that Fox reporters were working on. U.S. prosecutors would not say why the New York case was dropped. A Fox spokesman, Dennis Petroskey, would not comment on the case. Goldman's attorney, Alan Rubin, said he had persuaded the U.S. attorney's office in New York to drop the federal charges there. Goldman briefly worked for ``A Current Affair'' as well as ``Hard Copy,'' a competitor's show. He has written articles for National Review magazine, the Los Angeles Times and other publications. If convicted of all the state charges, Goldman could be sentenced to a maximum of six years in prison.
DOC.HEAD: Stock Exchanges' Plan Could Raise Price Tag for Data
DOC.TEXT: Small investors and the media could face higher costs for their daily diet of stock prices under a proposal by the nation's stock exchanges that could lead to new fees for market data. A group of news organizations, discount stock brokerages and database services is challenging the request for a contractual change that could open the door to charges on 15-minute-old stock quotes. Delayed last sale information, as it is called, is now free to vendors, except for transmission costs. Charges are applied only to ``real-time'' quotes, which are up-to-the-second prices. Individual investors pay about $13 a month for real-time quotations from the New York Stock Exchange. Institutions can pay up to $120 a month. The stock exchanges say they own the data, real or delayed, and need to recover the costs of compiling and distributing it. Opponents of the proposal by the NYSE and seven other exchanges, pending before the Securities and Exchange Commission, said April 6 that delayed-price fees would drive investors who can't afford to pay for real-time data from the markets. They said the 15-minute-old numbers are public property. ``It's like charging for the wrapper on the candy after it's been eaten,'' said Hugo Quackenbush, spokesman for discount broker Charles Schwab & Co. But Thomas Haley, the NYSE's vice president for market data, said the exchanges already have the right to charge for delayed data and to alter the definition of delayed data. Haley said charging some users for stock-price quotations and giving it away free to others is unfair and should be reconsidered. ``The exchange and the CTA receives nothing, zero, from those organizations for the use of that data,'' he said. ``That operation is being subsidized by all the others who are paying.'' With the development of lightning-quick transmission capability and competing computer databases in the last decade, more and more businesses are using the stock exchange's free data. Haley said the NYSE has 134 contracts to provide delayed data to vendors, who in turn make it available to an estimated 1.5 million personal users. He said about 200,000 display units have access to real-time data. The Associated Press is one of a dozen groups that have objected to the exchanges' proposal. In addition to Schwab and Quick & Reilly, others include Financial News Network, Dow Jones & Co., Fidelity Investments and Instinet Corp.
DOC.HEAD: Businessman Takes Aim at Fast-Food Fat Content
DOC.TEXT: A businessman who lobbies against heart-threatening foods used full-page ads in The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times, USA Today and more than a dozen other major newspapers April 4 to take on McDonald's Corp. and other fast-food companies. Phil Sokolof, a retired Omaha millionaire who has waged a one-man campaign against highly saturated fats in processed foods, called on McDonald's and other restaurants to reduce the fat content of their hamburger meat by 10 percent. About five newspapers declined to run the ad, which also attacks Burger King, Wendy's and other restaurants, Sokolof said. McDonald's reacted with outrage. ``I think this kind of advertising is sensational, ridiculous, and I think it's reckless,'' McDonald's senior vice president Dick Starmann said from Oak Brook, Ill. Sokolof, 67, blames high cholesterol for a near-fatal heart attack he suffered 24 years ago. He started the National Heart Savers Association in 1985 and supports it largely through his own contributions. After he launched a national advertising campaign in 1988, nine major food processors, including Nabisco, Kellogg's, Pepperidge Farm and Keebler agreed to begin phasing out cholestorol-elevating fats from products such as crackers, cookies, candies, cereals, cooking ingredients and TV dinners. Starmann said the Big Mac had less saturated fat in it than the ad claimed. A Big Mac with french fries contains about 19 grams of saturated fat, he said. McDonald's uses a combination of beef tallow and vegetable shortening to cook its fries and is testing cholesterol-free vegetable shortening that would eliminate beef tallow, he added. The company has introduced low-fat and low-cholesterol bran muffins and cereals to its menu, Starmann added.

DOC.HEAD: Broadcasters Point to Cuban `Warning Shot'
DOC.TEXT: Radio broadcasters are increasingly worried that Cuba will retaliate for the U.S. propaganda channel ``TV Marti,'' especially since a recent warning shot that was heard as far away as Utah. Radio station operators and engineers at the National Association of Broadcasters convention said they were concerned about reports that Cuba may have radio transmitters capable of 1 million watts or more, 20 times the strength of the strongest U.S. AM stations. Cuba has been jamming the TV Marti broadcasts, produced by the Voice of America, since they started March 27. Cuban President Fidel Castro warned April 3 that any U.S. attempt to interfere with the jamming could lead to war. The warning shot that has broadcasters worried came on March 23, four days before testing of TV Marti began. Federal Communications Commission monitors heard Cuban radio signals on six clear-channel, U.S. AM frequencies, said Walter W. Wurfel, senior vice president of the NAB. A half-dozen AM stations in Florida battled with the interference, and stations in Red Springs, N.C., and Donelson, Tenn., filed complaints, Wurfel said. The interference even turned up in Salt Lake City, said John Dehnel, chief engineer at that Utah city's clear-channel KSL-AM. ``If Castro fires up his AM radio transmitters, it poses a substantial potential to interrupt and cause interference to a lot of radio stations in the United States _ perhaps 1,000 to 1,500,'' Wurfel said.
DOC.HEAD: FCC Chairman Backs Industry Self-Regulation
DOC.TEXT: Alfred Sikes, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, reiterated support for self-regulation of radio and television April 4, but pledged not to permit ``regulatory neglect'' when rules and practices hamper competition. ``Now more than ever,'' Sikes said in a speech to a National Association of Broadcasters meeting, ``the future of your industry lies within your hands.'' Under Sikes, the FCC has increased enforcement of ``anti-indecency'' laws. Some in the industry have called content regulation unconstitutional. ``The constitution clearly limits government, and that's how it should be,'' said the FCC chairman, who once operated a Missouri radio station. ``Yet it is nevertheless true that a broadcast industry whose standards are no higher than its lowest common denominator not only ill-serves our nation but it also risks arousing an already too cynical public and invites more governmental intrusion.''
DOC.HEAD: Musburger Says Farewell to CBS After Championship Broadcast
DOC.TEXT: Brent Musburger, whose 15-year career at CBS ended April 2 when the network declined to renew his contract, blames the breakup on two former bosses. In an interview on ABC's ``PrimeTime Live'' on April 5, Musburger said that CBS Sports President Neal Pilson and executive producer Ted Shaker ``conspired to get me out of CBS.'' ``It was not a network firing,'' Musburger said in an interview with Sam Donaldson. ``It was a personal vendetta on the part of two people. ... These two men had decided I was too big for my britches and that they were just going to take me down a peg or two.'' Shaker and Pilson each issued one-sentence responses through CBS spokeswoman Susan Kerr. ``It was disappointing to watch,'' Pilson said. ``I wish to remember Brent the way he was (on his final broadcast for the network April 2), gracious and professional,'' Shaker said. Jack Buck replaced Musburger as the network's top baseball announcer and CBS filled Buck's spot on the second unit with Dick Stockton. CBS Sports executive producer Ted Shaker said the network has also talked with ABC's Al Michaels, NBC's Bob Costas and Vin Scully, a free agent who left NBC during the winter.
DOC.HEAD: Man Arrested After Bomb Scare in TV Station Lobby
DOC.TEXT: A man who claimed he was carrying a bomb was arrested after a standoff in the lobby of WTVJ-TV on April 2. ``We had someone walk into our station and claim that he had a bomb on him, so we followed the normal procedures for handling that, which is to take him seriously, evacuate the building and call police,'' said Linda Button, director of broadcasting and creative services. Police talked to the man and removed him about an hour later. They found shell casings, but no bomb, in a bag he brought with him. The station is located across from the federal courthouse, where defense attorneys were arguing for the dismissal of charges against ousted Panamanian ruler Manuel Noriega.
DOC.HEAD: Dallas Gets Second Local Spanish-Language News Program
DOC.TEXT: A UHF station has become the city's second television outlet to offer local newscasts in Spanish. KFWD-TV premiered its new 30-minute news show called ``Revista 52'' on April 2. It will be shown Mondays through Fridays, station officials said. The first half of each show will be devoted to news, with the second half carrying a series of nightly feature segments. KUVN is the other Dallas-area station offering the newscast in Spanish.

DOC.HEAD: Vezza Named Publisher of The Daily Journal
DOC.TEXT: Richard J. Vezza, publisher of The Hudson Dispatch of Union City, was appointed to the same post at The Daily Journal of Elizabeth, an announcement from North Jersey Newspapers Co. said April 3. Vezza was publisher at The Daily Journal from 1986 to 1987 and was editor at the paper from 1981 to 1985. He will continue as publisher at The Hudson Dispatch. Vezza also was named chief operating executive of the company's Union County weekly publications, the Suburban News of Westfield and the Independent Press group of weeklies in New Providence, Summit and Berkeley Heights. He replaces Sherwood L. Spitz, who becomes publisher of the company's six weeklies in Bergen County.
DOC.HEAD: Bacardi Appointed President of The San Juan Star
DOC.TEXT: Puerto Rican business executive Adolfo Comas Bacardi has been appointed president and general manager of The San Juan Star in Puerto Rico, Scripps Howard announced April 2. Comas Bacardi, 45, has served since 1986 as executive vice president of ACB Enterprises Inc., a San Juan fragrance and beauty products importer he co-founded. He previously served 19 years in various management positions with Bacardi Corp., the Puerto Rico rum producer. He succeeds John A. Zerbe Jr., who resigned from the Star March 31. Andrew Viglucci is editor of the English-language newspaper.
DOC.HEAD: Towers Leaving Sun-Times
DOC.TEXT: Former Chicago Sun-Times executive editor and vice president Kenneth D. Towers, who spent his entire journalism career at the paper, said April 5 he is leaving to become executive director of the Illinois Insurance Information Service. ``I felt that I would like to try something different after all these years in one field,'' Towers said. The agency is a public service and public relations organization supported by major property and casualty insurance companies in the state. Towers, 54, joined the Sun-Times as a part-time copy clerk at age 15. He was executive editor and vice president from June 1987 to September 1989 and currently is vice president for reader relations.
DOC.HEAD: Morris Named McCook Daily Gazette Publisher
DOC.TEXT: Gene O. Morris, a former managing editor of the McCook Daily Gazette, was named publisher of the newspaper on April 3. The announcement came from Dick Gozia, president of Gozia-Driver Media of Springfield, Mo. Morris started as a reporter at the Daily Gazette in 1961. Since 1981, he and his wife, Barbara, have owned and published The Benkelman Post & News-Chronicle about 50 miles west of McCook. He will continue to own the weekly. Morris was with the Daily Gazette from 1961 to 1965, was managing editor of the Winfield (Kan.) Daily Courier in 1965-67 and rejoined the Gazette in 1969. He served as managing editor until 1980. Gozia has been interim publisher of the Daily Gazette since John Burgess resigned last October to become publisher of the Daily American Republic in Poplar Bluff, Mo.
DOC.HEAD: McCants Returns to Kansas Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: Randy McCants was named publisher of the Goodland Daily News on April 2, replacing Rich Paulsen, who left to become advertising manager of the Wyoming Eagle and the Wyoming State Tribune in Cheyenne. The appointment was announced by Dick Gozia of Gozia-Driver Media, owner of the Daily News. McCants, whose family used to own the newspaper, started at the Daily News at age 12. He worked in several different production capacities before leaving to start Shopper's Advocate, a weekly advertising publication.
DOC.HEAD: Four Editors Get New Assignments
DOC.TEXT: The Cincinnati Enquirer announced four newsroom promotions April 3. Linda Cagnetti, deputy features editor, was named deputy managing editor for projects and planning. Jim Smith, executive news editor, was named assistant managing editor-news in charge of evening news operations. Smith will be succeeded by News Editor Neena Pellegrini, whose spot in turn will be filled by Jenny Barker, assistant news editor.
DOC.HEAD: Friedrich, Schwartz in New Cox Arizona Slots
DOC.TEXT: Peter W. Friedrich, vice president and general manager of Cox Arizona Publications Inc., has been named Phoenix general manager for Stuffit Inc., a new direct mail coupon advertising venture of Cox Enterprises. Friedrich was succeeded April 6 by Sanford Schwartz, executive editor of Cox newspapers in Mesa, Tempe and Chandler.
DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Editors Elect Six Directors
DOC.TEXT: The American Society of Newspaper Editors elected three new directors and re-elected three incumbents in its annual convention that ended April 6. New directors, elected for three-year terms, are Jane Healy of The Orlando (Fla.) Sentinel, John Driscoll of The Boston Globe and Robert Giles of The Detroit News. Re-elected to three-year terms were Jean Otto of the Rocky Mountain News in Denver and Larry Allison of the Long Beach (Calif.) Press-Telegram. Arnold Rosenfeld of Cox Newspapers was re-elected to a one-year term.

DOC.HEAD: DEATHS
DOC.TEXT: Vernon Davis, publisher of the Maryland Cracker Barrel magazine and former editor of The Morning Herald, died of a heart attack on April 1. He was 65. Davis joined the Hagerstown newspaper in 1942 as a reporter. While in Europe as an Army communications specialist in World War II, he filed a column on his experiences called ``Hagerstownian About Italy.'' Davis left the paper in 1960 to take jobs in public relations, and became publisher of the Cracker Barrel, a historical magazine that covers Western Maryland, in the mid-1970s. Davis is survived by his wife, two children and four grandchildren.

Walter Doty, a former editor of Sunset magazine, died March 28 at his home. He was 95. Doty was Sunset editor from 1939 to 1954, then became the magazine's editorial research director until he retired in 1960. He worked for Sunset as a consultant after retirement. He also worked on various promotional gardening pamphlets and books for Ortho, HP Books in Tucson, Ariz., and Western Publishing in New York. Doty is survived by two sisters, five grandchildren and several great-grandchildren.

Bill R. Hunter, who published several newspapers and worked in public relations in Prince George's County, died of a heart attack April 4 at age 58. After working as a journalist in the Navy, the Morgantown, N.C., native moved to the Washington area in 1960 and bought The Courier, a weekly paper with a circulation of 29,000 in Prince George's County and Southern Maryland. He was editor and publisher until selling the paper in the late 1970s. He also was publisher of The Gateway at Andrews Air Force Base, The Beam at Bolling Air Force Base, The Pentagram News at the Pentagon, The Prince George's Times and other papers. After selling The Courier, Hunter worked in public relations from his home. He is survived by his wife, four children, a brother and a grandchild.

Alex H. Joiner Jr., retired pictures editor of The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, died April 5 of a heart attack at age 66. Joiner, who had been ill with Parkinson's disease, had surgery for a broken hip two weeks earlier and was at an Atlanta hospital. He started at the Atlanta newspapers in 1949 and retired in 1988. He was picture editor of the Constitution for many years and held the same position when the Journal and Constitution news staffs were combined. Joiner is survived by four sisters.

Peter Jones, a senior sports announcer for British Broadcasting Corp.'s radio services, died March 31 after collapsing during coverage of the Oxford-Cambridge Boat Race. He was 60. The cause of death was not disclosed. Newspaper reports said Jones suffered a stroke while covering the rowing race on the Thames. Jones was a featured correspondent on Sports Report, the BBC sports roundup show. His work also included commentary on the Heysel Stadium riots in 1985, in which 35 people died, and the disaster at Hillsborough Stadium last April, in which 95 soccer fans were crushed to death. Survivors include his wife and twin sons.

Chuck Livolsi, a cartoonist and illustrator for The Pittsburgh Press for 27 years, died April 2 of cancer. He was 55. Livolsi produced a comic strip titled ``Brass Hats'' for several years with former Press Managing Editor Ralph Brem. He also produced editorial page cartoons for the newspaper for many years. Livolsi, a 1960 graduate fo the Art Institute of Pittsburgh, was awarded the Golden Quill and Printer's Devil awards for his work. Survivors include his wife, Donna, and two sons.

Bernard J. Miller, the founding publisher of Gentleman's Quarterly magazine, died April 3 of liver cancer at age 76. He joined Esquire Inc. in 1946 as an advertising salesman for Apparel Arts magazine and became publisher two years later. In 1957 Miller helped start Gentleman's Quarterly, also known as GQ. He became a vice president of Esquire Inc. in 1962. Miller served on the board of the United Jewish Appeal and on the executive committee of the National Conference of Christians and Jews. Survivors include his wife, Frances, a daughter and two grandsons.

Willie Musarurwa, a veteran journalist who spent 10 years in jail for his political activities, died April 4 of a heart attack. He was 62. Musarurwa was jailed without trial for 10 years because of political activism against white minority rule before Zimbabwe's independence in 1980. He was fired from his job as chief editor of Zimbabwe's main Sunday newspaper in 1985 after President Robert Mugabe accused him of being overly critical of the government.

J. Todd Prillhart, a county reporter for The Clarion-Ledger, died April 1 from injuries sustained when high winds sent a tree crashing onto the vehicle he was driving. He was 26. Prillhart, a native of Kingsport, Tenn., had worked at the weekly Aberdeen Examiner, the Enterprise-Journal daily in McComb and The Meridian Star, moving up to city editor at the Star last August. He had been hired by The Clarion-Ledger in March. Prillhart was the son of George Kenneth Prillhart of Columbia, publisher of the The Columbian-Progress weekly newspaper and past president of the Mississippi Press Association. Survivors include his parents, one sister and one brother.

Lawrence Wade, a reporter and editorial writer for the former Dayton Journal Herald, died March 31 of a brain tumor at age 41. Wade wrote for the Journal Herald from 1980 to 1982. He also worked for the Cleveland Press, The Wall Street Journal, The Miami Herald, The Orlando Sentinel and The Washington Times. He was communications director for the U.S. Civil Rights Commission in 1984 and 1985. Survivors include his wife, Deborah Burstion-Wade; a son, a brother and his parents.

DOC.HEAD: AWARDS
ASNE Cites 10 Newspapers as Examples of Excellence
DOC.TEXT: Ten small newspapers were cited April 4 as examples of excellence by the American Society of Newspaper Editors. Chosen from newspapers with less than 50,000 circulation were: The Bradenton (Fla.) Herald; Daily Camera in Boulder, Colo.; The Times in Gainesville, Ga.; Grand Forks (N.D.) Herald; La Crosse (Wis.) Tribune; The Capital Times in Madison, Wis.; The Sun News in Myrtle Beach, S.C.; Naples (Fla.) Daily News; The Day in New London, Conn.; and the West County Times in Richmond, Calif. ``I think this is one of the most thorough evaluations of small newspapers ever undertaken,'' said Jim Herman, editor of the Traverse City Record-Eagle in Michigan and chairman of the society's project on excellence in small newspapers. ``Our goal is to find small newspapers that are doing outstanding jobs and to learn from them.'' Herman said ASNE's selection process began last fall when 1,356 small daily newspapers were invited to compete. More than 450 newspapers were submitted for consideration and regional judges narrowed that field to 74 finalists. In January, 13 judges gathered at the Poynter Institute in St. Petersburg, Fla., and selected the 10 winners. The judges included editors, journalism teachers and readers. ``The papers were graded on a wide range of criteria,'' Herman said. ``One of the most important was that they have an independent style and that they have a strong sense of place.'' It was the second year ASNE has honored excellent small newspapers. Last year, 14 were chosen.
DOC.HEAD: Ithaca Businessman Gets Shenandoah College Award
DOC.TEXT: Roy H. Park, founder and chairman of Park Communications Inc., was awarded the Shenandoah College and Conservatory's Free Enterprise Medal on April 6. Park, of Ithaca, N.Y., publishes 41 daily newspapers and 35 weeklies, and owns seven television stations and 10 radio stations. Park Communications' WTVR-TV in Richmond was recently named the Mid-Atlantic Broadcasters Association's outstanding news operation in the region.
DOC.HEAD: NOTES FROM EVERYWHERE
DOC.TEXT: CBS Inc. has come up with a cost-cutting plan that requires its news division to share camera operators and technicians with other units that produce soap operas, sitcoms and other programs, The New York Times reports ... Arkady A. Maslennikov, Mikhail Gorbachev's first presidential spokesman, doesn't apologize for the differences between his office and the White House press operation some reporters are used to. ``First of all, I'm not a Fitzwater, I'm Maslennikov,'' he said ... Fawn Hall, known for her role in the Iran-Contra scandal as Oliver North's secretary, has taken an assignment for ``Evening Magazine'' at KDKA-TV in Pittsburgh: Reporting on three beach resorts favored by Pittsburgh vacationers.
DOC.HEAD: End Industry News

DOC.TEXT: Forecasters say the weather will cooperate when the space shuttle Discovery takes off with NASA's most valuable and eagerly awaited payload, the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope. ``This project has been difficult. ... There are at least three times when I thought we wouldn't do it,'' said Charles Pellerin Jr., NASA's director of astrophysics. ``But we're there and it all works and it's going to be great.'' The launch is scheduled for 8:47 a.m. EDT on Tuesday. Pellerin inspected the telescope before the payload bay doors were closed Sunday. He was pleased to note there was no evidence of midges, tiny mosquitolike insects that had invaded a payload preparation room at the launch pad two weeks ago.

Ryan White, who put a youthful face on AIDS and the fears and discrimination its victims encounter, was recalled as a young man who ``made a difference'' after losing a 5{-year struggle with the disease. ``He was the boy next door who first showed a stunned nation that no one is safe from the risk of AIDS,'' said Dr. Martin B. Kleiman, White's physician throughout his illness. ``He had no bitterness. ``With an honest simplicity, his was the voice that many, if not most, first heard, even though his was not the first voice.'' White, 18, died shortly after 7 a.m. Sunday of lung congestion from an AIDS-related respiratory infection. He had been in critical condition on a ventilator at Riley Hospital for Children since March 29.

Tens of thousands of Nepalese paraded through Katmandu in a delirium of joy today, chanting ``Victory, Victory'' to celebrate the government's agreement to establish a multiparty system. In a stunning announcement just two days after police killed as many as 200 pro-democracy protesters, King Birendra told the people of this Himalayan land on Sunday that he was lifting a 29-year ban on political parties. The city sprung to life early today after a two-day curfew was lifted, but a doctor at Bir Hospital said security forces had opened fire on celebrants Sunday night, killing at least one person and wounding two. The doctor said the people who brought the casualties to the hospital reported that at least 10 others killed and their bodies taken away by troops. The report could not be confirmed and police denied there was any firing.

Huge crowds lined up to see a photo exhibit that has resulted in obscenity indictments against an arts center. Many expressed indignation at attempts to remove photos of homosexual acts and naked children. During an emergency hearing Sunday, U.S. District Judge Carl Rubin ordered county and city authorities not to interfere with the exhibit of photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe while the obscenity charges are tried in state court. The 175-photograph show opened to the public Saturday morning. After nine grand jury members viewed the exhibit, it was closed for an hour in the afternoon when the Contemporary Arts Center and its director, Dennis Barrie, were indicted on state obscenity charges. The indictment sparked public interest in the show Sunday, when the center opened an hour early to accommodate a large crowd.

Prosecutors may call Oliver North and John Poindexter before a federal grand jury to answer questions about the Iran-Contra scandal, according to sources who have watched the investigation closely. That would give Iran-Contra prosecutors their first opportunity to conduct a wide-ranging interrogation of North outside the constraints imposed by a courtroom trial setting. Poindexter is a candidate for a grand jury appearance following his sentencing June 11 on his convictions Saturday for conspiracy, obstruction and lying to Congress, say the sources, speaking on condition of anonymity. Grand jury appearances by North and Poindexter probably would constitute the final phase of the Iran-Contra criminal investigation, the sources said. A Poindexter appearance could include questions about former President Reagan's role in the affair.

DOC.NOTE: For Release Fri PMs, April 13 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: A Kinder, Gentler Marillion
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: There was a time when the British band Marillion performed poetic tales of midlife crisis, tragic love affairs, politics and alcoholism that bordered on the negative. But these days, with a new optimism and a new lead singer, the group sings of strife in Northern Ireland in the elegant track ``Easter,'' of love gone obsessive in ``The Uninvited Guest'' and of global warming in the title track of ``Seasons End,'' their new LP. ``I'm trying to deal with all of those things on a soul level, on a humanity level, rather than trying to make some kind of political point,'' said Steve Hogarth, who replaced the introspective Derek Dick, who was called Fish, as vocalist and lyricist. ``I think it's a great romantic notion to turn all the poets into politicians,'' he said. ``I don't think it's our place or musicians' place to stand up and propose solutions other than to propose hope and to propose the wider and more common sense things like love and peace.'' That attitude carries over in Marillion's live performances. Hogarth is engaging on stage, leaping on to speaker cabinets to sing and making frequent eye contact with his audience. ``I try to be a bit friendly,'' he said. ``I try and love them _ I know that sounds like an insincere American sort of thing to say, but I do try in all sincerity to love them while I'm singing to them. I think that you've got to put something out to people to get something back from them that is genuine.'' Though popular in England for about a decade, Marillion is just beginning to gain an audience in the United States. The group started in 1978 as Silmarillion, a name taken from the J.R.R. Tolkein novel. Their leader was the enigmatic Fish. Others in the band were guitarist Steve Rothery, bassist Pete Trewavas, keyboardist Mark Kelly and drummer Ian Mosley. They released their first album, ``Script for a Jester's Tear'' in 1983 under their new name _ Marillion. Through 1988, Marillion released six albums. Their most notable efforts with Fish were the brilliant concept works ``Misplaced Childhood,'' released in 1985, and ``Clutching at Straws,'' in 1987. Fish left the band in 1988 and was replaced in 1989 by Hogarth, who had been in several lesser bands around Britain. Fish has just released a solo album, ``Vigil in a Wilderness of Mirrors,'' which is already in the Top 10 in Britain. Hogarth was familiar with the band's material before he joined, but didn't know the group was looking for a new singer until his publisher told him. ``I'd never seen the band play and I wasn't a member of the fan club or anything, so I didn't understand the band in terms of how they actually are as people,'' Hogarth said in a telephone interview following a concert stop in Philadelphia. But the connection between Hogarth and the rest of Marillion was immediate. ``They all knew straight off that it was right _ they don't know why. I think they just got the feeling that I was coming from the same planet in terms of what stimulated me,'' Hogarth said. The band had been looking for someone ``who's just going to be himself,'' he said, and they were more than willing to use music he had written. ``I think that's why spiritually the band feels so new,'' Hogarth said, ``because it has been a natural process. We haven't taken anything that was old and tried to chisel away at what's new in order to make it fit.'' However, Fish's departure was a strain on both sides, Hogarth said. ``The band were beginning to have a problem with the stuff Fish was writing, as well as Fish was beginning to have a problem with wanting to work with the band,'' Hogarth said. ``The problem the band were having with his writing was that he was beginning to be so introverted that the band were beginning to worry that nobody else in the world was ever going to relate to what he was going on about.'' Hogarth said it was a happier band that recorded ``Seasons End.'' ``We had a great time writing the album, and then a great time recording it because we co-produced it,'' Hogarth said. ``We didn't have anyone telling us what to do when we were recording the album, so the spirit right from day one has been extremely positive, and I think it's reflected not only in the album but in the spirit on stage and the live shows as well.'' Hogarth thinks the band can make it in the United States, but will have to do it through touring ``because nobody's ever go records to death on daytime rading to play ourio _ that's not the kind of band we are _ and in a way, that's our strength.'' But in a way, the singer appreciates the band's anonymity. ``We're in the fortunate position that our record company hasn't the foggiest idea why our fans love it, and so they leave us to just get on with it,'' he said.

DOC.NOTE: For Release PMs Monday April 16 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Japanese Companies Add Flexibility to Robotic Assembly Lines
DOC.TEXT: Thirty-five robot arms hold the main parts of a Nissan Sentra body in virtually perfect alignment and 16 others weld the parts together in 62 spots. Then, 45 seconds later, everything changes. The four-door sedan body moves on, a computer automatically readjusts the bank of robots to assemble the next item on the line, a hatchback. After the computer does its work again, the robots assemble the body of a station wagon. Down the line, each body will be painted a different color and receive different parts, all determined by computer command. Japanese companies are increasing the flexibility of production lines to handle a mix of models and options and permit easy changeover to new designs. In selling his Model T, the world's first mass-produced car, Henry Ford offered ``any color you want, as long as it's black.'' Japanese companies, in contrast, are using computerization to focus on ``miniproduction'' that offers specialized, low-volume models and even custom jobs. Toyota makes Supra, Lexus and Soarer models on the same line in its Tahara plant. Honda produces Accords and Integras on a single line at Suzuka. Each car at the Tahara factory carries a specially programmed identification disk. It emits radio signals picked up by receivers at each work station, which tell a robot or worker what kind of battery, shock absorber or stereo system to install. Nissan said the new ``intelligent body assembly system'' at the Zama plant was the first in the world to use computer-programmable robots instead of fixed jigs in aligning the main body parts, including floor, roof and side panels. That allows one assembly line to handle up to four different models and eight body types at once. ``The positioning operations for different models have been the most difficult aspects of body assembly work to automate,'' a company statement said. Officials at Nissan said the system greatly reduces the time and cost of model changes. Lengthy and expensive retooling of jigs and production machines for model changes result in long ``down times'' for production lines. With programmable robots, many changes can be made by modifying the computer program. That can be combined with the design process. ``With this system, we can take the computer program to another plant and begin production in three months,'' said Kazutake Kobatake, a Nissan spokesman. ``Before, it took 10-11 months to transfer production.'' The system will cut retooling costs for a new model in half, he said. Zama's No. 2 assembly line is one of the most highly automated in Japan, with 97 percent of the 3,000-4,000 welds per car done by robot, said Tsuneyuki Hane, general manager of the plant. Use of computerized production technology allows companies to send a computer program, rather than bulky new jigs and equipment, to an overseas plant to shift production to new or popular models. It also helps avoid excess inventory by tailoring each day's production mix to demand. Such flexibility allows Nissan to produce several low-volume specialty models for the Japanese market. The system, now used in Nissan's plants at Zama and Tochigi, will be introduced at two other Japanese plants and the U.S. factory in Smyrna, Tenn., company officials said. Other industries also are increasing the flexibility of production lines. Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., maker of Panasonic bicycles, allows people to custom-order from 18 models and 199 paint jobs, specifying size and choosing pedals, tires and logo. ``We're able to make a bicycle which fits the customer precisely and deliver it within two weeks,'' a Matsushita official said. He said the custom-order system adds about $45-$95 to the cost of a bicycle. It accounts for only about 15,000 of the 700,000 bicycles the company sells each year, but is growing and has spread to other companies, the official said. Analysts say the United States trails in flexible assembly line technology, and that large American companies have displayed less interest in specialized low-volume production.

DOC.NOTE: For Release Wed PMs, April 11 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Little-Known American Writers Find a Home on British Stage
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: It took a world premiere in Britain for playwright Sally Nemeth to get some attention at home in New York. Now, she says, agents answer her calls. London has always loved American dramatists, not just greats such as Tennessee Williams and Eugene O'Neill but the up-and-coming too, as Nemeth has discovered. John Logan is virtually unheard of in the United States, except in his home city, Chicago. But his 1983 play, ``Never the Sinner,'' is running on London's West End with an impressive cast headed by Joss Ackland and Julian Glover. Richard Nelson's off-Broadway play, ``Some Americans Abroad,'' was first produced by the Royal Shakespeare Company last summer. The American dramatist's second commission for the British company opens in Stratford-upon-Avon in the autumn. One reason American playwrights can make it in Britain is that production costs are much lower here than in New York. Another is that critical pressures are less acute. London fields an array of equally influential reviewers. It isn't just a one-critic town such as New York, where a nod from Frank Rich of The New York Times can make or break a production. Some dramatists feel their work strikes more sympathetic chords abroad. ``It's hard to go out on a stylistic limb in the States, although I think that is changing,'' said Nemeth, 30, whose rather parched, opaque writing style is at odds with much American drama. Her new play, ``Mill Fire,'' about an explosion at an Alabama steel mill, opened to mixed reviews March 16 at west London's Riverside Studios. ``I think my plays are somewhat hard to read in that they're very spare. It takes someone who can really read that kind of work to respond to it,'' she said. Nemeth has found that someone in director Brian Stirner, the Briton who staged her two London plays. Richard Nelson's oblique, ironic tone seems more attuned to contemporary British writers than to his American peers. ``The reaction here has been much more generous, much more understanding,'' said Nelson, 39, who has had two plays performed by the RSC: ``Some Americans Abroad'' and ``Principia Scriptoriae.'' Both got better reviews in London than in New York. ``Some Americans Abroad'' received an Olivier Award nomination as the year's best comedy. In London, says Nelson, his plays ``have been critically perceived and understood and argued about.'' Only recently has he hit problems. In mid-March he quit as book writer of ``King,'' the troubled London musical about the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. John Logan says his ``Never the Sinner'' shows an interest in history less evident in American playwriting. In the American theater, he charges, ``We have forgotten our history; we've betrayed it.'' He said he did not want to write the kind of personal play that proliferates in the United States. ``I have very little regard for anemic TV theater _ for naturalistic, self-indulgent, sometimes autobiographical drama,'' he said. Four of Logan's five favorite dramatists are British: Steven Berkoff, Howard Brenton, Caryl Churchill and Harold Pinter. Another Chicago writer, Aaron Iverson, wrote a play in 1982 only to find it being premiered, professionally, in London last month. ``I'd had readings of the play done (in Chicago) but no one expressed a whole lot of interest,'' said Iverson, 32. Instead, his ``Side Pockets'' ended its month-long debut March 3 at the Theater Royal, Stratford East. Iverson has been commissioned to write a second play for the theater. He said the playhouse, in a blue-collar, ethnically mixed area, reached a public more difficult to attract in the United States. There, he said, ``the audience I want only watches TV and movies.'' Iverson, who earns his living as a lawyer, says: ``I kind of feel like working-class or poor people aren't really addressed much.'' Nemeth has had many offers from American agents in the wake of London productions of her two plays, but producers so far haven't been forthcoming. Logan continues to work regularly in Chicago, where he currently has a commission from the Goodman Theater, but he has yet to have a major staging of any of his plays in New York. While none of the writers sees Broadway as a goal, few are ready to renounce the United States altogether and move to London as playwright Martin Sherman (``When She Danced,'' ``Bent'') did over a decade ago. Said Nelson: ``I love my country. I'm American; I love living in America.''

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Easter Sunday, April 15, the 105th day of 1990. There are 260 days left in the year. Today's highlight in history: In the early morning hours of April 15, 1912, the British luxury liner Titanic sank in the North Atlantic off Newfoundland, less than three hours after striking an iceberg. About 1,500 of the more than 2,200 people aboard died in the disaster. On this date: In 1817, the first American school for the deaf opened, in Hartford, Conn. In 1850, the city of San Francisco was incorporated. In 1861, President Lincoln declared a state of insurrection and called out Union troops. In 1865, at 7:22 a.m., President Lincoln died, several hours after he was wounded at Ford's Theater in Washington by John Wilkes Booth. Andrew Johnson became the nation's 17th president. In 1920, a robbery at the Slater and Morrill Shoe Co. in South Braintree, Mass., resulted in the deaths of a paymaster and guard. Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti were subsequently convicted of the murders and executed. In 1945, President Franklin D. Roosevelt was buried at the Roosevelt family home in Hyde Park, N.Y. In 1959, Cuban leader Fidel Castro arrived in Washington to begin a goodwill tour of the United States. In 1981, The Washington Post relinquished a Pulitzer Prize given to one of its reporters after the reporter admitted she had fabricated her award-winning feature story. In 1983, Roy L. Williams agreed to resign as president of the Teamsters union as part of a bargain with federal prosecutors. Williams was succeeded by Jackie Presser. In 1986, the United States launched an air raid against Libya in response to the bombing of a discotheque in Berlin on April 5. Libya says 37 people, mostly civilians, died in the raid. Ten years ago: Existentialist philosopher Jean-Paul Sartre died in Paris at the age of 74. Five years ago: South Africa said it would repeal laws prohibiting sex and marriage between whites and non-whites. One year ago: Students in Beijing launched a series of pro-democracy protests upon the death of former Communist Party leader Hu Yaobang, who had been forced from power for refusing to crack down on student unrest. Today's birthdays: Actor Michael Ansara is 68. Country singer Roy Clark is 57. Actress Elizabeth Montgomery is 57. Actress Claudia Cardinale is 51. Rock singer-guitarist Dave Edmunds is 46. Thought for today: ``The best mirror is an old friend.'' _ George Herbert, English author (1593-1633).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Monday, April 16, the 106th day of 1990. There are 259 days left in the year. Today's highlight in history: On April 16, 1889, comedian and movie director Charles Chaplin, creator of such film classics as ``The Tramp,'' ``The Gold Rush,'' ``City Lights'' and ``Modern Times,'' was born in London. On this date: In 1789, President-elect George Washington left Mount Vernon, Va., for New York for his inauguration. In 1862, a bill ending slavery in the District of Columbia became law. In 1879, Saint Bernadette, who had described seeing visions of the Virgin Mary at Lourdes, died in Nevers, France. In 1912, Harriet Quimby became the first woman to fly across the English Channel, using a Bleriot monoplane to travel from Dover, England, to Hardelot, France. In 1917, Vladimir Ilyich Lenin returned to Russia after years of exile. In 1935, the long-running radio comedy program ``Fibber McGee and Molly,'' starring Jim and Marian Jordan, premiered on the NBC Blue Network. In 1940, 50 years ago, Bob Feller of the Cleveland Indians pitched a no-hitter on opening day of the American League season, defeating the Chicago White Sox 1-0 in Comiskey Park. In 1945, U.S. troops entered Nuremberg, Germany, during World War II. In 1947, at least 500 people died in a series of fires and explosions in Texas City, Texas, after a French freighter blew up in the harbor. In 1972, Apollo 16 blasted off from Cape Kennedy, Fla., on a voyage to the moon. In 1987, the Federal Communications Commission put broadcasters on notice it would impose a broader definition of indecency over the airwaves. Ten years ago: More than 230 Cubans who had sought asylum inside the Peruvian Embassy compound in Havana were flown to Costa Rica. Five years ago: The White House announced that President Reagan would visit the site of a Nazi concentration camp, but would also go ahead with plans to visit a German military cemetery _ a move that sparked controversy. One year ago: Spain's ambassador to Lebanon, Pedro Manuel de Aristegui, was killed by shellfire that broke out between Christian militiamen and an alliance of Syrian and Moslem gunners. Today's birthdays: Actor-director-author Peter Ustinov is 69. Composer Henry Mancini is 66. Actress-singer Edie Adams is 61. Singer Bobby Vinton is 55. Queen Margrethe II of Denmark is 50. Basketball great Kareem Abdul-Jabbar is 43. Thought for today: ``In the creation of comedy, it is paradoxical that tragedy stimulates the spirit of ridicule, because ridicule, I suppose, is an attitude of defiance: we must laugh in the face of our helplessness against the forces of nature _ or go insane.'' _ Charles Chaplin (1889-1977).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Tuesday, April 17, the 107th day of 1990. There are 258 days left in the year. Today's highlight in history: Two hundred years ago, on April 17, 1790, American statesman, diplomat, author and inventor Benjamin Franklin died in Philadelphia at the age of 84. On this date: In 1492, a contract was signed between Christopher Columbus and Spain to seek a westward ocean passage to Asia. In 1521, Martin Luther went before the Diet of Worms to face charges stemming from his religious writings. In 1524, Giovanni da Verrazano discovered present-day New York harbor. In 1861, the Virginia State Convention voted to secede from the Union. In 1941, Yugoslavia surrendered to Germany in World War II. In 1961, about 1,500 CIA-trained Cuban exiles launched the Bay of Pigs invasion of Cuba in a failed attempt to overthrow the government of Fidel Castro. In 1964, Ford Motor Co. unveiled the Mustang. In 1964, Jerrie Mock of Columbus, Ohio, became the first woman to complete a solo airplane flight around the world. In 1969, Sirhan Sirhan was convicted of assassinating U.S. Sen. Robert F. Kennedy. In 1969, Czechoslovakian Communist Party chairman Alexander Dubcek was deposed. In 1975, Phnom Penh fell to Communist insurgents, ending Cambodia's five-year war. In 1984, machine-gun fire from Libya's Embassy in London raked a crowd during a protest against the government of Col. Moammar Gadhafi, killing a police officer and wounding 10 other people. In 1986, the bodies of American librarian Peter Kilburn and two Britons were found near Beirut. The three hostages had been slain apparently in retaliation for the U.S. raid on Libya. Ten years ago: President Carter told a news conference the U.S. might take military action against Iran if sanctions failed to produce the release of the American hostages. Five years ago: Lebanon's prime minister, Rashid Karami, and the country's one-year-old national unity cabinet resigned amid fierce fighting between rival militias for control of Moslem west Beirut. One year ago: The House Ethics Committee released its report accusing House Speaker Jim Wright of violating House rules on the acceptance of gifts and outside income _ charges denied by the Texas Democrat. Today's birthdays: CBS News correspondent Harry Reasoner is 67. Movie and theatrical director Lindsay Anderson is 67. Rock promoter Don Kirshner is 56. Composer-musician Jan Hammer is 42. Thought for today: ``If you would not be forgotten, as soon as you are dead and rotten, either write things worth reading, or do things worth the writing.'' _ Benjamin Franklin (1706-1790).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Wednesday, April 18, the 108th day of 1990. There are 257 days left in the year. Today's highlight in history: On April 18, 1775, Paul Revere began his famous ride from Charlestown to Lexington, Mass., warning American colonists that the British were coming. On this date: In 1906, a devastating earthquake struck San Francisco, followed by raging fires. About 700 people died. In 1923, Yankee Stadium had its debut with the first game played there. The Yankees defeated the Boston Red Sox, 4-1. In 1934, the first laundromat, called a washateria, opened, in Fort Worth, Texas. In 1942, four months after Pearl Harbor, an air squadron led by James H. Doolittle bombed Tokyo and other Japanese cities. In 1942, the U.S. Armed Forces published the first issue of The Stars and Stripes. In 1945, war correspondent Ernie Pyle was killed by Japanese gunfire on the Pacific island of le Shima, off Okinawa. In 1946, the League of Nations went out of business. In 1949, the Irish republic was proclaimed. In 1955, physicist Albert Einstein died in Princeton, N.J. In 1956, actress Grace Kelly married Prince Rainier of Monaco in a civil ceremony. A church wedding took place the next day. In 1978, the U.S. Senate voted 68-32 to turn the Panama Canal over to Panamanian control on Dec. 31, 1999. In 1983, 62 people, including 17 Americans, were killed at the U.S. Embassy in Beirut, Lebanon, in an explosion set off by a suicide bomber. In 1986, a Titan rocket carrying a secret military payload exploded seconds after liftoff from Vandenberg Air Force Base in California. In 1988, an Israeli court convicted John Demjanjuk, a retired auto worker from Cleveland, of committing war crimes at the Treblinka death camp more than 40 years earlier. Ten years ago: Zimbabwe, Rhodesia, became the independent nation of Zimbabwe as the British flag was lowered at a ceremony in Salisbury. Five years ago: Amid controversy over his plans to visit a German military cemetery, President Reagan told news editors in Washington that the German soldiers had been ``victims'' of the Nazis ``just as surely as the victims in the concentration camps.'' One year ago: Thousands of Chinese students demanding democracy tried to storm Communist Party headquarters in Beijing. Today's birthdays: Movie composer Miklos Rozsa is 83. Actor Clive Revill is 60. Actress Hayley Mills is 44. Actor James Woods is 43. Thought for today: ``Love has the quality of informing almost everything _ even one's work.'' _ Sylvia Ashton-Warner, New Zealander author and educator (1908-1984).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Thursday, April 19, the 109th day of 1990. There are 256 days left in the year. Today's highlight in history: On April 19, 1775, the American Revolutionary War began with the Battles of Lexington and Concord. On this date: In 1782, the Netherlands recognized American independence. In 1824, the English romantic poet Lord Byron died in Missolonghi, Greece. In 1897, the first American marathon race was run from Hopkinton, Mass., to Boston. The winner was John J. McDermott, who ran the course in 2:55:10. In 1910, after weeks of being viewed through telescopes, Halley's Comet was reported visible to the naked eye in Curacao. In 1933, the United States went off the gold standard. In 1943, thousands of Jews living in the Warsaw Ghetto began their fight against Nazi occupation forces. In 1951, Gen. Douglas MacArthur, relieved of his command by President Truman, bade farewell to Congress, saying, ``Old soldiers never die; they just fade away.'' In 1965, the oldest all-news radio station in the United States, WINS-AM in New York, began its round-the-clock news programming. In 1975, India announced it had launched its first satellite, from the Soviet Union atop a Soviet rocket. In 1982, astronauts Sally K. Ride and Guion S. Bluford Jr. became the first woman and first black to be tapped for U.S. space missions. Ten years ago: Barbara and Kenneth Timm, the mother and stepfather of Sgt. Kevin Hermening, one of the American hostages in Iran, arrived in Tehran to visit their son. Five years ago: The space shuttle Discovery landed at Cape Canaveral, Fla., after a mission marred by a deployed satellite that failed to operate properly. One year ago: 47 sailors were killed when a gun turret exploded aboard the USS Iowa. In New York, an investment banker jogging in Central Park was brutally beaten, raped and left for dead _ but survived. Six youths are accused of the attack. Today's birthdays: Actor-comedian Dudley Moore is 55. Actress Elinor Donahue is 53. Tennis player Sue Barker is 34. Thought for today: ``The charm, one might say the genius of memory, is that it is choosy, chancy and temperamental: it rejects the edifying cathedral and indelibly photographs the small boy outside, chewing a hunk of melon in the dust.'' _ Elizabeth Bowen, Irish-born author (1899-1973).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Friday, April 20, the 110th day of 1990. There are 255 days left in the year. Today's highlight in history: On April 20, 1902, scientists Marie and Pierre Curie isolated the radioactive element radium. On this date: In 1812, the fourth vice president of the United States, George Clinton, died in Washington at the age of 73 _ the first vice president to die while in office. In 1836, the territory of Wisconsin was established by Congress. In 1889, Adolf Hitler was born in Braunau, Austria. In 1940, 50 years ago, RCA publicly demonstrated its new and powerful electron microscope. In 1945, the U.S. 7th Army captured the German city of Nuremberg. In 1948, United Auto Workers president Walter P. Reuther was shot and wounded at his home in Detroit. In 1968, Pierre Elliott Trudeau was sworn in as prime minister of Canada. In 1971, the U.S. Supreme Court upheld the use of busing to achieve racial desegregation in schools. In 1972, the manned lunar module of Apollo 16 landed on the moon. In 1977, the U.S. Supreme Court said car owners could refuse to display state mottoes on license plates, such as New Hampshire's ``Live Free or Die.'' In 1978, a Korean Air Lines Boeing 707 crash-landed in northwestern Russia after being fired on by a Soviet interceptor after entering Soviet airspace. Two passengers were killed. In 1983, President Reagan signed a $165 billion Social Security rescue plan designed to prevent bankruptcy of the trust fund for the elderly. Ten years ago: The first Cubans to arrive in the United States as part of the massive Mariel boatlift reached Florida. They were the first of about 125,000 Cubans allowed to travel to the United States by President Fidel Castro. Five years ago: In his Saturday radio address, President Reagan called for more U.S. aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, saying that ``Russian military personnel'' were in battle zones. One year ago: Ramon Salcido, a California winery worker accused of killing six relatives and a co-worker, was deported from Mexico to the United States. The case of Oliver North went to the jury in his Iran-Contra trial. Today's birthdays: Jazz musician Lionel Hampton is 77. Supreme Court Justice John Paul Stevens is 70. Actress Nina Foch is 66. Actor Ryan O'Neal is 49. Actress Jessica Lange is 41. Thought for today: ``Taste. You cannot buy such a rare and wonderful thing. You can't send away for it in a catalog. And I'm afraid it's becoming obsolete.'' _ Rosalind Russell, American actress (1911-1976).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Saturday, April 21, the 111th day of 1990. There are 254 days left in the year. Today's highlight in history: On April 21, 1910, author Samuel Langhorne Clemens, better known as Mark Twain, died in Redding, Conn. On this date: In 753 B.C., according to legend, Rome was founded. In 1649, the Maryland Toleration Act, which provided for freedom of worship for all Christians, was passed by the Maryland assembly. In 1789, John Adams was sworn in as the first vice president of the United States. In 1816, author Charlotte Bronte, who wrote Jane Eyre, was born in Thornton, England. In 1836, an army of Texans led by Sam Houston defeated the Mexicans at San Jacinto, assuring the independence of Texas. In 1918, Baron Manfred von Richthofen, the German ace known as the ``Red Baron,'' was killed in action during World War I. In 1940, 50 years ago, the quiz show that asked the $64,000 question, ``Take It or Leave It,'' premiered on CBS Radio. In 1960, Brazil inaugurated its new capital, Brasilia, transferring the seat of national government from Rio de Janeiro. In 1967, Svetlana Alliluyeva, daughter of Soviet leader Josef Stalin, arrived in New York. In 1972, Apollo 16 astronauts John Young and Charles Duke explored the surface of the moon. In 1975, South Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu resigned after 10 years in office. In 1976, full-scale testing of the swine flu vaccine began in Washington D.C. In 1986, the United States, Britain and France vetoed a United Nations Security Council resolution condemning the U.S. air raid on Libya. Ten years ago: Barbara Timm, mother of one of the U.S. hostages in Iran, was allowed to spend 45 minutes with her son, Sgt. Kevin Hermening. Bill Rodgers won his third straight Boston Marathon; the first woman across the finish line was Rosie Ruiz, whose win was later ruled invalid. Five years ago: The president-elect of Brazil, Tancredo de Almeida Neves, died after an illness that had prevented his swearing-in the previous month as the country's first civilian president in two decades. One year ago: Tens of thousands of people crowded into Beijing's Tiananmen Square, cheering students who waved banners demanding greater political freedoms. Today's birthdays: Former California Gov. Edmund G. ``Pat'' Brown is 85. Actor Anthony Quinn is 75. Britain's Queen Elizabeth is 64. Actress-comedian-writer Elaine May is 58. Actor Charles Grodin is 55. Former New Jersey Gov. Thomas Kean is 55. Singer-musician Iggy Pop is 43. Actor Tony Danza is 39. Thought for today: ``Why is it that we rejoice at a birth and grieve at a funeral? It is because we are not the person involved.'' _ Mark Twain (1835-1910).

DOC.NOTE: For Release PMs Tues April 10 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Battle Over the Military Budget, Cheney the `Budget Hawk'
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: It was only a joke, but one with a message: when Secretary of Defense Richard B. Cheney heard the Berlin Wall had been torn down, he wanted it rebuilt. ``He said it was the only thing standing between us and the Russians,'' Speaker of the House Thomas S. Foley kidded Cheney at a formal dinner 10 days ago. Cheney is the administration's ranking budget hawk these days; he's being needled and challenged on all fronts. He makes a logical, tightly-reasoned case for a slow and cautious reduction in defense spending, but the pressure is intense to cut more, faster. The cutback case is made with matching logic, and with the advantage of representing change in a time of dramatic world change. ``The minute Dick Cheney walked through the Pentagon door he ordered all the clocks set back 10 years,'' joked Foley, a friend and a House colleague before Cheney joined the Cabinet. ``No matter what you've heard, I'm not a relic of the Cold War. . .,, Cheney joked back. ``But . . . . somebody in this town has to worry about what we're going to do when Stalin dies.'' There are serious numbers behind all that, beginning with the $295 billion defense budget the administration seeks for the year beginning next Oct. 1. That's more dollars than this year, but it represents a 2.6 percent reduction in inflation-adjusted spending. Cheney recommends 2 percent cuts in each of the following four budget years. Democratic leaders, and now two Republican members of the Senate Armed Services Committee, say those reductions don't go deep enough. Sens. William S. Cohen of Maine and John McCain of Arizona said Thursday that the defense budget can be cut by twice as much as the administration is proposing, to save at least $50 billion more over the next five years. Foley said their proposal will not preempt Democratic demands for sharper defense budget cuts. He said it shows the administration does not have wide support for the spending levels Cheney is advocating. ``The administration is really quite isolated in this,'' the speaker said Friday. Cheney has been arguing his side of the case in congressional testimony, speeches and Pentagon statements. He put it all together in an address to the American Society of Newspaper Editors last Wednesday, saying that the administration ``has moved aggressively'' to change defense proposals so as to fit changing times. ``But as secretary of defense, I have to focus on Soviet capabilities,'' he said. ``Intentions can change overnight. Capabilities take much longer to alter.'' Cheney said those capabilities include the world's largest standing army, and a strategic nuclear force even now being modernized. So, he said, the administration is proceeding cautiously and prudently, with a five-year defense plan that would cut spending by some $231 billion, putting the defense share of the budget and the gross national product at the lowest levels since before World War II. Even in the best of international circumstances, Cheney said, if the United States is to remain a leading world power, it must maintain offensive and defensive strategic forces; a system of military alliances; troops deployed abroad, fewer in number but still there; naval superiority; flexible forces to react to varying contingencies; and an industrial base to produce high-technology weapons. Cheney said people who talk about cutting defense spending by half over the next 10 years ``would give us the defense budget of a second-class power _ the budget of an America in decline. ``Far from becoming less of a force in the world, America is going to be taking on greater global responsibilities in the years ahead,'' Cheney said. ``No other nation will be capable of our kind of global reach. ``Security threats were not invented by the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, and threats will remain long after that party's gone out of business,'' he said. ``As a result, the world will still be a dangerous place, a place that will continue to benefit from _ and indeed require _ the stabilizing influence of the American military.'' That, in brief, is the case advanced by the administration's point man on the defense budget. The counter arguments are being sounded in Congress. The battle over defense spending is just beginning.
Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 26 years.

DOC.HEAD: Valerie Bertinelli Plays Private Detective `Sydney' in New Comedy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS Elsewhere in Television item on ``Days of Our Lives'' to CORRECT character's name from Bradley to Brady
DOC.TEXT: Valerie Bertinelli spent five years looking for a new television series until she was sold on becoming ``Sydney,'' a role she says emphasizes hidden elements of her own personality. The new CBS comedy, in which she plays a young and single private detective, is her first series since ``One Day at a Time.'' Bertinelli literally grew up on ``One Day at a Time'' as one of the daughters of Bonnie Franklin. She began when she was 15 and was 24 when the show ended in 1984. ``I was never allowed to go this far with Barbara Cooper on `One Day at a Time,''' she says of her character on ``Sydney,'' which airs Wednesdays. ``I couldn't yell at people and make it funny. Sydney yells at everybody when she doesn't get her way. She puts her foot down and says, `This is the way it's going to be.' ``I've been looking for a new series ever since the old one went off,'' she said. ``I've been looking and looking. My manager and partner, Jack Grossbart, and I must have gone through a hundred ideas. Then Michael Wilson came along with `Sydney' and it clicked for me. I want it to stay on a long time.'' The show was created by Wilson, who also is a co-executive producer. ``I'd heard so many ideas and they all sounded alike,'' Bertinelli said. ``I don't know if it was the idea or Michael himself. I really, really liked him. I liked his energy and the way his mind worked so fast. I knew I wanted to work with him.'' Bertinelli plays Sydney Kells, the daughter of a policeman, now dead, and sister of a rookie policeman played by Matthew Perry. She does most of her detective work for a conservative lawyer played by Craig Bierko, and drives him crazy. She hangs out at a neighborhood bar run by Barney Martin, her father's old police partner. Rebeccah Bush is her best friend, Perry Anzilotti is her snitch and Daniel Baldwin is the barroom pest. ``I keep wanting to say Sydney is like part of me,'' she said. ``But it all goes back to Michael. It's like the part of me I've never allowed anyone to see. She's gregarious. She's smart, intuitive and naive in a way. Let's say she's naively jaded.'' The stories involve both her cases and her personal life. Sometimes, they're mixed. In one episode, her best friend is kidnapped and she has to find her. The show got good reviews, but is doing only so-so in the ratings and will have to improve to run beyond its first 13 episodes. It faces two popular Wednesday shows, ABC's ``Head of the Class'' and NBC's ``Unsolved Mysteries.'' CBS hopes to boost the ratings with a special appearance by Pat Harrington, Bertinelli's co-star on ``One Day at a Time.'' The episode, in which Harrington also plays a private eye, will be broadcast as a special on Monday, April 23, in the time slot now occupied by ``City.'' The show's theme music is ``Finish What Ya Started,'' from the latest album by Bertinelli's husband, rock guitarist Eddie Van Halen, a member of the group Van Halen. ``I begged Ed to let me use it,'' she said. The first part of the name of her production company, OOMP & Friends, ``is a little personal thing between Ed and me,'' Bertinelli said. ``Let people try to figure it out,'' she added. After ``One Day at a Time,'' Bertinelli starred in the miniseries ``I'll Take Manhattan'' and 11 TV movies. She last was seen in October in the movie ``Taken Away,'' in which she played a single mother falsely accused of child abuse. Before that, she was a pioneer aviatrix in ``Pancho Barnes.''

Elsewhere in television ... BO IS BACK: Peter Reckell is returning to his role as Bo Brady on NBC's ``Days of Our Lives.'' Until he left in 1987, Reckell had been one of the most popular stars on daytime television. His first appearance will be Wednesday, April 18. After he left the soap opera, he joined the cast of ``Knots Landing'' as Johnny Rourke, where he also got a chance to showcase his musical talents. AWARD FOR OPRAH: Oprah Winfrey will receive America's Hope Award during the taping of an ABC special at the Bob Hope Cultural Center in Palm Desert on Saturday, April 28. The award goes each year to someone in the entertainment industry whose ``words, actions and deeds best exemplify the attributes of generosity and humanity.'' Previous winners were Hope and Elizabeth Taylor. The special will be broadcast later this spring.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tuesday PMs, April 10

DOC.HEAD: A Market of Individual Stocks
DOC.TEXT: An old maxim, that it is stocks rather than the stock market that should matter to individual investors, is getting a workout on Wall Street these days. It is written in the averages. In the year's first quarter, the Dow Jones industrial average, made up of very large and mostly very blue-chip companies, slipped only 50 points or so, which works out to a drop of 1.7 percent. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock average, which includes a good many relatively smaller companies, fell more sharply, about 3.8 percent, or more than double the descent rate of the DJ average. The even broader Value Line Composite Index, whose 1,700 members include an even bigger mix of smaller companies, fell 5.8 percent, leaving it about 15 percent lower than in the summer of 1987. The verdict: Many stocks, especially smaller stocks, are down a great deal more than is indicated by the DJ average, without question the most widely used numerical indicator of market strength. Smaller stocks have been hit hard for several years now. Wright Investors' Service points out that in 23 of the past 27 quarters, small stocks have lagged behind the bigger, brand-name companies that dominate most indicators. It is a rare situation, and one that tends to confuse a lot of people, and even some analysts. Has the stock market, for example, already had its correction, disquised from popular view by a rather slight decline in the DJ average? Is the correction yet to come? Is the direction of the market up or down? The confusion might be greatest, of course, for those who judge the market by the averages instead of the prices of individual stocks or groups of stocks, because the current market is an unusual mix. Utility stocks, which had risen sharply late in 1989, were big losers in the first quarter of this year, falling 6.8 percent. Financial stocks fell more than 7 percent in both the final quarter of 1989 and the first of 1990. In fact, only four of 25 industry groups advanced in the first quarter, and three of them _ construction, metal production and electronics _ showed gains not so much because of strength but because they had fallen earlier. Such figures drive home the point made by so many investment advisers, that popular averages hardly tell the full story or even a realistic one, that people invest in individual stocks rather than in the market, and that they must watch stock prices rather than stock market averages. Today's stock market also recalls a kernel of advice underlying a good many conservative investment philosophies, that within any industry, even those performing poorly, you may find companies that defy the generality. The lesson, it seems, is that the forest isn't just a mass of trees but an assembly of individual trees. And the stock market isn't a unit in itself but one made up of thousands of separate companies, each distinct in its own way.

DOC.HEAD: Swiss in Uproar About Spying on Citizens
DOC.TEXT: Switzerland, usually a tranquil haven in a troubled world, is in an uproar over disclosures that the government spied on its own citizens for decades. Paul C. Schaffroth, retired managing editor of the liberal newspaper Der Bund, was among hundreds of thousands who demanded a summary of his file. Federal police gave him a clean political bill of health, but their dossier on him went back 20 years. It noted, among other things, that the Chinese Embassy once invited him to watch a movie about pandas, he took part in a press trip to China and, as a city councilor in charge of police, once received a letter on the visit of a Soviet delegation. The federal police files on Schaffroth and more than half a million other Swiss and foreign nationals were secret until a parliamentary commission disclosed their existence in November. Another file was kept on Justice Minister Arnold Koller, who is in charge of the police and also serves currently as president of this nation of 6.5 million. Switzerland, one of the world's oldest democracies, celebrates its 700th anniversary next year. What Koller describes as a ``deep crisis of confidence'' threatens to overshadow the event. More than 300,000 people have asked the federal prosecutor's office for copies of file cards summarizing dossiers the police may have on them. Just answering the letters will take at least until the end of 1990. The government also is under pressure to release the full dossiers on which the file cards are based. Officials say that would take many more months. Fewer than 30,000 people have received information to date. Published excerpts of Schaffroth's and other files indicate surveillance focused on contacts with leftist circles and travels to Communist countries, but was not limited to them. Even a taste for beer or watching street theater was recorded. A car parked near an anti-nuclear rally could inspire an entry in the owner's dossier. ``These methods are unworthy of our democracy,'' Schaffroth, 69, told The Associated Press. ``I feel angry and concerned.'' Koller characterized the methods as ``unacceptable and amateurish,'' but said the surveillance began during the Cold War and was similar to that in other countries. ``Snooping state'' has become a widely used reference in the Swiss press, but the strongest reactions have come from regular critics of the establishment. Artists and writers have said they may refuse to help prepare for next year's celebrations. There have been calls for a boycott of a national census planned in December. ``What made us deserve a state which is so unsure of itself that its concern for security becomes paranoid?'' Adolf Muschg, a well-known novelist, asked at a protest rally last month in Bern. He said the federal police had turned Switzerland ``into a banana republic.'' Disclosures of other secret files in the Justice and Defense ministries have added to the clamor. they include lists of ``suspects'' to be interned or restricted in case of war or political emergency. Particularly startling was the discovery in the Justice Ministry of data on thousands of foreign children who vacationed in Switzerland in the early years after World War II under a Red Cross charity program. Hubert Bucher, secretary-general of the Swiss Red Cross, said the records were turned over to the government for lack of space. He denied suggestions that the Red Cross offered them for possible use by Swiss counterintelligence. ``A storm of mistrust is sweeping the country,'' Defense Minister Kaspar Villiger told a congress of his conservative Radical Democratic Party last month. An editorial in the influential conservative newspaper Neue Zuercher Zeitung spoke of the ``brutal disillusionment'' of citizens. The independent Basler Zeitung said the files ``reflect the reverse side of our national character: This proverbial tidiness, this efficiency, this zeal, once unleashed ... can turn into unscrupulous fulfillment of duty which evidently may eliminate intelligence as well as conscience.'' Since January, the scandal has been the main topic in newspaper letters columns. Many recent letters have defended surveillance, particularly as a means of controlling crime. Some writers adopt a mocking tone. One suggested all citizens keep files on themselves and send them to the authorities regularly. Another proposed that all dossiers be burned in a huge anniversary bonfire next year. Villiger, the defense minister, said at his party rally: ``One of the worst things that can happen to a state is exposing itself to ridicule.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tuesday AMs, April 17
