DOC.HEAD: Ivory Trade Ban Weakened, Threatening Survival Of African Elephants
DOC.TEXT: A landmark agreement banning world ivory trade has begun to crumble, posing a renewed threat to the survival of the African elephant, conservationists say. The opposition of several African nations had been expected, but the bombshell came in January when Great Britain pulled out of the accord. ``It was a shock to all conservationists,'' says Ginette Hemley, director of the U.S. office of TRAFFIC, the wildlife trade monitoring program of the World Wildlife Fund. ``It was a massive turnaround on the part of the United Kingdom.'' Britain had argued forcibly in favor of the ban last fall. ``It came down to a fight between the British foreign minister and the environment minister,'' Hemley says. The foreign minister recommended that Britain pull out to ensure confidence in the Hong Kong economy, she says. ``The problem with that is it will keep open ivory markets that otherwise would have shut down,'' says David Western, an ecologist in Nairobi with Wildlife Conservation International. ``And it sends out a signal to certain poachers in Africa that Hong Kong is still good as a market. And it therefore stimulates poaching once again in Africa.'' Nevertheless, the ivory trade ban, coupled with decisions by the United States, Europe and Japan to ban all ivory imports, seems to have temporarily slowed the slaughter of African elephants, Hemley says. ``Right now, we're in a bit of a holding pattern,'' she says. ``While poaching is going on, we have every reason to believe it's slowed down dramatically. The closing of the U.S. and the European markets had a major, major effect on the trade and, hopefully, on poaching in the field.'' A study is under way to determine the ban's precise effect on poaching, she says. ``Compared with this time last year, the poaching levels are down in Kenya, down in Tanzania, and down in Zaire _ way down,'' says Western. ``So viewed overall, the picture looks more promising.'' The price of luxury ivory products has dropped by 70 percent in the United States as demand has fallen, says Hemley. In Kenya, the price paid to poachers has dropped from $20 to $50 per kilogram (2.2 pounds) to $2 to $5 per kilogram, Hemley says. The average weight of a tusk in trade is 2 to 4 kilograms. The population of African elephants has declined from 1.3 million in 1979 to an estimated 625,000, according to a report published in October by the Ivory Trade Review Group, an international team of biologists and environmentalists. Highly organized poachers armed with automatic weapons roam freely across African borders, killing 10 percent of the remaining elephants each year, the report estimated. At that rate, elephants will be extinct in the wild within 30 years, says Western, one of the report's authors. The report was prepared in advance of a meeting last October in Lausanne, Switzerland, of the international agency that regulates ivory trade. At that meeting, the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, delegates from more than 100 nations voted to ban trade in ivory around the world _ but with a last-minute compromise that threatened to undo the agreement. Countries were given 90 days to lodge ``reservations'' about their participation in the trade ban. Delegates also agreed to commission a special review of the ivory trade before the next CITES meeting in 1992, where the ban conceivably could be overturned, although that is not considered likely. Zimbabwe, Zambia, South Africa, Malawi and Botswana filed reservations, arguing that they are able to manage their herds well enough to cull ivory without depleting their elephant populations. China also filed a reservation, raising fears that a new market could develop there. But Western discounts that possibility. ``China is in no position to buy up lots of ivory, because it doesn't have the hard currency,'' he says. Ivory carvers from Hong Kong reportedly also have begun moving to South Korea, which is not part of CITES, but the effect of that move also is uncertain. South Korea ``doesn't have the tradition of using ivory for trinkets and bangles, and that market doesn't build up overnight,'' says Western. Hemley notes that South Korea's role in wildlife trade has increased dramatically during the last few years. ``It is a booming economy and potentially the biggest new market for luxury ivory products,'' she says. Western, who expressed concern last fall that an ironclad ivory ban hadn't been enacted, is now more sanguine about the African elephant's future. ``The most important consumer countries _ Japan, Europe and America _ will stick with the ban,'' he says. ``Over 80 percent of the total demand is in those three countries.'' Hong Kong, where most of the world's ivory carvers are located, has a supply of 670 tons of ivory on hand, reports indicate, and may be stuck with it. ``The Hong Kong traders are not going to have a very easy time unloading that consignment,'' Western says. ``The shift in public opinion has been so great that ivory will not be a commodity you can wear any more. Elephants will be under much, much less pressure in the next few ye`It's sort of touch-and-go,'' says Hemley. ``The fight is by no means over.''

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
DOC.NOTE: For Release Sunday, April 22, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: From AP Newsfeatures
DOC.NOTE: (APN SUNDAY ILLUSTRATIONS: Mailed print subscribers get 4 b&w photos. ColorFoto subscribers get 2 35mm slides.)
DOC.TEXT: James Addison Baker III, secretary of state, has been one of the most powerful men in Washington since Ronald Reagan first moved into the White House. And one of the most paradoxical, like his current boss and pal, George Bush. Above all, the nation's top diplomat is an adroit politician.

He swills beer right out of the can at black-tie banquets, and spits horrid little gobs of tobacco juice upon the acutely manicured greens of choice country clubs. He's a charmer, this Jim Baker. He has charmed the president and the Congress of the United States, and the president and the Congress of People's Deputies of the Soviet Union. Nancy Reagan, no slouch for loyalty, adored him despite his prior command of two campaigns against her husband. He was the hit, rather than boss George Bush, of the National Prayer Breakfast a few weeks back, and his raunchy stories are rollicking triumphs with fellows in the locker room. Michael Dukakis' campaign manager was dazzled by him. Media misanthropes gush over him. Not bad for a man who, as secretary of state, has claimed little global vision, who reads few books, and has, for the longest intervals, had so little to say to so many eager to hear him say so much. Ask Mikhail Gorbachev. Or Eduard Shevardnadze. Or the tentative leadership of a tentatively free Lithuania. Or the Chinese students. Jim Baker, 59, does not hesitate to hesitate. Nor, when he likes, even to jump ship. He is the most paradoxical member of the president's team, save the president himself. And they are like twins, fellow Houstonians, except Bush is the highbred Easterner turned Texan and Baker the highbred Texan schooled in the East. Both tall, taut and athletic Ivy Leaguers, at home in tennis whites and golf pastels, but with a yen for sagebrush and bluejeans. For shooting quail and ducks and turkeys and wade-fishing in the bayous. For sharing thoughts, just one to the other. For months, James Addison Baker III was as mute as the statues in the Kremlin's Catherine Hall about the gusts of change in the Soviet empire. Some, including Gorbachev, leaders of the NATO allies and of the U.S. Congress, were dismayed that the secretary of state seemed almost spooked by the opportunities inherent in the Cold War thaw. While Gorbachev toured the world with a song of conciliation and unfolded one new arms-control initiative after another, Baker and his Texas friend, Bush, demurred to the outcome of a ``strategic review'' of Ronald Reagan's rush to detente with Moscow. No one need have been surprised at the tactics of the new team. Jim Baker, as architect of Bush's less-than-meteoric rise to the presidency and now as vicar of his foreign policy, is given even less to risk than Bush. Together, they have made ``caution'' and ``prudence'' the watchwords of this administration. Which is not to say that either suffers diplomatic lockjaw, nor, for that matter, that there haven't been some embarrassing slips. But as Baker himself explains it, ``Sometimes a pro-active policy is best advanced by doing nothing until the right time.'' And after that agonizingly dilatory start, the president and Baker have moved from tentative probing to vigorous advocacy of a friendlier East-West relationship. A so-called ``no agenda'' shipboard summit off Malta in December led Bush to advance 21 specific proposals for greater comity between the superpowers. Stay tuned. Bush-Gorbachev II is coming to Washington on May 30. To Jim Baker, timing is everything. Any politician knows that. Any lawyer knows that. He is both, even if he doesn't care to admit it. Years ago, in his sole, unsuccessful stab at elective office, he campaigned on the slogan, ``Texas needs a lawyer, not a politician, for attorney general.'' And he was once overheard snapping at an aide: ``I'm a lawyer. Not a politician. And don't ever forget it.'' Don't believe it, either. Fact is, Baker, who once regarded election days as a chance to go hunting, ranks as one of the most politically oriented secretaries of state in history. From the moment he settled into his small back office, behind the huge ceremonial one, he let it be known that he was ``George Bush's representative at the State Department and not the State Department's representative at the White House.'' At times, Baker acts as if he were still running Bush's 1988 campaign. Last September, he was challenged to respond to the complaint of Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, that the administration was dragging its feet on superpower issues. Baker, rather than addressing that charge, replied: ``When the president is rocking along with a 70 percent approval rating on his handling of foreign policy, if I were the leader of the opposition, I might have something similar to say.'' Baker's poll-watching galls the Foreign Service's idealists, who argue that in a rapidly changing world, the boldest vision can be the most realistic, the most aggressive policy the most prudent. Baker, first as Ronald Reagan's chief of staff, then as treasury secretary, and now as secretary of state, has been a master at working Congress, and he insists that his lieutenants emulate his meticulous courtesy when dealing with the legislative branch. He typically works until 9 p.m. or so, with most of those evening hours occupied with initiating or returning calls to Capitol Hill on his 41-line telephone. And it is through Congress that he sometimes exercises his power. After weeks of Israeli foot-dragging on his proposal for a negotiated settlement of the Palestinian issue, he induced Sen. Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, to suggest taking aid from Israel and Egypt and giving it to Eastern Europe. Baker then publicly smiled upon Dole's trial balloon, while insisting the idea had no connection with the Palestinian dispute. At Cabinet meetings, Baker occupies the traditional seat of honor, at the president's right. Rightly so. No man or woman enjoys more presidential confidence. And none can so comfortably tell him that he is dead wrong about something. ``There are others who can,'' Bush once said. ``But they don't.''

DOC.TEXT: Without Jim Baker, George Bush might not have become president. Because without Baker, Bush would not have been vice president, and Ronald Reagan's anointed successor. It was in May, 1980, when Baker looked at Reagan's delegate numbers and leaked it to the press that his candidate, Bush, would be withdrawing from the presidential race. That was news to Bush, who, several hundred miles away at the time, fully intended to press Reagan in the windup primaries in New Jersey, Ohio and California _ Reagan's home state. A furious Bush summoned Baker and his staff to his home in Houston. As Bush tells the story in his book, ``Looking Forward,'' he insisted to Baker that he still had a shot. Baker: ``George, you've got to know when to hold 'em and know when to fold 'em.'' Bush: ``Jim, I've never quit anything until it was finished.'' Baker: ``But the campaign IS finished, George. You're the only one who doesn't seem to know it.'' Bush withdrew, and Reagan got a unified convention in Detroit. ``What I'll admit to, but George never will,'' Baker said in 1981, ``is that the veep thing was always the fallback. It was always in my mind. That's why, at every opportunity, I had him cool his rhetoric about Reagan.'' And Reagan, he added, would have been ``terminally ticked off'' had Bush pursued him into California. It wasn't the vice president-elect who landed him his job in the Reagan White House, a fact Baker is quick to confide to anyone who suggests that he remains especially beholden to Bush. Instead, it was Reagan's longtime California confidant, Michael K. Deaver, and Nancy Reagan who sold the new president on making Baker the White House chief of staff. Reagan loyalists initially were aghast, but later viewed the appointment as a key to Reagan's first-term success. Baker did have enemies in the Reagan administration, and he wasn't entirely successful at cutting them down. He often found himself at odds with then-counselor Edwin Meese and Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger, and particularly with National Security Adviser William Clark and Secretary of State Alexander Haig. The latter two were not at all pleased with his resistance to their efforts to expand U.S. military involvement in Central America. ``Jim saw himself as guardian of the president's legislative agenda and was convinced that if we got too far into this, it could jeopardize our ability to get anything through Congress,'' Deaver recalled. In 1983, Clark left to become interior secretary, and Baker pressed Reagan to make him his national security adviser, with Deaver taking the chief of staff job. Reagan agreed, but then found himself confronted in the Oval Office by the quartet of Meese, CIA director William Casey, Weinberger and Clark, all of whom opposed the appointment. Baker told the president to kill the plan if it were a problem for him. Reagan did. Baker, wearied by the White House infighting, jumped at Treasury Secretary Donald Regan's offer to swap jobs after the 1984 election. Reagan did agree to that one, and Baker took his one-man think tank, his protege Richard G. Darman, with him. At Treasury, Baker built a record which ranks him beside Henry H. Fowler and John B. Connally as the most influential occupants of that job since World War II. In his 3{ years there, with Darman brainstorming behind the scenes, he negotiated major international agreements for economic coordination among industrialized nations, for dealing with Third World debt, and for an orderly decline in the dollar _ thus boosting U.S. exports. He was credited, too, with the single-handed rescue of the U.S.-Canada Free Trade Agreement when those talks were on the brink of collapse. Most notably, he pushed through a major tax reform, in part by conceding credit and a prominent role to congressional Democrats. None of those steps has yet drawn consensus raves from economists or historians. The budget and trade deficits have barely been dented, and the problem of Third World defaults won't go away. But without his initiatives, says Baker, ``matters would have been a great deal worse.'' Baker's reputation for honesty was tainted when, by his own admission, he told an unnecessary falsehood on national television last year to conceal the first trip of presidential envoys to Beijing following the Tiananmen Square massacre. In retrospect, said Baker, he should have ``no-commented.'' He was less than adroit, too, when he ad-libbed an expression of confidence about Germany's ``continued membership in _ or association with _ NATO,'' as if to open Germany's way out of the alliance and toward neutrality. He disavowed the ``association with'' phrase, but the slip served to weaken the U.S. position in the eyes of other diplomats. Though generally familiar with global issues from his years with Reagan, Baker came to his new job with huge gaps in his knowledge of the international players and the nuances of diplomacy. He was upstaged during some of his early encounters, like that first trip to Moscow, where Gorbachev caught him off balance with an announcement of Soviet troop cutbacks in Europe. But after more than 300 meetings with foreign leaders and 150,000 miles of travel, Baker is much more self-assured. Twenty-one years ago, Baker was a corporate attorney in Houston, nominally a Democrat, who didn't bother to vote in most elections and ``really didn't participate in partisan politics in any way.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: any way.''
DOC.TEXT: Not so for Baker's wife and college sweetheart, Mary Stuart McHenry, who had grown up in Dayton, Ohio, across the street from a relative of Bush's. When Bush ran unsuccessfully for the Senate in 1964, she donned a straw boater and passed out leaflets. Some years earlier, she once had attempted to organize a Republican precinct meeting in her living room. ``One person came,'' Baker recalls. ``I served the drinks.'' Other than that, Baker remained on the political sidelines, though Bush, who won a House seat two years later, became a frequent hunting and fishing companion as well as tennis partner. And they regularly attended services together at St. Martin's Episcopal Church. Then, in 1969, as Bush was preparing for a second stab at the Senate, Baker's world collapsed. Mary Stuart was dying of cancer. Bush accompanied his distraught buddy on the hospital visits, then to the funeral. Convinced that he needed a new challenge to salve the grief, Bush implored Baker to manage his campaign in Harris County _ Houston and the surrounding area. Finally, Baker accepted. Bush lost again, but Baker was hooked. In 1972 he served as state GOP finance chairman, and ran the 14 Texas Gulf Coast counties for Richard M. Nixon. And in 1975, Bush, by then Nixon's special envoy to China, recommended him to Commerce Secretary Rogers C.B. Morton as an undersecretary. Just eight months later, he was recruited to follow Morton into President Ford's campaign, which faced a stiff and burgeoning challenge from Ronald Reagan for the GOP nomination. Morton made Baker the chief ``delegate hunter'' to track and woo uncommitted delegates and to keep Ford's own convention force in line against Reagan's surging bandwagon. He proved so effective that Ford replaced Morton with Baker for the general election campaign. Ford came from 30 points down to lose a squeaker to Jimmy Carter. In 1978, Baker made his only attempt to win elective office himself, as Texas attorney general. He thought his opponent would be liberal Price Daniel, but he found himself facing Mark White, a more conservative and far more popular Democrat. Baker lost. There have been other setbacks. Baker's remarriage to Susan Garrett Winston, his first wife's closest friend and the widow of a Baker acquaintance, triggered resentments among the seven children by their previous spouses. But those family problems have now been patched up. Jim and Susan have had one child together, Mary Bonner, 12. The other seven are grown. What Jim Baker wants most to do, according to some intimates, is get the job now held by friend George. Baker ``categorically'' denies this, saying he intends to be secretary of state for eight years, then drive himself and Susan to his ranch in Wyoming. But a Princeton friend, Phil Uzielli, remembers that during the Bush campaign ``a group of us were sitting around and someone said again that Jimmy is the one who should be president, not George. He loved it, and he let the talk go on a bit before shutting it down.'' Susan Baker acknowledges that ``Jimmy has a tremendous ambition and drive to reach the top. But the presidency is the last thing in his mind right now ... he's got to be the best secretary of state he can. The rest may come later.'' ``Obviously, being president is on his mind,'' says former Democratic National Chairman Robert Strauss. ``He's that smart and that shrewd and that ambitious. He knows there's only one job in Washington worth having.''

DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON _ Secretary of State Jim Baker is the scion of one of Houston's most distinguished families _ the Bakers of Baker & Botts, one of the largest and oldest law firms west of the Mississippi. His button-down shirts say ``JAB III,'' but he is actually the fourth James A. Baker. The first, his great-grandfather, was a Civil War veteran and district judge who moved to Houston and co-founded the firm after the war. His grandfather, known as Captain Baker, a title bestowed by the ceremonial Houston Light Guard, was a founder and chairman of the Texas Commerce Bank, and, most dramatically, unraveled the murder of his client, New York industrialist William March Rice, in the fall of 1900. Captain Baker proved that Rice had been done in by a butler and lawyer who had prepared a false will; his sleuthing saved the fortune with which Rice University was built. Jim Baker's father, the third senior partner in Baker & Botts, was called ``The Warden'' by Jim's friends. He was a stern disciplinarian, quick to administer whippings and urge Jim and sister Bonnie to new challenges _ like jumping off the high dive no matter how scared they were. Baker recalls his father often awakened him by throwing ice water into his face. ``Gets you up real fast,'' he said. Following his father, Baker attended the Hill School and Princeton. He did a two-year stint in the Marines, commissioned as a lieutenant. The Korean War was on, but he spent most of his time on a ship in the Mediterranean. Then he went home to Texas for law school, where he made the Law Review and missed by one slot the ``Order of the Coif,'' accorded the 10 percent of the graduating class. He remains disappointed about that minor failure, even dwells on it, to this day. Baker, barred from joining his father's firm by a since-abandoned anti-nepotism rule, made his own mark as a corporate attorney, amassing assets now estimated at $4 million. He was little known outside legal circles and the Houston Country Club, where he and a fellow member won the tennis doubles championship twice in the early 1960s. But Baker, a Democrat by family tradition, and George Bush, a local oilman and son of a Connecticut Republican senator, kept politics out of their game.

DOC.TEXT: No one in the Ronald Reagan administration, with the possible exception of Secretary of State George Shultz, achieved the stature that Jim Baker did. As White House chief of staff, he cultivated members of Congress from the start, and rolled up legislative victories that eluded other couriers of the Reagan program. He also assiduously courted the news media, provoking Donald Regan, his successor as chief of staff, to tell a Republican group that he was ``appalled'' at the amount of time Baker spent with reporters, and then-CIA Director William Casey to complain that Baker was the biggest leaker in town. But his supporters credited Baker with pushing the essential elements of Reagan's first-term agenda through Congress, including those surprisingly early triumphs on the budget and taxes _ fashioned by luring ``Boll Weevil'' Democrats into a new Hill majority. Some critics fault him for just those successes _ saying he too often orchestrated short-term victories without much caring about the lasting consequences, a burgeoning federal deficit foremost among them. He was ``much more of a Mr. Fix-it'' than planner, ``much more interested in politics than in policy,'' said former Reagan Treasury official John E. Chapoton, a one-time law partner and neighbor of Baker's. William A. Niskanen Jr., a former member of the Council of Economic Advisers, said, ``He doesn't bring any particular convictions to bear on a job ... other than doing a good job. I don't think he has any particular vision.'' David Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget during Baker's tenure at the White House, wrote that ``Baker was, deep down, neither very versed on matters of policy nor intensely interested in them.'' Baker, at the time, admitted as much. ``I don't consider myself as one who has deeply held views on specific issues,'' he told Washingtonian magazine in 1982. Baker might have found himself the odd man out among Reagan's coterie of Californians around the Oval Office, but, under a plan drawn up by his prickly but creative sidekick, Richard G. Darman, he quickly managed to seize control of the White House paper flow to the president. With that came power, particularly the ability to ``knife his enemies and praise his own work,'' according to an undelighted but impressed Paul M. Weyrich, president of the super-conservative Free Congress Research and Education Foundation.

DOC.TEXT: Power, says Secretary of State Jim Baker, must be put in perspective. ``Power doesn't really bring the fulfillment that many think it does,'' Baker told a National Prayer Breakfast in February as President Bush and 3,000 other government employees listened. ``Over these last nine years,'' Baker said, ``I have had opportunities to participate in the exercise of more power than I would even have imagined. I have felt the weight of responsibility that that brings, and I have to admit to you as well that I have felt the temptations that are attendant to it.'' But that changed, he said, when he came up against a ``personal problem'' several years ago. He didn't say what it was. Perhaps he referred to the tribulations with his son John, who was arrested in 1982, fined $2,000 and required to enter a drug treatment program for selling marijuana. His wife, Susan, Baker said, helped him pray and to recognize that ``I really needed to stop trying to play God, and turn the matter over to him ... Without this kind of partnership, I'm convinced I would never have resolved the problem.'' Baker also described another moment that drove home, in his mind, the fleeting nature of power. He was riding to the White House in his limousine, he said, when he noticed a familiar figure, walking alone, on the sidewalk. ``He was someone many of you would have recognized, a chief of staff in a previous administration,'' Baker said. ``There he was, alone, no reporters, no security, no adoring public, no trappings of power _ just one solitary man alone with his thoughts. ``That mental picture continually serves to remind me of the impermanence of power and place. That man had it all, but only for a time. That memory puts my own life in perspective.''

DOC.TEXT: ``If a lot of people cling to General de Gaulle's image and say they have something Gaullist about them, it shows that his politics and ideas were very realistic,'' he says. De Gaulle had a large family, but he left no dynasty behind him. His son, Admiral Philippe de Gaulle, is a senator. Two grandsons are members of the National Assembly. Laurent is not sure about running for office. The general's shoes, all agree, are not easy to fill. Charles Andre Marie Joseph de Gaulle was born into a family going back five centuries into what was known as the sword-bearing officer class. France at the time, in its Belle Epoch, had produced Monet, Degas, Cezanne, Gauguin, Matisse, Toulouse-Lautrec and Renoir. Rodin was sculpting, Proust was dreaming, and Rostand had written ``Cyrano de Bergerac.'' De Gaulle's father, a teacher, kindled an interest in history and geography, but young Charles knew his role. Biographers recounted how, in a game of toy soldiers, his brother wanted to be king of France. ``Never!'' Charles blurted out. ``France is mine!'' When France was his, he treated it with respect. Shunning the trappings of power, he remained an acting brigadier general even when called back from retirement in 1958 to end the Algerian War. Despite his postwar popularity, he could not consolidate the turbulent politics. Wondering aloud how Joan of Arc would have looked atop a coalition, he retreated in 1946 to his beloved woods. His only home was the modest Boisserie in Colombey, a former brewery bought in 1934 with a small down-payment from his colonel's pay. He lived simply, amusing himself with long lone walks. During the bitter war over Algeria, maverick officers attempting a coup d'etat were such a threat that de Gaulle got back on the radio for another appeal: ``Frenchmen! Frenchwomen. Help me!'' Later, die-hard terrorists sprayed gunfire at his armored Citroen, among four other attempts on his life. But, for security, de Gaulle relied mostly on his aloof and forbidding presence. His political undoing came about on the streets of Paris in 1968. Rioting students, rebelling at a stagnating France under a leader from another age, set politics to boil. De Gaulle held a referendum, his old device to challenge France to find a better way. The vote showed he had lost the nation's confidence. He left the presidency and, a year later, he died. He is buried in a modest tomb at the little church in Colombey. Not far away, a 150-foot-tall granite-and-bronze Cross of Lorraine is visible for miles around. One of the two fragments of Gaullist philosophy chipped in the stone asserts: ``There exists a pact over 20 centuries between the greatness of France and freedom in the world.'' But Genevieve Anthonioz de Gaulle, a favorite niece, prefers the second, which she feels sums up her uncle's long, spare life: ``In our time, the only dispute of value is man's. It is man who must be saved, allowed to live and to develop.'' Each year, 120,000 Frenchmen and foreigners come here, out of respect or simple curiosity. During 1990, memories will be closer at hand. Jacques Chirac, the mayor of Paris who ran for president for the neo-Gaullist RPR, in March opened a display of photos, documents and memorabilia. The piece de resistance is a wax General de Gaulle, eerily lifelike. The post office issued a commemorative stamp, prompting the satirical weekly, Le Canard Enchaine, to draw its own version with a protruding annex to accommodate de Gaulle's ample nose. From Nov. 19-24, the Charles de Gaulle Institute and the U.N. Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization are sponsoring a seminar entitled, ``De Gaulle in His Century.'' Since 1986, the Institute has commissioned 500 studies from specialists in 50 countries to add to existing Gaulliana. Its own 22 books include a bibliography of thousands of works. It is hard to escape ubiquitous photos of the general's deadpan mien, his prominent nose brooding over a resolute and clean-shaven chin. But in a France that is melding slowly with a wider Europe, a less assertive France where the term ``grandeur'' provokes the occasional snicker, some Frenchmen see memories slipping away. On a sunny Saturday, a family from a village in northern France stood solemnly by de Gaulle's grave. Another visitor asked them what they knew of the man buried there. Lysiane Nourte, 17, and her 18-year-old sister, Anne-Lise, looked at each other and shrugged. Finally, Lysiane ventured, ``Wasn't he the chief of the war?'' Their father tried to tell them a little about de Gaulle and, to the reporter, he explained that the general was a sort of cartoon character to a new generation. As he spoke, 10-year-old Yann had a flash: ``Didn't he have a beard?'' Still, throngs pack into his old lair, with its lavishly signed photos of the century's other great leaders and a library that sandwiched Karl von Clausewitz between Balzac and Moliere. ``Some people come back year after year, to stand quietly and reflect,'' says Marinette Piot, a Colombey native who runs a postcard and kitsch shop near the church. ``He is not forgotten.''

DOC.TEXT: Back in the '70s there was talk of a back-to-the-city movement. In places like Detroit, that was mostly talk. Today Detroit faces an uncertain future with tens of thousands of derelict homes and businesses simply abandoned by their owners. But the city is trying to fight back.

Nearly 300 years after its founding as a French colony, Detroit is looking for new settlers willing to stake claims to a city losing ground every month to blight and desertion. Thousands of abandoned houses are being demolished in a multimillion-dollar effort to prevent arson and drugs from spreading throughout neighborhoods still trying to hold their own. In addition, low-interest loans are being offered to renovate derelict homes. After 40 years of white flight to the suburbs, Detroit _ like many other cities _ has become a tattered patchwork of new downtown high-rises, aging public housing, modest subdivisions, squalid tenements and ever-broader stretches of vacant land. Despite scattered private and public renovation efforts, the city has become the reluctant landlord of 20 percent of its total land area as buildings and vacant lots revert to city control because of unpaid taxes. Unofficial estimates say there are 80,000 parcels of vacant land within the city. Between 50,000 and 60,000 of those are owned by the city, which has no overall strategy for developing them. The Detroit Free Press in July 1989 counted more than 15,000 abandoned buildings in Detroit, two-thirds of them vacant single-family homes. Gary Sands, a professor of urban geography at Wayne State University, blames the city's economic, social and image problems. The city lost 100,000 jobs between 1980 and 1988, when its population fell from 1.2 million to about 1 million. The 1990 census is expected to show a drop below 1 million. ``A lot of the problem with the vacant derelict land is that there is no market for it,'' Sands says. ``There's no demand.'' Detroit's closest suburbs attracted increasing numbers of relatively affluent, better-educated blacks during the 1980s, while predominantly white suburban sprawl stretched even farther. Sands says the city must find a way to lure a generation native to the suburbs and which, except for downtown entertainment, avoids Detroit. ``People want bright, shiny stuff; they're not interested in pioneering,'' he says. ``Detroit has never had the real high-density office core, like New York, that makes people want to live close to where they work. There's more commuting from suburb to suburb than from suburb to central city.'' Robert Berg, Mayor Coleman Young's press secretary, puts part of the blame on negative news reports. ``We get tired of reading stories that convince people that we in Detroit live in little broken-down frame houses with a crack house next door,'' Berg says. Urban experts say the problem of abandonment of central cities isn't confined to the Rust Belt. Aggressive redevelopment of downtown areas is under way in cities as far-flung as Boise, Idaho; Beaumont, Texas; and Charlotte, N.C., says Ann Bowman, a political scientist at the University of South Carolina. Suburban sprawl likely will continue during the 1990s, even in cities with stronger housing markets and more aggressive redevelopment plans than Detroit's, says H. James Brown, director of the Joint Center for Urban Studies at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government. ``Detroit is actually leading a path that other cities may be on in the next 10 years,'' Brown says. ``All communities are going to find that there isn't the central city housing demand that there has been. ``Even in the '70s, when it was alleged that there was a back-to-the-city movement, young people were more likely to be moving to the suburbs.'' In Detroit, Berg says, the city and nine banks recently pooled $40 million to form the Detroit Neighborhood Investment Corp., which provides low-interest loans for renovating existing housing. A few private investors have joined the reclamation effort on their own. A corporation headed by Grosse Pointe developer Jim Saros bought the 62-year-old Chalfonte Apartments on the lower east side for $400,000. It spent an additional $700,000 to renovate the 20-unit building that had been vacant for seven years. Detroit has spent $15 million to demolish 3,000 vacant structures this fiscal year. The budget includes another $15 million to tear down 3,000 more buildings by June 30. ``One of the things you're doing when you knock down the abandoned houses is do it quickly before it spreads like a cancer,'' Berg says. Marcell Mayberry has seen that cancer ravage much of her lower east-side neighborhood. Now she fears it may reach Algonquin Street, too. A sagging, wood-frame bungalow next to Mayberry's house is so far the only abandoned house on Algonquin. Mayberry cuts the grass and joins other neighbors in keeping watch for arsonists or vandals. She says she never sees the owner. The neighborhood's decline began about 10 years ago, when absentee landlords began renting to welfare clients and neglected their property, Mayberry says. Later came the crack dealers, burglars and arsonists. Mayberry is unimpressed by Grayhaven, a condominium-marina project under construction near her home. ``When this crack cocaine came in, that's when things started disappearing,'' she says. ``It's an epidemic, and there ain't nothing anyone can do about it. If they've got the same problems we've got, how are Grayhaven residents going to help?'' In Cleveland, $16 million has been spent to demolish abandoned buildings over the past decade, says Mike Marcelino, a spokesman for Mayor Michael White. That compares with $15 million this year alone in Detroit, whose population is about twice that of Cleveland. ``When you start tearing down housing, you can quickly ruin a street or neighborhood,'' Marcelino says. ``How's it going to affect the houses on either side? A lot of people cannot afford a new house.'' Cleveland officials have created a land bank to pool vacant property in hopes of redevelopment, says Norman Krumholtz, the city's former planning director. ``In strategic locations, they assemble enough property so you have some kind of reasonable development,'' says Krumholtz, a professor of urban planning at Cleveland State University. Although the real estate market is soft in Cleveland, the land bank lets the city ``clear the titles and sit on it until it becomes ripe again,'' he says. Besides lacking specific incentives for developing large clusters of vacant land, a 1985 revision to Detroit's 1969 master plan still awaits City Council approval, says Councilman Mel Ravitz. ``We could and should be doing a whole lot more to woo investors for residential development or rehabilitation,'' he says. ``The city apparently has not appeared attractive enough to the risk-taking developers.''

DOC.TEXT: He's a composer for our time, a man who writes operas about the social condition of the modern world. Sir Michael Tippett, though better known in his native England than in America, has been called ``one of the three or four giant composers in the last half of the 20th century.''

Sir Michael Tippett, the 85-year-old British composer who was briefly jailed as a pacifist during World War II, is a musician with a message. To him, the sight of young people dancing on the Berlin Wall was ``a marvelous piece of theater.'' For one thing, no shots were fired. For 50 years, Sir Michael has been writing his philosophical reflections on world events into his oratorio and opera libretti, ever since T.S. Eliot gave him some tips for writing ``A Child of Our Time,'' which became his first major success. ``A Child of Our Time'' was inspired by a young Jew who killed a Nazi official in Paris, providing the excuse for Kristallnacht, the prelude to the Holocaust. ``When I wrote `A Child of Our Time' I had to come out from any notion that what I was writing was just for my countrymen,'' says the silver-haired composer. ``I had to write something about a condition that seemed to me really universal.'' Sir Michael's opera ``King Priam'' used a Greek myth to explore politics, power and choice. His opera ``The Ice Break'' explores violence, racism and political turmoil. In ``The Knot Garden,'' one of his characters was a scarred woman. He thought of her as a French underground fighter who'd been tortured by the Gestapo in World War II. When the opera was performed recently in Melbourne, Australia, the character became a Chinese student in Tiananmen Square. Sir Michael, who attended the performance, approved of the change. ``If a work has value, it will proceed in this way from a now to another now,'' he says. Sir Peter Hall, who staged the premiere of Sir Michael's fifth opera, ``New Year,'' last October in Houston, has called Sir Michael ``a child of our time in each decade. ``There is something extremely young about him,'' he says. ``He hasn't closed up at all.'' The Glyndebourne Festival will stage the English premiere of ``New Year'' on July 1. BBC television will tape it and there is talk of productions in Canada, Holland and Germany. In December, Sir Michael finished ``Byzantium,'' which the Chicago Symphony will premiere in April 1991 to honor Carnegie Hall's 100th birthday. He's now composing his fifth string quartet. David Gockley, general director of the Houston Grand Opera, says, ``I think he is probably one of the three or four giant composers in the last half of the 20th century. ``In this country he is predominantly known for his orchestral works. He has made the rounds of every major symphony in the last 25 years conducting his big orchestral works. ``In operas, he puts together these fantastical collages of allegory. I think his philosophical approach to the problems of complicated urbanized society has won him a great deal of friends among young people and people that share his concerns.'' When he was about 25, Sir Michael was strongly impressed by the movie ``The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse,'' starring Rudolph Valentino, in which a father wanders among the white crosses of a cemetery in Flanders. ``I realized all those wonderful young people had gone to the ground and never had a life at all,'' he says. ``When it came to the next war, it came to me that these young people could have been scapegoats, people thrown out by a society. I had to sing in some way about them. I could not get them out of my mind. They're there to this day.'' In England, where he is better known than he is in America, Sir Michael has a fan club and members get, just as Paul McCartney's fans do, a newsletter about his activities, performances and recordings. The Kent Opera is currently taking ``King Priam'' on tour to six cities. Sir Michael is conducting one recording a year of his compositions for Nimbus Records. His eyesight is failing, making it difficult for him to conduct concerts. Recordings are easier. When Covent Garden was rehearsing Sir Michael's ``The Ice Break'' in 1977, he told a reporter he'd never write another opera. ``That answer was given at the time I knew I was getting on in age and strength,'' he says. ``I had already decided I would like to do a big work for voices and orchestra for the concert hall. It became `The Mask of Time.' ``After having completed `The Mask of Time,' I still was very vigorous and the theater took over again. I don't quite know why it did but it did.'' Sir Michael celebrated becoming 85 on Jan. 2 by accepting invitations to hear his music played in several cities. The University of Cincinnati's College-Conservatory of Music performed his opera ``The Knot Garden.'' Sir Michael called the performances brilliant and the production masterly, adding, ``And I've seen a lot of them.'' The Cincinnati Symphony performed his lyrical ``Fantasia Concertante on a Theme of Corelli.'' At intermission, a young woman was overheard to say, ``I liked the Mozart but the Tippett completely blew me away. I loved it.'' Jesus Lopez-Cobos, music director of the Cincinnati Symphony, says, ``I think Tippett is one of the big composers. Of British composers, Benjamin Britten is more known here. I think Tippett's time will come, too.'' About Britten, Sir Michael says, ``We were mildly rivals if you like. We both wanted to go into theater. We didn't think the operas of the preceding generation were workable.'' Sir Michael says that on the eve of his entering prison for three months in World War II as a pacifist, Britten ``was much more frightened than I was.'' Now, he says, ``The world is changing very quickly. To my great delight and surprise I've lived long enough to see young people dancing on the (Berlin) Wall, a marvelous piece of theater for one who believes you can't really do it by guns. It was done in another way.''

DOC.TEXT: It's one of the last of the ``mom and pop'' jails, a place where serving time is a family affair. If you've got to be locked up, the Gilmer County Jail in West Virginia would sure beat Riker's Island in New York City.

At Lee and Terri Frederick's place, room guests enjoy old-fashioned home cooking and are greeted at breakfast with a friendly, ``Good morning.'' They can watch television, play table tennis in the recreation room, use the telephone and entertain visitors in the family's garage. But don't pack your bags for a weekend in the mountains. The Fredericks' place is the Gilmer County Jail, one of the nation's last ``mom and pop'' jails. The jail owes more to Mayberry than to Attica or Alcatraz. While inmates eat Terri's pasta, pizza and meat dishes in their upstairs cells, the Fredericks are eating the same fare downstairs. ``I just make extra for the guys upstairs,'' Mrs. Frederick says. Every other Thursday, the couple pulls their 1986 Chrysler out of their garage and sets up folding chairs so inmates can entertain visitors. The Frederick's house rules are posted in the jail's recreation room: ``Golden Rules: If you open it, close it. If you take it out, lock it up. If it will brighten someone's day, SAY IT!'' The Fredericks live with their two sons, Joey, 6, and Lynn, 2, in a three-bedroom brick house whose upstairs cells have housed the county's criminals for 50 years. The two-story building, built of flesh-colored brick, sits atop a hill, sandwiched between the county courthouse and a Glenville State College dormitory. The rest of the neighborhood is made up of modest single-family homes that look a lot like the Frederick house, except for the bars on the windows. Lee, 29, is a former truck driver who took the job of jailer a year ago. Terri, 27, who lived in the house as a child when her parents ran the jail, now does the cooking and cleaning. In her spare time, she dispatches sheriff's deputies, local police, ambulances and rescue workers from her living room. The room also has alarms for Glenville's two banks. Until recently, when a night jailer was hired, one of them was always on duty from 7 a.m. to midnight. After that, prisoners could summon Lee by pushing a button on the elevator that connects the first and second floors. Mrs. Frederick stays in touch with wall-mounted loudspeakers that allow her to hear calls when she's working in the kitchen. It's easy to know what's happening in the jail because, ``We can hear them right through the ceiling,'' Mrs. Frederick says. Frederick says his sons are not allowed upstairs no matter how curious they get. ``They'll find out about this stuff soon enough anyway,'' he says. On an average day, the jail houses about nine prisoners, most detained for drunken driving, destruction of property or game law violations. In the evenings, prisoners play table tennis or watch television in a family sized recreation room. They have access to the couple's telephone every night, but long distance calls are not allowed. Such homey touches aren't lost on the inmates. ``Lee treats me OK, and the food's all right, but I just don't like being in jail,'' says Carson Yeager, 45, who described himself as a ``chronic alcoholic.'' Yeager is one of the Fredericks' regulars. ``The majority of ours are not hardened criminals,'' Frederick says. ``They don't need to be exposed to that type of people.'' Some former inmates even come back to say hello occasionally. A 21-year-old former inmate, now incarcerated elsewhere, has written the couple four letters in the last two months. Still, rural ``mom and pop'' jails are increasingly being phased out because of generally substandard conditions, high maintenance costs and a move toward regional jails. ``They are a rapidly dying breed,'' says Michael O'Toole, chief of the jails division of the National Institute of Corrections. More than 19 million people filter through 3,300 county jails each year, according to U.S. Justice Department statistics. ``Small jails are not cost effective,'' O'Toole says. ``Although a lot are well-meaning and well-intentioned, the conditions of confinement aren't what they should be. A lot are just incapable of being up to standards. ``The operation rises and falls on the integrity of the operator. For each example where somebody is fulfilling their responsibility, you can look at another side of the ledger and see someone who shouldn't have any authority over anybody in custody whatsoever.'' Recently the state Facilities Review Panel took aim at the Fredericks, warning it would shut the jail down if Gilmer County officials didn't add staff at the jail. So Sheriff Kenneth Smith Jr. hired a night-shift jailer and beefed up the part-time staff so the Fredericks only have to work 40 hours a week. ``It's cramped our personal lives a little bit, sure,'' Frederick says.

DOC.TEXT: His mother was a maid in Memphis, Tenn., who brought books for him to read from the white homes where she worked. Today Eddie N. Williams heads the Joint Center for Political Studies, a research group playing an increasingly important role as blacks move into the political mainstream.

Eddie N. Williams is constantly on the phone these days fielding questions, what with black politicians so much in the news. Is Jesse Jackson maintaining his hold on black voters? How did L. Douglas Wilder pull off his election as the first black governor of Virginia? How is the indictment of Mayor Marion Barry playing among black voters in the nation's capital? Those are the kinds of questions people regularly ask Williams, president of the Joint Center for Political Studies, a little-known research institute he has built into the country's premier black think tank. The center has a staff of 60 providing research on the social, political and economic activities and concerns of African-Americans. It is most well known for the annual ``Roster of Black Elected Officials'' which has charted the growth of black officeholders from the 600 it originally listed to the more than 7,000 now included. The center now occupies a special political niche at a time when black candidates and voters are playing an increasingly influential role in national and local politics. The mainstream is the ``new frontier'' for black politicians, Williams says, citing the 1989 elections of Wilder in Virginia and David Dinkins as mayor of New York. ``That's where the jobs are,'' he says. ``All of the positions that are in predominantly black jurisdictions have just about been filled.'' Largely disenfranchised in many Southern states until the mid-1960s, blacks can now claim credit for electing Democratic senators in places like Alabama, Georgia, Louisiana, and North Carolina. The mayors of New York, Los Angeles, Chicago and Philadelphia, all are black. Yet, 18 years ago the president of the University of Chicago was startled to hear that Williams, his vice president for public affairs, was leaving to head a relatively unknown research organization. ``The challenge to me is to make you hear about it,'' was Williams' response. The black electorate remains overwhelmingly Democratic, but two photographs deliberately juxtaposed on a wall in Williams' office symbolize how jealously he guards the non-partisan status of the center. One shows Williams with President Bush; in the other he is with two-time Democratic presidential contender Jackson. ``People don't knock the Joint Center as being liberal or conservative or Republican or Democratic, and that's a very difficult position for a black organization to maintain,'' says Robert Bates, a Mobil Oil Co. lobbyist and close friend of Williams. ``It's a good role to be in, to call the shots as you see them,'' says Williams. ``I'll comment on the Republicans and I'll comment on the Democrats. I let the chips fall where they may.'' One question Williams is asked frequently is whether President Bush and Republican Party chairman Lee Atwater can achieve their goal of making significant gains for the Republican Party among black voters. The opportunity is there, Williams says, ``But until the Republicans can succeed in recruiting some visible black leaders with a following and until they disabuse themselves of the notion that they can create a black leader they're going to only be modestly successful.'' Williams, 57, was born in Memphis, Tenn., the only child of Ed Williams, a one-armed jazz piano player and his wife, Georgia, a maid at hotels and well-to-do private homes in the city. From her, Williams learned the value of finding and assembling seemingly evasive information. Williams says his mother would often bring home books, clothes and other artifacts from the homes in which she worked. ``This is what that white boy's reading, now you ought to be reading it,'' Williams recalls her saying. He says he read the materials that were otherwise not available to black children in the segregated school systems of the South during the 1930s and 1940s. Bebe Bowers Fingall, a high school English teacher called ``mama'' by her students, helped hone Williams' competitive spirit and self-confidence. Williams says that as one of ``mama's pets,'' he was drawn toward all kinds of writing and speaking anthologies and plays. After earning a bachelor's degree in journalism from the University of Illinois, he did graduate work in political science at Atlanta and Howard universities. Williams also served as director of the Center for Policy Studies at the University of Chicago. He was director of the U.S. Office of Equal Employment Opportunity and a foreign service reserve officer at the State Department. Williams has two children _ a son, Edward, 24, who is a graduate student at the Peabody School of Music at Johns Hopkins University, and a daughter, Tracy, 26, who is an actress at the Living Stage Theater in Washington, D.C. His 21-year-old stepson, Terrence Reddick, is a senior at George Mason University in Virginia. But his baby is the Joint Center for Political Studies, as reflected on the wall of his office in a framed and matted paraphrase of a popular slogan: ``Have you hugged your 501 (c) 3 today?'' _ a reference to the section in U.S. law that grants tax-exempt status to non-profit organizations. The center is funded by $3 million a year in grants from private foundations and corporations. ``What he has done is to provide a place for substantial, high quality, objective research where none existed before,'' says Norman Ornstein of the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative Washington think tank. Rep. Augustus Hawkins, D-Calif., the oldest and longest-serving black member of the House and chairman of the Education and Labor Committee, says he calls on the center's statistical data and analysis on a variety of issues, ``if I want to focus in on a minority viewpoint or get the specifics.'' The unofficial link between black elected officials and center dates to its beginning when noted black psychologist Kenneth Clark and several of the country's then-leading black politicians founded the center and secured a $2 million grant from the Ford Foundation. Williams hopes to secure the center's financial future with a $10 million endowment. The Ford Foundation has pledged $5 million, which Williams is working to match. The center, which celebrated its 20th anniversary this month, opened its doors in 1970 to provide technical assistance to a newly emerging cadre of black elected officials from the ranks of teachers, preachers, farmers and local community activists. ``Our role was to help them better understand the processes of governance, to share some information and some expertise about administration, planning, budgeting, identification of resource acquisition _ those kinds of technical things,'' Williams says. The center also served to document the nature and extent of black political participation, he says.

DOC.TEXT: Actor Ed Begley Jr., who frequently arrives at work on a city bus, comes for an interview this day on a bicycle. He sheds his backpack and plastic foam helmet and sits down to talk about USA Network's first miniseries, ``Not a Penny More, Not a Penny Less,'' to be televised Tuesday and Wednesday. Later, he will ride over the Hollywood Hills to Paramount Studios for some preliminary work on his forthcoming NBC series ``Parenthood.'' In the four-hour, two-part miniseries on USA, Begley plays an American teacher at Oxford University who organizes a sting. He and three Englishmen have lost a bundle in a stock swindle and want their money back. They devise their own swindles that appeal to the ego of the crooked financier played by Edward Asner. The lighthearted adventure, based on the novel by Jeffrey Archer and adapted by Sherman Yellen, was filmed on location in England and Monte Carlo by director Clive Donner. It also stars Maryam d'Abo, Jenny Agutter, Brian Protheroe, Nicholas Jones and Francois-Eric Gendron. ``My character on `Not a Penny More' was the ringleader,'' Begley says. ``We were trying to get our money back from Ed Asner. I come up with the plan, but the others are not convinced it will work.'' In ``Parenthood,'' Begley will play the role Steve Martin had in the hit movie. Producer-director Ron Howard, producer Brian Grazer and writers Lowell Ganz and Babaloo Mandel will also be working on the series. ``We're going to shoot `Parenthood' at a little studio past Valencia,'' Begley says. ``That's 20 miles north of here. I'll ride my bike up this weekend to see what it's like. If it's a grind, I'll take the bus. And if there's no bus, I'll have to take the car. ``I've eliminated that fix we all have for the automobile. I'm a person who runs around a lot. Riding the bus has made me slow down. It's been good for me.'' Begley is probably best known for his role as Dr. Victor Ehrlich on ``St. Elsewhere.'' But he's also become very active in movies. He was caught between Meryl Streep and Roseanne Barr in ``She-Devil.'' He'll soon be seen in ``Meet the Applegates,'' about an All-American family that probably has an aversion to insect spray. ``They're really large invasive bugs from South America who can adapt to any environment,'' Begley says. ``They turn themselves into human beings and become the Applegates.'' The movie also stars Dabney Coleman and Stockard Channing. Begley was born into an acting family and started his own career as a teen-ager. His father was Academy Award-winning actor Ed Begley (``Sweet Bird of Youth'') and his mother actress Jean Joyce. Begley began his acting career on ``My Three Sons'' when he was about 17. ``The first time I was ever noticed was on `Room 222,''' he says. ``I was on six or seven times playing students. I was Bob. I was Stretch Webster.'' Begley was born in Los Angeles and went to grade school in New York. ``My parents were doing a lot of work on the stage,'' he says. ``I came back here for high school and college. I used to go back and forth between the coasts. I loved the trains.'' He got his first taste of fame on ``Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman.'' He played a deaf-mute who was the boyfriend of Mary's sister. His fame didn't last long, however. He was in such movies as ``The In-Laws'' and ``Cat People.'' ``Then `St. Elsewhere' came along and things got better,'' he says. ``I was asked to be host of `Saturday Night Live.' That was a dream come true for a comedian. ``Ehrlich was a very noticeable character on `St. Elsewhere.'' People seemed to like to dislike him. I've been working ever since.'' Begley says his greatest regret is that he never got to work with his father, who died in 1970.

DOC.TEXT: It may seem odd for Kevin Kline to play a philandering pizza parlor owner in the outrageous new film ``I Love You to Death'' and then star in and direct ``Hamlet'' off-Broadway. But the versatile, good-looking actor shuttles from big-budget movie to Shakespeare classic with ease. It's something he has done for the last decade or so, alternating big-league Bard like ``Richard III,'' ``Henry V'' and ``Much Ado About Nothing'' with films like ``Sophie's Choice,'' ``Silverado'' and ``A Fish Called Wanda.'' ``I Love You to Death'' is black comedy opera buffo _ without the music. It's a flamboyant motion picture filled with purple passion and banana-peel humor, as a mousy wife (Tracey Ullman) tries _ again and again _ to murder her adulterous husband (Kline). Not exactly the melancholy Dane, which is Kline's other current project, and now on view at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater. It's a role he first did there four years ago, and his return to it is a rarity. American actors usually don't get a second chance with ``Hamlet.'' ``In England, there is a tradition of doing `Hamlet' twice, and I can understand why,'' the genial, soft-spoken Kline was saying the other day. ``Like any great classical part, you can only get part of it when you do it once. There are so many different ways to go. It's the biggest open door in theater.'' Kline's initial attempt at ``Hamlet'' in 1986 was thoughtful, clear-spoken and introspective, but the production, directed by Liviu Ciulei, received mixed reviews. ``There were rumors that I was unhappy with my first `Hamlet,' '' he says. ``Of course, I was unhappy with it. I'll be unhappy with this one. There is no way to be completely satisfied with any given production of `Hamlet' and there's also no way to satisfy a large group of people. It's like a Rorschach test. Everybody has their very own personal response to the play.'' While preparing for that first ``Hamlet,'' Kline knew he would do it a second time. It was something he and Joseph Papp, head of the Shakespeare Festival, knew they would do. ``Going into it, I said, `I don't want to do this just once,''' Kline recalls, and Papp agreed. What he hadn't planned on was directing the play himself _ his first job at directing. Steven Berkoff, who did a striking, modern dress ``Coriolanus'' at the Public Theater, was to have directed the new production, but the success of his version of Oscar Wilde's ``Salome'' in London kept him in England. With Papp's blessing, Kline took over. ``It was a decision that was arrived at spontaneously after years and years of thinking about it,'' Kline jokes. ``I had been thinking about directing for a couple of years and suggested it to Joe. I thought, `Why not direct a play I know pretty well?' There's no way you can know a play better than having played so central a character.'' For the first time in his career, Kline became involved in an entire production, not only the direction but the design _ sets, costumes and lighting _ and casting. Was it odd sitting on the other side of the fence, auditioning his fellow performers? ``I love actors, and I have a great sympathy for the audition process, which is one of the more barbaric aspects of show business,'' Kline says. ``I'm not a good auditioner myself. So I take each audition with a grain of salt. You can't show everything in an audition.'' He knew the work of some of the actors, like Brian Murray, who plays Claudius, and Dana Ivey, who plays Gertrude, so well that he didn't ask them to audition. Others he did, sometimes even getting up on stage to act out scenes with them. ``A lot of them said, `If it doesn't happen, it was fun working on it,''' Kline says. ``They knew that they couldn't all be in it. The director simply has to find the actor who is best suited for each role.'' Ask Kline about his ideas for ``Hamlet,'' and he hesitates, begging off answering since he had just started rehearsals. But it's not one of those weird productions that set the play in Mexico in the 19th century or some other exotic place and time, he reveals. ``It's a `non-concept' concept production,'' he laughs. ``Right now, it takes place where it did in Shakespeare's time, on a stage that is Denmark, but Shakespeare's Denmark. We are just taking our cues from the play.'' And that's how h HOUSTON (AP) _ The number of w and natural gas rigs declined ount showed a modest decrease after posting a gain of 53 rigs the previous week. A year ago, the count was 778, Baker Hughes said Monday. Baker Hughes' rig count _ the widely watched industry index of drilling activity _ reflects the number of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of producing wells. Houston-based Hughes Tool Co., an oil toolmaker company that merged with Baker International Corp. of Orange, Calif., has kept track of the rig count since 1940. In December 1981, at the height of the oil boom, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But oil prices plunged to less than $10 per 42-gallon barrel in the summer of 1986, prompting a collapse in the rig count that bottomed out at 663 _ the lowest since Hughes began compiling figures. Among major oil-producing states, Texas and Colorado lost nine rigs each, Ohio was down by three and North Dakota was down two. New Mexico's count increased by three rigs and the counts in California and Louisiana each increased by one.

AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
In the Groove: Record Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``Pale'' (Columbia) _ Toad the Wet Sprocket
Toad the Wet Sprocket's new album, ``Pale,'' exemplifies everything that's wrong about the wheezing alternative rock scene. Far from the cutting edge, the underground scene has too many imitators instead of innovators. The reigning gods are still R.E.M., which methodically built a successful career with originality and relentless work. Since the early 1980s, R.E.M. has had more impersonators than the late Elvis Presley. Toad the Wet Sprocket is only the latest to emulate the form rather than the substance of R.E.M. ``Pale'' is loaded with moody, slightly incongruous lyrics. The guitar rock mixes the jangle and the drone. The cover's a grainy picture of something indistinguishable and the band photo is blurry. Sound familiar? Admittedly, the failure of an entire genre is a tough burden to place on the shoulders of an unassuming California rock band. They're somewhat adept interpreters; the sound is more muscular than ``Murmur''-era R.E.M., though the songs, of course, lack distinctiveness. But it would be far better to see bands try to make their mark with their own visions rather than someone else's. _ By David Bauder, Associated Press Writer.
DOC.HEAD: Trumpet Concertos (Telarc) _ Rolf Smedvig, trumpet; Scottish
DOC.TEXT:
Chamber Orchestra, conducted by Jahja Ling
Rolf Smedvig has recorded frequently as a member of the superlative Empire Brass Quintet and played six years with the Boston Symphony, joining the orchestra at the remarkable age of 19. Surprisingly, this is his first solo endeavor on disc. It's a good one. His playing has life and spirit, and Smedvig knows how to scale his performance up or down for the work at hand. He also has a wonderful mellow tone that can even fool the listener into hearing an oboe. Aside from the Haydn E-flat concerto, he doesn't have much top-quality raw material with which to work. But then, all trumpet soloists have to deal with a narrow field. Another work on the program is the E-flat concerto by Johann Nepomuk Hummel, one of history's corrections. That is, he was tremendously popular and highly regarded in his day, but has since fallen into a deserved obscurity. His concerto is second-rate and uninteresting, yet a staple of the instrument. Nevertheless, Smedvig calls attention to the pleasing moments in this work. He also displays some beautiful legato playing in the Haydn Andante. Ling and the Scottish players make an excellent contribution in this piece, and are first-rate in general. Also on the program is a routine Baroque concerto by Giuseppe Torelli; a nicely tossed-off piece of fluff by a young Vincenzo Bellini originally written for oboe; and a transcription of a violin concerto by Giuseppe Tartini. The last work has a striking andante movement with lovely, bittersweet melodies. It seems destined for plunder by a wine advertiser looking for a bucolic soundtrack. _ By Daniel Wakin, Associated Press Writer.

DOC.TEXT: Forty of the most prominent realist and representational painters in the United States will gather in Hilton Head, S.C., next month to exhibit their latest efforts at the Greenwich Workshop. Included in the group show are Charles Wysocki, Americana art; Frank McCarthy, Western art; Simon Combes, African wildlife; Richard Schmid, impressionist art; Scott Kennedy, wilderness art; and Christopher Blossom, marine and nautical art. Also attending the May 6-10 meeting are Alan Bean, who uses moon dust in his paintings, and Bonnie Marris, who tracks wolves across Michigan's Northern Peninsula to use as subjects in her work. Here is a list of exhibits and shows at other galleries and museums in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
The Artists: A Snapshot of American Life
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: In 1889, George Eastman wrote to a colleague that the potential market for his new easy-to-use camera and film was ``immense.'' ``There is more millions in it than anything else,'' the founder of Eastman Kodak Co. said. ``If we can fully control it, I would not trade it for the telephone.'' The story of Eastman's millions and his exceptional success in the fledgling photography industry is chronicled in the 45,600 letters he wrote and received from 1880 to his death in 1932. The letters were donated this week by Kodak to the International Museum of Photography at George Eastman House. It is the first time the collection has been made open to the public. The letters, some handwritten by Eastman in large, looping script, fill 18 shelves of gray boxes and leather-bound volumes in a cellar at Kodak's Rochester headquarters. They provide insights into a broad slice of American history _ from the specifications for a pair of carriage horses to Eastman's opinions on the layout of downtown Rochester, from turn-of-the-century legal and political issues to the development of modern photography. The collection includes letters to and from many of the most important inventors, photographers, businessmen and educators of the day, as well as correspondence with four United States presidents. There is a 13-year correspondence with educator Booker T. Washington. Washington's Tuskegee Institute was one of many educational and charitable institutions to which Eastman donated millions of dollars over his lifetime. Another correspondent was Franklin D. Roosevelt. In 1927, Eastman donated a ``Moving Picture Machine'' to Roosevelt's Warm Springs Foundation for victims of Infantile Paralysis, so that doctors could record patients' movements. Eastman did not refrain from expressing his strong opinions in his letters. He vehemently opposed the U.S. government's policy of neutrality in the World War I, and was exasperated with auto magnate Henry Ford, a prominent pacifist. ``This neutral talk makes me sick,'' Eastman wrote in 1915 to a friend in London. ``And as for Henry Ford, he makes me sick and tired.'' Charles Apfelbaum, a New York rare book collector who helped appraise the collection, called the letters ``one of the greatest archival collections in America.'' The collection was estimated to be worth $750,000, but appraisers said it could be worth more than $1.5 million if the letters were sold individually. ``Rarely has the history and development of an important technical subject, photography in all its phases, been so dominated by one person,'' Apfelbaum said. ``The history of 20th century photography is here in these files.'' Eastman perfected his system of mass-producing dry photographic plates in 1880 and began their commercial manufacture. The dry plates were a great advance over the chemicals and water tanks that earlier photographers had to lug with them. The young industrialist, who had dropped out of school at age 14 to support his family, spent much of the next decade experimenting with lighter and more flexible substitutes for glass plates. In 1887, a chemist hired by Eastman found the emulsion he was looking for, one that was ``quick and plucky and keeps.'' ``The new film is the `slickest' product we ever tried to make, and its method of manufacture will eliminate all of the defects hitherto experienced in film manufacture,'' he wrote to a colleague. ``The new film anybody can work,'' he wrote to a dealer. It was absolutely certain that it would ``entirely replace glass plates, at least for amateur work, at once or as fast as the goods can be made.'' By the end of the decade, Eastman had more orders than he could fill at his Rochester plant. ``We could do double the business if we could turn out the goods,'' he wrote to his business partner, Henry A. Strong, in 1990. As the company expanded, Eastman stayed involved in every facet of the business _ from ordering chemicals and inspecting construction blueprints to distributing dividends. ``My regular business takes every minute day and night that I can spare from sleep,'' he said in an 1889 letter declining an offer to invest in another business. Eastman was a detail man in his personal as well as business life, whether writing a furniture maker with precise instructions for the design of his piano legs, reviewing the medical records of his cows, giving directions for the cultivation of corn on his North Carolina farm or ordering his favorite brand of Java coffee. An 1898 letter contained a list of specifications for the bicycle Eastman was ordering. ``I have no use for a brake,'' he wrote. ``I think they are very dangerous things.'' Despite its successes, Eastman's young company was plagued with legal wrangling over patent infringements, antitrust suits, and injunctions to stop former employees from stealing company secrets. In an 1898 letter written shortly after the American victory over the Spanish at Manila Bay, Eastman commented on the steady stream of lawsuits. ``Everybody here is feeling jubilant over the first reports of the Manila victory,'' he wrote. ``Peace extends only to private life, however. In business it is war all the time.''
