Music Makers: From a Scream to a Whisper
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Margo Timmins was thinking about the house near Montreal where she lived with her parents and five siblings. ``A huge playground'' is how the singer for Cowboy Junkies described it _ big rooms, high ceilings and a winding staircase in back. It was there that Timmins and her brother, Michael, argued about Elton John records, never dreaming that one day they'd form a band of their own. And it was there that she taught herself to sing, dropping embarrassing attempts to belt it out like Pat Benatar, lowering her voice from a scream to a whisper. ``I decided when I sang quietly, at home, when I was singing around the house, that's when I had control of my voice,'' Timmins said in gentle tones at the Manhattan offices of RCA Records. ``Right from the beginning, I was aware that being a good singer was phrasing. I realized when I sang around the house, I could phrase a lot better, I could twist words, I could go up and down.'' Fans heard her loud and clear, purchasing nearly a million copies of the Junkies' ``The Trinity Session,'' and critics were also impressed, frequently placing the album among their 10 best of 1988. Only the sound men had trouble adjusting. ``In the early days, I had more sound men cursing at me, saying, `You have to sing louder.'' I said, `No, You figure out how to get me out there.' When I started to sing lower and quieter, everyone became quiet so they could hear me.'' ``The Trinity Session,'' the Junkies' second album, was recorded in 14 hours at the Trinity Church in Toronto, costing a tidy sum of $250. The sound was as lean as the budget, blues and country chilled by the arctic air of that November day. On covers of ``Blue Moon'' and ``I'm So Lonesome I Could Cry,'' Timmins' phrasing is as dry as powdered snow, the words in danger of snapping like frozen twigs. ```The Trinity Session' was something we worked really hard on,'' Timmins recalled. ``We had day jobs as well at that point, and every night we would come together for five months prior to recording it. We were so focused. These songs, we knew they were good. We knew they filled us with something.'' It was a hard act to follow. Impossible, the Junkies learned. Last spring, they went to a wooden temple nearby, built by Quakers in 1830, and recorded their followup record, to be released in September. After returning from a European tour, they gave the album another listen and changed their minds. ``It sounded old,'' Timmins said. ``But I think that's when we realized that no one was pressuring us to put an album out, that we could take our time. ``When we realized this isn't what we want on this album, we thought, `Let's do it again,' and did it in November. We sort of got rid of that time pressure we imposed and relaxed about it and did it our way.'' Appropriately titled ``The Caution Horses,'' the album has eight originals, _ seven by Michael Timmins and one (``Witches'') by both siblings _ plus covers of fellow Canadians Neil Young (``Powderfinger'') and Mary Margaret O'Hara (``You Will Be Loved Again''). The atmosphere is filtered through the utterly modern 48-track digital equipment of Toronto's Eastern Sound studio. This time, the Junkies are less interested in a single mood than in a series of moods, 10 different takes on modern love. The music, warmed to room temperature, is looser, fuller, with more of a country feel. ``We were aware that some people wouldn't want us to break away from that purist way of recording,'' Timmins said. ``If we went into a studio we knew that people would be mad and if we did more low-key songs, we knew they'd say it's just the same.'' Timmins can turn lyrics into snapshots. ``It's the kind of night where it's so cold and you spit,'' she sings in ``Cheap Is How I Feel,'' pausing midway, ``it freezes before it hits the ground.'' Beds, bars, cars and mirrors also pop up. Thank the Canadian weather and abundance of space for the Junkies' visual approach to music. ``I think that we really have a picturesque kind of way of dealing with things. Everything's gray for six months out of the year, so you better have a big imagination. You're locked inside and you read a lot.'' ``To me the songs on the new album are stories that have to be made believable,'' she said. ``There's a time and a place and a message and a mood, like short stories. That's the way I approached them, basically, because that's the way I read them when Mike handed them to me.'' The quintessential Junkie, Timmons says, is shy, aloof, like bassist Alan Anton. Timmins insists that she's not shy, but quiet _ a big difference. Approach her at a party and she'll talk to you all night. Approach her for an interview, and she just might find a little extra time in her schedule. ``I think there must be a part of me inside that wants the attention, otherwise I wouldn't allow it to happen. I do enjoy buying a magazine and seeing my picture. ``But there are limits to that. If it's a choice between visiting my mom in Florida and getting my picture taken, then I'll see my mom. Although, if I can take the photographer along I'll do both.''

DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp.'s directors agreed to a $4.38 billion buyout by the company's employees, but some analysts doubted the viability of the deal that would make the parent of United Airlines the world's largest worker-owned corporation. The three union groups which negotiated the $201-a-share deal have not yet secured financing for the buyout, a source who was involved in the talks said Friday. Analysts said that weakness could prove fatal. The stock market reflected investor skepticism that the deal will be completed. UAL fell $2 a share to $163.50 in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

The price tag on the savings and loan bailout could hit $500 billion if the economy falters, congressional auditors said in their bleakest assessment of the thrift crisis yet. The General Accounting Office said Friday it would cost the government at least $325 billion to close or sell failed savings institutions. That's greater than the Pentagon's annual budget. But even the new projection, a sharp 26 percent higher than the $257 billion estimate offered by the GAO only five months ago, is optimistic, said Comptroller General Charles A. Bowsher, who heads the GAO.

Civilian unemployment dipped to 5.2 percent in March, down from 5.3 percent in February and the lowest rate in a year, the government said. But analysts attributed Friday's report more to a statistical quirk than to an economic upswing. Indeed, the Labor Department report said the number of new jobs last month hit a four-year low.

States are in worse financial condition than a year ago, and 21 governors want to remedy the problem with tax increases, a new report said. The report, released Friday by two organizations representing state governments, blamed the fiscal problems on increased spending for Medicaid, education, prisons and transportation. The report was issued by the National Governors' Association and the National Association of State Budget Officers. The groups survey state finances twice a year.

Mesa Limited Partnership pulled its Hugoton Royalty Trust holdings off the market, saying prices were too low to sell the prime properties in the nation's largest natural gas field. Mesa, T. Boone Pickens Jr.'s energy company, said in December it would package its Hugoton holdings into a separate trust and sell shares to raise money to help pay down some of the partnership's $1.5 billion in long-term debt. But it pulled the holdings off the market Friday.

A federal jury convicted two Wall Street arbitragers of insider trading, fraud and other and counts linked to the so-called ``Yuppie Five'' scandal, capping a 12-week trial. But a defense attorney said after Friday's verdict that Victor Teicher and Ross Frankel both plan to appeal. Teicher, 38, headed the arbitrage firm Teicher & Co. Frankel, 33, is former head of arbitrage research at now-defunct investment house Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

The chairman of the Pepper Commission defended its refusal to include recommendations on how to pay the estimated $23 billion cost to provide health insurance for all Americans. Sen. John D. Rockefeller IV told a hearing of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee on Friday that the commission had, in fact, accomplished a great deal by putting a total price tag on its proposals _ $66.6 billion.

The Bush administration said it intends to monitor closely Japan's efforts to implement a historic market-opening trade agreement. President Bush said the American public would be satisfied only with ``concrete results.'' With the ink barely dry on the pact, however, a major Japanese retailers' group vowed Friday to fight a key provision and doubts were voiced by U.S. trade experts over how effective the agreement would be in reducing America's huge $49 billion deficit with Japan.

Fisher-Price announced that 20,000 of its child car seats made since Feb. 1 could break during a crash and offered free repair kits so consumers can fix the problem. A faulty die that weakened a metal part was discovered during tests, company spokeswoman Carol Blackley said Friday. The repair kit includes a new part and tools with which to install it. The problem affects, at most, one-fifth of the child seats made between Feb. 1 and April 1, Blackley said.

Stock prices slipped in quiet trading Friday, as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials lost 4.05 to 2,717.12, reducing its gain for the week to 9.91 points. Bond prices finished little changed. The dollar moved slightly lower in foreign exchange. Copper futures rallied sharply; precious metals and livestock rose; grain and pork prices declined and oil prices were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
March Oil Output Highest Since 1981: Newsletter
DOC.TEXT: OPEC member nations produced an estimated 24.09 million barrels a day of crude oil in March, the highest monthly output since 1981, the weekly Middle East Economic Survey reported Monday. The influential newsletter said the production was up from 23.62 million barrels per day in February and 23.32 million in January. Daily production in December was only slightly lower at 24 million. The newsletter said Iran showed the biggest increase in production, jumping from 2.8 million barrels a day in February to 3.15 million in March. It is the first time since August that Iran has been able to produce at the level of its 3.14 million barrels per day quota assigned under the cartel's shared production system. ``Observers will be interested to see whether their level can be sustained in the coming months,'' the newsletter said. Export facilities were severely damaged during the 1980-88 war with Iraq, but the government made repairs its first priority. The overall production level was well above the ceiling of 22.1 million barrels per day that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed on for production in the first six months of 1990. Some members, led by the United Arab Emirates and Kuwait, have been ignoring their production quotas and calling for their abolition. Last week, the Paris-based International Energy Agency estimated March production at 23.7 million barrels a day. Oil prices soared in January but have been gradually slipping since, falling in early March below the cartel's target of $18 a barrel to about $17.75 for the average of a basket of seven crude oils. The newsletter said the supply and demand for OPEC crude are ``roughly in balance.''

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Slightly Firmer at Midday
DOC.TEXT: Stocks were slightly higher across the board at midday Monday but traders showed a reluctance to trade. Analysts said they expect the London market to continue drifting aimlessly, and that Wall Street will also reflect investor apathy when it opens. At about 12:30 p.m. in London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 4.0 points, or 0.01 percent, at 2,225.1. Volume came to 155.3 million shares by midday compared with 334.5 million shares at the same time Friday.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
GM Head Warns of Raised Expectations From Trade Talks
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of General Motors Corp. today warned that recent U.S.-Japan trade talks could lead to undesirable new American laws if current high U.S. expectations are not met. Most trade talks between the two nations have focused on improved market access for particular products. But last week's negotiations dealt with business practices and customs in both countries that have worsened their trade imbalance, which has stood at about $50 billion for several years. ``I am not a Japan-basher, and never will be,'' said Roger Smith, chairman of the world's largest automaker. ``But we have to learn to trade together. And I look for Japanese companies to take the leadership in helping resolve these trade issues. We should not have governments trying to resolve some of these trade issues.'' In the trade talks, Japan pledged to alter its Anti-Monopoly Law to provide foreign companies more access to business opportunities by reducing Japanese business collusion. It also promised to reduce restrictions on the opening of large-scale stores, which U.S. trade officials say are more likely to sell imported products. ``I don't know whether that's going to be good for trade or bad for trade, because it's going to raise expectations, but if it doesn't produce results to lower that $50 billion trade deficit, it may backfire in Congress and bring on some unwanted rules,'' Smith said. He said Japanese customs and attitudes have blocked sales of U.S. cars in Japan, and warned that such non-tariff barriers were dangerous. ``I don't think you need those barriers, and I think they are very dangerous, because they are the things that the people in the United States hold up as an example and say, `See, you can't trust the Japanese','' he told reporters at the Japan National Press Club. The record 182,168 cars, trucks and buses that Japan imported in 1989 accounted for only about 3 percent of the 5.8 million vehicles sold during the year. The imported passenger cars included 120,293 from West Germany, 19,084 from the United States, 14,519 from Britain and 10,487 from France, the Japan Automobile Importers' Association said. Smith, who is retiring in July, arrived in Japan Thursday on a farewell visit, GM officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Truck-Driver Trainer Saves Tires, Transmissions and Trainer Nerves
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS 5th graf, Doron is ... to make it cable car sted trolley. Also in Monday AMs report. This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The gears grind, the engine growls and the rig jumps a curb, bumps into a shiny Corvette and rolls over a stop sign. At the hands of an untrained driver, a 45-foot trailer truck can do a lot of damage. But, in what Doron Precision Systems Inc., says is the world's first affordable truck driver training simulator, all the damage is to the ego. The truck and the Corvette weigh only a few pounds, and the scene out the windows is a four-screen, live TV show. ``Step on the gas, you can't hurt a thing,'' said Doron President Carl Wenzinger as a first-time truck driver took the wheel, checked his mirrors, let out the clutch and attempted to back up to a dock at the end of a narrow alley. Doron is the company that builds those futuristic capsules that rock and roll a dozen shopping mall patrons at a time through a filmed roller coaster adventure, a San Francisco cable car ride or a helicopter flight over Manhattan. But Wenzinger said his first and still most important business is creating realistic training devices for car, bus and truck drivers. The Binghamton, N.Y., company claims to be the world leader in audio-visual driver training equipment. ``This is not a video game,'' Wenzinger said. ``We are in the serious business of traffic safety.'' The company is keeping parts of its new L-300 Vehicle Maneuvering Trainer system secret behind black plastic sheets during public showings until all of the patents are accepted. But what was uncovered in a demonstration last week was a life-sized cab complete with steering wheel and most of the gauges and controls of a normal truck, two video projectors for a sweeping view of the road, and two 24-inch television sets for side windows with inset rear-view mirrors. Wenzinger also acknowledged what was not immediately obvious until the silver Corvette at the side of the road bounced rather than crunched _ the L-300's driver is actually controlling a scale model which can either be placed in another room or stacked on top of the cab. The scene includes a cab and trailer mounted with miniature video cameras. ``It doesn't make sense to tie up an instructor fulltime in the front seat,'' Wenzinger said. The whole thing could fit into a large living room. The cost: about $130,000, compared to several million dollars for airplane or railroad simulators that use computer-generated images. The difference in conducting training in an L-300 and a real truck, Wenzinger said, is that the trainee burns no fuel, can't destroy the transmission, doesn't wear out the tires or brakes and can't damage the training course. It also saves on instructors, he said. One can monitor several simulators at a time. The disadvantage is that the machine can't simulate highway driving. The model would have to be too big. Some of the training still has to be in a classroom simulator with a movie screen or in a real rig. The first two L-300 simulators are to be delivered late this month to the Pinellas Technical Education Center, run by Pinellas County, Fla. ``I think it's fantastic,'' said Warren Laux, principal of the school's St. Petersburg campus. ``I felt a lot of anxiety in driving it and didn't want people watching me,'' said Laux after test-driving the L-300. ``I'd rather have students get those feelings in a simlulator than in a $100,000 piece of equipment they could ruin.'' Models could be constructed to duplicate most conditions a driver might face in turning, parking or docking, said David Lindsey, director of truck fleet operations for Doron. Lindsey said courses could simulate rugged terrain for training in military vehicles or a school yard or city street for bus-driver training.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Narrowly Mixed in Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were narrowly mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting a variety of supply-and-demand developments. The soybean market was mostly higher amid perceptions that the Soviet Union is shopping for U.S. soybeans and soybean meal. Soybean futures also were supported by strength in the European meal market and by reports that wet weather over the weekend caused soybean harvest delays in South America. Corn futures were fractionally lower on profit-taking after last week's gains. Friday's Agriculture Department announcement that the Soviets bought 750,000 metric tons of U.S. corn was discounted by the market, which had risen sharply before the announcement on rumors of a large Soviet purchase. Wheat was very narrowly mixed. Forecasts for mild, rainy weather in the winter wheat belt prompted selling that offset buying linked to fears that cold weekend temperatures may have caused some frost damage to the crop. In early trading, wheat futures were { cent lower to } cent higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.66 a bushel; corn futures were \ cent to } cent lower with May at $2.68} a bushel; oats were { cent to 1 cent lower with May at $1.51 a bushel; soybeans were \ cent lower to } cent higher with May at $5.96 a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle futures were unchanged to .10 cent higher with April at 79.85 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .03 cent to .15 cent higher with April at 83.85 cents a pound; live hogs were .03 cent to .53 cent higher with April at 54.60 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .12 cent lower to .30 cent higher with May at 54.75 cents a pound. DOC.HEAD: Talks End Between Rival Software Standards Groups
DOC.TEXT: Formal talks have broken off between two rival groups promoting different versions of AT&T's Unix computer software, though the groups said they have agreed to certain standards. However, the groups said they determined that a merger of the rivals ``could not be practically achieved at this time.'' One of the groups, Unix International, was set up by American Telephone & Telegraph Co. The other, the Open Software Foundation, was established by such AT&T rivals as International Business Machines Corp., Digital Equipment Corp. and Siemen's AG of West Germany. The groups are vying for control of the Unix operating system, a base layer of software that fast is becoming an industry standard. But different versions of Unix have sprung up since AT&T invented it, meaning computers running on one version are not compatible with those running on another. The Open Software Foundation was established by the AT&T rivals in 1988 when they became concerned that the phone giant was trying to retain control of Unix rather than allow it to become an industry standard. In response, AT&T formed Unix International and ceded control of its versions of Unix to the group. The two groups said in November they were involved in formal discusssions on cooperation aimed at ending the perception they were rivals. Today they said the talks had concluded, but that informal discussions would continue. Among the progress the groups cited were agreements to adhere to a number of industry standards.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Unification Could Boost Economy In West Germany, Unemployment In East
With AM-Poland-Layoffs Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The planned union between West and East Germany should prevent a West Germany economic slowdown over the next two years, experts said Monday, but they reiterated concerns that East German unemployment could soar. West Germany's five leading economic research institutes said increased demand resulting from the economic reconstruction of East Germany likely will prevent a significant slowdown in West German growth. Klaus-Werner Schatz, an economist at the Institute for World Economics in Kiel, said the five institutes expect growth to slow marginally to 3.75 percent in 1990 from 4 percent in 1989. In 1991, they expect the economy to grow at an almost similar pace. In 1991, growth should be 1.5 percentage points higher than it would have been without economic union, said Schatz. West Germany has launched plans to create an economic union with East Germany on the road to German unification. Under such a union, West Germany virtually would control East Germany's economy as it rebuilds its eastern neighbor. Monetary union, in which West Germany's strong mark will replace East Germany's nearly worthless currency, is a central part of plans for economic union. Some West Germans have raised concerns that unification could prove to be a heavy economic burden. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said Monday part of the costs of unification could be covered by spending less on defense. Some opposition politicians have said West Germany will have to raise taxes to cover the high price for unity. But the five institutes said West German growth likely would handle unification costs. ``In the mid-term, tax increases ... will not be necessary,'' Schatz said. But Schatz also called on West German and East German politicians to take the necessary steps to preserve East German jobs as the two nations negotiate the terms of currency union. East German politicians are pressing for a general 1-to-1 swap of East German marks for West German marks. But Western financial experts continually have warned that could create high unemployment in East Germany because it would increase businesses' debts as well as their payrolls. Some forecasts have said 2 million East Germans could lose their jobs under such a plan. In their report, the five institutes said strong economic growth in West Germany over the next two years hinges on East Germany scrapping its planned economy in favor of a free-market system. West Germany's economic, legal and tax systems will have to be adopted by East Germany, the experts said. Schatz said East Germany will face ``enormous pressures'' during the transition to a market-economy system. But he said those same pressures ``bring great advantages.'' He said that after East Germany's full ``entry into a market-economy system ... in a short time an enormous production impulse will be realized.'' In addition, East Germans will have to pay far less for Western imports then they do now, he said. According to Schatz, as East Germany's economic health recovers, that will provide a bonus for West Germany's economy as well. ``The economic reconstruction (of East Germany) will lead to a high need for investment goods, which without a doubt will be met for the most part by deliveries from the Federal Republic (West Germany),'' said Schatz. He said East German demand for West German consumer goods likely will increase immediately after monetary union is implemented, which may occur as early as July 1. The economic forecasts were conducted jointly by the Ifo Economic Research Institute in Munich, the German Institute for Economic Research in West Berlin, the RWI Economic Research Institute in Essen, the Institute for World Economics in Kiel, and the HWWA Institute for Economic Research in Hamburg.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Fall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: An AMs version planned by 5:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar fell Monday against other major currencies in Europe after an early round of intervention by most Group of Seven nations. Gold prices also declined. Dealers said early intervention helped send skittish buyers to the sidelines. But the flurry of dollar selling against the yen by the major European central banks didn't help the Japanese currency because the market does not believe the G-7 is committed to supporting it, dealers said. The finance ministers of the United States, West Germany, Japan, France, Britain, Italy and Canada agreed at their meeting in Paris on Saturday that the yen's recent downswing could have ``undesirable consequences.'' But they only said they would keep developments under review. The absence of the Federal Reserve until late European dealings helped underpin the dollar, dealers said. But even after the Fed stepped in selling the dollar at 157 yen, the dollar didn't find any significant market selling, they said. One British corporate dealer said: ``The market wants Japan to raise its interest rates.'' In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 1.02 yen to 156.45 yen Monday. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 157.28 yen. DOC.HEAD: London Shares Close Higher
DOC.NOTE: EDS: RECASTS throughout to UPDATE with later activity, closing indices; No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Shares closed modestly higher Monday on London's Stock Exchange after the market spent the day drifting lazily upward. Dealers said investors were sticking to the sidelines on the first full day of a new trading account and as the long Easter holiday weekend approached. The exchange divides trading into two-week and three-week trading periods for accounting purposes. ``It's going to be a quiet week, I'm afraid,'' one British equities dealer said. A sharp rebound in Tokyo earlier Monday and a relatively steady Wall Street bolstered the London market, dealers said. They also cited a shortage of some stocks. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index rose 6.6 points, or 0.3 percent, to close at 2,227.7. DOC.HEAD: Firm Buys Drexel's Junk Bond Data Base, Software
DOC.TEXT: Salomon Brothers Inc. said Monday it had acquired Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s black book on junk bonds, including details on thousands of issuers and investors that made up the firm's fabled money-raising network. The purchase covers Drexel's data base containing information on more than 3,000 public and private issues of high-yield bonds. The data base also contains information on the junk holdings of about 1,000 institutional investors _ the insurance companies, mutual funds and savings and loans that Drexel tapped to raise billions of dollars for smaller companies and takeover artists in the 1980s. Along with the data base, Salomon is obtaining computer software that will give its sales, trading and research staff access to descriptions of securities in the data base, histories of their trading prices, research and other information. ``There's considerable value in all of that,'' said Mark Field, head of high-yield sales at Salomon. ``This puts us in the center of the securities holders.'' The high-yield system also includes management reporting, back office and recordkeeping features, Salomon said. The purchase price wasn't disclosed, but Drexel said Salomon's bid was the highest from among 15 firms that had expressed interest in the assets. ``The purchase of this system, along with the recent addition of several experienced high-yield professionals, merely serves to underscore our continued long-term commitment to the high-yield market,'' C. Daniel Tyree, head of Salomon's high-yield department, said in a statement. Salomon has hired about five Drexel junk bond specialists since the start of the year including the firm's former head of high-yield research, Joseph C. Bencivenga, who joined Salomon about a week ago, Field said. Drexel was the biggest underwriter and market maker of junk bonds and fostered the explosive growth of junk in the 1980s into a $225 billion market. The firm is liquidating as a result of the Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing by its parent in February. Drexel has whittled its securities portfolio down from about $47 billion to a little under $1 billion _ mostly junk bonds, private placements of high-yield debt and equity stakes in companies the firm helped finance, said Steven Anreder, a Drexel spokesman. The firm is trying to sell its portfolio in an orderly fashion to obtain the best prices and doesn't have a target date for finishing the job, Anreder said. ``We'd like to do it as expeditiously as possible but we're not going to give it away, either,'' he said. There are 700 to 800 people still working at Drexel, and that number should be cut in half within the next month or two, Anreder said. The firm employed 5,380 workers before its bankruptcy filing.

DOC.HEAD: Most Crop Futures Slide; Late Selloff In Wheat
DOC.TEXT: Futures prices of grain and soybeans closed mostly lower Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Wheat fell late on speculative selling possibly linked to expectations the government will raise its wheat stockpile figure. In a pair of reports scheduled for release after Tuesday's close, the Agriculture Department will revise its estimates for U.S. grain stocks and issue production estimates for a number of crops other than grains. Steve Freed, a grains analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said the USDA is likely to increase its estimates for the wheat and corn stockpiles and lower its soybean stocks figure. Wheat futures fell rapidly in the last half-hour of trading after advancing earlier in the session on news the Soviet Union had bid for 300,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices. Soybean futures closed mostly lower following forecasts for a rainy week in the Midwestern soybean country. Corn ended nearly unchanged. At the close of trading, wheat futures were 1} cents to 4} cents lower with the contract for delivery in May at $3.60{ a bushel; corn was unchanged to { cent higher with May at $2.69\ a bushel; oats were 1} cents to 2 cents lower with May at $1.49} a bushel; soybeans were 3{ cents lower to 2 cents higher with May at $5.92 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Heinz Plans Ketchup Bottle Made of More Easily Recycled Plastic
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Heinz ketchup will be packaged next year in clear plastic bottles that the food giant says can be recycled more readily than the squeezable containers it introduced in 1983, the company said Monday. H.J. Heinz Co. officials said they hoped the new plastic technology for their ketchup bottles would reduce the flow of plastic into landfills and boost the company's already dominant share of the $600 million ketchup market. But some environmental activists said many areas of the country are not gathering and recycling plastic containers and said they feared many of the new bottles would end up in the landfill anyway. Heinz officials said they planned an educational effort over the next year in conjunction with the U.S. Conference of Mayors to encourage development of recycling programs and awareness that its containers will be recyclable. Anthony J.F. O'Reilly, chairman and chief executive of Pittsburgh-based Heinz, told a news conference that solid waste disposal issue leaves food manufacturers with both their ``biggest problem and biggest opportunity'' in the 1990s. Heinz introduced the first squeezable plastic ketchup bottles in 1983, and now sells about 60 percent of its ketchup in such containers. But O'Reilly said the cloudy plastic containers are ``technically recyclable,'' but no economical system has been developed for collecting and cleaning them and making use of the resins. Over the past several years, Heinz has been working on a container made chiefly of a plastic, widely used for soft drinks, that could keep ketchup fresh. The plastic is called polyethylene terephthalate or PET. The new Enviropet ketchup bottle, which was created by Continental PET Technologies Inc., a division of Continental Can Co. Inc., should start showing up on grocery store counters at this time next year, the companies said. The problem with the original plastic bottle, according to Corby Mathisen, manager for plastics technology at Heinz's domestic division, was that it consisted of five layers bound by an adhesive and could not economically be broken down for use in other products. But the new bottle contains no adhesives and an industry is already in operation using PET plastics for a variety of products ranging from carpeting to tennis ball felt, sleeping bag fiberfill and paint brush bristles. He said more than 300 towns already have curbside collection programs for PET containers, and said 20 percent of all PET products are recycled. O'Reilly said the new containers are more expensive to produce but the added cost will not be passed on to consumers. He said the company will make up the difference through reducing costs of other ingredients or selling more ketchup. He said Heinz has more than 51 percent of the $600 million a year ketchup market, up from 45 percent to 46 percent when it introduced the plastic ketchup bottle in 1983. The company plans eventually to introduce the new packaging technology for its other condiments and sauces. Allen Hershkowitz, senior scientist for the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental advocacy and research organization, said the new containers were a step in the right direction. But he said the recycling industry is ill-equipped to handle the flood of new containers. ``Of the 200 million of these bottles that will be sold next year, it is likely that the overwhelming majority of them will be dumped in a landfill or incinerated,'' he said. The Heinz bottles displayed at Monday's news conference carried the word ``Recyclable!'' on the label. Hershkowitz said the use of that term likely would draw objections if the recycling capacity for handling PET bottles was not expanded substantially by next year. But Mathisen said a healthy portion of PET products are recycled and consumers should be told when a container can be recycled. He also said he had begun talks with appropriate regulatory authorities on the labeling issue.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Lower, Gold Off
Precede LONDON-BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended modestly lower Monday against all major currencies except the Japanese yen and British pound, following a wave of selling by several central banks overseas to help prop up the yen. Gold prices declined in the United States and abroad. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $376 a troy ounce, down $4.70 from late Friday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $375.65 an ounce, off $4.85. Currency dealers said several central banks, including the Federal Reserve, sold dollars in Europe and Asia in an attempt to stem the yen's decline. But they said it did little to help the Japanese currency because the market did not believe the major industrial nations known as the Group of Seven nations were totally committed to supporting it. The yen has weakened in recent weeks amid increasing signs of a weakening Japanese economy, helping worsen a sharp decline on the Tokyo stock market. The finance ministers of the United States, West Germany, Japan, France, Britain, Italy and Canada agreed at their meeting Saturday in Paris that the yen's recent slide could have ``undesirable consequences.''However, they only said they would keep developments under review. The absence of Fed intervention until late European dealings also helped underpin the dollar, dealers said. ``One does not get any sense of a dramatic or large-scale type of intervention that would shock the market,'' said Trevor Woodland, chief corporate trader for Harris Trust & Co. in Chicago. ``The market is generally trying to test the waters.'' In Tokyo, the dollar fell 1.02 yen to 156.45 yen Monday. It rebounded to 157.28 yen in London and traded at 158.335 yen in New York, up from 157.70 yen late Friday.
