DOC.HEAD: Miller to Expand Sales of Low-Cal Genuine Draft
DOC.TEXT: Miller Brewing Co. announced Monday it would expand sales of its new, low-calorie Genuine Draft Light beer into 10 states and end testing of a ``genuine draft'' version of its popular Miller Lite brand. Genuine Draft Light, which capitalizes on the success of Miller's fast-growing regular Genuine Draft brand, was introduced in several test markets last July. Milwaukee-based Miller said the beer, which is brewed in Milwaukee and Irwindale, Calif., now will be sold statewide in Alaska, Arizona, California, Colorado, Hawaii, Idaho, Nevada, Oregon, Utah and Washington. It also will continue being offered in selected markets in Wisconsin, Texas, Kentucky, Tennessee and Ohio, the brewer said. Genuine Draft Light's introduction pitted it against another new product, Lite Genuine Draft. That test brand was an extension of the popular Miller Lite, the second best-selling beer in the United States. The announcement Monday means Genuine Draft won and testing of Lite Genuine Draft will end. Genuine Draft, which like regular draft beer is brewed without pasteurization, became the 10th best-selling beer in the United States last year, displacing Anheuser-Busch Inc.'s Michelob brand. A 12-ounced serving of the new light version of Genuine Draft has about 98 calories, about a third less than regular beer, Miller said.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Recalls About Two-Thirds of 1986 Aerostar Minivans
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. on Monday recalled 101,000 of its 1986-model Aerostar minivans because of the chance of a fuel leak. The company said leaks can occur at the seal between the fuel tank and the fuel-filler pipe when the tank is full or nearly full. Ford said it was aware of no fires caused by the leak. The vehicles recalled are about two-thirds of all 1986 Aerostars made by Ford. The others don't have the fuel leakage problems, Ford spokesman Jim Trainor said. Owners are being notified by mail. Repairs will be performed for free.

DOC.HEAD: Troubled Home Builder May Expand Bankruptcy Filing
DOC.TEXT: General Development Corp. further trimmed its work force Monday as the troubled real estate company considered expanding its bankruptcy filing to include subsidiaries. Miami-based General Development, which pleaded guilty last month to a scheme to sell overpriced homes, laid off 239 workers involved in construction at some of its nine Florida communities, spokesman Otis Wragg III said. Last week, General Development closed all home-site sales offices and broker bureaus around the world and laid off about 1,100 employees. Meanwhile, an attorney for the company told a bankruptcy judge Sunday that some of General Development's three subsidiaries may join the parent company in bankruptcy court. But attorney Brian Gart did not indicate which segments of General Development could seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The filing last week did not affect General Development's Vistana Resort and Glen Ivy subsidiaries, which operate time-share developments near Disney World and in the West. The company's other subsidiary, General Development Utilities Inc., also was not named in the filing. Gart represented the company at an emergency hearing before U.S. Bankruptcy Court Judge A. Jay Cristol, who ordered that General Development must honor all paychecks issued before Friday's bankrupcty filing. The company listed assets of $860 million and liabilities of $830 million. General Development, however, has not indicated how the action may affect a proposed $100 million restitution plan for about 10,000 victims of a scheme to sell overpriced homes. But Gart said he is ``almost certain'' the bankrupcty filing was not linked to the restitution plan, which is being reviewed by a court-appointed master. Cristol said he would appoint a special trustee to respresent about 100,000 home-site buyers, presently are not listed as creditors. General Development stock closed Monday down 37{ cents at $1.87{ in New York Stock Exchange trading.

DOC.HEAD: GM, Ford Chairmen Made More Than $9 Million Last Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead to tighten; INSERTS 2 grafs after 4th graf pvs, `The payouts... to UPDATE with union comment; PICKS UP 5th graf pvs, `GM President...
DOC.TEXT: The chairmen of General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. took sharp pay cuts in 1989 during an auto industry slump, but still received more than $9 million between them, the companies said Monday. Ford Chairman Donald Petersen received $6.6 million in salary, bonuses and stock options last year, down from $10.5 million in 1988, the No. 2 automaker said in its annual proxy statement. GM Chairman Roger Smith was paid $2.5 million, down from $3.6 million the previous year, the proxy for the world's largest automaker revealed. The payouts were the last for a full year for the two executives. Petersen retired March 1 as Ford's chairman and chief executive, while Smith retires at the end of July. The United Auto Workers union called the payments ``a disease that's still in need of a cure.'' ``The auto industry has real and pressing problems, but the companies signal only arrogance and business-as-usual attitudes through these excessive payments to senior executives,'' UAW President Owen Bieber and the union's GM and Ford department heads said in a statement. GM President Robert Stempel, who takes over Aug. 1 as chairman, received $1.8 million in compensation last year. More than half of Smith's and Stempel's compensation were in stock options. Ford's new chairman, Harold Poling, received $2.9 million for 1989, about $2.1 million in salary and bonuses and the rest in stock options. Chrysler Corp. on Friday is expected to release its proxy statement, which details executive compensation and other information prior to annual shareholders' meetings. The auto industry is mired in a slump reflected by 1989 profits, when Big Three earnings fell 25 percent from 1988. GM profits declined 13 percent to $4.22 billion, Ford's dropped 28 percent to $3.84 billion and Chrysler's tumbled 66 percent to $359 million. Ford's proxy statement showed that Petersen received $3.1 million in salary and bonuses and $3.5 million on stock options last year. His 1989 compensation was 37 percent less than in 1988, when he was the auto industry's top-paid executive. At GM, Smith's earnings declined about 31 percent. Three other officers listed separately in Ford's proxy, President Philip Benton and executive vice presidents Allan Gilmour and Louis Ross, received more than $1.7 million apiece. Collectively, Ford awarded about $214 million to 5,286 Ford executives in bonuses for the company's performance in 1989. According to a formula, Ford could have distributed $229 million in bonuses. The board reduced that, leaving $1.3 million in the bonus pool for 1990 and transferring $14.4 million into general operating coffers. About 150,000 hourly Ford workers last month received profit-sharing checks of about $1,025 each. GM paid an average of $50 to about 443,000 employees. Ford's proxy statement, which also includes a slate of 17 board of directors candidates, was sent to the company's 287,000 shareholders before the company's annual meeting in Detroit on May 10. GM's proxy went to more than 1 million shareholders, officially notifying them of the annual meeting May 25 in Detroit. GM's proxy statement also included a proposal to boost to 500 million the number of shares of Class E common stock the company would be authorized to issue. About 91 million shares are oustanding of Class E shares, which are linked to GM's Electronics Data Systems Corp. subsidiary. GM said the authorization to issue new Class E shares is needed ``to provided flexibility for possible future actions such as additional stock dividends, splits or acquisitions.'' The company said it had no plans to issue more Class E stock now.

DOC.HEAD: Former Auditor Refuses to Testify in Keating Suit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 5-6, `He asked ... Lincoln case' to CORRECT spelling to Atchison. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The former chief auditor of Lincoln Savings and Loan, who later earned more than $900,000 a year working for Lincoln owner Charles H. Keating Jr., has refused to testify in Keating's suit to reclaim the seized thrift, a government lawyer said Monday. James Murphy, an attorney defending the federal takeover of the $5.5 billion Irvine, Calif., S&L a year ago, said accountant Jack D. Atchison filed an affidavit invoking his Fifth Amendment protection against self-incrimination. Atchison is the fifth former Keating employee or business associate to invoke the Fifth Amendment in refusing to testify on Keating's suit, which accuses the government of ``arbitrarily and capriciously'' seizing Lincoln. Murphy said he wanted to question Atchison about a tax-sharing arrangement between Lincoln and its holding company, American Continental Corp., and a June 1988 decision by ACC to bolster the thrift's capital by $10 million under regulatory pressure. He asked U.S. District Court Judge Stanley Sporkin to consider Atchison's refusal to testify as a ``negative inference'' in Keating's civil suit. Keating lawyer John Lundin said Atchinson didn't want to testify amid a ``tremendous swirl'' of criminal investigations under way in the Lincoln case. A federal grand jury in Los Angeles is weighing possible criminal charges against Keating, the chairman of American Continental, and several other Lincoln and ACC officials. As the largest S&L collapse in history, regulators estimate that risky land investments directed by Keating using federally insured deposits could cost taxpayers up to $2 billion. Regulators have sued Keating, alleging that he and nearly a dozen associates engaged in widespread illegal acts of fraud and racketeering in their operation of Lincoln from the time Keating bought it in February 1984. Formerly the managing partner in the Phoenix office of accounting firm Arthur Young _ now Ernst & Young _ Atchison was the chief author of audit reports on Lincoln later cited by five U.S. senators defending their intervention on Keating's behalf with federal regulators in 1987. Atchison, who left Arthur Young to work for Keating at an annual salary above $900,000, also refused last fall to testify before the House Banking Committee. He now works as a private consultant. Keating, meanwhile, testified Monday that he ordered American Continental to buy $10 million of preferred stock from Lincoln on June 30, 1988, as part of a ``memorandum of understanding'' with regulators calling for an infusion of new capital to support the thrift's risky investments. Although he said the Federal Home Loan Bank Board gave an Oct. 1 deadline for the $10 million capital infusion, Keating said he came up with the money three months early ``to show our good will'' toward ending a long-running feud with regulators.

DOC.HEAD: Dow Jones Posts Sharp Decline in First-Quarter Profit
DOC.TEXT: Dow Jones & Co. Inc. said Monday its first-quarter profit fell 87.6 percent from a year earlier, when its results included a huge one-time gain on the sale of its investment in a cable-system operator. Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal and Barron's magazine, said it earned $24.9 million, or 25 cents a share, in the three months ended March 31 compared with $200 million, or $1.99 a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 5 percent to $427.1 million from $406.8 million in 1989. The 1989 results included an after-tax gain of $164.1 million, or $1.63 a share, on the cable investment sale. Excluding the gain, its net income was down 30.6 percent in the latest quarter. Operating income fell 22.2 percent. The company said income from its business publications rose 20.2 percent, but that its income fell 34.6 percent from information services, mainly because of losses associated with the introduction of a foreign-exchange trading service by its Telerate Inc. subsidiary. The trading service had not been in operation in the first quarter of 1989. The latest results were also hurt by a decline in operating income at the community newspaper segment, a higher effective tax rate and increased interest expense and goodwill amortization related to Dow Jones' January acquisition of the one-third stake in Telerate that it did not already own. Revenue rose 9 percent to $184.3 million at the information services segment, which includes Telerate, Dow Jones News Service and Dow Jones News-Retrieval service. But operating income fell to $35.8 million from $54.6 million. Revenue rose 3.5 percent to $189.3 million at the business publications, while operating income rose to $26.2 million from $21.9 million. Advertising linage fell 3.9 percent at The Wall Street Journal, while it rose 2.1 percent at the weekly Barron's. Revenue fell 2.5 percent to $53.4 million at Ottaway Newspapers Inc. while operating income at the community newspaper segment fell 39.3 percent to $4.5 million.

MCI Communications Corp., seeking greater inroads into the long-distance market dominated by AT&T, said it would spend $1.25 billion to acquire Telecom USA Inc. MCI, the nation's second-largest long-distance company, said Monday that acquisition of the No. 4 carrier, active primarily in the Midwest and Southeast, would bring an immediate boost in customers and open new areas of technology and service to MCI.

The planned union of West and East Germany should prevent a West German economic slowdown over the next two years, economists said, but they reiterated concerns that East German unemployment could soar. West Germany's five leading economic research institutes said Monday that increased demand resulting from the economic reconstruction of East Germany likely will prevent a significant slowdown in West German growth.

A top economic adviser to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said authorities will have to overcome strong public resistance to push through a radical market-oriented economic reform program this year. ``A speedy transition to a market economy will come up against powerful opposition,'' Deputy Prime Minister Leonid Abalkin told a news conference Monday. ``We must do it, whether we like it or not.''

The committee representing Eastern Airlines' preferred shareholders proposed a reorganization plan for the carrier that would give Eastern to its shareholders, other creditors and new managers. The move Monday marks the first time one of the parties in Eastern's bankruptcy proceeding has challenged the airline's reorganization plan by submitting its own proposal.

Time Warner Inc. agreed to provide $650 million to help fund Pathe Communication Corp.'s purchase of MGM-UA Communications in exchange for distribution rights to current and future Pathe and United Artists films. Monday's announcement followed weeks of rumors that Time Warner was negotiating to provide the financial backbone for Pathe's $1.27 billion acquisition of MGM-UA.

A new thrift institution regulator took office as the Bush administration conceded its savings and loan bailout will cost taxpayers more than previously estimated. Timothy Ryan, sworn in as director of the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision, began his five-year term Monday by pledging to intensify government efforts to rid S&Ls of fraud.

The chairmen of General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. took sharp pay cuts in 1989 during an auto industry slump, but still received more than $9 million between them, the companies said. Ford Chairman Donald Petersen, who retired March 1, received $6.6 million in salary, bonuses and stock options last year, down from $10.5 million in 1988, the No. 2 automaker said in its annual proxy statement Monday. GM Chairman Roger Smith was paid $2.5 million, down from $3.6 million the previous year, the proxy for the world's largest automaker revealed. Smith retires this summer.

Pepsico Inc. signed a $3 billion, 10-year pact to double Soviet production of Pepsi in exchange for ships and expanded sales of Soviet vodka in the United States. The deal also will broaden the choice of Western fast food for Muscovites by opening two Pizza Hut restaurants in the Soviet capital.

Heinz ketchup will be packaged next year in clear plastic bottles that the food giant says can be recycled more readily than the squeezable containers it introduced in 1983. H.J. Heinz Co. officials said Monday they hoped the new plastic technology would reduce the flow of plastic into landfills and boost the company's already dominant share of the $600 million ketchup market. But some environmental activists said many areas of the country are not gathering and recycling plastic containers, and they feared many of the new bottles would end up in the landfill anyway.

The stock market was mixed as traders bided their time awaiting first-quarter earnings reports. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 4.95 points to 2,722.07, but declining issues outnumbered advances by about 5 to 4. Bond prices fell, partly in reaction to the dollar's decline against most major currencies. Gold declined. Crude oil futures plunged below $19 a barrel to an eight-month low following a report that OPEC production hit its highest level since 1981. Precious metals and copper weakened; grains and soybeans were mostly lower; cocoa and orange juice futures fell; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Petroleum Industry Adopts `Guiding Environmental Principles'
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS `principals' to `principles' in first and last grafs; Also moved on general newswires
DOC.TEXT: The nation's major petroleum companies have adopted a set of ``guiding environmental principles,'' their trade association announced Monday. But a senior attorney for an environmental organization said the 11 principles adopted Friday in Dallas by the American Petroleum Institute sound instead like hollow promises. ``The commitments are so vague as to be practically meaningless,'' said Bob Adler of the Natural Resources Defense Council. The American Petroleum Institute's board of directors, which includes all of the nation's major petroleum companies, adopted the environmental principles in a unanimous vote. Those principles include pledges to promote the safe use, transportation and disposal of raw materials; to address problems created by the handling and disposal of hazardous substances from oil operations; and to operate plants and facilities in a way that protects the environment as well as the safety and health of employees and the public. ``It sounds like hollow promises, especially coming from an industry that has violated not only government regulations but its own promises time and time again,'' Adler said. Adler said the industry appears to be seeking to replace ``badly needed'' enforceable government regulations with more unenforceable industry promises. ``This industry has said `trust me' many times in past but has proven as many times in the past that they cannot be trusted on their own,'' Adler said. The API's environmental principles were adopted within days of the first anniversary of the nation's worst oil spill, in which the tanker Exxon Valdez spewed nearly 11 million gallons of toxic crude oil into the sea when it ran aground in Prince William Sound, Alaska. The proposals also come as a House-Senate conference committee considers oil spill liability legislation that Adler said would increase liability standards for oil spills, impose a bigger tax to finance a cleanup fund, and require better clean-up plans. The House-passed version of the bill would require double hulls and bottoms on tankers. The oil industry also is seeking to drill in such restricted areas as Bristol Bay in Alaska, off the Florida Keys and the California coast, and at the Arctic National Wildife Refuge. The industry, Adler said, ``is facing increasing opposition to those drilling plans in light of their recent record. Maybe they're trying to assure Congress and the public they can drill safely.'' API Board Chairman Allen E. Murray said the industry understands public concern about the environment. ``At the same time, we firmly believe that the nation can have both environmental protection and economic growth,'' said Murray, who is chairman of the board, president and chief executive officer of Mobil Corp. A preamble to the environmental principles declares that API members are ``dedicated to continuous efforts to improve the compatibility of our operations with the environment while economically developing energy resources and supplying high quality products and services to consumers.''

DOC.HEAD: Continental Completes Central American Hub
DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines announced Monday it will have access to each of the seven Central American countries with its inaugural nonstop service to Nicaragua from Houston's Intercontinental Airport. The nonstop service to Managua, Nicaragua, is scheduled to begin July 1. ``Houston's new international terminal to open in May provides the perfect focal point for our Central American service,'' said Mickey Foret, Continental's president. ``The addition of the Nicaragua route brings all of Central America into our growing global air system.'' Continental currently offers nonstop service from Houston to Guatemala City, Guatemala; San Salvador, El Salvador; and Belize City, Belize, with continuing service to San Pedro Sula, Honduras. The airline plans to start nonstop service to Panama City, Panama, with continuing service to San Jose, Costa Rica, on May 15, the first day of operations at the new international terminal in Houston. Houston-based Continental, a subsidiary of Texas Air Corp., is the largest U.S. carrier to Mexico, with service to eight cities. In May it will be the largest U.S. carrier to Central America.

DOC.HEAD: New Scratch-Ticket Game Off to Good Start
DOC.TEXT: The name of Washington's newest lottery game may have offended some securities industry insiders, but ``Wall Street'' got off to a good start Monday, state officials said. ``This is official Day One, and from what we can tell so far, it's going very well,'' said Terry Massoth, telemarketing supervisor for the Washington State Lottery. The state began distributing ``Wall Street'' scratch tickets Monday and some lottery outlets already have placed a second round of orders, Massoth said. Players scratch across rows of boxes on the $1 tickets to reveal amounts under ``Buy,'' ``Sell'' and ``Profit.'' If the sell number is higher than the buy number in the same row, the player wins the profit. Prizes range from $1 to $10,000. The relatively large size of the top prize likely accounts for the new game's popularity, Massoth said. ``The `Wall Street' game offers advantages not found in trading on that New York City street,'' lottery Director Evelyn Sun said in a pre-startup statement. Players ``cannot lose more than they invested,'' she said. Some strategists on the real Wall Street were offended by the pitch. ``It's only players who speculate and don't know what they're doing who get killed or sucked in by the market,'' said Yale Hirsch in New York, a prominent investment adviser who publishes the Stock Trader's Almanac. Massoth laughed when told that the name of the new game had aroused indignation in stock-market circles. ``They don't feel that's gambling, huh?'' he said, noting that stock market fluctuations sometimes are attributed to such non-financial events as the outcome of the Super Bowl. ``That's real science,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern's Preferred Shareholders File Alternate Reorganization Plan
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 4th graf to UPDATE with attorney for unsecured creditors declining comment; picks up 5th graf pvs bg'ng, The preferred ...; SUBS 7th graf to CORRECT amount owed preferred shareholders to around $680 million sted $1 billion; picks up 8th graf pvs bg'ng, Robert Miller, ...
DOC.TEXT: The committee representing Eastern Airlines' preferred shareholders proposed a reorganization plan for the carrier Monday that would give Eastern to its shareholders, other creditors and new managers. The move marks the first time one of the parties in Eastern's bankruptcy proceeding has challenged the airline's reorganization plan by submitting its own proposal. Miami-based Eastern has submitted several restructuring plans since its Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing on March 9, 1989. Its exclusive right to file a plan with the U.S. Bankruptcy Court expired Feb. 20 after the court extended it several times. Eastern spokeswoman Karen Ceremsak in Miami said the airline hadn't yet seen the shareholders' proposal and declined comment. So did Joel Zweibel, an attorney for Eastern's unsecured creditors, the other major group that is owed money. The preferred shareholders' committee said it filed with the court a plan to reorganize Eastern as an ``independent, stand-alone'' airline that would be owned by shareholders and unsecured creditors and operated by a new management team. The shareholders' committee had objected previously to Eastern's plan that would have paid them only 10 cents on the dollar. The preferred holders, whom Eastern owes about $680 million, would own 45 percent of the new airline under the plan. The unsecured creditors, who are owed $980 million, would get 50 percent of Eastern. The remaining 5 percent would be held by the new management team. Robert Miller, an attorney for the preferred shareholders, said the committee has spoken to ``several people'' as possible new managers of Eastern, but he refused to identify them. Eastern's unions, which struck the airline on March 4, 1989, long have advocated that Frank Lorenzo, chairman of Eastern's parent Texas Air Corp., be replaced in running Eastern by a special court-appointed trustee. The unsecured creditors, unhappy with Eastern's proposals to repay them only partially, indicated last week they also would seek a trustee. Under the preferred holders' plan, the unsecured creditors also would receive $200 million in new, collateralized Eastern bonds and $50 million in cash. They would get another $70 million in notes to be repaid from funds Eastern might win in litigation against its parent Texas Air and its sister Continental Airlines over Eastern assets transferred to them before the strike and bankruptcy. The unsecured creditors include such aircraft manufacturers as Boeing Co. and Airbus Industrie and jet engine makers like General Electric Co. Court-appointed bankruptcy examiner David I. Shapiro recently found that Texas Air owes Eastern between $280 million and $400 million for the difference between what it paid for the assets and what they were worth. Houston-based Texas Air has offered to settle the potential claims by paying Eastern around $280 million, but the unions have said that is insufficient and a trustee should be appointed. If the $70 million in notes were repaid, the rest of the money from the litigation would be invested in the new airline's operations, Miller said. He said the preferred holders have discussed their new plan with representatives of Goldman, Sachs & Co., financial advisers to the unsecured creditors. ``We would hope that (the unsecured creditors) would be supportive of a reorganization rather than a liquidation,'' Miller said in a telephone interview. ``We don't want to see this airline liquidated.'' Last Tuesday, the committee of unsecured creditors voted unanimously to reject Eastern's latest reorganization proposal, which would give them only 25 cents for each dollar owed. A majority of the creditors also voted to seek the appointment of a special trustee. However, the unsecured creditors dropped an earlier threat to press for a liquidation of Eastern, because they were concerned about the potentially negative impact of such a request on passenger bookings.

DOC.HEAD: Business Plane Maker Sold for $75 Million
DOC.TEXT: Learjet Corp., the maker of small business jets favored by corporate executives, will be sold to Canada's Bombardier Inc. for $75 million under an agreement announced Monday. The deal must be approved by a U.S. Bankruptcy Court judge in New York. Learjet's parent, Integrated Resources Inc., filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in February after defaulting on debt payments. In addition to the purchase price, a newly formed Bombardier subsidiary will assume liabilities associated with Learjet's continuing operations, including loans outstanding under the company's $38 million line of credit. Montreal-based Bombardier designs and manufactures transportation equipment and motorized consumer products. It also has interests in civilian and military aerospace. Learjet spokesman Bill Robinson said the deal amounts to $15 million more than the last bidder had offered. Learjet was founded by Bill Lear in the late 1950s to manufacture business jets. It currently makes three light jets and a medium class model selling for $3.8 million to $7.2 million. Learjet employs 2,750 people company-wide and has annual sales in excess of $250 million. It was acquired by Integrated in 1987. Bombardier's products include rail transit equipment, snowmobiles and a heavy business jet called Challenger jet, which is manufactured by its Canadair Group and sells for $14 million to $18 million. The company has plants in Canada, the United States, Austria, Belgium, France, England, Finland and Sweden, and employs 22,500 people. Bombardier's annual business volume is more than $2 billion Canadian. Bombardier plans to keep Learjet's current operations in Wichita and allow present management to operate the business, Robinson said. In late February, another group that tentatively had agreed to buy Learjet for $60 million let its offer lapse. The group said at the time that the bankruptcy filing by Integrated could hamper the deal. Learjet officials said other potential buyers had written the bankruptcy court expressing an interest in buying the company for more than $60 million. Bombardier confirmed it was one of those companies. ``We are in the process of selling a significant number of assets prior to presenting our restructuring program to our creditors,'' said Stephen D. Weinroth, Integrated's chairman and chief executive officer. He said the Learjet sale will be the first major asset disposition outside Integrated's former core businesses. Integrated began as a real estate company and expanded rapidly several years to become the largest seller of tax-sheltered investments. But the tax-shelter business was scuttled by the 1986 tax-law revisions, so Integrated moved into insurance and mutual funds, financed largely through junk bonds.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Gets First-Run Rights to 10 Films
DOC.TEXT: CBS said Monday it acquired rights to 10 Universal Pictures 1989 films, including ``Born on the Fourth of July'' and ``Field of Dreams,'' bypassing a decade-old practice of selling first to cable TV. The movies will be shown during the 1990-91 television season, CBS said. The deal follows complaints by MCA Inc. that its movies have been shut out of the pay television market dominated by Time Warner Inc., which owns both the Home Box Office and Cinemax pay TV networks and the Warner Bros. film studio. It also culminates a search by MCA's Universal Pictures unit for an outlet for popular films that failed to attract strong bids from either HBO or Viacom Inc.'s Showtime and The Movie Channel units. ``CBS is pleased to bring the big event of feature film television premieres back to network television, where all of the public will have the opportunity to see them,'' CBS Entertainment President Jeff Sagansky said. Cable channels were not ``disposed to come forth and make a deal that was in any way viable,'' MCA President Sidney J. Sheinberg said. ``CBS and Jeff Sagansky have shown that they are completely committed to attracting viewers back to network television.'' Terms of the deal were not announced by CBS or MCA, but the network is believed to have paid between $6 million and $8 million per film. The Universal films will move directly from videocassette sales to CBS. For the past decade, rights to feature films have been sold first for video distribution, then for cable broadcast and then to the three networks. The pact could foreshadow changes in the way the major movie studios and the networks do business with one another, analysts said. ``I fully expect that the networks will be bidding heavily with pay TV for movie rights in the next few years,'' said Steven Rosenberg, head of Rose Media Corp. of Pebble Beach, Calif. Earlier this year, MCA general counsel Robert Hadl told a Federal Communications Commission hearing that HBO had not been interested in buying Universal's films since Time Inc., HBO's parent, acquired Warner Communications, parent of Warner Bros., last year. The movie package includes Spike Lee's ``Do the Right Thing''; ``Sea of Love,'' with Al Pacino; ``Uncle Buck,'' with John Candy; ``K-9,'' starring Jim Belushi; as well as ``Field of Dreams'' and ``Born on the Fourth of July.'' Also included are ``Fletch Lives,'' ``Renegades,'' ``Shocker'' and ``The Wizard.'' CBS also will have broadcast rights to several Universal films to be shown on pay cable. They include ``Parenthood,'' ``The Dream Team'' and ``The 'burbs.''

DOC.HEAD: Tribune To End `USA Tonight' Under Deal With Turner Broadcasting
DOC.TEXT: Tribune Broadcasting Co. will discontinue its nightly ``USA Tonight'' newscasts and use Cable News Network in six markets under an agreement announced Monday with Turner Broadcasting System Inc. The 10-year deal, announced by TBS Chairman Ted Turner and Tribune President James C. Dowdle, also includes joint production of news, documentary specials and entertainment programs. As part of the agreement, Tribune will end ``USA Tonight'' and its IDNX news service. Six Tribune stations will become affiliates of Cable News Network, subscribing to CNN coverage on a non-exclusive basis. Those stations are WPIX in New York, KTLA in Los Angeles, WGN in Chicago, WGNX in Atlanta, KWGN in Denver and WGNO in New Orleans. The stations will use the CNN coverage to expand their evening newscasts to one hour this summer, Tribune officials said in a statement. ``USA Tonight'' and IDNX will be discontinued in June, Dowdle said. ``We're delighted to bring Turner Broadcasting's worldwide news-gathering capabilities to the Tribune newscasts and are very optimistic about the future entertainment program undertakings,'' Dowdle said. ``We have worked with Tribune Broadcasting Company over the years with very positive results,'' Turner said. ``We are convinced that the extension of this relationship will result in a significant programming venture.'' The two companies also will work together to produce quarterly news specials and original entertainment programming. Tentative plans include production of two mini-series per year for broadcast on Tribune stations, Atlanta television station TBS and in general syndication. The entertainment programs will be distributed worldwide by Turner Program Services while Tribune Entertainment Company will handle advertising sales.

DOC.HEAD: French Bid for Farmers Insurance Denied; BAT Deal Threatened
DOC.TEXT: California insurance regulators Monday rejected a French takeover of the Farmers insurance companies, jeopardizing the proposed $21 billion hostile buyout of Britain's BAT Industries PLC. BAT owns Farmers Group Inc., and bidder Sir James Goldsmith had proposed to sell Farmers to Axa-Midi Assurances of France upon acquiring BAT, Britain's biggest conglomerate. California regulators ruled that policyholders' interests would not be served either by a takeover of BAT by Goldsmith's Hoylake Investments Ltd. or the sale of Farmers to the French company. A key objection was that Axa-Midi was putting no cash behind its $4.5 billion offer. Axa-Midi Chairman Claude Bebear had agreed to give Goldsmith $1 billion to help with the BAT purchase. To buy Farmers, Axa-Midi was to borrow $2.25 billion from banks and $2.25 billion from Goldsmith by giving him promissory notes. Goldsmith then was to sell the notes for cash. ``While Axa-Midi has an outstanding European record, the leverage of this deal is such that it would endanger the Farmers group of insurance companies,'' Insurance Commissioner Roxani Gillespie said in a statement issued by her department. The department said Axa-Midi ``basically looked to the financial performance of the Farmers companies to repay the acquisition debt.'' ``However, insurance companies cannot be relied upon to repay this type of sizable debt as it would be dangerous to policyholders and claimants,'' the statement said. Axa-Midi spokesman Eliot Sloane said Bebear believed the deal could be restructured to win approval from Ms. Gillespie. ``They're raising the issue of leverage and we think we can address that and correct it,'' he said. Bebear issued a statement saying the Insurance Department's reservations about Axa-Midi's financing were within reason and Axa-Midi would press ahead in attempts to address them and win regulatory approval. The statement did not say how Axa-Midi intended to put more cash into the deal. Its officials have suggested in the past that it might do so by issuing stock, selling non-insurance assets, or restructuring the deal with Goldsmith. Lorraine Johnson, senior staff counsel to the Insurance Department, said Axa-Midi could fight the ruling by asking a Superior Court judge to order the department to reconsider, or by making a new proposal. She noted the department had ruled that Axa-Midi had failed to meet three of five test standards and Hoylake had failed four of the five tests. The problems with the proposal primarily deal with how the deal would be financed, including the collapse of the junk-bond market and banks' recent difficulty in providing bridge loans. Ms. Johnson also said Goldsmith never has formally presented his latest offer for BAT since withdrawing an earlier one. ``There is no offer there for us to look at,'' she said. She said Bebear had suggested earlier that he could sell assets or stock to raise cash, but too vaguely to persuade state officials. Farmers, the third largest U.S. auto and homeowner insurer, had maintained that Axa-Midi was too small to take over Farmers. ``The commissioner's decision to deny the applications ... recognizes that the proposed takeover of Farmers would have placed policyholders at significant risk,'' Farmers Group chairman and chief executive Leo E. Denlea Jr. said. In order for Goldsmith to proceed with his bid for BAT, the British Takeover Panel has said he must gain clearance for his plans for Farmers in each of the nine states in which Farmers operates an insurance company. Illinois, Idaho, Oregon and Washington also have held hearings on the proposed takeover but have not announced decisions. Hearings began Monday in Texas. Insurance departments in Arizona, Kansas and Ohio have yet to set hearing dates.

DOC.HEAD: China Shows Zero Industrial Growth Over First Quarter
DOC.TEXT: China's slumping economy recorded zero growth in industrial output during the first quarter, although some signs of recovery were seen in March. State Statistical Bureau figures, reported in the official press Tuesday, also revealed that smaller township and private enterprises continued to expand, while state-run enterprises showed declining output and productivity. Industrial output for March was up 1.4 percent compared to the same month in 1989. Output in state enterprises was the same as last year, while collectives showed 0.7 percent growth, township enterprises 5.4 percent and others, mainly small private firms, 32.3 percent. For the first quarter, the industrial output value of state-owned enterprises fell 1.1 percent to 285.5 billion yuan ($60.7 billion) and collectives were down 1.4 percent to 111.6 billion yuan ($23.7 billion). Township enterprises, however, were up 3.5 percent, and others by 30.4 percent. Combined industrial output in the first quarter was 415.8 billion yuan ($88.5 billion), the same as in 1989. Tough austerity measures aimed at curbing inflation and unsustainable economic growth brought industrial output growth down to 8.3 percent last year from 21 percent in 1988. But in the past six months, thousands of factories have closed down or reduced production because tight money policies have deprived them of funds and the suspension of capital investment projects have left them without work. Through February, industrial output was down 0.9 percent compared to the same period last year, the Statistical Bureau report said. The government, concerned about rising unemployment and the threat of recession, has begun pumping money back into the economy. But the bureau warned that despite the slight recovery in March, the industrial outlook for the coming months remained grim. It said productivity in state-owned enterprises during the first two months of 1990 was down 2.3 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Time Warner to Provide $650 Million Toward Pathe's MGM-UA Purchase
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, `Pathe made... to UPDATE with Monday payment; PICKS UP 4th graf pvs, `Monday's joint...
DOC.TEXT: Time Warner Inc. has agreed to provide $650 million to help fund Pathe Communication Corp.'s purchase of MGM-UA Communications in exchange for distribution rights to current and future Pathe and United Artists films, it was announced Monday. Time Warner has been rumored for weeks to have been involved in discussions that could lead to its providing the financial backbone for Pathe's $1.27 billion acquisition of MGM-UA. Pathe made the second $50 million deposit toward the purchase Monday, adding to last month's $50 million installment. At that time Pathe had not said how it planned to fund the acquisition. Monday's joint announcement by Time Warner's Warner Bros. unit and Pathe said the loan and other details of the deal were subject to the completion of Pathe's purchase of MGM-UA. Under the deal, Warner Bros. will provide long-term support services to Pathe and MGM-UA in exchange for worldwide theatrical, television and home video distribution rights to existing and future UA and Pathe films. Those services will include a $650 million bank loan to MGM-UA that would be secured by the UA film library and guaranteed by Time Warner. The money would be used by MGM-UA to purchase certain Pathe assets, and Pathe would in turn use the money to buy MGM-UA. ``This agreement represents a major step for Pathe towards implementing its plans to create an international, major entertainment company,'' Giancarlo Parretti, Pathe's president, and Yoram Globus, the company's co-president, said in a joint statement. ``We are gratified that Pathe has chosen the worldwide distribution and marketing team at Warner Bros. to support its product,'' Warner Bros. Chairman and Chief Executive Robert A. Daly and President and Chief Operating Officer Terry Semel said in their joint statement.

DOC.HEAD: Court: Insurers Liable for $960 Million in Claims Against Owens-Illinois
DOC.TEXT: Insurance companies are liable for $960 million in damage and injury claims against Owens-Illinois Inc. arising from the use of its products containing asbestos, a New Jersey court has ruled. The ruling is believed to be one of the largest surrounding the issue of who is liable for claims that asbestos made people ill, The New York Times said in its Tuesday editions. New Jersey Superior Court Judge Erminie Conly on Friday issued a finding of liability against five insurance companies: Allstate, Cigna Reinsurance, General Reinsurance, United Insurance and American Risk Management. The case relates to industrial insulating materials the Toledo, Ohio, company made between 1948 and 1958 that contained 15 percent asbestos, said Andrew Berry, who represented Owens-Illinois. As a result of the production, Owens-Illinois is a defendant in thousands of cases brought on behalf of individuals and property owners who contend they have been made ill by the materials, the Times reported. ``This is the latest and biggest of a series of decisions over the last decade,'' Berry said. David D'Aloia, who represented Allstate and United Insurance, said an appeal was under consideration. The ruling appeared to be a setback for the insurance industry, which had recently been on a winning streak in liability cases, the Times said. Companies that produced material with asbestos have been wrangling with their insurance companies for more than a decade over whether the insurance covers death and illness claims arising from long-term asbestos exposure. Insurers have argued successfully in many cases that illnesses from asbestos exposure have not been accidental events typically covered by insurance. Instead, they have said the injuries were due to corporate strategies that knew the health risks but continued production.

DOC.HEAD: To Launch Car Rental Venture in Japan
DOC.TEXT: Mazda Motor Corp. said Tuesday it had formed a joint car rental venture in Japan with Hertz Corp., the world's largest automobile rental company. The new Hertz Japan Ltd., with $3.16 million in capital, will be fully integrated with Hertz's worldwide network comprising about 5,000 locations in more than 120 countries, Mazda said in a statement. Hertz Japan is scheduled to start operations this summer, with the number of rental and lease cars to be increased to 10,000 vehicles at 250 outlets across Japan by the end of 1993. ``This is an exciting development for Hertz on the international front and further strengthens our global car rental leadership,'' Hertz chairman and chief executive Frank A. Olson said in the statement. Hertz, based in Park Ridge, N.J., is 55 percent owned by Ford Motor Co., while 24.2 percent of Mazda share is owned by Ford Motor. Mazda is Japan's fourth largest automaker. Norimasa Furuta, president of the Hiroshima-based Mazda, said Hertz's ``established expertise in customer service meets our own philosophy to seek what is best for our customers.'' The new car rental venture will be operated as a nationwide franchise system with all vehicles purchased and owned by Hertz Japan. The fleet will include Mazda models and other Japanese and foreign cars, the statement said. Mazda spokesman Yutaka Kaita said 70 percent to 80 percent of the total rental and lease cars in the new firm will be foreign cars, including models such as Ford, Citroen of France and Lancia of Italy. The spokesman said Mazda separately operates its own car rental company with 13,700 Mazda models at 250 outlets in Japan, making it the country's third largest rental firm after Toyota Motor Corp. and Nippon Rent-A-Car Service Inc.
